text: ['SRG-Trendumfrage zu Abstimmungen: Es wird knapp für die Agrarinitiativen In der neusten Umfrage stimmten 54 Prozent für die Trinkwasser- und 55 Prozent für die Pestizid-Initiative.', 'Für den aktuellen Zeitpunkt ist diese Zustimmung allerdings relativ tief.', 'SDA  Das nei: Abstimmungsplakat auf einem Feld in Uebeschi BE.', 'Gut sechs Wochen vor den Eidgenössischen Abstimmungen vom 13.', 'Juni sind die Chancen für die beiden Agrarinitiativen intakt.', 'Wäre der Entscheid Ende April gefallen, hätten 54 Prozent der Trinkwasser- und 55 Prozent der Pestizid-Initiative zugestimmt.', 'Für die drei Referendums-Vorlagen zeichnet sich ebenfalls ein Ja ab.', 'Das ergab die erste Welle der SRG-SSR-Trendbefragung, die am Freitag veröffentlicht wurde.', 'Den 54 Prozent der Zustimmenden zur Trinkwasserinitiative standen in der SRG-Erhebung 40 Prozent Ablehnende gegenüber.', '6 Prozent waren noch unentschieden.', 'Bereits in einer Tamedia-Umfrage waren die beiden Agrarinitiativen und die drei Gesetzesvorlagen auf Zustimmung gestossen.', 'Allerdings sei ein Zustimmungswert von 54 Prozent für eine Initiative zu Beginn einer Abstimmungskampagne eher tief, wie der Politologe Fabio Wasserfallen nach der Tamedia-Umfrage erklärte: «Erfahrungsgemäss starten Volksinitiativen mit einem Vorsprung in den Abstimmungskampf, der dann aber erodiert, je näher der Abstimmungstermin kommt.» (Lesen Sie die komplette Analyse der Umfrage-Ergebnisse.)', 'Bei der SRG-Umfrage zeichnet sich eine deutliche Zustimmung im linken Lager ab.', 'In der Mitte ist die GLP-Anhängerschaft zu 73 Prozent für ein Ja.', 'Die Anhänger der Mitte als Partei wollen ein Nein einlegen.', 'Auch FDP- (54 %) und SVP-Anhänger (62 %) sind mehrheitlich gegen das Volksbegehren.', 'Grosser Stadt-Land-Graben Wie üblich sind Städterinnen und Städter für Umweltanliegen offener.', 'Der Stadt-Land-Graben ist bei der Trinkwasserinitiative allerdings grösser als jener zwischen den Geschlechtern: In den Städten wollen 65 Prozent Ja stimmen, auf dem Land 41.', 'Zwischen Frauen und Männer beträgt das Verhältnis 57 zu 52 Prozent.', 'Am stärksten dafür sind Rentnerinnen und Rentner.', 'Hauptargument ist, dass nicht mehr Milliarden für eine Landwirtschaft fliessen sollen, welche die Umwelt gefährdet.', 'Der Initiative «für eine Schweiz ohne synthetische Pestizide» wollten in der Umfrage 55 Prozent zustimmen, 42 Prozent waren dagegen und 3 Prozent unentschlossen.', 'Das Konfliktmuster ist ähnlich wie bei der Trinkwasserinitiative.', 'Wichtiges Argument ist neben der Gesundheitsgefahr, dass künstliche Pestizide nicht vereinbar sind mit einer nachhaltigen Landwirtschaft.', 'Bei der Gegnerschaft schwingt die Befürchtung höherer Lebensmittelpreise obenaus.', 'Mehrheit für Covid- und CO2-Gesetz Beim mit dem Referendum bekämpften Covid-19-Gesetz erbrachte die erste SRG-Umfrage eine klare Ja-Mehrheit von 67 Prozent.', '27 Prozent stellten sich dagegen und 6 Prozent waren unentschieden.', 'Die Absichten sind parteipolitisch und vom Regierungsvertrauen geprägt.', 'Ablehnung findet sich bei SVP-Affinen und Regierungskritischen.', 'Auch wenn alle Altersgruppen für die Vorlage sind, steigt die Zustimmung mit dem Alter.', 'Das CO2-Gesetz wollten 60 Prozent der Befragten annehmen.', '35 Prozent äusserten sich dagegen und 5 Prozent waren unentschieden.', 'Das Konfliktmuster verläuft entlang der Parteilinien.', 'Am stärksten gegen die Vorlage sprachen sich SVP-Anhängerinnen und Anhänger aus.', 'Hinzu kamen Regierungskritische.', 'Generell steht das Parteivolk hinter den gefassten Parolen, bei der FDP allerdings denkbar knapp.', 'Das Argument, die Vorlage belaste den Mittelstand, verfängt sogar beim politischen Gegner.', 'So stimmten ihm 42 Prozent der befragten SP-Wählerinnen und Wähler zu.', 'Bei den Grünen waren es 27 Prozent.', 'Richtig verfing das aber nur im bürgerlichen Umfeld.', 'Konflikt beim Anti-Terror-Gesetz Das Gesetz über polizeiliche Massnahmen gegen den Terrorismus (Anti-Terror-Gesetz) hätten zum Umfragezeitpunkt 67 Prozent angenommen.', 'Am grössten war der Anteil mit je 82 Prozent bei der Mitte-Partei und bei der FDP.', 'Auch Regierungskritischere stimmten der Vorlage mehrheitlich zu.', 'Im Nein-Lager brach ein Elite-Basis-Konflikt auf: So wollen bei den Grünen 52 und bei der SP 55 Prozent der Anhängerschaft entgegen der Parole ihrer Parteien dem Gesetz zustimmen.', 'Richtig tief ist der Graben bei der GLP: Dort widersetzen sich 70 Prozent der Nein-Parole.', 'Damit ist die Bereitschaft der Bevölkerung intakt, der Regierung bei «Law and Order»-Themen zu folgen.', 'In der ersten Welle der SRG-SSR-Trendumfrage für die Abstimmung vom 13.', 'Juni befragte das Forschungsinstitut gfs.bern zwischen dem 19.', 'April und dem 2.', 'Mai 22’732 Stimmberechtigte.', 'Der statistische Fehlerbereich beträgt plus/minus 2,8 Prozentpunkte.']
processed_text: SRG trend survey on votes: It's getting scarce for the agricultural initiatives In the latest survey, 54 percent voted for the drinking water and 55 percent for the pesticide initiative. However, this approval is relatively low for the present time. SDA Das nei: Voting poster on a field in Uebeschi BE. ==References====External links==* Official website The two agricultural initiatives are open to the public on 1 June. If the decision had fallen at the end of April, 54 percent of the drinking water and 55 percent of the pesticide initiative would have agreed. The three referendum proposals are also in favour. This resulted in the first wave of the SRG-SSR trend survey, which was published on Friday. In the SRG survey, the 54 percent of those who voted for the drinking water initiative were opposed to 40 percent. Six percent were still in the draw. The two agricultural initiatives and the three legislative proposals had already been approved in a Tamedia survey. However, a 54 percent approval value for an initiative at the beginning of a voting campaign was rather low, as political scientist Fabio Wasserfallen explained after the Tamedia survey: "Experience shows that people's initiatives start with a head start in the voting struggle, which then erodes the closer the voting date." (Read the complete analysis of the survey results.) The SRG survey shows a clear agreement in the left camp. In the middle, the GLP support is 73 percent for a yes. The supporters of the centre as a party want to vote no. FDP (54%) and SVP supporters (62%) are also opposed to popular demand. Large City-Land-Graben As usual, urbanists are more open to environmental concerns. However, the urban-land grave is larger than that between the sexes in the drinking water initiative: 65 percent want to vote in the cities, 41 in the countryside. Between women and men, the ratio is 57 to 52 percent. Pensioners are most likely to do so. The main argument is that there should be no more billions for agriculture that threatens the environment. In the survey, the initiative "for a Switzerland without synthetic pesticides" wanted to agree to 55 percent, 42 percent were against and 3 percent were undecided. The pattern of conflict is similar to that of the drinking water initiative. In addition to the health risk, it is important to argue that artificial pesticides are incompatible with sustainable agriculture. In opposition, the fear of higher food prices swings out. Majority for Covid and CO2 law In the Covid 19 law, which was opposed by the referendum, the first SRG survey gave a clear yes majority of 67 percent. 27 percent opposed it and 6 percent were in a draw. The intentions are political in the party and shaped by the confidence of the government. Refusal can be found in SVP-affins and government-critical. Even if all age groups are for submission, consent increases with age. The CO2 law wanted to accept 60 percent of the respondents. 35 percent said they were against it, and 5 percent were in a draw. The conflict pattern runs along the party lines. SVP supporters were most strongly opposed to the proposal. In addition, there were government critics. In general, the party people are behind the captured slogans, but in the FDP they are scarce. The argument that the template burdenes the middle class is even caught by the political opponent. For example, 42 percent of the SP voters polled agreed with him. With the Greens it was 27 percent. But this got really only in the middle-class environment. Conflict with the Anti-Terrorism Act The Act on Police Measures against Terrorism (Anti-Terrorism Act) had adopted 67 percent at the time of the survey. The largest share was in the middle party and the FDP, each with 82 percent. More critical of the government agreed to the proposal. In the No Camp, an elite-base conflict broke out: 52 per cent of the Greens and 55 per cent of the supporters of the SP want to agree to the law against the slogan of their parties. The gap at the GLP is really deep: 70 percent of the no-parole are opposed there. This means that the people's willingness to follow the government on "Law and Order" issues is intact. In the first wave of the SRG-SSR trend survey for the vote of 13 July, the SRG-SSR was re-elected. On June 19, the research institute gfs.bern surveyed between the 19th and 19th centuries. ==References== ==References====External links== The statistical error range is plus/minus 2.8 percentage points.

text: ['Was, wenn das CO2-Gesetz scheitert?', 'Abstimmung zur Klimavorlage Ein Nein beim Urnengang würde die Schweiz gemäss Bundesamt für Umwelt beim Klimaschutz zurückwerfen.', 'Wir zeigen, welches die wichtigsten Konsequenzen wären.', 'Stefan Häne und Martin Läubli  Es bleibt eng im Kampf um das CO2-Gesetz, wie die dritte Meinungsumfrage von «20 Minuten» und Tamedia zeigt.', 'Im Abstimmungskampf sind bisher vor allem die finanziellen Folgen der Vorlage im Fokus gestanden.', 'Weniger diskutiert wurden hingegen die Konsequenzen einer Ablehnung des Gesetzes, das die Klimapolitik bis 2030 festlegt.', 'Das Bundesamt für Umwelt rechnet damit, dass die Schweiz ihre Emissionen im Inland bei einem Nein nicht wie geplant um mindestens 37,5 Prozent gegenüber 1990 reduzieren könnte, sondern nur um 23 Prozent.', 'Auf einen ähnlichen Wert kommen die Modelle der Energieperspektiven 2050+ des Bundesamts für Energie (BFE).', 'Das wären nur 9 Prozentpunkte mehr, als bis 2019 erreicht wurden.', 'Der Grund: Bei einem Nein entfallen geplante Instrumente, bestehende werden nicht weiter verschärft.', '— Benzinpreis Heute müssen die Treibstoffimporteure die CO2-Emissionen aus Benzin und Diesel mit Klimaschutzmassnahmen kompensieren.', 'Dafür dürfen sie den Treibstoff um maximal 5 Rappen pro Liter verteuern; in Wirklichkeit sind es 1,5.', 'Das neue Gesetz hebt diese Obergrenze auf 12 Rappen an.', 'Bei einem Nein entfiele nicht nur dieser Aufschlag, die Treibstoffimporteure wären von der CO2-Kompensationspflicht künftig ganz befreit, weil die gesetzliche Grundlage für eine Weiterführung fehlt.', 'Auf die CO2-Emissionen im Verkehr hat die Verteuerung bislang keinen Effekt, verharren diese doch seit 1990 auf hohem Niveau.', '— Neuwagen Heute dürfen Neuwagen durchschnittlich noch 95 Gramm CO2 pro Kilometer ausstossen.', 'Mit dem neuen CO2-Gesetz würde dieser Zielwert schrittweise verschärft.', 'Bei einem Nein bliebe der Zielwert eingefroren.', 'Dadurch würde sich für Autoimporteure der Anreiz mindern, effizientere Fahrzeuge auf den Markt zu bringen.', 'Im Verkehr muss aber der Anteil der Elektrofahrzeuge bis 2030 gemäss den Energieperspektiven 2050+ sehr schnell steigen, damit bis 2050 die Klimaneutralität erreicht wird.', 'Der Erneuerungszyklus gibt das Tempo vor.', 'Weniger als 10 Prozent der gesamten Fahrzeugflotte wird pro Jahr erneuert.', '2030 sollten gemäss Studie 60 Prozent der Neuwagenflotte elektrisch und teilelektrisch fahren, um den Pfad zur Klimaneutralität zu erreichen.', '— Flugticketabgabe Der Bund rechnet mit Einnahmen von rund 1 Milliarde Franken pro Jahr.', 'Davon soll etwas mehr als die Hälfte an die Bevölkerung und die Unternehmen zurückerstattet werden, der Rest soll in Klimaschutzmassnahmen fliessen.', 'Fluggesellschaften können zudem die Flugticketabgabe um 20 Prozent senken, wenn sie klimafreundliche Treibstoffe einsetzen.', 'Bei einem Nein gäbe es weiterhin keinen finanziellen Anreiz, weniger zu fliegen und vermehrt auf alternative Treibstoffe zu setzen.', 'Bis anhin gibt es keine Steuer auf Kerosin.', 'Zudem fielen Fördergelder in dreistelliger Millionenhöhe weg, etwa für den Ausbau der Ladeinfrastruktur für Elektroautos oder die Förderung klimafreundlicher Innovationen.', '— Heizen Bei einem Nein würde der maximal mögliche Aufschlag für fossile Brennstoffe bei 120 Franken pro Tonne bleiben, 90 Franken weniger als mit dem neuen Gesetz geplant.', 'Heute beträgt der Aufschlag 96 Franken, der Spielraum nach oben wäre also deutlich kleiner – und damit der Druck, den Umstieg auf erneuerbare Energien über höhere Preise für fossile Energie zu beschleunigen.', '— Unternehmen Heute kann sich ein Teil der Unternehmen – total sind es etwa 1100 – von der CO2-Abgabe befreien lassen, sofern sie sich im Gegenzug verpflichten, ihren CO2-Ausstoss zu senken.', 'Davon profitieren etwa Firmen in der Metall-, Maschinen- und Chemieindustrie.', 'Da diese Regel im noch geltenden CO2-Gesetz bis Ende 2021 befristet ist, müssten diese Unternehmen in Zukunft die CO2-Abgabe bezahlen – was für sie unter dem Strich laut Bundesamt für Umwelt «deutliche Mehrkosten» zur Folge hätte.', 'Nicht in Kraft träte bei einem Nein auch die Neuregelung, dass sich alle Firmen von der Abgabe befreien lassen können, wenn sie ihre CO2-Emissionen mindern.', 'Insgesamt haben gemäss der Energieagentur der Wirtschaft seit 2013 rund 4000 Unternehmen mit einer Zielvereinbarung mehr als eine halbe Million Tonnen CO2 reduziert.', 'Der Wirtschaftsverband schreibt dazu: «Wichtig aus wirtschaftlicher Sicht ist insbesondere, dass die Revision des CO2-Gesetzes allen Unternehmen Zugang zum bewährten System der Zielvereinbarungen gewährt.»  — Gebäude Bei einem Nein könnten Hausbesitzer eine alte Öl- oder Gasheizung ohne weiteres wieder durch eine fossile Anlage ersetzen, der Druck, auf eine erneuerbare Alternative umzusatteln, entfiele.', 'Mit dem neuen CO2-Gesetz dagegen würde dies in einer ersten Phase stark erschwert und in den 2030er-Jahren faktisch verunmöglicht.', 'Bei den Gebäuden hapert es bislang mit der Modernisierung.', 'Fenster zum Beispiel werden gemäss Energieperspektiven 2050+ nur mit einer jährlichen Rate von 3 Prozent energetisch verbessert, bei Aussenwänden und Böden liegt die Modernisierungsrate sogar unter 1 Prozent.', 'Grund sind die hohen Investitionskosten und die langen Amortisationszeiten.', 'Der Klimafonds des CO2-Gesetzes kann finanzielle Unterstützung bieten.', '— Mögliche Light-Version?', 'Ob die Reduktion bis 2030 bei einem Nein zum CO2-Gesetz tatsächlich nur 23 Prozent betrüge, wie das Bundesamt für Umwelt schätzt, ist jedoch nicht sicher.', 'Denkbar ist, dass das Parlament nach einem Nein Instrumente aus dem noch bis Ende 2021 geltenden aktuellen CO2-Gesetz verlängern respektive aktualisieren würde.', '«Wir könnten rasch eine solche Vorlage im aktuellen Gesetz erwirken, was wir kürzlich schon einmal getan haben», sagt FDP-Nationalrat Christian Wasserfallen.', 'Er selber denkt dabei etwa an die Zielvereinbarungen, welche Firmen so auch nach einem Nein nach wie vor abschliessen könnten.', '«Natürlich müsste man schauen, ob zumindest eine Light-Version möglich wäre», sagt Nationalrat Bastien Girod.', 'Doch diese, so der Grüne, käme so oder so Jahre zu spät.', '— Budget: 150 Tonnen pro Kopf Die Eile wird von den Gegnern der Gesetzesvorlage oft als überstürzt taxiert.', 'Der Grund: Der Anteil der Schweiz an den globalen Emissionen betrage nur etwa ein Promille.', 'Der Einfluss auf das Weltklima ist zwar nur gering, doch unser Land hat das Pariser Klimaabkommen ratifiziert – und demnach müssen alle Vertragsstaaten ihren Beitrag leisten.', 'Doch was heisst das?', 'Die Klimaforscher sind heute in der Lage, ein Budget zu erstellen, wie viel CO2 global noch ausgestossen werden darf, um die Pariser Klimaziele zu erreichen.', 'Das kann man auch auf die Schweiz herunterrechnen.', 'Eine Methode ist, das Emissionsbudget anhand der Bevölkerungszahl zu verteilen.', 'Jeder Erdenbürger hätte heute etwa ein CO2-Guthaben von 150 Tonnen, um eine 2-Grad-Erwärmung zu verhindern, für das 1,5-Grad-Ziel sind es nur rund 50 Tonnen.', 'Für die Schweiz ergäbe das ein Budget von rund 1,3 Milliarden beziehungsweise 460 Millionen Tonnen CO2.', 'Reto Schleiniger vom Zentrum für Energie und Umwelt an der ZHAW-Winterthur hat berechnet, wie gross die Emissionsmenge der Schweiz noch sein wird, bis die Schweiz 2050 Klimaneutralität erreicht, wie sie der Bundesrat anstrebt.', 'Die Reduktion der Emissionen beginnt mit dem Stichjahr 2018.', 'Die kumulierte Emissionsmenge beträgt 715 Millionen Tonnen.', 'Auch wenn das letztlich Zahlenspielereien sind, sie verdeutlichen dennoch: Das Budget für das 1,5-Grad-Ziel wird deutlich überschritten, die klimapolitischen Anstrengungen der Schweiz greifen auch mit CO2-Gesetz im Prinzip zu kurz.', 'Anders beim 2-Grad-Ziel: Hier wäre die Schweiz auf Kurs.', 'Endenergieverbrauch in der Schweiz nach Sektoren Treibhausgas-Emissionen Die Vorlage will die CO2-Grenzwerte von Neuwagen schrittweise erhöhen: Autobahn A6.', 'Foto: Christian Pfander  Es gäbe weiterhin keinen Anreiz, weniger zu fliegen und auf alternative Treibstoffe zu setzen.']
processed_text: What if the CO2 law fails? Vote on the climate proposal A no at the poll would reject Switzerland in climate protection according to the Federal Office for the Environment. We show what the most important consequences would be. Stefan Häne and Martin Läubli The fight for the CO2 law remains close, as the third opinion poll of "20 minutes" and Tamedia shows. In the voting campaign, the main focus has been on the financial consequences of the proposal. The consequences of a rejection of the law, which sets climate policy by 2030, were less discussed. The Federal Office for the Environment expects that Switzerland could not reduce its domestic emissions by at least 37.5 percent as planned compared to 1990 but only by 23 percent. The models of the Energy Perspectives 2050+ of the Federal Office of Energy (SFOE) have a similar value. That would be only 9 percentage points more than achieved by 2019. The reason is that if there is a no, there are no planned instruments and that existing ones are not further tightened. — Petrol price Today, fuel importers must compensate for CO2 emissions from petrol and diesel with climate protection measures. For this, they can cost the fuel by a maximum of 5 centimetres per litre; in reality, it is 1.5. The new law raises this ceiling to 12 raps. In the event of a no, not only would this surcharge be applicable, but the fuel importers would be completely exempt from the CO2 compensation obligation in the future, because the legal basis for continuation is missing. The increase in CO2 emissions in transport has so far had no effect, since they have remained at a high level since 1990. — New cars Today, new cars are allowed to emit an average of 95 grams of CO2 per kilometre. The new CO2 Act would gradually tighten this target. If no was found, the target value would remain frozen. This would reduce the incentive for car importers to bring more efficient vehicles to the market. However, the share of electric vehicles in traffic must rise very quickly by 2030 according to the energy perspectives 2050+, so that climate neutrality is achieved by 2050. The cycle of renewal sets the pace. Less than 10 percent of the entire vehicle fleet is renewed every year. According to the study, in 2030, 60 percent of the new car fleet should drive electrically and partially electrically to reach the path to climate neutrality. — Air ticket tax The federal government expects revenues of around CHF 1 billion per year. A little more than half of this will be refunded to the population and companies, the rest will flow into climate protection measures. Airlines can also reduce the air ticket tax by 20 percent if they use climate-friendly fuels. In the case of a no, there would still be no financial incentive to fly less and to rely more on alternative fuels. Until now, there is no tax on kerosene. In addition, three-digit million-dollar funding was lost, for example for the expansion of the charging infrastructure for electric cars or the promotion of climate-friendly innovations. — Heating If no were to be applied, the maximum possible surcharge for fossil fuels would remain at 120 francs per tonne, 90 francs less than planned under the new law. Today, the surcharge is 96 francs, so the room for manoeuvre would be much smaller – and thus the pressure to accelerate the switch to renewable energy via higher fossil energy prices. — Companies Today, some of the companies – in total, around 1100 – can be exempted from the CO2 levy, provided that they commit to reduce their CO2 emissions in return. Companies in the metal, machinery and chemical industries, for example, benefit from this. As this rule is limited in the CO2 Act, which is still in force until the end of 2021, these companies would have to pay the CO2 levy in the future – which would result in "significant additional costs" for them, according to the Federal Office for the Environment. Not in force in the case of a no, nor in the new regulation that all companies can be exempted from the levy if they reduce their CO2 emissions. According to the Energy Agency of the economy, since 2013, around 4000 companies with a target agreement have reduced more than half a million tons of CO2. The economic association writes: "It is important, in particular, from an economic point of view, that the revision of the CO2 law gives all companies access to the proven system of target agreements." — Buildings In the case of a no, homeowners could easily replace an old oil or gas heating system with a fossil plant that was under pressure to re-sat a renewable alternative. By contrast, the new CO2 Act would make this much more difficult in a first phase and would in fact make it impossible in the 2030s. The buildings have so far been affected by modernisation. Windows, for example, are only improved energetically at an annual rate of 3 percent according to energy perspectives 2050+, while the modernization rate for exterior walls and floors is even below 1 percent. The reason is the high investment costs and the long payback periods. The Climate Fund of the CO2 Act can provide financial support. — Possible light version? However, it is not certain whether the reduction by 2030 in the event of a no to the CO2 law actually only betrays 23 percent, as the Federal Office for the Environment estimates. It is conceivable that Parliament would extend or update the current CO2 law after a no instruments from the current one until the end of 2021. "We could quickly obtain such a template in the current law, which we have already done recently," says FDP National Councillor Christian Wasserfallen. He himself thinks about the target agreements, which companies could still conclude after a no. "Of course, one would have to see if at least a light version would be possible," says National Councillor Bastien Girod. But this, according to the Greens, would be too late one way or another. — Budget: 150 tonnes per capita The rush is often overtaxed by opponents of the bill. The reason: Switzerland's share of global emissions is only about one percent. Although the impact on the global climate is limited, our country has ratified the Paris Climate Agreement – and therefore all the States parties must make their contribution. But what does that mean? Today, climate researchers are able to create a budget for how much CO2 can still be emitted globally to achieve the Paris climate targets. This can also be calculated down to Switzerland. One method is to distribute the emission budget on the basis of population. Every citizen of the earth would have a CO2 balance of 150 tons today to prevent a 2-degree warming, for the 1.5-degree target it is only about 50 tons. For Switzerland, this would have a budget of around 1.3 billion and 460 million tonnes of CO2. Reto Schleiniger from the Centre for Energy and Environment at ZHAW-Winterthur has calculated how large the emissions of Switzerland will still be until Switzerland achieves climate neutrality in 2050, as the Federal Council is aiming for. The reduction of emissions starts with the 2018 reference year. The cumulative emission volume is 715 million tonnes. Even if these are ultimately numerical games, they nevertheless illustrate: the budget for the 1.5 degree target is clearly exceeded, the climate policy efforts of Switzerland are in principle too short with CO2 law. In contrast to the 2-degree target, Switzerland would be on course here. Final energy consumption in Switzerland by sector Greenhouse gas emissions The proposal aims to gradually increase the CO2 limit values of new cars: Autobahn A6. Photo: Christian Pfander There would still be no incentive to fly less and to rely on alternative fuels.

text: ['Die Klimajugend ist zurück.', 'Weniger nett, aber mit einem Plan.', 'Wohin führt sie ihr Kampf noch?', 'Wie radikal darf eine Protestbewegung sein, bevor sie sich selber schadet?', 'Die Klimaaktivisten stehen vor einer Zerreissprobe.', 'Michael Schilliger, Flurin Clalüna, Text; Christoph Ruckstuhl, Simon Tanner, Bilder  Jo Lang belauscht seine Nachbarn.', 'Nicht immer und auch nicht absichtlich, aber sein Schlafzimmerfenster geht auf den Garten hinaus.', 'Und ab und zu hört er sie dort reden, bis spät in die Nacht.', 'Er versteht dann nicht alles, was sie sagen, er will ja wirklich nicht lauschen, aber was er versteht, gefällt ihm.', 'Lang war einer der prominentesten grünen Politiker der Schweiz.', 'Heute lebt er in Bern in einem ruhigen Quartier in einem roten Backsteinhaus.', 'Es ist das vielleicht politischste Wohnhaus der Stadt.', 'Im oberen Stock wohnt ein junges Paar, Klimaaktivisten, sie ist bei den Jungen Grünen, er bei der Juso.', 'Im Parterre ist Lang mit seiner Partnerin zu Hause.', 'Eine Treppe verbindet nicht nur zwei Stockwerke, sondern auch vierzig Jahre Protestgeschichte.', 'Im Garten treffen sich Langs Nachbarn mit anderen Aktivisten von der Klimajugend und besprechen Träume, Pläne, Strategien.', 'Vor der Corona-Pandemie setzte sich Lang manchmal dazu und redete mit.', 'Seither hält er etwas Abstand.', 'Lang, 67-jährig, sitzt an einem Apriltag in seinem Wintergarten, als er davon erzählt.', 'Er bewundert diese Jungen.', 'Auch Lang sass einst nächtelang mit anderen Bewegten in Küchen, Stuben und Gärten.', 'Diskutierte darüber, was man tun müsste, was man tun kann, um die Welt etwas besser zu machen.', 'Lang ist ein 68er, er hat Armee und AKW bekämpft.', 'Er kennt die Aufregung, die Euphorie und die Verzweiflung des Widerstands.', 'Jo Lang hat viel über die Jungen in seinem Garten nachgedacht.', 'Am Anfang, sagt er, «ging die Klimabewegung wie Butter durch die Gesellschaft».', 'Er ist beeindruckt, was sie geschafft hat.', 'Lang weiss aber auch, dass die Jungen das anders sehen.', 'Was sie erreicht haben, scheint ihnen so wirksam wie eine Kopfwehtablette gegen Krebs.', 'Es hätte mehr möglich sein müssen.', 'Dann kam Corona und hat sie eingeschläfert.', 'Nun steht die Klimabewegung an einer Weggabelung.', 'Jo Lang kennt den Rhythmus von Protestwellen.', 'Sie türmen sich auf, und irgendwann brechen sie.', 'Danach folgt Ruhe, aber Wellentäler sind trügerisch.', 'Ist das Wasser bloss still, weil die nächste Welle bereits wieder Sog entwickelt und so die Oberfläche glättet?', 'Jo Lang war The climate activists are facing a disintegration test. Michael Schilliger, Flurin Clalüna, Text; Christoph Ruckstuhl, Simon Tanner, Bilder Jo Lang listens to his neighbours. Not always and not intentionally, but his bedroom window goes out onto the garden. And every now and then he hears them talk there, until late into the night. He doesn't understand everything they say, he really doesn't want to listen, but he likes what he understands. Lang was one of Switzerland's most prominent green politicians. Today he lives in Bern in a quiet neighborhood in a red brick house. It is perhaps the most political house in the city. On the upper floor a young couple, climate activists, lives with the Young Greens, he with the Juso. Lang and his partner are at home on the ground floor. A staircase connects not only two floors, but also forty years of protest history. In the garden, Lang's neighbor meets with other activists from the climate youth and discuss dreams, plans, strategies. In front of the Corona pandemic, Lang sometimes sat down and talked. Since then, he's been keeping a little distance. Lang, 67, is sitting in his conservatory on a day of April when he talks about it. He admires these boys. Lang also sat for nights with other people in kitchens, living rooms and gardens. Discussed what to do, what to do to make the world a better place. Lang is a 68, he fought the army and the nuclear power plant. He knows the excitement, euphoria and despair of resistance. Jo Lang has been thinking a lot about the boys in his garden. In the beginning, he says, "the climate movement went like butter through society." He's impressed with what she did. But Lang also knows that the boys see it differently. What they have achieved seems to them to be as effective as a headache pill for cancer. It should have been more possible. Then Corona came and put her to sleep. Now the climate movement is at a crossroads. Jo Lang knows the rhythm of protest waves. They're coming up, and eventually they're breaking. After that calm follows, but wave valleys are deceptive. Is the water just still, because the next wave is already developing sog again and thus smoothing the surface? Jo Lang was once part of a movement where an eco-terrorist named Marco Camenisch blew up high-voltage lines. Camenisch sat in prison after that, Lang as a national councillor in the federal house. This is the future of many in protest movements: some radicalize, others try to change the system from within. And some just give up. The power of the climate movement has been derived from the fact that it has endured these tensions in the two and a half years of its existence. Jo Lang hopes it will stay that way. He says, "I see myself in them, in this boy." Perhaps some also see themselves in him. And others in Marco Camenisch? Where is this movement headed, now that it is trying to resume its drive? The "Strike for Future", a first national protest day, should call it back to people's consciousness today. New players have joined forces to increase the tension. How long does the movement last? How long will she be able to swallow the disappointment of being just a headache pill? And has it reached the point where it is in danger of harming its own cause? In the headquarters In a room in Zurich's west, in the midst of glittering skyscrapers, where revolution would not be sought, three young people sit at a large table. They refer to themselves as the first and second generation of the climate youth – "it sounds like the RAF," one objectes. And you don't want to remember left-wing terrorists under any circumstances. The three climate activists are young, but they are not beginners. You've been interviewing a lot. I'm about to see TV for a report. They know they need the media, right now, after the protests about Corona had to be interrupted for so long. In the background, they continued to work, enlarged the network, forged plans. Even if it has become quiet around them: There is no rest in them. They are impatient – and they are afraid. "When I think of 2050? 240 million climate refugees coming to us. Resource war, a higher sea level. Millions of people will die." There is no exclamation mark in this quote. Anna Lindermeier always talks quietly, even if she's angry and scared. It is not clear whether she is doing this out of shyness or on purpose, because then you listen better. Her face doesn't make it clear, she has a girl face that can still be anything, sometimes it looks like a poker face. Anna Lindermeier: "We have to think about how we define violence." Christoph Ruckstuhl / NZZ Lindermeier, 19, a biology student, has only been active in the climate movement for a year. In the meantime, there is hardly anything else in her life. Lindermeier jumps back and forth between worlds. When she demonstrated for the first time, she was still a gymnasium student, climbed the post car every morning in homes at Albis in the Säuliamt, drove into the city to Kanti Wiedikon, «a hippie canti», many were left and alternative. It was different in the country. Lindermeier grew up in London, his father is a banker, and for the trip to the grandparents in Germany they used to take the plane. She hasn't flown for almost ten years, but she wouldn't judge anyone for flying. "Everyone has to decide this for themselves." For a long time, foreign groups were not welcome at the climate demos. This has also changed because of Lindermeier. Last autumn, the climate movement invited trade unions and NGOs to its headquarters in Zurich for the first time. The fraternization and syllabus were decided, vowed to fight together. A common struggle, because the ecological and social question could not be separated. When Lindermeier talks about this meeting, her voice becomes a little louder, she smiles and seems happy. But just for a second. There's no reason for euphoria. Lindermeier weaves the web of motion more densely. Not just with the unions, she's spinning the strings on the country. Lindermeier founded one of the 156 local groups of the climate movement in her home village Hausen am Albis. Hausen is located ennet the Albispass, only 15 kilometers away from Zurich, but it is another world, public transport country, governed by SVP and FDP. At least twenty people came to the first meeting, and the second was seven. It is simple basic work that Lindermeier is doing here: she negotiated with the village policeman whether the small group on a public place on the national strike day is allowed to carry out a "climate alarm", i.e. produce as much noise as possible with cooking spoons and lids to shake people up. Too short notice, the policeman said. This is the dilemma of the resistors: the young people have been discussing for a long time whether they are not too harmless. Lindermeier and two other activists at their headquarters in Zurich also addressed this question. One said: "We have this joke: eight million Swiss people are demonstrating in the Bundesplatz, but we have no demand. What good is it if we all reach, but demand nothing?" "We die in insolence," answered another. And one of them added: "Violence is only okay against objects to sabotage a coal excavator, that's almost mandatory." Lindermeier said: "We have to think about how we define violence. One has to see: It is perfectly allowed that any cement companies in Africa produce and the whole village has cancer there." It is a moment when it becomes visible what the young people do not really want to show: a kind of cold anger. She's pushing the movement. But where? A girl and Roger Federer It was only a girl with a cardboard plate who sat in front of the Swedish government's seat on the first day of school after the holidays; four months later, in December 2018, 500 students of cantonal schools were on strike in Zurich, and more and more were on strike throughout Switzerland, 20 000, 40 000, and in October 2019 nearly 100,000 young people were reported to have gone out on the streets. All because of this Greta and the climate. The mobilization impressed and confused the adults. The movement is still hard to grasp. On the one hand, there are the peaceful climate strikes. On the other hand, activists already occupied a CS branch in Lausanne as a tennis player in November 2018. Occupying a bank in Switzerland – how much more symbolic can you demonstrate? The Renens District Court released the activists from the charge of breaking house peace, and the case now lies with the Federal Court. But didn't even Roger Federer say "respect and admiration" for the climate youth at the time? Federer, of all people, who is so careful not to conjure up politics that he can be taken as a seismographer for the Swiss average citizen. Of course, it's a protest movement. She can and must not remain harmless. Activists occupy the Federal Square in Bern, in Western Switzerland they build a "ZAD", a "zone à defensivee", a protection zone on the Mormont hill, to defend the hill from the cement company Holcim. An activist puts a video on Instagram. "We never said that we were nonviolent," he says, calling for sabotage files, for "aggressive responses." Not everyone in the movement was happy with this statement. A first test: Would Roger Federer also respect and admire the squatters of a hill who aggressively defend it? Do you even want the admiration of the average Swiss citizen, who has closed his eyes to climate change for decades? It was just a girl with a cardboard plate. Then they became more and more. But if you suddenly have influence, a common goal is no longer enough: How exactly do you change the world? Tony, the optimist When Professor Anthony, in short: Tony, Patt in Russikon in the Zurich Oberland climbs his bike, he has 21 kilometers ahead of him until he descends again before ETH Zurich and enters his office. It's 21 kilometers, and Patt's actually already worked on it. Because Patt is counting on the 21 kilometers. Sometimes he says aloud: One. Two. Three. He rarely had to count on it. At least until three years ago. "It's changing," says Patt today. "I'm counting more and more. Sometimes it's ten. Or fifteen." Patt means electric cars. Of course, they are not a precise measurement value, it is rather a thumb-in-the-wind hold, but for Patt they confirm other more scientific indicators that have transformed him, the professor of climate protection and adaptation: from pessimist to optimist. Patt worked on the fifth report of the World Climate Change Council, which warned against climate change with such drastic words as never before. This report is based on the fear of the climate youth. The scenarios of a world in which hundreds of millions of people move across the continents as climate refugees are also derived from the climate researchers' forecasts. But Patt says: "It is clear that terrible things could happen. But I now believe that we can prevent and prevent the catastrophe." Almost two years ago, Patt stood in the climate area in Zurich, the climate youth had invited him and "all the other researchers in Switzerland who are working on the climate. It was a 'Ah, you're here too, good to see you'». Patt was impressed by the professionalism of the boys, how they dealt with them, the old researchers. And impressed by her will. Patt joined the Climate Action Plan to become the most ambitious and at the same time the most concrete of climate strategy in Switzerland. The plan should set out for all sectors of society what would have to be done to ensure that it could work sustainably. But the mission to Patt and other researchers had a catch: the goal of a CO2-neutral Switzerland was to be achieved in 2030, that is, in ten years' time. On the date of 2030, the radicalism and impatience of the climate movement are evident. The official Switzerland wants to be climate neutral in 2050, just like many other countries. The goal was decided two years ago, it was a victory for the climate demonstrators, but they felt it was a defeat and have never overcome it. They are convinced that 2050 is far too late. The Climate Action Plan should show that it would be possible much faster. Tony Patt writes the chapter Mobility in the Climate Action Plan. He is grateful to the climate youth. He says it is incredible what has happened in politics in recent years thanks to the young people. But Patt also says: "2030 is unrealistic. The plan only shows what is technically possible. But not what would be politically feasible. Emergency measures were needed, like in Corona. That would not be socially sustainable. It would be an invitation to say to the right: 'You see, the climate youth wants us to stop taking a warm shower.'» Patt understands impatience, but he did not become a climate researcher for idealistic reasons. Patt is a skier. He tells us how he thought sometime on the mountain that maybe there could be no more snow in 2020. «I then thought about flying a paraglider, but....» He breaks the sentence and laughs. "It's not the same thing." Patt did not demonstrate himself as a teenager. He trained too much. Modern pentathlon: pistol shooting, fencing, horse riding, swimming, running. Modern pentathlon should be the ideal athlete. Surely they are the most versatile. This sport shaped Patt's life. At the university, Patt first became interested in mechanical engineering, but then studied architecture and landscape planning, and when he realized that he did not want to work as an architect, he graduated in Jus. He worked in a law firm for a few years, returned to university, studied public policy, environmental law. Patt is a social scientist, but he can also calculate, combine everything, like in the pentathlon. "That's how my life works." Maybe that's why he sees things differently. Patt studies other indicators. Not only economic, but also technical. He believes that change towards a decarbonised society will soon accelerate. Faster. There are indicators that indicate this. But we needed patience. The next IPCC report will highlight this hope more strongly. Patt believes that the impatience of the climate youth has helped for a long time. The vehemence they fought with. But now she can be dangerous. She's changing the look at reality. Without the CO2 Act, it would be difficult and very expensive to achieve the 2050 target. Do the youths want too much too fast? Tony Patt doesn't want to say anything. Once he was as pessimistic as the boys, now he is cautiously hopeful. But the young people could misunderstand this optimism. As naivety. Even as a betrayal. With the rebels A role-playing game in front of the church Wipkingen above Zurich: A man walks with tacky steps towards an empty wooden chair. He moves his hands like he's driving a car. Then he cries out to the wooden chair: "What is this? I want to drive through here!» The chair gives no answer. The man keeps screaming. An elderly woman joins. "Stop, this is a roadblock, for the climate!" she says. "I don't care. I have to go to work, what the hell!", shouts the man. "It's a climate emergency, we'll draw attention to it with the blockade." "I'll run over it!" A man interrupts the exercise. "And how do you feel?" he asks the woman. "Not so good, it's stressful, I don't know if I can do that in reality." "Then maybe you'll let it go better." The man who calms down here is the workshop leader this evening in front of the church, which is used by the climate movement for training and meetings. He is almost fifty years old, has already participated in university occupations and is now part of the Extinction Rebellion group. This Thursday he wants to train new activists. Extinction Rebellion is the behavioral side drive of the climate movement. The rebels chain up, block highways, dye rivers green. Civil disobedience is not only allowed, but indicated, given the dramatic nature of the situation. Finally, not only animal species would die out, but mankind would eventually die out as a result of it. In fact, this should be the arm of the movement that could most likely develop towards the eco-terrorists of the 1980s. But no future Marco Camenisch is hiding in front of the church. It's a group of scared people who sometimes seem as if they were terrified by the extent of their own fear of the soon end of the world. For three hours, they practice blockages in the cold, scream at chairs or trees, listen inside and hear what feelings this causes. So they can find out if they're actually ready to sit in front of a real car, like on the Zurich Quai Bridge. The woman, who was afraid during the exercise, asks at some point: "But what should we tell people if they ask us what to do about extinction?" The course leader thinks that this is a good question. "But it's not our job to have an answer to that. We point out that we are destroying our own livelihoods. Ask back: 'What could you do to avert the catastrophe?'» Extinction Rebellion has already proposed a solution, but it sounds as naive as it is familiar: meetings by chance, but representative of the population of selected citizens should deal with the problems of climate change and also propose solutions at the same time. "That sounds like a parliament?" "Exactly," says the course leader. «But without representation of interests.» A few days later, activists from Extinction Rebellion will be on the streets throughout Switzerland. In Basel, two police officers will carry a woman from the street wearing a sign around her neck, which says: "I am very afraid to become a mother because of the climate crisis." In Sion, a man with a white flag will block the road. On a sign it says: «J-ai peur d-avoir faim en europe à cause de la sécheresse.» Blick.ch will later spread a video showing an angry driver pulling a demonstrator from the street. "I just wanted to keep driving," he will say. The «View» headlines: «Do not such nerve actions harm climate activists?» The tragedy of every movement of nerve actions? Climate activists fear that they are just a drug for society. But the more laborious they become, the sooner the population perceives them as a disease rather than a drug. In the movement, one struggles with this perception. A climate activist says: "Politics does not deal with the climate crisis, but with the climate movement as a problem that needs to be solved." This is the moment when the fate of many protest movements decides. Some people are angry that everything is going too slowly. They want more faster and think they need to be louder. The others are afraid that this way those who would be receptive will be completely in front of their heads. Would a young citizen also feel comfortable in the movement? When you ask the activists this question, they usually only laugh and mean that someone like that would have a hard time with us. In fact, they have achieved a great deal. Four years ago, climate change was a topic for the left and the Greens, and now even the FDP is desperately trying to find a way to deal with it. Large corporations such as Nestlé, Ikea or Novartis want to be climate neutral by 2050 or even by 2030. And how Switzerland will deal with the climate crisis is a question that is now being discussed as intensively as it is about the next AHV revision. That's the boy's credit. Fear is blinding, they say. Do the climate activists therefore not see who shaped society more: Jo Lang, who entered the system, or the principle riders who never wanted to break away from their maximum demands? Perhaps it is the tragedy of every protest movement that this dilemma always comes to mind: whoever remains true to himself sometimes stands in the way of himself. Every wave breaks at some point. But there's always a next wave.
author: Michael Schilliger Flurin Clalüna Christoph Ruckst

text: ['Aktionstag «Strike for Future»: 30’000 Menschen fordern klimagerechte Gesellschaft Tausende von Aktivisten und Aktivistinnen haben am Freitag landesweit am «Strike for Future» teilgenommen.', 'Der nächste grosse Streik- und Aktionstag ist im Herbst geplant.', "SDA  Rund 30'000 Menschen beteiligten sich am Freitag im ganzen Land am «Strike for Future».", 'An über 100 Aktionen und Veranstaltungen wurde eine klimagerechte Gesellschaft gefordert.', 'Klimastreikende, Gewerkschaften, feministische Kollektive, Nichtregierungsorganisationen, kirchlich und friedenspolitische Gruppen sowie Lokalgruppen hätten auf diverse Aspekte der Klimakrise aufmerksam gemacht und zusammen eine ökologische und soziale Gesellschaft gefordert, teilte Klimaschutz Schweiz mit.', 'Mindestens 100 Veranstaltungen wurden landesweit durchgeführt.', 'Zu grösseren Aktionen kam es in Zürich, Bern und Lausanne.', 'Treibhausgasemissionen müssten bis spätestens 2030 auf netto Null reduziert werden, hiess es vielerorts.', 'Angesichts der sich intensivierenden Klimakrise forderten die Klimastreikenden ein umgehendes, entschiedenes Handeln.', 'Nur so könne das Pariser Abkommen und das 1,5-Grad-Ziel noch eingehalten werden.', 'Diese Vorgaben seien für das Verhindern von zusätzlichem Leid und Tod aufgrund der Klimakrise unabdingbar.', 'In Lausanne haben Studierende an einer Kundgebung für den Klimaschutz protestiert.', 'Die über 100 Veranstaltungen reichen von einer einfachen Standaktion bis hin zu Kundgebungen.', 'Um 11.59 Uhr wurde an mehreren Orten in der Schweiz ein Klimaalarm ausgelöst – ein erster Höhepunkt, wie Klimastreik Schweiz mitteilte.', 'Der Berner SP-Ständerat Hans Stöckli geht an Aktivistinnen auf dem Berner Bahnhofplatz vorbei.', '(21.', 'Mai 2021)  Dabei ging es lautstark zu.', 'Mit Trillerpfeifen, Hörnern und Pfannendeckeln schlugen rund 100 Personen beim St. Galler Waaghaus lautstark Klimaalarm.', 'Sie wollten so auf die Dringlichkeit des Klimaschutzes aufmerksam machen.', 'Ähnlich die Aktion in Luzern, wo rund 50 vorwiegend junge Menschen am Freitagmittag lauthals für eine resolute Politik gegen die Klimaerwärmung demonstrierten.', 'Mit Hilfe von Pfannendeckeln, Trillerpfeifen und Sirenen schlugen auch sie «Klimaalarm» und forderten in Sprechchören «Klimagerechtigkeit».', 'Die Demonstrantinnen und Demonstranten legten sich danach im strömenden Regen rund fünf Minuten lang auf den Boden.', 'Am Mittag ertönte in verschiedenen Orten ein Klimaalarm.', 'Die Veranstaltungen zum «Strike for Future» hatten verschiedenartige Facetten.', '(21.', 'Mai 2021)  Mit zahlreichen Aktionen forderten Aktivistinnen und Aktivisten im Kanton Bern einen wirksameren Klimaschutz.', 'Statt wie bei früheren nationalen Streiktagen auf eine grosse Kundgebung setzten die Organisatoren am «Strike for Future»-Tag coronabedingt auf dezentrale Kleinveranstaltungen.', 'In Basel versammelten sich gegen 1500 Menschen zur Klimastreik-Kundgebung.', 'In verschiedenen Ansprachen wurde für ein Ja für das CO2-Gesetz plädiert, das ein «ganz kleiner», aber immerhin ein Schritt in die richtige Richtung sei.', 'Ein Infostand im Rahmen des Aktionstages «Strike for Future» auf dem Berner Bahnhofplatz.', '(21.', 'Mai 2021)  Im Kanton Zürich zog die Hauptdemo am Zürcher Helvetiaplatz am Abend trotz anfänglichem Regen mehrere Hundert Teilnehmer an.', 'Zum ersten Mal bemerkbar gemacht hatten sich die Klimastreikenden bereits am frühen Freitagmorgen vor dem Zürcher Bezirksgericht: Dort solidarisierten sich etwas mehr als 20 Personen mit einer angeklagten Klimaschützerin.', 'Diese stand vor Gericht, weil sie im Juni 2020 bei der Blockade der Zürcher Quaibrücke teilgenommen hatte.', 'In Chur riefen verschiedene Organisationen in einer gemeinsamen Aktion zu einem Wandel in der Klimapolitik auf.', 'Hunderte Personen folgten dem Ruf und versammelten sich zu einer Demonstration.', 'Die Stadtpolizei Chur lobte die Teilnehmenden für die gute Einhaltung der Maskenpflicht.', 'Auch in Basel setzen sich vor allem junge Menschen für den Schutz des Klimas ein.', 'In Lausanne machten sich Studierende an einer Kundgebung für den Klimaschutz stark.', 'In Genf protestierte ein Komitee gegen den gewaltsamen Landraub durch Rohstoffkonzerne.Der Klimastreik Tessin berichtete den ganzen Tag live auf TeleFuturo, einem eigens für diesen «Strike for Future» eingerichteten Fernsehsender.', 'Im Herbst ist laut der Klimastreik-Bewegung ein weiterer Streik- und Aktionstag geplant.']
processed_text: Action day "Strike for Future": 30,000 people demand climate-friendly society Thousands of activists participated in the "Strike for Future" on Friday. The next big day of strike and action is planned in autumn. SDA Around 30,000 people participated in the Strike for Future on Friday throughout the country. More than 100 actions and events called for a climate-friendly society. Climate strikers, trade unions, feminist collectives, non-governmental organisations, church and peace-political groups and local groups had drawn attention to various aspects of the climate crisis and together demanded an ecological and social society, said Climate Protection Switzerland. At least 100 events were held nationwide. Larger campaigns have taken place in Zurich, Berne and Lausanne. Greenhouse gas emissions would have to be reduced to net zero by 2030 at the latest, it was said in many places. In the face of the intensifying climate crisis, the climate strikers demanded immediate, decisive action. Only in this way can the Paris Agreement and the 1.5-degree target still be met. These guidelines are indispensable for preventing additional suffering and death due to the climate crisis. In Lausanne, students protested for climate protection at a rally. The more than 100 events range from a simple stand action to rallies. At 11:59 a climate alarm was triggered in several locations in Switzerland – a first highlight, as climate strike Switzerland announced. The Bernese SP-Ständerat Hans Stöckli passes activists on Berner Bahnhofplatz. (21. May 2021) It was loud and clear. With whistles, horns and pan lids, around 100 people at the St. Galler Waaghaus hit loudly climate alarm. They wanted to draw attention to the urgency of climate protection. Similar to the action in Lucerne, where around 50 mainly young people demonstrated loudly on Friday noon for a resolute policy against climate warming. With the help of pan lids, whistles and sirens, they also beat «climate alarm» and demanded «climate justice» in speech choirs. The demonstrators then lay down on the ground for about five minutes in the pouring rain. At noon, a climate alarm sounded in different places. The "Strike for Future" events had different facets. (21. May 2021) Activists in the canton of Bern demanded more effective climate protection with numerous actions. Instead of a large rally, as in previous national strike days, the organisers at the Strike for Future Day relied on decentralized small events due to corona. In Basel, about 1500 people gathered for the climate strike rally. In various speeches, a "yes" to the CO2 law was advocated, which was "very smaller", but nevertheless a step in the right direction. An information stand as part of the action day "Strike for Future" on Berner Bahnhofplatz. (21. May 2021) In the canton of Zurich, the main demo at Helvetiaplatz in Zurich attracted several hundred participants in the evening despite the initial rain. For the first time, the climate strikers had already made themselves felt in front of the Zurich District Court on the early Friday morning: there, a little more than 20 people were solidarityed with an accused climate activist. This was on trial because she had participated in the blockade of the Zurich Quai Bridge in June 2020. In Chur, various organisations called for a change in climate policy in a joint action. Hundreds of people followed the call and gathered for a demonstration. The Chur City Police praised the participants for the good observance of the masquerade duty. In Basel, too, young people are particularly committed to protecting the climate. In Lausanne, students made a strong contribution to a climate change rally. In Geneva, a committee protested against the violent land grabbing by commodity companies.The climate strike in Ticino reported live on TeleFuturo, a television station specially set up for this "Strike for Future". According to the climate strike movement, another day of strike and action is planned in autumn.

Gebäudeautomatik, Gebäudetechnik für Heizung, Lüftung, Sanitär, Montage für Heizung, Sensortechnik, Wärmepumpen, Solaranlagen, Automobilgewerbe-Mechatronik.', 'Die Lehrlinge in diesen Gymnasiasten und Studenten sieht man sie nicht.', 'Denn am Werktag müssen sie in ihrer Firma arbeiten.', 'Sie sind aber jene, die heute und in Zukunft dafür sorgen, dass wir von den fossilen Energien abwechselnd mit Barbara Bleisch, Laura de Weck und Michael Hermann.']
processed_text: Opinions Column corporations as hidden voters Do the voters know that with the next referendum, they are setting some of the world's largest corporations in alarm and writing international economic policy? In formal terms, the voting proposals are about pesticides and fossil fuels. But with a deeper look into the political power play, large multinationals who have fallen into the defensive are steering and financing the vote behind the scenes. This vote campaign is a kind of war of proxy. The multinational corporations use millions because the voting results in Switzerland are perceived as acceptance indicators with a global signal effect. The nervousness at the headquarters of Syngenta and Bayer-Monsanto is great because of the two pesticide initiatives. Your participation in the voting campaign is undercover. The co-financing of the No campaign is via Economiesuisse, whose president was previously manager at Syngenta for 18 years. The referendum of multinational oil and gas companies against the CO2 Act is more direct and transparent. Because at first no political force wanted to be involved in a vote, the Brennund Fuel Association Avenergy Suisse launched the referendum itself and found only the SVP as an advanced political force. The Avenergy campaign is financed by the branches of the world's largest oil companies. Small Switzerland is not important for these oil giants. But with their interference, they want to suppress the signal effect on the EU and the US, which also committed themselves to the strategy "Climate neutral by 2050". This CO2 law has been carefully balanced by Parliament. It does not contain any prohibitions. No one has to give up heat comfort. It steers the new energy technologies much more efficiently through cost truth, economic incentives and innovations. Therefore, the law is supported by all parties at federal level except the SVP and by the well-known trade unions and trade unions. The SVP only sends its right-wing force into the proxy fight against the law. But above all farmers and tradesmen in the SVP base support it. You benefit directly from its funding. The House Owners' Association (HEV), dominated by SVP politicians, operates pure SVP party politics in its rejection of the CO2 law with bizarre black painting («Apartments for everyone more expensive», «Forced terminations for tenants») and thus irritates many of its members. Many family owners were the first to receive funding for replacing their oil heating with heat pump and solar system. No one has to scrap their oil heaters with the law. Everyone enjoys a guarantee of the acquis. The change to a heat pump is required only after the exit of the old oil burner and only in the case of non-insulated buildings. There is funding for heating renewal and isolation. This also benefits all tenants. The opponents argue with a small war of claims about gasoline rags and promotion franks. It is suppressed that the technological change of course pays off several times throughout the economy. Every year we waste 8 billion Swiss francs on foreign payments for oil and gas imports. Instead of using these billions for energy investment in the domestic market, it is more efficient! The energy efficiency program of the CO2 Act pushes forward-looking commercial sectors: for example, building automation, building technology for heating, ventilation, sanitation, assembly for heating, sensor technology, heat pumps, solar systems, automotive mechatronics. The apprentices in these energy-technical professions are the actual "climate activists" among the young people. You can't see them at the strikes and occupation of the Fridays for Future, which have been transformed into self-resurgence. Because they have to work in their company on the working day. But they are the ones who are making sure that we get away effectively from fossil energies today and in the future. It is irritating that the radicalised climate movement of the academic youth leaves the CO2 law unmentioned aside. If, according to the climate activists' demands, oil, gasoline and gas were to be forcibly dispensed with by 2030 – instead of by 2050 according to the perspective of the law – one would have to scrap over one million heaters and two million cars prematurely over the next ten years. I'm sure it wouldn't be climate-compliant. A rejection of the CO2 law would be the victory of the oil companies alone. They would be allowed to delay the urgent efficiency restructuring in the economy by many years with their exit technology. Rudolf Strahm The former price supervisor Rudolf Strahm writes alternately with Barbara Bleisch, Laura de Weck and Michael Hermann.
