beobachtbaren Klimatrends in den nächsten Jahrzehnten verstärken werden, hängt stark davon ab, welche Massnahmen die internationale Staatengemeinschaft ergreift.', 'Steigen die Treibhausgasemissionen ungebremst weiter (was unwahrscheinlich ist), könnte die Temperatur in der Schweiz bis zur Mitte des Jahrhunderts um weitere 2 bis 3,3 Grad steigen.', 'Mit konsequentem Klimaschutz wären es 0,7 bis 1,9 Grad.', 'Mit der Annahme des CO2-Gesetzes hat es die Schweiz in der Hand, ihren Teil zur Halbierung der Treibhausgasemissionen beizutragen und so ihren in Paris gemachten Zusagen nachzukommen.']
processed_text: Supporters of the CO2 Act claim that Switzerland is particularly affected by climate change. A fact check 2003 was a year with a summer of the century. At that time, mortality was similar to that in the Corona year 2020. What's going on? Christian Speicher A thawing permafrost makes steep mountain slopes unstable, which leads to murmurs. The photo is taken from the Zernez National Park. Joël Hunn / NZZ Fruit farmers fear the late frost like the devil's holy water. When the temperatures drop at night again far below freezing point in April, the delicate flowers of the fruit trees threaten to freeze. But the fruit farmers should not fear the late frost, but rather climate change. It is not so unusual that icy air reaches our latitudes from the Arctic in April. Rather, it is unusual for fruit trees to start blooming earlier because of global warming. This mixture of unpredictable weather and the long-standing climate trend destroyed half of the Swiss fruit harvest in 2017. It brought the fruit farmers a loss of 100 million Swiss francs. Climate change is not an abstract threat to future generations. Its effects are already noticeable today – also in Switzerland. The vote on the revised CO2 law is now due. It sets the framework for a halving of CO2 emissions by 2030. The Federal Council, the Parliament, the cantons and numerous scientists recommend the adoption of the law. They say Switzerland is particularly affected by climate change. But is that true? Two degrees of warming since 1860 The statement is correct, and yet it is only half-right. In fact, temperatures in Switzerland have increased by two degrees since the beginning of industrialization – twice as high as in the global average. Compared to other landlocked countries, however, Switzerland is not a special case, says Stephan Bader of Meteo Switzerland. Country regions generally warmed up more than coastal regions. Because the dampening influence of the oceans, which absorb part of the heat, is lacking. With its warming of two degrees, Switzerland is therefore well integrated into the continental overall picture. Temperature is the most important indicator that the climate in Switzerland is changing. But it is far from the only one. Last year, Bafu and Meteo Switzerland gathered together in a comprehensive report on the causes of climate change and its effects. The authors strictly distinguish between changes that are already noticeable, and those that can be expected due to model calculations up to the middle of the century. A direct consequence of the warming is that heat waves in Switzerland have become more frequent and also more intense since 1901. This increase has a direct impact on health. As Martina Raglettli and Martin Röösli from the Swiss Tropical and Public Health Institute showed in an investigation last year, heat waves and individual heat days lead to the need for more and more people to be hospitalised. And mortality is also increasing. According to the authors, there were 975 additional deaths in Switzerland in the record-breaking summer of 2003. This corresponds to an increase of 6.9 percent. In 2003, the number of people killed was as high as in the Corona year 2020. Agriculture, too, suffers from prolonged periods of heat. According to the Federal Office for the Environment (Bafu), economic losses amounted to 500 million Swiss francs in the summer of 2003. Global warming is also changing winters in Switzerland. Thus, since 1961, the number of frost days has fallen by 60 percent. In the same period, the zero-grade limit has moved upwards by 300 to 400 meters. These are changes that did not pass without a trace in an Alpine country like Switzerland, says Bader, one of the co-authors of the climate report. Since 1850, the glaciers in Switzerland have lost more than half of their volume due to the warming. Year after year, about a half to a cubic kilometre of ice was lost, depending on the intensity of the summer heat. It is therefore foreseeable that there will be only a few glaciers on shady slopes by the end of the century. That is not just an aesthetic problem, says Bader. Low precipitation regions such as the Valais consumed in summer from the melting water of the glaciers. The agricultural and energy sectors would therefore have to adjust in time to a new water regime. Climate change affects not only the glaciers. The permafrost in the Swiss mountains also retreats. This is shown by measurements of the Swiss Permafrost measurement network Permos, which spans a period of 20 years. The researchers found that the temperatures measured at 10 and 20 metres depth in 2019/20 have reached or even exceeded the record values from 2015. This can be attributed, among other things, to the high air temperatures as well as to the early snowfall, which prevented the heat stored in the summer from being radiated. As a result, a more powerful layer of permafrost will thaw in the following summer. For the Swiss mountain regions dependent on tourism, the warning signals are. Because the permafrost holds the ground. If the kitt thaws, ice-bearing debris in the high mountains is set in motion and slip to the valley. This increases the danger of mudslides. The operators of mountain railways also have to adapt to a new situation. In future, they will have to monitor regularly whether the thawing underground is still viable enough. In addition, thawing permafrost could lead to more mountain falls and make high alpine hiking trails insecure. The heat summer 2003 provided a foretaste here. At that time, thousands of cubic meters of rock were dissolved on the Hörnligrat. Over 90 climbers had to be rescued by helicopter. The popular climbing route on the Matterhorn remained closed for several days. More rain in winter The fact that climate change can also have positive effects is evident in the winter precipitations. These have increased by 20 to 30 percent since 1864. However, only very high-altitude ski resorts benefit from this. In deep areas, you have to adjust more to rain in winter. The number of snow days below 2000 metres has decreased by 20 percent since 1970, and even by 50 percent under 800 metres. For many pre-alpine ski resorts, this will mean the end sooner or later. Averaged throughout the year, there is no statistically significant increase or decrease in precipitation in Switzerland. Nevertheless, the summers seem to tend to get drier. This can be explained by the evaporation that has increased as temperatures rise, Bader explains. This trend is not yet very pronounced. However, it should be noted that dry summers have accumulated over the last 10 to 15 years. This problem is likely to be accentuated in the coming decades. According to the climate scenarios of the National Centre for Climate Services (NCCS), summer rainfall could decrease by up to 25 percent by the middle of the century, and the longest dry season could last up to nine days longer than today. Extremely dry summers as in 2018 could then accumulate in Switzerland. At that time, the level of rivers and lakes fell to low temperatures. And also the soil was so dry that the grass and grain dried up in the fields. The situation was so critical that some farmers were forced to fly water for their cows to the Alps by helicopter. And hay suddenly became a shortage. Whether the climate trends, which are already observed today, will intensify in the coming decades depends heavily on what measures the international community is taking. If greenhouse gas emissions continue to rise unchecked (which is unlikely), temperatures in Switzerland could rise by another 2 to 3.3 degrees by the middle of the century. With consistent climate protection, it would be 0.7 to 1.9 degrees. With the adoption of the CO2 Act, Switzerland has the power to contribute its part to the halving of greenhouse gas emissions and thus fulfil its commitments made in Paris.
author: Christian Speicher

Green National Council Bastien Girod says how to win the vote. Stefan Häne Mr Girod, how much is your fear that the voters will reject the CO2 law? According to the second Tamedia survey, approval is crumbling. Fear is the wrong word. But I'm worried because there's a lot at stake. ==References== June would be a disaster for climate protection. However, I am still convinced that the voter will approve the proposal. The opponents have managed to make the vote a question of wallet. The debate seems to me like this: our house is on fire and we are talking about whether the fire hose is a little too expensive. Or if we'd better wait and see if there might be a better fire truck coming by. With the fire truck, you're alluding to the part of the climate strike movement that rejects the law. So it would be the fault of people from the green camp to say no. It's too early to ask the guilt question. The criticism that you mention makes it certainly more difficult to arouse enthusiasm for the CO2 Act. The law is a great success for the climate change movement. Without the commitment of the climate strikers and the 2019 climate election, the law would not have come about that way. Until the vote, we must succeed in fuelling this enthusiasm. It could be too late for that. Radical climate protectionists have publicly dismissed the law, declaring politics incapable of solving the climate problem. You can ask me so many times: I do not commit self - carnage. The fact is that a no to the law would throw us back years in climate protection. In addition, a new proposal would certainly be less ambitious and less economical. An example: today, some companies can be freed from the CO2 levy on fossil fuels if they reduce their CO2 emissions in return – a measure that is now running out. By contrast, the new law would open this instrument to all companies. The Green Party is conspicuously holding back in the vote. Don't you want to upset your party's radical wing? This is a big task, because the opponents of the law are financially very well equipped, because foreign oil importers have great financial interests in a no. text: [' Die Argumente gegen das Elektroauto werden immer schwächer Was bringt der Umstieg aufs Elektroauto?', 'Alles zu Anschaffungs- und Betriebskosten sowie der effektiven Umweltwirkung.', 'Herbie Schmidt  Sollte das CO2-Gesetz in der Volksabstimmung am 13.', 'Juni genehmigt werden, stehen höhere Kosten für Treibstoffe und Fahrzeuge mit Verbrennungsmotor ins Haus.', 'So viel ist bekannt, wenngleich die Beurteilung der Kostensteigerungen unterschiedlich ausfällt.', 'So mancher Autobesitzer stellt sich nun die Frage, ob sich ein Umstieg auf ein CO2-ärmeres Fahrzeug lohnen würde, und zwar sowohl was den Geldbeutel des Kunden als auch was den Effekt auf die Umwelt betrifft.', 'Die Preise für Elektroautos haben sich in den vergangenen Jahren und Monaten deutlich verringert, was durch die immer grösseren Stückzahlen und die sinkenden Kosten für die Batterieherstellung begründet ist.', 'Das günstigste Angebot ist der kleine SUV Dacia Spring, der mit einer elektrischen Reichweite von 230 bis 305 Kilometern zu Preisen unterhalb von 20\xa0000 Franken zu haben ist.', 'Mittlerweile sind Elektroautos etwa gleich teuer wie Benziner.', 'Im direkten Vergleich zwischen einem VW Golf und seinem elektrischen Pendant VW ID.3 zeigt sich der Stromer mit 204 PS als Einstiegsmodell «Pro Performance Life» mit knapp 40\xa0000 Franken rund 1000 Franken teurer als der 150 PS starke, jedoch leichtere VW Golf 1.5 eTSI DSG Style.', 'Grosse Differenz bei Betriebskosten Interessant wird es bei den Betriebskosten, denn hier hat der Batteriewagen gegenüber dem Benziner heute deutliche Vorteile.', 'In vielen Kantonen beträgt die jährliche Motorfahrzeugsteuer für den im Beispiel genannten VW Golf rund 250 Franken.', 'Und beim Direktvergleich der Treibstoffkosten entfallen beim Golf mit 15\xa0000 Kilometern Jahresfahrleistung gemäss Normverbrauch (6,0 l/100 km) 900 Liter Benzin.', 'Bei einem durchschnittlichen Benzinpreis von 1 Franken 60 ergeben sich 1440 Franken.', 'Wird das CO2-Gesetz angenommen, könnten die Treibstoffpreise mit CO2-Abgabe um bis zu 12 Rappen pro Liter anwachsen, womit die jährlichen Spritkosten im Beispiel um 108 Franken steigen würden.', 'Beim Elektroauto gewähren die meisten Kantone auf die jährliche Fahrzeugsteuer einen Rabatt.', 'Im Kanton Zürich wird die Steuer gar ganz erlassen.', 'Doch endet diese Grosszügigkeit per Ende 2024.', 'Der Normverbrauch des Beispiel-ID.3 beträgt 19,4 kWh/100 km.', 'Bei 15\xa0000 Jahreskilometern ergeben sich 2,91 Megawattstunden.', 'Beim gegenwärtigen Durchschnittsstrompreis von 20,5 Rappen pro kWh ergibt dies knapp 600 Franken Stromkosten pro Jahr.', 'Dabei ist aber zu beachten, dass das Aufladen von Elektroautos an auswärtigen Ladesäulen und Schnellladestationen deutlich teurer sein kann.', 'Die Kosten dürften jedoch die Benzinkosten des Beispiel-Golfs kaum überschreiten.', 'Aus Betriebskostensicht also ist der Elektroautofahrer aus heutiger Sicht klar im Vorteil.', 'Dies zumindest solange in der Schweiz keine Zölle auf Elektrofahrzeugstrom erhoben werden.', 'Eine solche Besteuerung durch den Bund ist durchaus zu erwarten, entgehen ihm doch aufgrund sinkender Benzin- und Dieselverbrauchszahlen und der wachsenden Nachfrage nach Elektroautos stetig mehr Treibstoffzölle.', 'Aus Sicht der CO2-Belastung kommt es auf den Betrachtungszeitraum an.', 'Berechnet man rein die Emissionen der Fahrzeuge während 15\xa0000 Jahreskilometern, ergeben sich in unserem Beispiel beim VW Golf rund 20,5 Tonnen CO2.', 'Beim ID.3 hingegen ergibt sich eine dicke Null.', 'Doch diese Anschauungsweise greift zu kurz.', 'Zu beurteilen wären etwa die Emissionen aus der Bereitstellung von Benzin an der Zapfsäule und von Strom an der Steckdose.', 'Hinzu kommen die Emissionen aus der Rohstoffbeschaffung und der Herstellung der Fahrzeuge selbst, bis hin zum Recycling.', 'Man spricht von der «Cradle to cradle»-Betrachtung, also von der Entstehung des Autos bis zur Entstehung des nächsten aus rezyklierten Materialien.', 'Dies sind alles Werte, die vor allem beim Elektroauto derzeit stark kritisiert werden.', 'Schliesslich braucht es für Elektromotoren Magnete aus seltenen Erden und für die Batterien Lithium, Kobalt, Mangan und weitere Rohstoffe.', 'Zudem ist die Verwertung von Elektrofahrzeugen alles andere als simpel.', 'Immerhin stehen vor allem bei Elektroautos die Wiederverwendung und das Recycling der Materialien im Vordergrund.', 'Eine Verschrottung ist hier nur in seltenen Fällen die letzte Option.', 'Die Berechnung der CO2-Emissionen bei der gesamtheitlichen Cradle-to-cradle-Betrachtungsweise ist komplex.', 'Das Paul-Scherrer-Institut und der Touringclub der Schweiz (TCS) haben ein Berechnungswerkzeug geschaffen.', 'Damit kann für mehr als 2000 Autos der ökologische Fussabdruck berechnet werden.', 'Vergleichsrechner für jedermann Der kostenlose Klimabilanzrechner des TCS ist weltweit der Erste seiner Art.', 'Er geht von einer durchschnittlichen Laufleistung der Fahrzeuge von 200\xa0000 Kilometern als Grundlage zur Berechnung aus und greift dazu auf Daten des Paul-Scherrer-Instituts (PSI) und verschiedener Bundesämter (Astra, BfE) zurück.', 'Als wissenschaftlicher Partner steuert das PSI auch die Modelle für die Berechnungen des CO2-Fussabdrucks der Fahrzeugproduktion bei.', 'Das Besondere daran: Aufgrund der gesamthaften Sicht auf die Emissionen über das ganze Autoleben hinweg können nun auch unterschiedliche Antriebsarten (Verbrenner, Elektro und Hybrid) bezüglich ihrer Klimabilanz miteinander verglichen werden.', 'Das gab es weltweit noch nicht.', 'Im Vergleich unserer beiden Beispielfahrzeuge ergibt sich laut TCS-Berechnungswerkzeug, dass der um 650 Franken höhere Fahrzeugpreis des VW ID.3 Pro Performance Life gegenüber dem des VW Golf 1.5 eTSI DSG Style bei einer Laufleistung von jährlich 15\xa0000 Kilometern nach 8557 Kilometern über die geringeren Betriebskosten amortisiert sein wird, also innerhalb von gut einem halben Jahr.', 'Bei einer ganzheitlichen Betrachtung beider Fahrzeuge hat der Elektro-VW ID.3 die höheren CO2-Emissionen aus der Fahrzeugherstellung über die geringeren CO2-Emissionen während des Betriebs nach einer Laufleistung von 38\xa0783 Kilometern kompensiert.', 'Ab dieser Laufleistung ist ein VW ID.3 Pro Performance Life klimafreundlicher als ein VW Golf 1.5 eTSI DSG Style unterwegs.', 'Dabei wird allerdings der Schweizer Strommix zugrunde gelegt, der einen hohen Anteil an erneuerbarer Energie aufweist.', 'All dies sind Argumente für einen Wechsel zum Elektroauto.', 'Nicht bezifferbar ist zudem der höhere Fahrkomfort des lautlosen Elektroautos, und schwer zu berechnen ist zudem seine geringere Lärmbelastung gegenüber dem Benziner.', 'Und ein letztes Argument für den Stromer: Zurzeit sind die Wiederverkaufswerte bei Elektroautos deutlich höher als jene bei Benzinern.']
processed_text: The arguments against the electric car are becoming weaker and weaker What brings about the switch to the electric car? Everything about acquisition and operating costs as well as the effective environmental impact. Herbie Schmidt Should the CO2 Act in the referendum on 13 May 2012 On the other hand, there is a higher cost of fuel and vehicles with internal combustion engines. This is known, although the assessment of cost increases varies. Some car owners are now asking whether it would be worthwhile to switch to a lower-carbon vehicle, both in terms of the customer's wallet and the environmental impact. The prices of electric cars have decreased significantly in recent years and months, due to the increasing number of units and the decreasing cost of battery production. The cheapest offer is the small SUV Dacia Spring, which is available with an electric range of 230 to 305 kilometers at prices below 20 000 francs. In the meantime, electric cars are about as expensive as gasoline cars. In a direct comparison between a VW Golf and its electric counterpart VW ID.3 the electric power supply with 204 hp is a starting model "Pro Performance Life" with almost 40 000 francs about 1000 francs more expensive than the 150 hp, but lighter VW Golf 1.5 eTSI DSG style. Large difference in operating costs It is interesting to see the operating costs, because here the battery car has significant advantages compared to the petrol engine today. In many cantons, the annual motor vehicle tax for the VW Golf mentioned in the example amounts to around CHF 250. And when comparing the fuel costs directly, the golf with 15 000 kilometres of annual driving power according to standard consumption (6.0 l/100 km) eliminates 900 litres of petrol. With an average petrol price of CHF 1 60, the result is CHF 1440. If the CO2 law is adopted, fuel prices could increase by up to 12 centimetres per litre with CO2 emissions, which would increase the annual fuel costs by 108 francs in the example. In the case of electric cars, most cantons grant a discount on the annual vehicle tax. In the canton of Zurich, the tax is even completely abolished. But this generosity ends at the end of 2024. The standard consumption of the example ID.3 is 19.4 kWh/100 km. At 15,000 kilometers a year, there are 2.91 megawatt hours. At the current average electricity price of 20.5 rappen per kWh, this results in almost 600 Swiss francs per year. However, it should be noted that charging electric cars at external charging stations and fast charging stations can be significantly more expensive. However, the costs are unlikely to exceed the gasoline costs of the example golf. From the point of view of operating costs, the electric car driver is clearly in advantage from today's point of view. This is at least as long as no tariffs are imposed on electric vehicle electricity in Switzerland. Such a tax by the federal government is to be expected, because of the declining petrol and diesel consumption and the growing demand for electric cars, it evades steadily more fuel tariffs. From the point of view of CO2 pollution, it depends on the period considered. If the emissions of vehicles are calculated purely for 15 000 km/year, our example of VW Golf results in about 20,5 tonnes of CO2. The ID.3, on the other hand, results in a thick zero. But this view is too short. For example, emissions from the supply of petrol at the pump and electricity at the socket could be assessed. In addition, emissions from raw material procurement and the manufacture of vehicles themselves, up to recycling, are also included. One speaks of the Cradle to Cradle consideration, i.e. from the origin of the car to the origin of the next one from recycled materials. These are all values that are currently strongly criticised, especially in the case of electric cars. Finally, for electric motors, magnets from rare earths and for the batteries lithium, cobalt, manganese and other raw materials are needed. In addition, the use of electric vehicles is far from simple. After all, the re-use and recycling of materials are the main focus of electric cars. Scraping is only the last option in rare cases. The calculation of CO2 emissions in the overall Cradle-to-cradle approach is complex. The Paul Scherrer Institute and the Touring Club of Switzerland (TCS) have created a calculation tool. This allows the ecological footprint to be calculated for more than 2000 cars. Comparison calculator for everyone The free climate balance calculator of the TCS is the first of its kind worldwide. It is based on an average mileage of 200 000 kilometres and uses data from the Paul Scherrer Institute (PSI) and various federal offices (Astra, BfE). As a scientific partner, the PSI also contributes the models for the calculations of the CO2 footprint of vehicle production. The special feature of this is that due to the overall view of emissions throughout the entire car life, different types of engines (burners, electrics and hybrids) can now be compared with each other in terms of their climate balance. It hasn't been around the world yet. In comparison with our two example vehicles, according to the TCS calculation tool, the vehicle price of the VW ID.3 Pro Performance Life increased by 650 Swiss francs compared to that of the VW Golf 1.5 eTSI DSG Style at a mileage of 15 000 kilometres per year after 8557 kilometres will be amortized over the lower operating costs, i.e. within a good half a year. When considering both vehicles in a holistic way, the electric VW ID.3 compensated for the higher CO2 emissions from vehicle production via lower CO2 emissions during operation after a mileage of 38,783 kilometres. From this mileage, a VW ID.3 Pro Performance Life is more climate-friendly than a VW Golf 1.5 eTSI DSG style. However, this is based on the Swiss electricity mix, which has a high share of renewable energy. All these are arguments for switching to an electric car. In addition, the higher driving comfort of the silent electric car is not quantifiable, and it is also difficult to calculate its lower noise exposure compared to the petrol engine. And one last argument for the electrician: At present, the resale values for electric cars are significantly higher than those for petrol.
author: Herbie Schmidt

Wirtschaftsverbände stellen sich damit gegen die Allianz aus Erdölbranche, Strassenverbänden und Kaminfegern.', 'Am 13.', 'Juni stimmt das Schweizer Stimmvolk über das revidierte CO2-Gesetz ab.', 'Dazu kommt es, weil ein Wirtschaftskomitee – unterstützt vom Gewerbe- und Hauseigentümerverband und der SVP – das Referendum gegen die Vorlage zustande gebracht hat.', 'Ein grosser Teil der Wirtschaft setze sich jedoch für das CO2-Gesetz ein, teilte das Komitee «Schweizer Wirtschaft für das CO2-Gesetz» am Montag mit.', 'Darin vertreten sind etwa Swissbanking, der Schweizerische Versicherungsverband, Bauenschweiz, AEE Suisse und Suissetec sowie Unternehmen wie der Chemiekonzern BASF und der Rückversicherer Swiss Re.', 'Angeführt wird das Komitee vom Wirtschaftsdachverband Economiesuisse.', '«Gut schweizerischer Kompromiss» Die Klimakrise sei für die Schweiz eine grosse Herausforderung, schreibt das Wirtschaftskomitee.', 'Die Schweizer Wirtschaft sei sich dessen bewusst, wolle Verantwortung übernehmen und handeln.', 'Geschehe nichts, wüchsen die Kosten für Klimaschäden.', '«Ein Nein ist keine Option, bedeutet Stillstand und würde die Schweiz beim Klimaschutz weit zurückwerfen», heisst es.', 'Das revidierte CO2-Gesetz bietet laut den Befürwortern grosse Chancen für die Schweizer Wirtschaft, «die mit vielen klugen und wirksamen Lösungen zur Bewältigung der Klimakrise präsent ist».', 'Das neue Gesetz arbeite mit Anreizen, orientiere sich an Massnahmen mit Lenkungswirkung und sorge damit für Investitionen und Arbeitsplätze in der Schweiz.', 'Die Vorlage sei «ein gut schweizerischer Kompromiss», heisst es weiter.', 'Die Wirtschaftsvertreter begrüssen insbesondere, dass die Lenkungsabgaben mehrheitlich an die Bevölkerung zurückverteilt werden sollen.', 'Zudem erhielten Schweizer Unternehmen mit dem Klimafonds Sicherheiten, um klimafreundliche Technologien rascher auf den Markt zu bringen.']
processed_text: Voted on 13 March. June: Strong support to the economy for the CO2 Act Economiesuisse and around 200 companies and business associations oppose the alliance of oil industry, road associations and chimney sweeps. SDA Wide circles of the Swiss economy support the CO2 law adopted by Parliament. Economiesuisse and around 200 companies and business associations are thus opposed to the alliance from the oil industry, road associations and chimney sweeps. ==References== The Swiss voters voted on the revised CO2 Act on June 5. This is because an economic committee – supported by the trade and homeowners' association and the SVP – has brought about the referendum against the proposal. However, a large part of the economy is committed to the CO2 Act, the Committee on the Swiss Economy for the CO2 Act announced on Monday. This includes Swissbanking, the Swiss Insurance Association, Construction Switzerland, AEE Suisse and Suissetec, as well as companies such as the chemical group BASF and the reinsurer Swiss Re. The committee is led by the Economiesuisse Economic Association. "Good Swiss compromise" The climate crisis is a major challenge for Switzerland, writes the Economic Committee. The Swiss economy is aware of this, wants to take responsibility and act. If nothing happens, the cost of climate damage will increase. "A no is not an option, it means a standstill and would throw Switzerland far back in climate protection," it says. The revised CO2 law offers great opportunities for the Swiss economy, according to the supporters, "which is present with many wise and effective solutions to the climate crisis". The new law works with incentives, orients itself on measures with steering effect and thus provides for investments and jobs in Switzerland. The proposal was "a good Swiss compromise", it continues. In particular, the business representatives welcome the fact that the majority of the steering levies are to be redistributed back to the population. In addition, Swiss companies received collateral with the Climate Fund to bring climate-friendly technologies to the market more quickly.

gesteuert.', 'Ohne Versicherungsschutz kann auch heute noch kein Passagierjet starten, denn im Falle eines Absturzes könnte dies für eine Fluggesellschaft das Aus bedeuten.', 'Amerikanische Airlines Bieri / Keystone  Man will sich lieber nicht ausmalen, wie eine womöglich von der Eidgenossenschaft geführte Swiss die nächste grössere Krise, nämlich die Bankenkrise 2008/09, überstanden hätte.', 'Die Bankenkrise löste in mehreren Ländern eine Rezession aus, was wiederum der Luftfahrt zusetzte.', 'Die Einbindung der Swiss in die Lufthansa-Gruppe half sehr, und nach einem kurzzeitigen Taucher der globalen Luftfahrt ging es ab 2010 ziemlich steil aufwärts.', 'Weder 9/11 noch der Ausbruch einer Sars-Epidemie 2002 in Südchina und Hongkong, noch die Bankenkrise, noch das im Jahr 2012 zuerst in Saudiarabien aufgetauchte Mers-Virus richteten nachhaltigen Schaden an.', 'Das Vertrauen der Kunden war jedes Mal vergleichsweise rasch wieder zurückgekehrt.', 'Hoffnung auf die Sommermonate Wird das Vertrauen auch diesmal, nach dem Abklingen der Sars-CoV-2-Pandemie, zurückkehren?', 'Vieles hängt davon ab, ob in den nächsten Monaten weltweit die Impfaktionen ihre positiven Wirkungen entfalten werden.', 'Die Hoffnung wächst, dass ein digitaler Impfpass, der auf Initiative des Branchenverbands Iata, einzelner Airlines und von der Icao entwickelt worden ist, rasche Verbreitung finden wird.', 'Auch der Digital Green Pass der EU verspricht Fortschritte.', 'Eine enge Abstimmung mit der Weltgesundheitsorganisation (WHO) und den nationalen Gesundheitsbehörden ist wohl noch vonnöten.', 'Denn ohne deren Zutun für eine gegenseitige Anerkennung von Impfpässen bleiben den Fluggesellschaften vor allem bei Langstreckenflügen die Hände gebunden.', 'Mehrere Airlines haben bereits Testflüge durchgeführt, die zeigen sollen, dass geimpfte Passagiere, die mit den nötigen Reisedokumenten ausgestattet sind, in Konformität mit geltenden Corona-Auflagen wieder frei ein- und ausreisen können.', 'Oder wer etwa mit Delta von New York nach Malpensa/Mailand fliegt, soll dank drei negativen Tests – je ein PCR-Test und ein Schnell-Antigen-Test vor dem Abflug und ein nochmaliger Antigen-Test nach der Ankunft – um die Quarantäne herumkommen.', 'Das Prozedere mit den Corona-Tests tönt umständlich, zeigt aber auch die wachsende Bereitschaft von Fluggesellschaften und von ihren Kunden, viel Bürokratie auf sich zu nehmen, um endlich wieder fliegen zu können.', 'Singapore Airlines wird ab Anfang Mai den Iata Travel Pass systematisch verwenden; vor allem asiatische Airlines setzen auf dieses Reisedokument, um das Geschäft wieder in Gang zu bringen.', 'Viele Schäden sind noch nicht sichtbar Ausser Zweifel steht, dass viele Airlines das Jahr 2020 nur dank staatlichen Finanzhilfen überlebt haben.', 'Der Branchenverband Iata kommt auf die stolze Summe von 225\xa0Mrd.', '$, die aber in Bezug zu Einnahmenausfällen in der Grössenordnung von 400\xa0Mrd.', '$ und einem addierten Verlust von rund 125\xa0Mrd.', '$ zu sehen ist.', 'Gemäss Icao-Zahlen hatten die Airlines international Erlösausfälle von 250\xa0Mrd.', '$ zu beklagen, wogegen das Inlandgeschäft – vorab dank einer raschen Erholung in China und teilweise in Amerika – mit einem Minus von 120\xa0Mrd.', '$ besser über die Runden kam; China überflügelte im Pandemiejahr im Inland übrigens erstmals die USA mit 398 Mio.', 'gegenüber 358 Mio.', 'Fluggästen.', 'Die Flughäfen büssten in der Summe laut Icao-Berechnungen etwa 110\xa0Mrd.', '$ an Einnahmen ein.', 'Schwieriger greifbar ist, wie heftig die vielen Zulieferer der Fluggesellschaften von der Pandemie getroffen worden sind.', 'Und trotz allem gab es auch einige Lichtblicke: Die Luftfracht büsste volumenmässig im vergangenen Jahr lediglich 8% ein, wobei sich die Profitabilität wegen der Kapazitätsengpässe und der in Reaktion darauf stark anziehenden Frachtraten markant verbesserte.', 'Christoph Ruckstuhl / NZZ Am Flughafen Zürich werden nach dem Lockdown Flugzeuge stillgelegt, und die Rolltreppen sind auch ausser Betrieb.', 'Christoph Ruckstuhl / NZZ  Nun hoffen die Airline-Manager, in diesem Sommer noch stärker als 2020 Nutzen aus einer Belebung des Reisegeschäfts ziehen zu können.', 'Das dürfte, wenn es um den europäischen Markt geht, vorab Billigfluggesellschaften wie Easy Jet, Ryanair, Wizz Air oder auch der Lufthansa-Tochter Eurowings die Chance geben, wieder Kräfte zu tanken.', 'Es gibt aber jetzt schon Rückschläge und viel Verunsicherung, weil Feriendestinationen wie Mexiko oder Ägypten plötzlich wieder als Risikoländer bezeichnet werden und Rückkehrer in die Quarantäne müssen.', 'Ein grosses Fragezeichen setzen im Weiteren viele, wenn es um die mittel- bis langfristigen Perspektiven für Geschäftsreisen geht.', 'Die Konnektivität, vor allem die Anzahl von Direktverbindungen, hat durch die Pandemie schon grossen Schaden genommen.', 'Der Ende März zurückgetretene Iata-Generaldirektor Alexandre de Juniac bezeichnet es als Katastrophe, dass von 30\xa0000 City-Pairs, also den Direktflügen zwischen Grossstädten, deren 18\xa0000 verschwunden sind.', 'Damit ist die Luftfahrt auf ein Niveau zurückgeworfen worden, wie es 1998 erreicht worden war.', 'Eine Begleiterscheinung der Pandemie ist, dass die Konsolidierung in der Branche, die mit Ausnahme der USA noch stark fragmentiert ist, fast zum Stillstand gekommen ist.', 'Wird von einigen Firmenpleiten wie Avianca in Südamerika, Virgin Australia oder Compass Airlines in den USA oder von Norwegian Air in Europa abgesehen, ist auf den ersten Blick nicht viel passiert.', 'Zuvor erfolgreiche Fluggesellschaften wie Lufthansa, Singapore Airlines, International Airlines Group (British Airways und Iberia) oder Qatar Airways haben genug zu tun, um ihr eigenes Überleben zu sichern.', 'Und bevor zugekauft werden darf, müssen in der Regel die Corona-Staatskredite zurückbezahlt sein.', 'Das trifft auch auf Lufthansa und die Swiss zu, die nach einem schwachen Start ins neue Jahr ebenso wie viele Konkurrenten mit Verlusten zu kämpfen haben.', 'Die Umweltbilanz muss besser werden Zur ungemütlichen Ausgangslage gehört, sich wegen der Pandemie für mindestens zwei Jahre vor allem auf der Langstrecke auf tiefere Passagierzahlen einrichten zu müssen.', 'Das zwingt dazu, das über die Jahre gewachsene Streckennetz grundsätzlich zu hinterfragen.', 'Und immer stärker rückt ins Zentrum der Überlegungen, wie das Fliegen umweltverträglicher gestaltet werden kann.', 'Die von der Iata ausgerufenen Ziele, bis 2050 die CO2-Emissionen gegenüber 2005 um 50% zu senken und mit dem globalen Programm Corsia (Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation) vorwärtszumachen, wirken etwas unverbindlich.', 'CO2-Emissionen zu kompensieren, indem letztlich der Kunde einen Aufpreis bezahlt, ist nicht mehr als eine behelfsmässige Übergangslösung zur Verbesserung der Schadensbilanz.', 'Die kommerzielle Luftfahrt verursachte 2019 einen CO2-Ausstoss von ungefähr 920\xa0Mio.', 't, wobei Schadstoffe wie Stickoxid, Russpartikel, Feinstaub und Schwefeloxid um- und eingerechnet sind.', 'Das entsprach etwas mehr als 2,5% des globalen CO2-Ausstosses.', 'Auch mitten in Pandemiezeiten stehen die einzelnen Airlines daher unter dem Druck, mehr Geld in neue Flugzeuge und erneuerbare Kraftstoffe zu investieren.', 'Der Einsatz von Biokraftstoffen, die etwa aus gebrauchten Pflanzen- und Speiseölen gewonnen werden, ist schon vielfach erprobt und bietet zumindest als Beimischung zu Kerosin technisch keine Probleme.', 'Die im Vergleich mit fossilem Kerosin dreimal so teuren Kraftstoffe sind aber erst in sehr begrenztem Ausmass verfügbar.', 'Eine A321 der Lufthansa wird für einen Testflug mit Biokraftstoffen und Kerosin im Verhältnis 1:1 betankt.', 'Jörg Böthling / Imago  Auf jeden Fall müssen sich die Fluggesellschaften darauf einstellen, dass umweltpolitische Auflagen härter formuliert und CO2-Emissions-Abgaben teurer werden.', 'In Frankreich wird das Verbot von Kurzstreckenflügen ernsthaft erwogen.', 'Und die Schweiz steht mit ihrem geplanten CO2-Gesetz vor der Erhebung von Ticketabgaben zwischen 30 und maximal 120 Fr.', 'für Kurz- und Langstreckenflüge, wobei Zweifel bestehen, ob das eingenommene Geld vernünftig eingesetzt wird.', 'Nur rund die Hälfte der neuen Steuereinnahmen von jährlich mehreren hundert Millionen Franken soll direkt der Bevölkerung zurückerstattet werden; mit dem Rest wird ein Klimafonds dotiert, was Partikulärinteressen Tür und Tor öffnet, aber kaum technologische Durchbrüche aus helvetischen Forschungslabors garantiert.', 'Ein grosses Potenzial zur Verbesserung der Klimabilanz wird in der Herstellung von synthetischen Treibstoffen vermutet.', 'Flugzeugbauer und Hersteller von Triebwerken sind längst an der Arbeit, um im Zeitalter der Dekarbonisierung dafür neue Konzepte zu entwickeln.', 'Elektroantriebe, Brennstoffzellen und Wasserstofftechnologie sind drei Stichworte dazu.', 'Der Airbus-Konzern, der im Pandemiejahr lediglich 566 Flugzeuge (–35%) ausliefern konnte, steht auch in diesen Belangen im Wettbewerb mit Boeing.', 'Der Airbus-Konzernchef Guillaume Faury stellt in Aussicht, schon im Jahr 2027 mit einem mit Wasserstoff betriebenen Nurflügler Testflüge zu absolvieren; beim «Flugzeug der Zukunft» bilden Flügel und Rumpf einen kompakten aerodynamischen Körper.', 'Faury sagte hierzu unlängst an einem Anlass der Flugsicherungsbehörde Eurocontrol, grossvolumige Wasserstofftanks würden die Ingenieure dazu zwingen, das Flugzeug von Grund auf anders zu konzipieren.', 'Das lässt doch hoffen.', 'Die kommerzielle Luftfahrt wird sich früher oder später von der Pandemie erholen.', 'Die «Blended Wing»-Studie ist die optimale Variante für den Einbau von Wasserstofftanks.', 'Visualisierung Airbus  Warum sollte es den Aviatik-Ingenieuren nicht ebenso wie den Autobauern gelingen, umweltverträglichere Transportmittel zu bauen?', 'All die Wünsche, Träume oder auch Sachzwänge, welche die Menschen in die weite Welt haben hinausfliegen lassen, können sich ja nicht plötzlich in Luft aufgelöst haben.', 'Die grosse volkswirtschaftliche Bedeutung der Luftfahrt ist zudem unbestritten: Das hat nicht zuletzt die rechtzeitige Versorgung mit Medikamenten, Beatmungsgeräten und Hygieneprodukten sowie die Repatriierung von Mitbürgern nach dem Ausbruch der Pandemie gezeigt.']
processed_text: Decarbonization – the great challenge for aviation The pandemic is bringing global aviation the worst setback of all time. The pace of recovery depends on the effectiveness of vaccination operations. Just as important as safe flying in Corona times, however, is the transition to environmentally friendly offers. Werner Enz Swissair aircraft on the ground: The Airbus A321-111, HB-IOF "Winterthur", in the fog at Zurich Airport. For decades, Swissair has been observing that the increase in aviation's transport performance is keeping pace with economic growth, or even surpassing it. The wealth created made it possible for more and more people to discover the world while traveling or to visit relatives and friends in the distance. Businessmen jetted around the world to see on-site factories on the right or to visit customers. And with the drive of the innovation of aircraft construction, it has been possible over the years with great constancy to offer flights to broad populations at attractive prices. However, the outbreak of the Sars-CoV-2 pandemic has now led to such a sharp drop in traffic figures that doubts are raised as to whether the return to normality will still be possible. According to the statistics of the International Civil Aviation Organisation (Icao), passenger volume fell by 74% on international routes in 2020 and by 50% on domestic markets. Only 1.8 billion left. People got on a plane. ==References====External links==* Official website Passengers were counted, with 60% painfully out. How much longer does this pandemic keep people in fear and terror? How effective will the vaccines be? It's unusual times: Tokyo wants to play Olympic games this summer, but for health reasons it doesn't welcome foreigners in the country with a few exceptions. What the Swissair broke its neck A flashback to past crises and disasters that aviation also struggled with may provide guidance to assess the long-term impact of the pandemic. At the beginning of the nineties, the second Gulf War created an uncomfortable environment, which dampened the desire for travel during two or three years. The demand for the terrorist attacks on America on 11 November was much more severe. ==References====External links==* Official website Traffic volumes in the US market decreased by 12% in 2001, and in the fourth quarter there had even been a 20% drop in demand. An analogy to the Corona pandemic is that the government ordered a temporary closure of the aircraft fleets at that time and quickly came to the aid of the affected airlines. At that time, grants of 5 billion were granted. $ and twice as much in collateralized loans. The U.S. government had to take over as a guarantor overnight, after insurance companies had revoked their cover with explicit reference to a terrorist clause in the contracts. It is well known that two aircraft had been driven into the cockpit by storming terrorists into the twin towers of the World Trade Center and another aircraft into the Pentagon building. Without insurance cover, no passenger jet can still start today, because in the event of a crash, this could mean the exit for an airline. American airlines were even held harmless for higher insurance premiums after 9/11. The Swissair finally broke its neck in 9/11, because after the disaster in New York, the over-indebted airline was no longer able to secure the necessary money for its survival in time with the sale of subsidiaries such as Swissport or the Nuance's duty-free shops. The treacherously implemented Hunter strategy, which began with the purchase of Sabena in the mid-nineties and ended abruptly in January 2001 with the ejection of Philippe Bruggisser, had led to destruction. The grounding of the Swissair fleet was completed on 2 July 1899. October 2001 – the Swiss gathered for a rescue operation. Although the sinking of Swissair decided on a proud chapter in Helvetic aviation history, it was possible to sell Swiss following Swissair after a necessary re-dimension of Lufthansa in 2005. Alessandro della Valle / Keystone Walter Bieri / Keystone Thousands of Swissair employees protest with big marches in Bahnhofstrasse and on Balsberg in front of the airline's headquarters. The whistles are directed against the two major banks UBS and Credit Suisse. Alessandro della Valle / Keystone Walter Bieri / Keystone You don't want to imagine how a Swiss, perhaps led by the Swiss Confederation, would have survived the next major crisis, namely the 2008/09 banking crisis. The banking crisis triggered a recession in several countries, which in turn caused aviation. The integration of Swiss into the Lufthansa Group helped a lot, and after a short-term diver of global aviation, it went up quite steeply from 2010. Neither 9/11, nor the outbreak of a 2002 Sars epidemic in South China and Hong Kong, nor the banking crisis, nor the Mers virus, which first appeared in Saudi Arabia in 2012, caused sustained damage. The trust of the customers had returned comparatively quickly each time. Hope for the summer months Will confidence return this time again after the end of the Sars-CoV-2 pandemic? Much depends on whether vaccination operations will have their positive effects worldwide in the coming months. The hope is growing that a digital vaccination passport developed at the initiative of the Iata industry association, individual airlines and the Icao will be rapidly disseminated. The EU's Digital Green Pass also promises progress. Close coordination with the World Health Organization (WHO) and national health authorities is still needed. Without their intervention for mutual recognition of vaccination passports, airlines remain bound by their hands, especially in the case of long-haul flights. Several airlines have already carried out test flights to show that vaccinated passengers equipped with the necessary travel documents can return freely in compliance with current Corona regulations. Or if you fly from New York to Malpensa/Milan with Delta, you should get around the quarantine thanks to three negative tests – one PCR test each and one fast antigen test before departure and another antigen test after arrival. The procedure with the Corona tests sounds cumbersome, but also shows the growing willingness of airlines and their customers to take on a lot of bureaucracy in order to finally be able to fly again. Singapore Airlines will systematically use the Iata Travel Pass from the beginning of May; Asian airlines in particular are relying on this travel document to get the business back on track. Many damages are not yet visible There is no doubt that many airlines have survived 2020 only thanks to state financial aid. The Iata branch association is proud to receive the sum of 225 billion. In the United States and Japan, however, there were no more than 400 billion in revenue outflows. $ and an added loss of about 125 billion. $ is to be seen. According to the Icao figures, the airlines had an international revenue shortfall of 250 billion. $, whereas domestic business – ahead of it thanks to a rapid recovery in China and partly in America – with a decline of 120 billion. China was the first country to outstrip the US with 398 million dollars in the pandemic year. against 358 million Passengers. According to the Icao calculations, airports paid around 110 billion. $ in revenue. It is more difficult to see how violently the many suppliers of airlines have been hit by the pandemic. And despite all this, there were also some bright spots: air freight fell by only 8% in volume last year, with profitability improving significantly due to the capacity shortages and the strongly increasing freight rates in response to this. Christoph Ruckstuhl / NZZ Zurich Airport is closed after the lockdown aircraft, and the escalators are also out of service. Christoph Ruckstuhl / NZZ Now the airline managers hope to be able to take advantage of a revival of travel business even more than 2020 this summer. This is likely to give the chance to refuel the power of low-cost airlines such as Easy Jet, Ryanair, Wizz Air and Lufthansa's subsidiary Eurowings in advance when it comes to the European market. However, there are already setbacks and a lot of uncertainty, because holiday destinations like Mexico or Egypt are suddenly called risk countries again and returnees have to be quarantined. In addition, many put a big question mark when it comes to the medium to long-term perspectives for business travel. Connectivity, especially the number of direct connections, has already been seriously damaged by the pandemic. The Iata Director General Alexandre de Juniac resigned at the end of March, calling it a disaster that of 30,000 city pairs, i.e. the direct flights between major cities, the 18 000 of which have disappeared. This has led to a reduction in aviation to a level that had been achieved in 1998. One side effect of the pandemic is that consolidation in the industry, which is still highly fragmented with the exception of the US, has almost come to a halt. Except for some corporate bankruptcies such as Avianca in South America, Virgin Australia or Compass Airlines in the USA or Norwegian Air in Europe, not much has happened at first glance. Previously, successful airlines such as Lufthansa, Singapore Airlines, International Airlines Group (British Airways and Iberia) or Qatar Airways have enough to do to ensure their own survival. And before it can be bought, the Corona state loans must usually be repaid. This is also true of Lufthansa and Swiss, who have to face losses after a weak start to the new year, as well as many competitors. The environmental balance needs to be improved One of the most uncomfortable starting points is the need for lower passenger numbers due to the pandemic for at least two years, especially on long-haul routes. This forces us to question in principle the network that has grown over the years. And the focus is increasingly on how to make flying more environmentally friendly. The goals announced by the Iata to reduce CO2 emissions by 50% by 2050 compared to 2005 and to advance with the global Corsia (Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation) programme seem somewhat non-binding. To compensate for CO2 emissions by ultimately paying the customer an extra charge is no more than a temporary transitional solution to improve the damage balance. In 2019, commercial aviation generated a CO2 emission of approximately 920 million tonnes. t, including pollutants such as nitrogen oxide, soot particles, particulate matter and sulphur oxide. This represented slightly more than 2.5% of the global CO2 emissions. In the midst of pandemic times, the individual airlines are therefore under pressure to invest more money in new aircraft and renewable fuels. The use of biofuels, which are derived from used vegetable and edible oils, has been tried and tested many times and at least as an admixture to kerosene offers no technical problems. Compared to fossil kerosene, the three times as expensive fuels are only available in very limited quantities. A Lufthansa A321 is fuelled for a test flight with biofuels and kerosene in a 1:1 ratio. Jörg Böthling / Imago In any case, airlines have to prepare themselves for environmental policy requirements to be formulated harder and CO2 emissions dues to be more expensive. In France, the ban on short-haul flights is being seriously considered. And Switzerland, with its planned CO2 law, is facing the imposition of ticket charges between 30 and a maximum of 120 Fr. for short- and long-haul flights, doubting whether the money collected is being used properly. Only about half of the new tax revenues of several hundred million Swiss francs a year will be refunded directly to the population; the rest will be donated to a climate fund, which opens the door to particular interests, but hardly guarantees technological breakthroughs from Helvetic research laboratories. A great potential for improving the climate balance is assumed in the production of synthetic fuels. Aircraft manufacturers and manufacturers of engines have long been at work to develop new concepts for this in the age of decarbonisation. Electric drives, fuel cells and hydrogen technology are three keywords. The Airbus Group, which was able to deliver only 566 aircraft (–35%) in the pandemic year, is also in competition with Boeing in these areas. Airbus Group CEO Guillaume Faury is looking forward to completing test flights with a hydrogen-powered Nurflügler in 2027; in the "Flug of the Future", wings and fuselage form a compact aerodynamic body. Faury recently said on an occasion by the Eurocontrol Air Traffic Control Agency that large-volume hydrogen tanks would force engineers to design the aircraft from the ground up. I hope so. Commercial aviation will recover from the pandemic sooner or later. The "Blended Wing" study is the optimal variant for the installation of hydrogen tanks. Visualisation Airbus Why should the aviatics engineers not succeed in building more environmentally friendly means of transport, as should the car manufacturers? All the desires, dreams or even constraints that people have let fly out into the wide world cannot have suddenly vanished into thin air. The great economic importance of aviation is also undisputed: this has shown not least the timely supply of medicines, respirators and hygiene products as well as the repatriation of fellow citizens after the outbreak of the pandemic.

text: ['Wissenschaft mischt sich in politische Debatte ein CO2-Gesetz Nun mischt sich die Wissenschaft in den Abstimmungskampf ein.', 'Gestern haben mehr als hundert Forschende, darunter die bekanntesten Klimaforscher der Schweiz, öffentlich die Ja-Parole zur Vorlage abgegeben, über die das Volk am 13.', 'Juni befindet.', 'Im verschärften CO2-Gesetz sehen sie «einen wichtigen Schritt in die richtige Richtung», um das Klimaziel der Schweiz zu erreichen.', '«Wir haben das Feld zu lange den Lobbyisten überlassen», sagt Reto Knutti, Klimaforscher an der ETH Zürich.', 'Der Schritt aufs Feld der Politik ist umstritten.', 'Je politischer die Wissenschaft werde, desto verhandelbarer könnten ihre Positionen werden, sagt Politgeograf Michael Hermann.', 'Gespalten ist die Politik.', 'Applaus erhalten die Forschenden aus jenen Kreisen, die das Gesetz unterstützen.', 'Kritik gibt es dagegen von den Gegnern der Abstimmungsvorlage.', '(sth/lae) Seite 38']
processed_text: Science meddles in political debate a CO2 law Now science interferes in the voting struggle. Yesterday, more than a hundred researchers, including Switzerland's most well-known climate researchers, publicly submitted the Ja-parole for submission, about which the people on 13 July were invited to participate. ==References== In the intensified CO2 law, they see "an important step in the right direction" to achieve Switzerland's climate goal. "We left the field to lobbyists for too long," says Reto Knutti, climate researcher at ETH Zurich. The move towards politics is controversial. The more political science becomes, the more negotiable its positions could become, says political geographer Michael Hermann. Politics is divided. The researchers from those circles who support the law receive applause. There are criticisms of the opponents of the vote. (sth/lae) page 38

genau gleich viel Geld zurückerstattet – umweltschonendes Verhalten wird damit finanziell belohnt.', 'Eine unlängst publizierte Studie von Swisscleantech zeigt: Das Gesetz trifft reiche Umweltsünder Ölheizung lebt und mit dem Auto weite Wege fahren muss.', 'Die Studie beziffert dies in einem Fallbeispiel auf jährlich 470 Franken im Jahr 2030, 380 Franken mehr als heute.', 'Das Fazit: Das Gesetz ist übers Ganze gesehen ziemlich fair.', 'Am härtesten trifft es reiche Haushalte, die ökologisch häufig auf grossem Fuss leben.', 'Allerdings sind die Folgen durchaus auch für Leute mit kleinerem 1990 noch 8 Tonnen Treibhausgase pro Kopf aus, heute sind es noch etwa 5,5 Tonnen.', 'Damit liegt der Wert unter dem globalen Durchschnitt, der bei 6 Tonnen liegt.', 'Er ist aber um eine Mehrfaches Hand.', 'Wie viele neue Arbeitsplätze geschaffen werden, darüber gibt es bis anhin aber noch keine zuverlässige Daten.', 'Die Direktorin des Schweizer Wirtschaftsverbandes Economiesuisse, Monika Rühl, processed_text: Fact check on the SRF "Arena": Is the CO? law a cost driver? According to the advocates, the law strengthens climate protection and creates jobs. Opponents warn against high costs for the population and prohibitions. We've checked statements on the vote. Stefan Häne,Martin Läubli,Yannick Wiget "Eight billion Swiss francs flow abroad for oil and natural gas alone": Environment Minister Simonetta Sommaruga assumes that some of these foreign investments would flow into Switzerland with the new CO? law. ==References== The people vote on the revised CO2 Act, which aims to halve Switzerland's greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 compared to 1990. An alliance of the oil and automotive industries – supported by the SVP, the Home Owners' Association and Gastrosuisse – has successfully taken the referendum against the proposal. Opponents argue that the cost of heating, mobility and flying are increasing, weakening the Swiss economy. It also burdened families, car commuters, the rural and mountain population and the trade. The supporters – the Federal Council, all political groups except the SVP, the cantons, the municipal and municipal associations, environmental organisations, the mobility associations TCS and VCS, Economiesuisse and other business associations – contradict this. According to them, the law strengthens climate protection, reduces dependence on foreign oil companies and creates jobs domestically. The liberal framework would leave companies room for manoeuvre and freedom of choice. In the SRF "Arena" the supporters discussed among other things: The initiative was opposed, among other things: "The CO2 law changes zero in climate change."The check: The share of small Switzerland in the global emissions of greenhouse gases is indeed small, and accordingly the influence on global climate change is small. However, this view has been obsolete since the conclusion of the Paris Climate Treaty: Switzerland has ratified the agreement. And there, under Article 3, "all parties" – no matter how big the outburst – are required to "take ambitious efforts" which must be increased over time. Industrialized countries are ahead of developing countries. The conclusion: Although the effect of the CO2 law on global climate change is physically not zero, it is certainly marginal. Nevertheless, Switzerland must assume its responsibilities together with all other States parties, in accordance with the Paris climate agreements. From 2050, all nations must be climate neutral, so according to climate research, climate targets can only be achieved. "We have no prohibitions in this law." The check: The new CO2 law does not contain explicit prohibitions. However, it attracts the screw in the building area in such a way that it becomes increasingly difficult from 2023 to replace a fossil heating with a new oil or gas heating. Although existing buildings may continue to be heated with oil or natural gas. However, if the heating is replaced during a renovation, a new upper limit applies for the CO2 emission: 20 kilograms CO2 per square meter heated area. This maximum value will then be reduced by five kilograms every five years. In 2028 it was still 15 kilograms, in 2033 it was 10, in 2038 it was 5. In 2043, the limit is 0 kilograms. However, according to the Federal Office for Energy, the owners of most of the buildings concerned can reach the limit values of 20 or 15 kilograms by 2032 at least with solutions that combine a heat pump with a fossil heating system. In this way, even quite inefficient buildings can continue to rely at least on a partially fossil solution. The conclusion: Müller's statement is correct in the sense of the word, but with the building area it hides an element in the new law, which amounts to a ban on fossil heaters when replaced. "We now have to compensate 90 percent of CO2 emissions." The check: Fuel importers already have to compensate for some of the CO2 emissions from transport with climate protection projects. This is 12 percent. This compensation rate increases with the new law – to a maximum of 90 percent. However, the increase is not in one step, but successively. The Federal Council determines the individual stages. The decree on the law, which until 15 December, was still in force. The plan shows in detail: for the years 2022 to 2024 the compensation rate is on average 20 percent, after which it rises to 60 percent (2025 to 2027) and 70 percent (2028-2029). In 2030, it will be 75 percent. It is unclear when and whether it will reach the maximum rate of 90 percent at all. It depends on whether Switzerland achieves its CO2 reduction targets. If it proves that she won't make it, the Federal Council will adjust the compensation rates. The conclusion: Bamert's statement is sharpened. The new law does not immediately require fuel importers to compensate 90 percent of their emissions, nor is it certain that they will ever have to do so. "The cost per year is 720 million Swiss francs." The check: Bamert means the additional costs incurred in the fuel sector. How does he get that number? It estimates the annual fuel consumption in Switzerland to about 6 billion litres, which is roughly true. This value is multiplied by the 12 raps per litre, which fuel importers can increase because of the compensation of their CO2 emissions. These 12 raps per litre, however, constitute only a legal upper limit: More than this amount, importers at the pump must not hit on it – and this only from 2025; until then, there are new 10 raps. Today, the maximum possible surcharge is 5 rappen per litre. However, importers do not take advantage of this margin, in fact it has been only about 1.5 centimetres up to now. The conclusion: that petrol and diesel will be introduced with the new law is considered as safe, especially since the importers will have to make at least 15 percent of the CO2 compensation in Germany from 2024 and at least 20 percent of the CO2 compensation in 2025 – i.e. where it is usually more expensive to save CO2. However, it is still unclear how high the impact will be. This depends, among other things, on how the cost of compensation for CO2 will develop and whether importers will pass the surcharge completely, only partially or not at all on drivers. "The CO2 law is social, fair and family-friendly." Check: Sommaruga expects an additional 100 francs per year and family. It takes average values, for example, for mobility consumption and living space. The opponents argue that there is hardly a family that is exactly the average. Therefore, in their calculations, they come up with additional costs per family and year for amounts of CHF 1000 in some cases – but they do not say that there are also households that are moving forward in the end. Imark spoke of an average value of 600 francs in the show. The fact is that some of the CO and air ticket taxes are distributed back to the population. Thus, regardless of income and lifestyle, everyone receives exactly the same amount of money back – this will reward environmentally friendly behaviour financially. A recent study by Swisscleantech shows that the law is the hardest hit by rich environmental offenders. However, families with low income and high consumption also have to expect appreciable additional costs, for example if they live decentralisedly in an ill-insulated old house with oil heating and have to drive far away by car. In a case study, the study estimates this to 470 Swiss francs per year in 2030, 380 Swiss francs more than today. The conclusion: The law is quite fair on the whole. The hardest hit is rich households, which often live on a large scale ecologically. However, the consequences are also noticeable for people with smaller incomes. It is therefore beautiful to call it social and fair. "The CO2 emissions per capita have decreased significantly." The check: In 1990, Swiss citizens still had 8 tonnes of greenhouse gases per capita, and today it is still about 5.5 tonnes. This means that the value is below the global average of 6 tonnes. However, it is several times higher than in developing countries. However, according to a tweet by ETH climate researcher Reto Knutti (also present in the Arena studio), Imark shows a completely misguided curve in which the scaling for the per capita output is not correct (wrong set indication) and the curve has been extrapolated simply by 2030, i.e. is a pure assumption and suggests a strong decrease in the per capita output over the next ten years. On the other hand, spectators of the arena only see the curve, but not the information on the axes. They will be led astray by it. 1/ In @SRF #ARENA, @ChristianImark argues with a multiple false graph that Switzerland has massively reduced its per capita emissions and that a #CO2 law is unnecessary.Fact check: pic.twitter.com/FNsrdquwBf— Reto Knutti (@Knutti_ETH) May 15, 2021 For comparison of countries and responsibility for climate protection, per capita figures are useful. Nature, on the other hand, takes no account of this, since absolute values are required, as in the Paris climate agreement. Switzerland is less well placed here: domestic greenhouse gas emissions have fallen less than per capita since 1990, by 14 percent. Switzerland is thus missing the target of 20 percent by 2020. The conclusion: Although statistically correct, the statement is in fact correct, but irrelevant in the context of Switzerland's climate targets under the Paris Agreement. "Eight billion Swiss francs flow abroad for oil and natural gas alone." The check: This figure is undisputed. The Minister of the Environment wants to show that in Switzerland, dependency on foreign countries would fall and that many additional jobs would be created if part of this foreign investment were to flow into our country. It is obvious that the number of additional jobs will increase due to investments in non-fossil technologies in Switzerland. How many new jobs will be created, but up to now there is no reliable data on this. Monika Rühl, Director of the Swiss Economic Association Economiesuisse, says: "With innovations and efficient technologies, the Swiss economy can make a significant contribution to reducing greenhouse gases and thus solving the climate problem." However, more than industry, the local industry is likely to benefit. For example, through energy renovations of buildings, construction of district heating networks, expansion of photovoltaics or construction of charging stations for electric cars. But there are also losers, such as the fossil industry or distributors of fuel and fuel. However, this does not completely eliminate the dependence on foreign raw materials, such as the production of batteries for electric cars or possibly the import of synthetic fuels. It is also open how large the import of electricity will be after the exit from nuclear power and if the traffic is completely electrified as intended. The conclusion: The statement of the Minister for the Environment is correct, how great the dependence on raw materials from abroad will be in the post-fossil age, will be. "The best thing is that the climate fund itself is abolished: if no one needs fossil fuels, there is no money left in the fund." The check: The climate fund is a new money pot that arises with the CO2 law. It feeds on fossil fuels from a part of the CO2 levy. A maximum of one third of the revenue – a maximum of CHF 450 million per year – flows into the fund, with which the federal government intends to continue the building renovation programme and finance other climate protection measures, for example the construction of charging stations for electric cars in multi-family buildings. In addition, a maximum of half of the revenue from the planned air ticket tax. In total, the federal government expects revenues of about CHF 1 billion per year. The conclusion: Wismer-Felder's statement is imprecise. While it may be that one day in Switzerland fossil fuels are no longer needed and that air travel is also declining or alternative propulsion is standard for aircraft. Then the fund would actually empty. But that does not mean that no one needs fossil fuels anymore. Because from road traffic no money flows into the fund. The new CO2 law sets the lever elsewhere: It increases the CO2 charges for new cars, among other things.

processed_text: Swiss indulgence trading in climate protection? The new CO2 Act allows for the saving of emissions abroad – this is due to Christoph Eisenring's criticism It doesn't matter for the climate where greenhouse gases are saved in the world. Human-induced global warming is a global challenge. In order to get as much climate protection as possible for your money, you should reduce CO2 where it is best. A global emissions trading scheme or a world-wide rise in the price of greenhouse gas would provide the right incentives. But the world community is far from that. Nevertheless, we should not abandon the search for favourable measures to reduce emissions. This is particularly true for Switzerland, where saving CO2 is comparatively expensive. In the Paris Agreement, it committed itself to halving its greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 compared with 1990. ==References====External links== The Commission is proposing that a quarter of the promised savings be made abroad. This is sharply criticised by parts of the climate youth. On the one hand, Switzerland is not taking responsibility for global emissions. Only one tonne of CO2 saved domestically is therefore considered to be good. However, it should be crucial that decarbonisation is approached with the lowest possible cost. Secondly, foreign compensation programmes would not work, they say. Preventing double counting A certain scepticism about foreign programs is understandable for two reasons: First, projects in the past often fell ill because the state there claimed the reduction for itself and the buyer from an industrial country did the same. With bilateral agreements, Switzerland is now ensuring that this is not happening. The first agreements with Peru and Ghana were concluded, and a declaration of intent was reached with Senegal. It helps that in the Paris Agreement (almost) each country has announced its own reduction target and must be measured by it. Secondly, such compensation projects have often not brought any additional savings. Jürg Füssler from the consulting firm Infras has evaluated the experience. 85% of the projects showed only a small probability that they actually reduced CO2 in addition to what the country had planned anyway. Only 2% of the projects could be said with great certainty. Füssler says that the payment from a western country was often simply the icing on the cake for a project that had already been carried out. Many projects on wind or hydroelectric power plants, for example, had shown this design defect. Switzerland is therefore very strict in which projects from abroad can be counted at all. Firstly, there must be an agreement with the country concerned. Secondly, because of the high take-over effects, it must not be wind or solar power plants. Thirdly, forest projects are also excluded, as they are often difficult to monitor. Then certain environmental and social standards must be met. These guardrails do not make the work of the Foundation Climate Protection and CO2 Compensation (Klik) easy. It has the task of compensating Swiss oil companies for the emissions of some of the imported fossil fuels. Projects in Germany and new abroad serve this purpose. Mischa Classen, who is responsible for foreign business at Klik, explains that the projects should not only offer a favourable opportunity to reduce CO2. It is equally important that they improve the lives of people in partner countries. In the Peruvian Andes, for example, cooking ovens are to be distributed to thousands of households. Not only do they need about 40% less wood than conventional fireplaces, they also drain the smoke, which benefits health. Credit guarantees are also being discussed for companies that want to increase their energy efficiency and need bank loans. Another focus is the management of waste dumps, in which the strong greenhouse gas methane is produced. This is used for electricity generation. The certainty here is great that the greenhouse gas will be further reduced, as the countries have neither the technical nor the financial resources for such measures. By 2030, 30 to 35 million will be spent abroad. CO2 emissions. However, in order to be able to track enough projects in the next few years, Klik is dependent on the Federal Office for the Environment to establish bilateral agreements with various states. The environmental ambassador Franz Perrez is responsible for this. He is confident that he will have concluded agreements with five to ten countries by the end of 2022. Four people in the Federal Office are currently engaged in negotiations. He believes that the strict requirements for projects are necessary to bring about real reductions and to ensure the protection of the environment and human rights. Of course, high requirements on the projects do not make emission reductions cheaper. Estimates of between 30 and 35 Fr. per tonne of CO2 saved. In the free market, certificates cost a tenth of it, says Classen. However, compensation in Switzerland is still significantly more expensive with project costs of often 100 to 150 Fr. per tonne saved. How does Switzerland maintain the motivation of the partner countries to pursue ambitious climate goals when buying them CO2 savings? The respective countries themselves would have to implement the measures that they could achieve, says Perrez. The emission reductions that can be calculated for Switzerland would therefore focus on more demanding areas. A partner country will also not agree to a project that would have been implemented anyway, he explains. It should be possible to calculate the emissions that reduce Switzerland and prevent them from improving the Swiss balance sheet. In addition, the Klik Foundation is engaged in a project for a maximum of five to seven years. Thus, Switzerland can only count on CO2 reduction for a few years. The projects then go back to the country. If it continues, it will now improve its climate balance. International division of labour A study has estimated savings if all countries are expected to acquire certificates abroad to meet their Paris 2030 targets. If this were used consistently, costs could almost halve to 250 billion. $. For Perrez, Switzerland is primarily given time with its foreign projects. They were a good instrument for the next ten to twenty years. However, if, under the Paris Agreement, all countries had to gradually tighten their targets from 2030 onwards and go towards net zero, there would be less and less room for compensation. But this is for the time being future music. The CO2 Act certainly has questionable parts such as the Climate Fund, which is to distribute subsidies in Switzerland. And for fuels, inclusion in emissions trading would be obvious from an economic point of view. With the possibility to reduce CO2 and allow the reduction to be calculated abroad, one tries nevertheless to use the international division of labour also in climate protection. That is why the instrument deserves a chance.
