Real estate. In fact, the revised CO2 Act imposes a remedial obligation, but only in certain cases. Anyone who needs to replace his heating and wants to stay with an oil or gas heating is de facto obliged to renovate his property energetically. For a heating replacement, a new upper limit for CO2 emissions applies. This can only be achieved with a good energy standard for fossil heating. The alternative is to switch to non-fossil heating (heat pump, wood, district heating, biogas). Then even with the new CO2 law no renovation is necessary. There may be cases where insulation measures are mandatory for older buildings when a fossil heating is replaced because the heat pump does not have enough power. But according to experts, this is the absolute exception. In such cases, wood heating would probably be the better solution. "Requirements for tenants due to remediation obligations": As mentioned, there is a remediation obligation only in those cases where a fossil heating is replaced by an equivalent. But even in these cases, empty announcements are not a must. Energetic renovations of the building envelope can also be carried out in the inhabited state. This does not mean that there will be no empty announcements for renovation projects, because larger modifications in the inhabited state are usually associated with a higher effort and sometimes difficult to accomplish. But it's not forced terminations. "Massive increased demand for electricity": According to the HEV, the pressure to switch to non-fossile energy sources leads to a massive increased demand for electricity. That's right. The Federal Office of Energy expects a quadrupling of electricity consumption by 2050, taking into account electric vehicles and heat pumps. This could be detrimental, for example, from the perspective of security of supply in winter. In contrast, hidden electric heaters (they can no longer be installed today) are not heat pumps. In general, 20 to 30% of the heating power comes from electricity, the rest comes from the air or from the soil. In a poorly insulated property, the electrical content on cold winter days can be higher, but it is not likely to be more than 50% electricity. «Raubzug auf dem Wallemonnaie der Tenter»: The HEV quotes in its advertisements a study of the Federal Offices for Energy (BfE) and for Housing (BWO), according to which the rents for a 100 square meter apartment allegedly around 140 Fr. Price per month. Apart from the fact that there is no such number, it is important to bear in mind that the study dates back to 2015. As Marianne Zünd of the BfE points out, heating costs have changed in the meantime. For example, the CO2 levy at the time was 60 Fr. per tonne of CO2 (today it is 96 Fr. ), and would pump systems were sometimes more expensive than today. According to the BWO, it is also not correct to refer to the results of this study in connection with the CO2 law, because this does not take into account the influence of the CO2 levy. A recent study by Wüest Partner from 2000 leads to a more optimistic conclusion. Climate-friendly renovations and the exchange of heating systems, especially in older buildings, could reduce the total cost for tenants, the report says. Investments can be partially transferred to rent, but also reduce ancillary costs. According to Zünd, it is also important that tenants benefit from the redistribution of the CO2 levy. A family of four received 348 Fr. on the sickness insurance premium. With the new CO2 law, this family will receive a refund of 668 Fr. per year. «Immense additional costs for residential owners»: This redistribution to the population also applies, of course, to residential owners. The revised CO2 Act not only sets standards in the building sector, but also provides for financial support for the building owners. In total, the CO2 levy amounts to a maximum of 450 million. Fr. per year available for the building program. This is not intended to reduce the investment costs that are due when the heating is withdrawn or has to be renewed due to its age. With the CO2 law, these will be higher in the case of existing oil or gas heaters without. This can put some homeowners in financial trouble. However, according to the BfE, these higher investment costs are regularly amortised over the life of the heating system. If you're better at insulating your house, you'll need less energy and have lower energy costs. And if you switch to renewable heating systems, you don't have to pay a CO2 levy afterwards. Higher utilization possible In addition, and this often goes under in the discussion: In the case of replacement new buildings and comprehensive energetic building renovations, according to the revised CO2 law, there is the possibility to expand the living space. Cantons can allow a higher use of the property. Thus, the owner has more space available to use for himself or for renting his apartment. It is certain that the new CO2 law will directly affect many homeowners, and this will happen in the foreseeable future. According to the BfE, more than half of the residential buildings are still heated with oil or gas. Whenever the heating or burner needs to be renewed in these buildings, the owner is faced with the decision whether to switch to renewable energy or whether to renovate his building. This may not be a problem for financially strong institutional owners, but for a couple of pensioners. And maybe even for the tenants. This is less because of possible higher rents, because you save energy costs and the CO2 levy. However, major renovations often mean empty terminations, and a move often means higher rental costs.
author: Andrea Mart

text: ['CO2-Gesetz: Gut gemeint ist nicht gut gemacht Gastkommentar von Alain Schwald und Lukas Robers  Das Weltklima erwärmt sich, und darunter werden wir alle leiden.', 'Grund genug, effiziente und wirksame Gegenmassnahmen zu ergreifen.', 'Aber die weitgehend unumstrittene Feststellung, dass etwas getan werden muss, lässt noch lange keinen Schluss darauf zu, was konkret getan werden sollte.', 'Da der Klimawandel ein globales Problem ist, müssen alle mit anpacken; mit dem Abkommen von Paris wurde das versucht.', 'Es zeichnet sich aber ab, dass sich viele Länder früher oder später nicht mehr daran halten werden.', 'Wenn zwei von drei Menschen weltweit von weniger als 15 Dollar am Tag leben – das sind über 5 Milliarden Menschen –, dann ist ihre oberste Priorität verständlicherweise nicht das Weltklima in 50 Jahren.', 'Sie wollen ihr Lebensniveau anheben, was einem höheren Energieverbrauch gleichkommt.', 'Diese Energie werden sie aus den günstigsten Quellen nehmen.', 'Das wird zu mehr Treibhausgasemissionen führen, es sei denn, der Verzicht auf fossile Brennstoffe hat konkrete Vorteile.', 'Also müssen die Alternativen billiger werden.', 'Aber genau daran scheitert das CO2-Gesetz.', 'Es besteht aus einer Fülle von Vorschriften, Verboten, Abgaben und Steuern, die sich kein Land leisten wird, solange es dort Menschen in Armut gibt.', 'Für die Schweiz bedeutet das zweierlei: Erstens muss sie ihren Verpflichtungen nachkommen, und zwar so effizient wie möglich, so dass ähnlich reiche Länder sich die Schweiz zum Vorbild nehmen können.', 'Das wird durch einen CO2-Preis bzw.', 'CO2-Handel und nicht durch Vorschriften erreicht – da sind sich praktisch alle Volkswirtschafter einig.', 'Wichtig ist, dass die Einsparungen dort erfolgen, wo sie auch am wirtschaftlichsten sind.', 'Ein Markt schafft das deutlich besser als Politiker, die entscheiden, welche Technik ihnen am besten gefällt.', 'Mit dem Verkehrs- und Gebäudesektor sollte begonnen werden.', 'Mittelfristig müsste die Schweiz versuchen, sich dem europäischen Emissionshandel anzuschliessen, und darauf drängen, ihn auf alle Wirtschaftszweige auszudehnen.', 'Zweitens muss alles darangesetzt werden, die Alternativen so günstig und robust zu machen, dass sich der Einsatz von fossilen Brennstoffen nicht mehr lohnt.', 'Das bedingt weit grössere Investitionen in Forschung und Entwicklung.', 'Zwar ist ein gewisser Teil des Klimafonds dafür vorgesehen, aber der Ansatz ist verkehrt, weil Politiker und Beamte entscheiden, was gefördert werden soll.', 'Stattdessen hat die Schweiz Rahmenbedingungen und Anreize zu schaffen, welche private Akteure zu mehr Forschung und Entwicklung im Bereich klimaschonender Technologien anregen.', 'Um die Chancen auf einen Durchbruch zu erhöhen, muss zusätzlich der Budgetanteil für die Forschung zur Lösung des Klimaproblems angehoben werden.', 'Dieses Geld sollte direkt den Universitäten und Forschungsinstituten zur Verfügung gestellt werden.', 'Gelingen bessere Rahmenbedingungen für Forschung und Entwicklung nicht, werden alle Anstrengungen letztlich nutzlos sein.', 'Denn mit einem Anteil der weltweiten Emissionen von 0,1 Prozent kann die Schweiz einsparen, so viel sie will – ohne Nachahmer ist das vergebens.', 'Das vorgeschlagene CO2-Gesetz hingegen schafft weder ein effizientes System zur Bepreisung von Treibhausgasen, noch beinhaltet es genügend starke Innovationsanreize.', 'Zwar kann der CO2-Ausstoss durch das Gesetz ein wenig gesenkt werden, allerdings nur durch zu hohe Kosten und unter Ausblendung der internationalen Komponente.', 'Daher sollte das Gesetz grundlegend überarbeitet und verbessert werden.', 'Die Schweiz mit ihren Möglichkeiten hätte die Verantwortung, Lösungen zu entwickeln, die nicht nur das eigene Gewissen beruhigen, sondern die so gut sind, dass sie als Vorbild für andere Staaten dienen können.', 'Denn wenn es irgendwann zu heiss wird, macht es auch keinen Spass mehr, sich im eigenen Erfolg zu sonnen.', 'Alain Schwald und Lukas Robers sind Mitglieder des Liberalen Komitees für eine wirksame Umweltpolitik.']
processed_text: CO2 law: Well meant is not well done Guest commentary by Alain Schwald and Lukas Robers The global climate is warming up, and we will all suffer from it. There is reason enough to take effective and effective countermeasures. However, the largely undisputed finding that something needs to be done does not allow for a long time to come to an end on what should be done in concrete terms. Since climate change is a global problem, everyone must take part in the process; the Paris Agreement has tried to do so. However, it is becoming apparent that many countries will sooner or later not comply with it. If two out of three people worldwide live on less than $15 a day – that is over 5 billion people – their top priority is understandably not the global climate in 50 years. They want to raise their living standards, which is equivalent to higher energy consumption. They will take this energy from the most favourable sources. This will lead to more greenhouse gas emissions, unless the abandonment of fossil fuels has concrete advantages. So the alternatives must be cheaper. But that's exactly what the CO2 law fails. It consists of a plethora of regulations, prohibitions, taxes and taxes that no country will afford as long as there are people in poverty there. For Switzerland, this means two things: firstly, it must fulfil its obligations, as efficiently as possible, so that equally rich countries can take Switzerland as their model. This is due to a CO2 price or a CO2 price. CO2 trade and not achieved by regulation – virtually all national economies agree. It is important that the savings are made where they are also the most economical. A market does this much better than politicians who decide which technology they like best. The transport and building sector should be started. In the medium term, Switzerland would have to try to join the European emissions trading system and press for it to be extended to all sectors of the economy. Secondly, everything must be done to make the alternatives so cheap and robust that the use of fossil fuels is no longer worthwhile. This means far greater investment in research and development. While a certain part of the climate fund is earmarked for this, the approach is wrong because politicians and civil servants decide what to promote. Instead, Switzerland has to create framework conditions and incentives that encourage private actors to increase research and development in the field of climate-friendly technologies. In order to increase the chances of a breakthrough, the budget share for research to solve the climate problem must be increased. This money should be made available directly to universities and research institutes. If better framework conditions for research and development do not succeed, all efforts will ultimately be useless. With a share of global emissions of 0.1 percent, Switzerland can save as much as it wants – without imitators, this is in vain. The proposed CO2 Act, on the other hand, does not create an efficient system for the pricing of greenhouse gases, nor does it contain sufficient strong incentives for innovation. While the law can reduce CO2 emissions a little, it is only because of too high costs and the exclusion of the international component. Therefore, the law should be fundamentally revised and improved. Switzerland, with its possibilities, would have the responsibility to develop solutions that not only calm its own conscience, but which are so good that they can serve as a model for other states. Because when it gets too hot at some point, it is no longer fun to sunbathe in your own success. Alain Schwald and Lukas Robers are members of the Liberal Committee for Effective Environmental Policy.
author: Alain Schwald Lukas Robers

processed_text: Pilot gives his job for the climate From cockpit to climate protection Winterthurer Daniel Lüscher is only 53 and could fly even further. But now he has changed sides. What happened? Jigme Garne Lakes, on the outskirts of Winterthur: In a series of identical single-family houses, the Lüscher family house is easy to spot. It has more solar panels than all the others on the roof. In the open garage there is a pool table and three bicycles. "And my sledge," says Daniel Lüscher – he means his Davoser. He hasn't had a car in years. Daniel Lüscher saw as a pilot the damage caused by climate change; how the snow on the Montblanc became less and less and how the ice caps in the far north were fading. So he decided to do something about it, and he founded the citizens' initiative Myblueplanet. It has the message that everyone and everyone with their behaviour can contribute to climate protection. That was 15 years ago. «Everywhere Warning Lamps» Today, Myblueplanet is an established NGO with 15 employees and 150 volunteers engaged in educational programs and environmental campaigns in Winterthur and its surroundings. The impressively good story – pilot finds a green conscience – always depended on the flaw that the passionate professional pilot Lüscher continued to jettison around the world. Part-time climate defender, part-time flight captain of kerosene fliers: He used to say that his profession should not prevent him from doing something for the climate. Now Lüscher, at 53, has given up the pilot's job. He wants to devote himself entirely to climate protection. "Time is pressing," he explains the step. If Earth were a plane, it would have to stay on the ground, he says. Too dangerous. "Red and orange warning lights are flashing everywhere in the cockpit." In the next ten years, climate protection is to be the top priority in his life. After that, he plans his pension. "And if we haven't stopped climate change until then, it's too late," he is convinced. He thinks of irreversible tilting effects such as thawing permafrost soils that trigger uncontrolled processes in the ecosystem. One of the current Myblueplanet projects is the Climate Actions app, which is designed to playfully animate the climate-friendly lifestyle. In the coming weeks, Myblueplanet will apply to the Bündner Klimarally with various actions. Among the embassies is Alt-Bundesratin Doris Leuthard. Myblueplanet is also present in schools nationwide, for example with the project "Every cell counts", in which classes with crowdfunding campaigns bring solar systems to the Schuldach. When ex-pilot Lüscher talks about these projects and campaigns, he shines. He raves about the helpers, from the risk manager to the kindergarten teacher to the retired advertiser. Myblueplanet is as positive as its founder. The message: We save the world! Why the UBS is allowed to be there But what does the small-sized child do in a personal lifestyle when the important decisions in large numbers meet others? Unlike the climate youth, who demands decisive action from politics, Myblueplanet is in vain looking for political positions. "Politics must do its job, and we do ours," says Lüscher. There were enough people and organisations to be involved in politics. "We build solar plants on roofs and plant trees with the Pathi – that's what no one else does." The list of Myblueplanet's partners shows the difference between the climate youth and the climate youth. In addition to public offices such as the Federal Office for the Environment, Lottery Funds and Foundations, the private sector is also represented, for example with the large banks UBS and CS, to which climate activists blame a co-inflict on climate change. Lüscher says that he perceives a change of thinking at the financial centre, albeit not everywhere. "The big players will need to create the transition from the old to the new world, for example in the form of loans for renewable technologies." A persuasive person Personally, Lüscher first considers it indispensable that the CO2 Act was adopted on 13 May. It was adopted on 1 June. And flying must be more expensive, of course. He was glad that the world community had committed itself to the net zero target. The EU is doing a good job, Lüscher says, Joe Biden in the USA too. "And we in Switzerland are just as often not the fastest." He does not regret the fact that he himself took a long time to finish his pilot career. "That was just my way I had to do. I like our planet so much because I have met him so intensively as a pilot."After years of long-haul flights and business flying he worked as a cargo pilot. His last flight was from Leipzig to Rome at the end of 2020, and aboard was Covid's protective material. Lüscher invests the newly gained time in a Master's degree in Sustainable Business at the Business School in Lausanne. He wants to develop sustainable ideas with companies in the future and further develop the Climate Actions project for companies. This should also bring money, because the income from the small part of the population he has on Myblueplanet today will not be enough for a long time. Lüscher is a persuasive man. "Everything I've changed in my lifestyle has turned out to be a gain for me." Travelling on the train is more exciting than travelling on a plane or in a car. The climate-conscious diet is good for his health. And the car-free garage is now a kind of meeting place. During the Football-EM, the free entrance becomes a public viewing for friends and neighbors. Daniel Lüscher is the founder of the environmental protection organization Myblueplanet.
author: Daniel Lüscher

processed_text: "The claim that gasoline is increased by 12 cents is a gross misinformation of the opponents of the CO2 law" FDP Group President Beat Walti says that one can be liberal and still agree with the new CO2 law. He contradicts internal critics such as Christian Wasserfallen and Filippo Leutenegger. And he says what bothers him personally about the template. Christof Forster, Bern FDP Group President Beat Walti says: "You can't wash the fur without getting wet". Peter Klaunzer / KEYSTONE Mr. Walti, free-minded exponents such as the Zurich City Council and former National Councillor Filippo Leutenegger see the FDP leadership in the CO2 law on the wrong side. How can you, as a liberal, support the proposal? The revised law continues to implement widely proven instruments such as CO2 emissions on fuels. They are based, to the very greatest extent, on steering and not on prohibitions. Businesses and households can continue to free up their decisions on consumption and investment, but they have to bear the costs due to the causes. Leutenegger criticises the law leading to additional taxes. In the case of the charge on fuels, two thirds are reimbursed via the health insurance premiums. That's a decent quota. With the new air ticket tax, it's half. One must not forget something: there is also an indirect redistribution. Meaning? Everyone benefits from the funds that flow from the fund to reduce CO2 emissions. This brings Switzerland closer to the CO2 target. As a result, the steering instruments need to be less sharply designed. This indirect effect is very difficult to quantify. But it's like this: you can't wash the fur without getting wet. The levies will be felt by some. That's the idea of steering. It is crucial that one can influence or even avoid the consequences by one's own behavior. But there are people, for example in peripheral regions, who depend on the car. It is a gross misinformation of the opponents who claim that the gasoline is increased by 12 raps. This decision is not taken by policymakers, but by oil importers who do not want to increase their product unnecessarily. They will try to achieve their compensation target with 'favourable' measures, which they can finance with the lowest possible surcharges on fuels. Today, this impact is only 1.5 rappen. Maybe five raps. It is very unlikely that the surcharge will rise to 12 rappings with the new law. Another criticism of the law is that it brings about dirigistic interventions. What do you say? That's not true. You can keep driving or flying as much as you want. With the exception of the specifications for fossil heating systems, there are no additional dirigistic interventions in the law. According to polls, the FDP base is divided in the CO2 Act. Why? This has to do with the no campaign that carries false statements. It is also true that the proposal does not only correspond to our wish programme, but is a compromise that has been negotiated with difficulty. In the end, the question arises of how important the goal is to you. What's the most disturbing part of the law? Personally, I am most disturbed by the air ticket tax and its lack of links with innovation in aviation. I would have liked a fixed amount from the levy to have flowed into the development and production of new fuels. The new eco-course of the FDP was supported by a member survey. Now, according to surveys, half of the FDP base rejects the template. How do you explain that? It's not the same base. Our members are very determined, as the 2019 survey showed. The delegates' meeting and the cantonal parties supported the law with around 80 percent votes in favour. That's a great deal of support. In the voting polls, on the other hand, it is simply asked at the end which party you are close to. This has a certain blurry, because the electorate is less involved in the discussions than the members. ==References== June will show whether we have managed to communicate the liberal considerations to our voters.
author: Beat Walti Christian

Bodens.', 'Bei grösseren Neugestaltungen von Umgebungsbereichen muss das Regenwasser versickern können.', 'Das gilt auch für Parkplätze, die dank Verbundsteinen durchlässig gemacht werden können.', 'Neukom beruft sich hier auf die Pflicht gemäss eidgenössischem Natur- und Heimatschutzgesetz, die Versiegelung des Bodens einzudämmen.', 'Schliesslich umfasst die «klimaangepasste kühlere Luft von den Hügeln um Zürich und Winterthur bis ins Stadtinnere strömen kann.', 'Die Städte sollen nun zusätzliche Kompetenzen erhalten, um die Kaltluftströme in ihre Planung einzubeziehen.', 'Diese Bestimmung betrifft Grundeigentümer.', 'Neukom betonte aber am Montag vor den Medien, dass sie ebenfalls profitierten, wenn sich dadurch die Situation in einem ganzen Quartier verbessere.', 'Dass die Vorlage vor allem eine Lex Zürich und Winterthur sei, verneinte er.', 'Das Problem der Hitzestaus sei zwar in den Zentren am grössten, es stelle sich aber ebenso in der Agglomeration und processed_text: Plant more trees and secure the flow of cool air: With these measures, the Zurich government councillor Martin Neukom wants to prevent heat jams In hot summers, global warming can hit the mind and health. Now the communities should be given more opportunities to prevent this. Stefan Hotz So much green would be better: the garden city of the family home cooperative Zurich in Friesenberg. Christian Beutler / Keystone Climate protection has two sides: one is combating the causes of warming by reducing the emission of greenhouse gases. The CO2 Act, which will be voted on in June, or the Cantonal Energy Act, which the Cantonal Council adopted a month ago, serve this objective. Secondly, the aim is to mitigate the effects of climate change. This includes improved flood protection, for example, because the heavy rains are increasing. It is also noticeable and measurable that summers are getting hotter on average. This is especially noticeable by the inhabitants in the cities. In densely populated areas, the temperature is sometimes up to 10 degrees higher than in rural areas. Winterthur climate map: The inner city becomes a heat island. BD For several years there have been maps on which you can see where the heat is stifling and the air is not really cooled at night. Buildings and plants as well as sealed surfaces heat up during the day by the sunlight and release the stored heat at night. For older and sick people, such heat islands are a health burden. Reinforce tree protection The cantonal construction directorate has now prepared a template to counter this. What can be done against too much heat is known. However, some of the legal bases are missing to be able to act. Principles and targets for public investments are set out in Part-Revision 2020 of the indicative plan, which is already in progress. Now the construction director Martin Neukom (Green) sends adjustments to the planning and construction law as well as to various regulations into the consultation. According to Neukom, the aim of the revision is primarily to give the municipalities more opportunities. Accordingly, it contains several can formulations. The intention is to preserve large trees in the settlement area and to achieve that more trees are generally planted. According to Neukom, about one percent of the trees fall victim to construction projects in the settlement area of the city of Zurich every year. Although new trees are planted, they do not offset the loss for a long time. Big old trees don't just give a lot of shade. They evaporate hundreds of litres of water in a day, which removes heat from the environment. This is why the municipalities and cities should be given the opportunity to better protect the trees in already green quarters and to introduce a duty to plant trees in areas with too little green in new buildings. The corresponding regulations are to be anchored in the municipal building and zone regulations. However, too many buildings in the underground often prevent enough soil from being present so that larger trees can form roots. The municipalities should therefore be able to restrict the construction of land. There are two variants to the discussion: Either the eligible proportion of the land area that may be undercut, for example, is limited to 60 percent. Or an underground car park may be created only under one part of the green area. A planned provision can be used by landowners and builders directly for themselves. Today small trees must have a distance of four meters to the neighboring plot, large trees eight meters (see graph). This distance is to be reduced to two meters. The rule is to be lifted towards a street, as is already the practice in Zurich and Winterthur. Planned reduction of the current border distances from trees to neighboring plots (left) and roads. BD Martin Neukom is not afraid that this will lead to more conflicts. Branches that rise into another property are occasionally the subject of legal proceedings. Often, a neighborhood dispute that has other causes is only about building law, said the construction director. Moreover, the rule of separation in the Civil Code dates back to 1911. Furthermore, the municipalities should be able to adopt new regulations on the greening of roofs and building facades. This is also a contribution to the conservation of biodiversity. The canton thus implements a motion that the cantonal council overridden last summer. Rainwater should leak The only mandatory provision that the canton makes binding is the so-called desealing of the soil. With larger redesigns of surrounding areas the rainwater must be able to seep away. This also applies to parking spaces that can be made permeable thanks to composite stones. Neukom refers here to the obligation according to the Swiss law on natural and homeland protection to contain the sealing of the soil. Finally, the «climate-adapted settlement development», as the name of the template implies, also includes the securing of a good ventilation. Measurements and tests have shown how lock-like buildings sometimes prevent the cooler air from the hills around Zurich and Winterthur to the inner city at night. Cities are now to be given additional skills to integrate cold air flows into their planning. This provision concerns landowners. However, Neukom stressed on Monday before the media that they also benefited if this improved the situation in an entire neighborhood. He denied that the template was above all a Lex Zurich and Winterthur. The problem of heat congestion is the biggest in the centres, but it also occurs in the agglomeration and sometimes small cities.
author: Martin Neukom
