processed_text: Taboo break for climate vote on CO2 law Actually, science is not doing anything about politics. More than a hundred researchers now make an exception and stand up for a yes. Will scientists become activists? Stefan Häne and Martin Läubli It is rare that science interferes with political processes, even a voter's slogan. Actually, this is considered taboo in the circle of science. Now more than a hundred researchers, among them the most well-known climate researchers in Switzerland, have publicly submitted the "yes-parole" to the CO2 bill, which was published on 13 July. The vote will take place at the next voting time. This is an unusual procedure. For the scientists, the facts about man-made climate change have long been known. "The urgency of climate change justifies decisive action", they write in the communication. They see the broad-based tightened CO2 law as "an important step in the right direction" in order to achieve Switzerland's climate target – by 2050, virtually no more fossil fuels will be burned, i.e. climate neutral. The law sets the economy and the population a "clear framework within which the economy can develop the best solutions". Fact or opinion? Climate research is a burned child. Climate lieners and sceptics of climate research repeatedly denounced the World Climate Council (IPCC) that science is far too close to the political process of international climate policy. Indeed, there were conflicts of interest among individual researchers. However, renowned climate researchers such as Thomas Stocker always explained that the researchers never had to compromises that were scientifically untenable. In the meantime, only isolated voices can be heard, which maintain the accusation of dependence. Nevertheless, the current position of the scientists in the CO2 Act triggers different reactions. Science is not minded to interfere in a public debate, even in a voting struggle, says Michael Hermann of the Sotomo Research Institute. Another question, however, was whether this was useful and appropriate. For Hermann, the answer to this is "not so clear". It is important that the population is well aware of the facts in the climate issue. But the more political science becomes, the more negotiable its positions could become, says the political geographer. "There is a danger that scientific facts will suddenly be seen as opinions." This danger is all the greater if science appears too apodictic and signals that only it knows the truth. "In the present case, however, the tone seems to me to be good." Harsh criticism of the SVP The opinions in politics are dashed. "I am – as with the Covid-19 task force – against a muzzle for science," says SP Group leader Roger Nordmann. Other parliamentarians, who also approve of the CO2 Act, have similar views. These include those who have criticized the public relations work of the Covid-19 task force itself in the past, such as Damian Müller. "There is a crucial difference," says the FDP stand. For an advisory body such as the Taskforce, the principle of loyalty to the political decision-making level – the Federal Council – has a very different meaning than for private groups on a public question, as is now the case with the scientists and the vote on the CO2 law. Moreover, scientists are free to become public, who consider climate change to be different and who therefore consider the CO2 law to be wrong. Harsh criticism, however, comes from the opposing camp. SVP National Councillor Christian Imark calls the scientists "activists": "Under the guise of science, a socialist system should be established in Switzerland." That is what they are all about. The CO2 emissions in Switzerland are already sinking under today's legislation, Imark argues. "However, the scientists do not mention with any word that greenhouse gases can be reduced without redistributing billions and establishing new bans and a lot of bureaucracy," says Imark. That would make them untrustworthy. However, opponents of the vote have not yet explained what the alternatives to the CO2 law look like. In order to accelerate the reduction of greenhouse gases, there are much more meaningful measures, says Imark. Which are, the opponents of the law want to present in early May. The measures are effective Against such accusations Reto Knutti, ETH climate researcher, defends himself: "It is not about socialism at all, but about the future of our planet. Because we have proven that ownership and market alone are far from sufficient to solve social crises, there is a need for a certain framework conditions that everyone is adhering to." This was the case with waste, waste water, ozone hole, air pollution, phosphate, asbestos and pesticides, and it was the case with CO2. The academies of science have already shown various ways in which instruments such as steering levies and price surcharges, which are provided for in the CO2 Act, affect the behaviour of climate protection. The researchers refer in their communication to the fact that fossil fuels and fuels would be slightly more expensive, but a large part of the tax on fuel, for example, would be distributed back to the population. Those who behave climate friendly will therefore be rewarded. The young people's demands were always based on science: climate strike in Bern in May 2019. Photo: Dominique Meienberg Researchers' arguments for the CO2 Act * The world and thus Switzerland are not on course for the Paris climate targets. With today's global measures, we are heading for a warming of about 3 degrees to 2100. * Switzerland has only reduced its greenhouse gases by 14 percent from 1990 to 2019, but wants to halve emissions by 2030 under the Paris climate agreement. * A rejection of the CO2 law would most likely weaken Swiss climate policy over years. * Switzerland can only reliably export climate protection technologies to the world if it applies these technologies domestically. * Incentive mechanisms have achieved initial encouraging results in the building sector. It is now time to extend measures to include transport, particularly air transport. * The vast majority of leading economists believe that the benefits of ambitious climate protection are greater than the costs. (lae) lae / Läubli Martin «Have left the field for too long lobbyists» Mr Knutti, you once said that political demands would not be possible for you as a scientist. Now you have signed the Yes-Parole for the CO2 Act. Is that a turnaround? No, in principle, I am still of this opinion. But in this case, it is a matter where the scientific facts are clear and Switzerland has set the course. It has ratified the Paris Climate Agreement, which aims to reduce CO2 emissions to net zero by 2050. Industrial countries such as Switzerland must take the lead. But the Ja-Parole is a direct influence in a political process, which is considered taboo for science. The voting proposal is supported by the cantons, the associations up to most of the economy. Nevertheless, the outcome is not certain, the oil lobby and also the SVP have enough money to influence the mood against the template. The Ja-Parole is a hint that we must not let ourselves be misled by the interests of the car and oil lobby. We left the field to lobbyists for too long. Why did the climate researchers wait so long? For too long, we probably believed in a strict separation between science, society and politics. Germany is ahead of us. There is the "Scientific Advisory Board of the Federal Government for Global Environmental Change", which can directly advise the Federal Government on climate change issues and go to the public politically completely detached. It is currently effective in Switzerland to communicate directly with the media. I also try to provide fact-based information directly to certain people in Parliament. You take the risk of being an activist. That has nothing to do with it. I'm not losing my independence, I'm only providing scientific information. There is the example of the 2009 earthquake in Italy. They wanted to bring scientists to justice for manslaughter because they had not warned. If there is a risk that people will suffer or die, then it is our job to say that out loud. Martin Läubli
author: Stefan Häne Martin Läubli

text: [' Nur die tief hängenden Früchte geerntet  Architekt Niklaus Haller sieht auf dem Weg zu netto null noch teurere Massnahmen auf den Kanton Zürich zukommen   Reto Flury Von einem «Weckruf für den Klimaschutz» schrieb die NZZ.', 'Das SRF sendete einen «Tagesschau»-Beitrag und meldete, die Wissenschaft mache «mobil für die Energiewende», während der «Blick» vor allem Gefahr witterte: «Dem Klima zuliebe: ETH-Professoren wollen uns die Ölheizung verbieten».', 'Der Anlass für diese Überschriften in den Medien im August 2015 war ein politischer Vorstoss, der damals im Zürcher Rathaus vorgestellt wurde: die Einzelinitiative für eine Reduktion der Emissionen, kurz: Redem-Initiative.', 'Das Spezielle daran war, dass sie von über vierzig Wissenschafterinnen und Wissenschaftern der ETH Zürich und weiterer Universitäten unterstützt wurde und dass diese sich damit direkt in die Umweltpolitik des Kantons Zürich einmischten.', 'Ihr Ziel: Mittelfristig sollten keine neuen Öl- und Gasheizungen mehr eingebaut werden, damit die selbstgesteckten CO2-Ziele – damals noch 2 Tonnen pro Kopf im Jahr 2050 – erreicht werden können.', 'Die Initiative ging somit in eine ähnliche Richtung wie das Energiegesetz, dessen Beratung soeben abgeschlossen worden ist.', 'Einmischung der Wissenschaft?', 'Entstanden war der Redem-Vorstoss im Umfeld des ETH-Lehrstuhls für Gebäudetechnik von Hansjörg Leibundgut – einige Monate vor dem Pariser Klimaabkommen und lange vor den ersten Klimastreiks.', 'Man sei einfach unzufrieden gewesen mit dem Tempo, das bei der Umrüstung des Zürcher Gebäudeparks auf emissionsärmere Technologien angeschlagen worden sei, erinnert sich der Architekt und Erstunterzeichner Niklaus Haller, der kurz vor der Lancierung am Lehrstuhl seine Dissertation abgeschlossen hatte.', 'Ausgerechnet der Kanton Zürich, der einst mit seiner Luftreinhalteverordnung oder der Entwicklung des Minergie-Standards umweltpolitisch führend war, hinkte hinterher.', 'Noch wichtiger sei indes die Einsicht gewesen, dass das blosse Vorhandensein alternativer Technologien für eine Transformation nicht ausreichen würde, sondern dass es auch die richtigen Rahmenbedingungen brauche.', 'Zwar gibt es seit Jahren die Mustervorschriften der Kantone (Muken), die eine bessere Energieeffizienz der Gebäude bewirken sollen und auch unter Mitarbeit der Baudirektion wiederholt überarbeitet wurden.', 'Doch für Haller sind sie ungenügend.', 'Erstens hätten sie jahrzehntelang vorwiegend auf eine Reduktion des Energiebedarfs gesetzt und den Fokus damit primär auf die Sanierung der Gebäudehülle gerichtet.', 'Zweitens würden sie in einem langwierigen Prozess alle paar Jahre verschärft, wenn festgestellt werde, dass die Emissionsziele nicht erreicht würden.', 'Vor diesem Hintergrund entstand die Idee der Initiative: Die zulässigen Emissionswerte sollten schrittweise gesenkt werden, so dass Öl und Gas ab Mitte der 2030er Jahre als Energieträger faktisch ausgeschieden wären.', '«Wir wollten langfristige Rahmenbedingungen vorgeben, damit die Immobilienwirtschaft und die Industrie sich darauf einstellen können», sagt Haller.', 'Anders als vielleicht im Verkehr seien in der Gebäudetechnik in den nächsten Jahren keine bahnbrechenden Innovationen zu erwarten.', '«Die notwendigen Technologien sind vorhanden, was es braucht, ist die Umsetzung.»  Um dem Vorstoss mehr Gewicht zu verleihen, ging Haller in der Schweizer Science-Community auf Unterschriftensammlung.', 'Nicht jeder Angesprochene gab sein Plazet.', 'Manche Professoren hätten sich zurückgehalten mit der Begründung, es sei nicht Aufgabe der Wissenschaft, sich direkt in die Politik einzumischen, berichtet Haller.', 'Er war schon damals – vor der Klimadiskussion und der Pandemie – anderer Ansicht.', '«Wir wollten der Gesellschaft sagen: Wenn das die Ziele sind, die sie sich berechtigterweise steckt, sind diese Schritte notwendig, um sie zu erreichen.» So konnte er sich die Unterstützung von Wissenschaftern wie Thomas Stocker, Anton Gunzinger oder der Rektorin Sarah Springman sichern.', 'Nach einem ersten Rummel wurde es indes still um die Redem-Initiative.', 'Ein paar Monate nach der Lancierung hat der Kantonsrat sie mit den Stimmen von links-grünen Fraktionen vorläufig unterstützt.', 'Als es im Ringen um das Energiegesetz dann aber hart auf hart ging, war es vor allem die FDP, die sich für die Idee eines Absenkpfads, wie Haller ihn forderte, einsetzte.', 'Die Gründe waren, wie freisinnige Vertreter hervorhoben, die Kompatibilität mit dem nationalen CO2-Gesetz, das einen Pfad enthält, sowie die Technologieneutralität: Theoretisch hätte es die Initiative zugelassen, eine Ölheizung zu verwenden und das ausgestossene CO2 etwa mit Apparaten von Climeworks gleich wieder abzuscheiden.', 'Wertvolle Beweislastumkehr Doch der grüne Baudirektor Martin Neukom und die Klima-Allianz – die Kantonsratsfraktionen von der AL bis zu den Grünliberalen – favorisierten einen anderen Weg, der das Energiegesetz jetzt prägt: das Zuckerbrot-und-Peitsche-Modell, wie es Basel schon eingeführt hat.', 'In Zürich bedeutet dies: Der Staat unterstützt den Kauf und den Einbau von emissionsfreien Heizungen wie Wärmepumpen mit viel Geld.', 'Umgekehrt dürfen Hausbesitzer nur noch dann auf Öl oder Gas zurückgreifen, wenn sie darlegen können, dass eine umweltfreundliche Alternative technisch nicht möglich und über den gesamten Lebenszyklus mehr als fünf Prozent teurer wäre.', 'Diese Beweislastumkehr sei das eigentlich Wertvolle an dieser Lösung, findet Haller.', 'Sie zwinge die Immobilienbesitzer, sich mit den Kosten und Technologien auseinanderzusetzen.', 'Mangelndes Wissen sei der häufigste Grund, warum immer noch die Mehrheit von ihnen eine Öl- oder Gasheizung eins zu eins ersetze, sagt der Architekt, der heute Geschäftsführer der Firma BS2 ist, die von seinem Doktorvater Hansjörg Leibundgut gegründet worden war.', 'Idee aus Basel übernommen Ein weiterer Vorteil des Gesetzes sei seine Ähnlichkeit mit demjenigen in Basel, sagt Haller.', 'Das helfe seiner Branche.', '«Bauherren, Industrie und Planer wie ich sind daran interessiert, dass sie sich nicht in jeden Kanton neu eindenken müssen.» Auch dass die vorgeschriebenen Photovoltaikanlagen bei Neubauten nicht allein auf deren Dach gebaut werden müssen, sondern Nachbargebäude zu einem Verbund zusammengeschlossen werden können, wertet er als sinnvoll.', 'Die Regelungen zu den Gasheizungen, etwa der Kauf von Zertifikaten im Ausland, hält Haller indes für «verwässert».', 'Ursprünglich war eine viel höhere Hürde vorgesehen.', 'Nun dürfte es politisch immer schwieriger werden, aus dieser langfristigen Infrastruktur, die sich häufig in öffentlichem Besitz befindet, auszusteigen.', 'Insgesamt erkennt Haller im neuen Zürcher Energiegesetz einen ausgewogenen Kompromiss, der von politischem Pragmatismus geprägt sei.', 'Umgekehrt bedeutet es für ihn aber auch: «Wir holen uns nur ‹low-hanging fruit›.» Über die teureren Massnahmen auf dem Weg zu netto null müssten dann wieder einmal künftige Generationen entscheiden.', 'Der Kantonsrat hat das Energiegesetz am Montag in der Schlussabstimmung mit deutlichem Mehr angenommen, nachdem er Ende März noch Präzisierungen und Ergänzungen eingebaut hatte, die zwischen der FDP und der Klima-Allianz ausgehandelt worden waren.', 'Sein Verdikt über die Redem-Initiative hatte das Parlament bereits im Februar gefällt.', 'Sie wurde mit 143 zu 0 Stimmen bei 19 Enthaltungen abgelehnt.']
processed_text: Only the low-hanging fruits harvested architect Niklaus Haller sees on the way to net zero even more expensive measures coming to the canton of Zurich Reto Flury The NZZ wrote of a «recall for climate protection». The SRF sent a "Tagesschau" contribution and reported that science is making "mobile for the energy transition", while the "view" was particularly dangerous: "For the sake of the climate: ETH professors want to ban oil heating for us." The reason for these headlines in the media in August 2015 was a political advance, which was presented at the time at the Zurich City Hall: the individual initiative for a reduction of emissions, in short: Redem Initiative. The special thing about this was that it was supported by more than forty scientists from ETH Zurich and other universities and that they thereby directly interfered with the environmental policy of the canton of Zurich. Their goal: In the medium term, new oil and gas heating systems should no longer be installed so that the self-imposed CO2 targets – at that time still 2 tonnes per capita in 2050 – can be achieved. The initiative thus went in a similar direction to the Energy Act, whose consultation has just been completed. Involvement of science? The Redem advance was created in the context of the ETH Chair of Building Technology by Hansjörg Leibundgut – a few months before the Paris Agreement and long before the first climate strikes. One was simply dissatisfied with the pace that had been hit by the conversion of Zurich's building park to lower-emission technologies, remembers the architect and first-signator Niklaus Haller, who had completed his dissertation shortly before the launch of the chair. The canton of Zurich, which was once the leader in environmental policy with its air regulations or the development of the Minergie standard, lagged behind. More importantly, however, it had been understood that the mere existence of alternative technologies would not be sufficient for transformation, but that it also needed the right framework conditions. Although for years there have been the model regulations of the cantons (Muken), which are intended to improve the energy efficiency of the buildings and have also been revised repeatedly with the cooperation of the construction directorate. But they are insufficient for Haller. First, for decades, they would have focused primarily on reducing energy demand and thus focusing primarily on the renovation of the building envelope. Secondly, they would be tightened up every few years in a lengthy process if it was found that the emission targets would not be met. Against this background, the idea of the initiative arose: the permissible emission levels should be gradually reduced, so that oil and gas would have effectively been eliminated as energy sources from the mid- 2030s. "We wanted to set long-term framework conditions so that the real estate industry and industry can adapt to this," says Haller. Unlike perhaps in transport, no groundbreaking innovations can be expected in building technology in the coming years. "The necessary technologies are available, what it needs is the implementation." In order to give the push more weight, Haller went to the Swiss science community on a signature collection. Not every one of them gave his place. Haller reports that some professors have held back on the grounds that it is not the responsibility of science to interfere directly with politics. Even then, before the climate discussion and the pandemic, he was of a different opinion. "We wanted to tell society that if these are the goals that it rightly sets itself, these steps are necessary to achieve them." Thus, he was able to secure the support of scientists such as Thomas Stocker, Anton Gunzinger and the Rector Sarah Springman. After a first blush, however, it became silent about the Redem initiative. A few months after the launch, the cantonal council has provisionally supported them with the votes of left-green factions. But when the struggle for the energy law was hard on the ground, it was above all the FDP who was working for the idea of an absink path, as Haller demanded. The reasons were, as free-minded representatives pointed out, the compatibility with the national CO2 law, which contains a path, as well as the technology neutrality: Theoretically, the initiative would have allowed to use an oil heating system and to immediately separate the emitted CO2 with climeworks apparatuses, for example. Valuable reversal of the burden of proof But the green construction director Martin Neukom and the climate alliance – the cantonal councils from the AL to the green liberals – favored another way that is now shaping the energy law: the carrot and whip model, as Basel has already introduced. In Zurich, this means that the state supports the purchase and installation of emission-free heaters such as heat pumps with a lot of money. Conversely, homeowners can only rely on oil or gas if they can demonstrate that an environmentally friendly alternative is technically impossible and more than five percent more expensive over the entire life cycle. This reversal of the burden of proof is actually the most valuable thing about this solution, Haller finds. They force real estate owners to deal with costs and technologies. Lack of knowledge is the most common reason why the majority of them still replace oil or gas heating one to one, says the architect, who is now the managing director of the company BS2, which was founded by his doctoral father Hansjörg Leibundgut. Idea taken from Basel Another advantage of the law is its resemblance to that in Basel, says Haller. That helps his business. "Building contractors, industry and planners like me are interested in the fact that they do not have to rethink each canton." He also considers that the required photovoltaic systems for new buildings do not have to be built on their roof alone, but that neighbouring buildings can be combined into one network. However, Haller considers the regulations on gas heaters, such as the purchase of certificates abroad, to be "diluted". Originally, a much higher hurdle was planned. Now it is likely to become increasingly difficult politically to get out of this long-term infrastructure, which is often in public ownership. In the new Zurich Energy Law Haller recognizes a balanced compromise, which is characterized by political pragmatism. On the other hand, it also means for him: "We only get 'low-hanging fruit'." The more expensive measures on the way to net zero would then have to decide once again for future generations. The Cantonal Council adopted the Energy Act on Monday in the final vote with a clear increase, after it had added further clarifications and additions to be negotiated between the FDP and the Climate Alliance at the end of March. Parliament had already approved its ruling on the Redem initiative in February. It was rejected by 143 votes to 0, with 19 abstentions.
author: Niklaus Haller Reto Flury

text: [' Das neue CO2-Gesetz bringt eine Umverteilungsmaschine für 2,5 Milliarden Franken pro Jahr  Der am Mittwoch präsentierte Verordnungsentwurf des Bundesrats zum CO2-Gesetz bringt einen Fahrplan für Erhöhungen der Abgaben.', '2024 könnte die CO2-Abgabe von 96 Franken auf 140 Franken pro Tonne steigen.', 'Hansueli Schöchli  Die Emissionen von Treibhausgasen in der Schweiz waren 2019 rund 14 Prozent tiefer als 1990.', 'Damit verpasst die Schweiz laut Bundeseinschätzung wohl das Etappenziel für 2020 (minus 20 Prozent).', 'Im Jahr 2030 soll der Ausstoss von Treibhausgasen höchstens noch halb so hoch sein wie 1990.', 'Der Rückstand auf die Marschtabelle liefert Rückenwind für die Befürworter der Revision des CO2-Gesetzes, die im Juni vor das Volk kommt.', 'Die Vorlage enthält drei Hauptelemente: zusätzliche Umweltabgaben, verschärfte Vorschriften für Gebäude und Fahrzeuge sowie einen Ausbau der Subventionen via «Klimafonds».', 'Fahrplan für Lenkungsabgabe Das vom Parlament beschlossene Gesetz liefert die Eckwerte, lässt aber im Konkreten manches offen.', 'Der Bundesrat hat am Mittwoch den Entwurf seiner Umsetzungsverordnung in die Vernehmlassung geschickt.', 'Diese liefert nähere Angaben zu einer ständigen Grundfrage der Politik: Wer bezahlt wie viel, und wer bekommt wie viel?', 'Laut bisherigem CO2-Gesetz darf die CO2-Abgabe auf fossilen Brennstoffen (vor allem Heizöl, Erdgas und Kohle) höchstens 120 Franken pro Tonne CO2 betragen.', 'Bei der derzeitigen Abgabe von 96 Franken ist dieses Maximum nicht ausgeschöpft.', 'Doch weil bald mit deutlich höheren Abgaben zum Anpeilen der Klimaziele zu rechnen ist, enthält die Gesetzesrevision eine Erhöhung des Maximums auf 210 Franken pro Tonne.', 'Der Bundesrat kündigt nun in seinem Verordnungsentwurf konkrete Erhöhungen der CO2-Abgabe je nach Entwicklung der Brennstoffemissionen an.', 'So soll auf Anfang 2024 die CO2-Abgabe auf 140 oder 145 Franken steigen, falls die Emissionen aus Brennstoffen 2022 mehr als 60 Prozent der Emissionen von 1990 betragen.', 'Zum Vergleich: 2019 betrugen die Emissionen der Brennstoffe in der Schweiz rund 70 Prozent von 1990.', 'Eine deutliche Erhöhung der Abgabe auf 2024 ist somit aus heutiger Sicht gut möglich.', 'Der Verordnungsentwurf enthält weitere Erhöhungsetappen auf Anfang 2026, 2028 und 2030.', 'So soll die CO2-Abgabe 2030 auf das neue Maximum von In 2024, CO2 emissions could rise from 96 francs to 140 francs per tonne. Hansueli Schöchli In 2019, greenhouse gas emissions in Switzerland were around 14 percent lower than in 1990. According to the Federal authorities, Switzerland is thus likely to miss the stage target for 2020 (minus 20 percent). In 2030, greenhouse gas emissions are expected to be at most half as high as in 1990. The backwardness of the march table provides a tailwind for the supporters of the revision of the CO2 law, which comes before the people in June. The proposal contains three main elements: additional environmental taxes, stricter regulations for buildings and vehicles, and an extension of subsidies via the "Climate Fund". Roadmap for steering levy The law adopted by Parliament provides the basic values, but leaves many things open in concrete terms. On Wednesday the Federal Council sent the draft implementing regulation to the consultation. This provides more detailed information on a permanent policy issue: who pays how much, and who gets how much? According to the current CO2 law, CO2 emissions on fossil fuels (especially fuel oil, natural gas and coal) may not exceed CHF 120 per tonne of CO2. At the current levy of 96 francs, this maximum is not exhausted. However, because significantly higher taxes on the targeting of climate targets are expected soon, the legislative revision includes an increase in the maximum to 210 francs per tonne. In its draft regulation, the Federal Council now announces concrete increases in CO2 emissions depending on the development of fuel emissions. At the beginning of 2024, CO2 emissions are expected to rise to 140 or 145 Swiss francs if fuel emissions in 2022 exceed 60 percent of 1990 emissions. By comparison, in 2019, emissions of fuels in Switzerland amounted to around 70 percent of 1990. A significant increase in the levy to 2024 is therefore possible from today's point of view. The draft regulation contains further increases to the beginning of 2026, 2028 and 2030. For example, the 2030 CO2 levy is expected to rise to the new maximum of 210 Swiss francs, if the emissions from fuels are more than 42 percent of the 1990 level two years earlier. The law also provides for a new flight billet for flights from Switzerland from 30 to 120 francs per flight. The draft regulation also says more precisely about this. For short-haul flights (large: flights to Western and Central Europe) the cheapest booking class is a charge of CHF 30 per flight, in the more expensive booking classes it is CHF 60. For medium-haul flights (big: Eastern Europe, Middle East and North Africa), the charge is 60 or more. 90 francs. It is the most common of the two. 120 francs. In addition, the draft regulation clarifies the planned levy on flights departing from Switzerland from commercial and private jets. Depending on the weight of the aircraft and travel distance, this tax amounts to CHF 500 to CHF 3000 per flight. Honeypot not yet distributed The distribution of funds from environmental levies is also of great interest to those concerned. The CO2 levy at present level and the new aviation charges are estimated to total around 2.5 billion Swiss francs per year for air traffic without a pandemic brake. Of this, about 1.2 billion could flow back to the population via deduction from the health insurance bill – about 140 francs per capita. Some 350 to 400 million Swiss francs are expected to flow back to the companies via AHV compensation funds – probably in the order of 60 to 100 Swiss francs per 100 000 Swiss francs. The Federal Council mixes climate policy with social policy. According to the draft regulation, only wage components up to the maximum insurable amount are to apply to the determining wage sum in accordance with the accident insurance law; this year this maximum is 148 200 Swiss francs annual wage. With this limitation, the Federal Council wants to achieve a hidden redistribution of high-wage industries into low-wage industries. The feast for lobbyists is increasing, especially in the case of those parts of environmental taxes that are not directly distributed back to the population and businesses. This remaining item is happy and, according to the federal estimate, is expected to make up about 1 billion Swiss francs per year without pandemic brake. The law mentions various uses for this money. This includes the already ongoing programme for energy-efficient building renovations plus further measures regarding buildings (maximum CHF 450 million). In addition, the law generally allows subsidies for activities that contribute to the achievement of climate targets. The draft regulation makes some clarifications, but leaves much to be done to distribute subsidy funds among the various activities. In a transitional phase until 2024, the Federal Council will set annual cost roofs for perhaps five to ten subgroups – for example for innovation projects in Germany, projects abroad, emission reductions in air transport and loan guarantees for technology promotion. These figures then flow into the federal budget for the following year. The Federal Council is expected to decide the cost roofs for the first year around the beginning of June.

bin schon lange der Meinung, dass wir die Produktion von Strom aus erneuerbaren Energien in der Schweiz massiv ausbauen müssen, um die Versorgungssicherheit zu stärken.', 'Noch vor dem Sommer bringe ich deshalb eine Vorlage ins Parlament, die genau das bezweckt.', 'Darin sind auch Massnahmen vorgesehen, welche die Versorgungssicherheit im Winter stärken.', 'Brauchen wir zusätzlich ein das Rahmenabkommen unterschreiben, damit wir uns mit einem Stromvertrag besser in den europäischen Markt integrieren können?', 'Die Frage des Rahmenabkommens wird im Bundesrat derzeit diskutiert.', liefert auch im Winter zuverlässig Strom.', 'Sollte sich trotzdem eine Versorgungslücke abzeichnen, könnten Gaskraftwerke ein Thema werden.', 'Sie müssten dann aber klimaneutral sein, und das würde teuer.', 'Fossile Energien sind eben teuer.', 'Deshalb erwarte ich von Energieproduzenten, dass sie jetzt wirklich auf erneuerbare Energien aus dem Inland setzen.', 'Ist das realistisch?', 'Wenn wir schon nur auf allen geeigneten Dächern in der Schweiz Solarpanels installieren, können wir doppelt so viel Strom produzieren wie alle Atomkraftwerke zusammen.', 'Dieses Potenzial zu nutzen, steht für Schweiz auch ein Klima-Corona-Programm?', 'Ich finde nicht, dass wir jetzt einfach mehr Geld aus der Bundeskasse nehmen sollten.', 'Wir brauchen vielmehr die richtigen Rahmenbedingungen.', 'Die Wirtschaft will von sich aus vorwärtsmachen, braucht dafür aber Sicherheiten.', 'Diese können wir mit dem CO2-Gesetz liefern.', 'Zudem stellt der Klimafonds die nötigen Mittel bereit, um Klimaschutzmassnahmen zu finanzieren.', 'Heisst das, dem Bund fehlt aufgrund der Corona-Krise ohnehin das Geld, um kräftig in den Klimaschutz zu investieren?', 'Nein, das Geld ist nicht das Problem.', 'Das CO2-Gesetz ist bereits unser Klimaprogramm, mit dem wir gleichzeitig den Standort Schweiz stärken können.', 'Mit dem Gesetz gibt es Aufträge für unsere KMU.', 'So sichern wir Arbeitsplätze in der processed_text: Interview with Simonetta Sommaruga : «If we reject the law, the oil industry has won» The Environment Minister also sees the Climate Act as an economic stimulus and calls on the climate youth not to play into the hands of the opponent Denis von Burg, Adrian Schmid Simonetta Sommaruga fights on all fronts for the CO? law. With the vote on the CO2 levy, climate policy is once again coming to the fore. Minister for the Environment and Energy Simonetta Sommaruga is required. For them, the template is the A and O of climate policy, and it quickly gets between all fronts. For the SVP and parts of the economy the law goes far too far, for the climate youth it is far too tame. We confront the Federal Council with the best arguments from both camps. Germany is now aiming to become climate neutral by 2045, while Switzerland is not planning to become climate neutral until 2050, according to the Federal Council's objective. Are we already being abandoned? I hope not. But it is all the more clear that the CO2 law is absolutely necessary for the climate and location of Switzerland. The law will halve CO2 emissions by 2030. Further steps are needed after 2030 for the "Net Zero" target. We must now move forward, including for our economy. Otherwise, we will stand there in 2030 and rub our eyes because we have been technologically and economically abandoned. Why? The other countries have understood that the future belongs to climate-friendly technologies. Europe is therefore moving forward, and the US is back in the field of climate protection. The competition that is leading and exportable in the field of technology is fully launched. The US also wants jobs and value added in its country. We must have this claim too! Switzerland is well positioned today. With the CO2 law and the investments it entails, we lay the foundation for maintaining technology competition and getting away from oil and natural gas. For the climate youth, the CO2 law is completely inadequate. I understand that the law goes too little far for some. But if we reject the law, the oil industry won, not the climate youth. The oil companies want us to continue to pay 8 billion foreign oil and gas producers every year, instead of building up clean energy production at home and applying climate-friendly technologies. "The US also wants jobs and value added in its country. We too must have this claim!» The question is whether this will succeed? The technologies are there, they are profitable. We need to use it now. With the law, we create the conditions for this. But it's going to be expensive for many in this country. How much? First of all, if we don't do anything, it will be very, very expensive for our children and grandchildren. The law promotes access to new cheap technologies, helps save energy and rewards those who consume little oil. Many households save money with the law and end up having more money in the wallet than they do today. The SVP says: A family of four will have to pay 1000 francs more in the year. Look: Behind the referendum is the oil industry, which wants to save its business model and therefore now peddles with such figures. That's not credible. Why not, you can recalculate it. Because the opponents operate with extreme examples. How many families do you know, who fly with their children three times a year on vacation, live in a huge villa and want to hold on to their oil heating? Such a budget may pay a thousand francs more. That's not representative. "Behind the referendum is the oil industry, which wants to save its business model and therefore now has such figures. This is not credible." What is representative? When you look at how most families actually live. On this basis, the experts of the Federation have counted. A family with two children, an average living space, an average petrol car and a European flight per year will pay 100 francs more at the end of the 2020s. It is also important: if the family heats with wood or with a heat pump or does not fly every year, it has more money in the wallet thanks to the redistribution. He who lives in the countryside is the one who is bruised. The law strikes a ditch between the city and the country. This is demonstrably wrong. Otherwise, the farmers' association and the working group for mountain areas would not be in favour of the law. The rural and mountainous regions in particular are already feeling the costly consequences of climate change. If nothing happens, agriculture will increasingly be faced with problems, cable cars are at risk, the forest of protection must be reforested, and tourism is under even more pressure. This is going to be very expensive. That may be. But people often need one or two cars and rely on oil heating because there is no district heating connection like in the city. Four out of ten households are already heating without oil and gas and therefore do not pay any CO2 levy, zero francs. In various rural cantons, it is even more than half of households that do not pay CO2 dues, for example in Graubünden or Valais. Many heat with a heat pump or wood and save so much money. You want to go on vacation. This will continue to be possible in the future. With the ticket tax and the expected refunds, only 10 percent of the population will have to pay on it, namely frequent flyers. They don't live in the countryside and in the mountain areas......and you have to go to work by car. You can keep doing that. Thanks to the CO2 Act, more efficient vehicles are introduced to the market that consume less petrol. That's how you save money. Whether the price of petrol will rise will not be decided by the Federal Council, but by the oil industry. However, Parliament has set an extra ceiling for the protection of motorists. Because we know that many depend on the car. The oil lobby, which decides on a price increase, is fear-making with the petrol price. Parts of the CO2 dues are refunded, but nobody sees it because it is a small number on the health insurance bill. That's right. Here we missed to show people clearly what they're getting back. Everyone – from the toddler to the grandfather – receives the same amount. This is very social and important for families and the middle class. Today every person receives 87 francs, with the new law it is considerably more, namely 167 francs. I want this climate bonus to become more visible. With a family of four, that's a lot of money, 668 francs a year. "Ideal if the population were to receive the money directly. Then a family would have the 668 francs in hand in the future. Or everyone will receive a check." What exactly should be changed? It would be ideal if the population were to receive the money directly. Then a family would have the 668 francs in hand in the future. Or everyone gets a check. But we'd have to turn the whole system around for that. In the short term, I would like to begin by improving information. Each person should see at a glance how high this climate bonus is every year. And I want to make sure that the information works electronically. What is not refunded from the CO2 levy goes into the climate fund. Who guarantees that this will support truly climate-friendly projects? The law is clear. For example, the money supports homeowners who replace their oil heating, promotes the construction of charging stations for electric cars or supports communities in the construction of district heating networks. ==References== promoting the development of green kerosene in aviation. But is all this worth the high price at all? Switzerland has already saved a lot of CO2 and only emits a negligible part of world consumption. The age of oil and coal is coming to an end. These energy sources no longer have a future. The question has long ceased to be whether we want to continue with climate-damaging energy consumption or rely on climate-friendly technologies. What? We must ask ourselves how we as a country benefit economically from this change, which is unstoppable. In Switzerland, there are countless companies that want to bring environmental technologies to the market and thereby gain a competitive advantage. If we do not go ahead, we will continue to pay our money to the foreign oil industry, and business with the new technologies will be done by other countries. "If we do not go ahead, we will continue to pay our money to the foreign oil industry, and the business with the new technologies will be done by other countries." The counter-committee says that with a switch to a kind of hydrogen economy and the exploitation of CO2, the climate problem could be solved without the CO2 dues. The same circles have said no to everything – the current CO2 law, the new CO2 law and the energy strategy. Now they are bringing expensive and inadequate proposals. That's not credible. I do not see how this plan, if it were to work technologically at all, could be implemented without huge sums of funding. In addition, hydrogen technology can also be promoted with the CO2 law. What do you personally do for the climate? I use public transport very often. Last year as President of the Federal Republic of Germany, I went to Vienna on the night train to visit the state. I was also travelling by train for a work visit to Rome. I also have a Tesla as a service car. I'm sure you can do more. I think I'm like most people in our country. We do a lot of things, but we can do even more without giving up anything. For example, I have solar panels on the roof, producing my own electricity. Now I would like to connect the house to the district heating network. "My mini is only three years old now. But I can assure you that if I ever need a new car, it will certainly be an electric one." Will you also sort out your mini you drive privately? My mini is only three years old now. But I can assure you, if I ever need a new car, it'll certainly be an electric one. Also car fans who have switched privately to electric vehicles say they never want to go back. The CO2 law is relatively defensive in terms of the load on petrol and diesel. Is that enough to herald the end of the combustion engines? The fact that the oil industry still depends on the petrol is understandable from their point of view. But the development is towards electric cars. The long-standing president of the TCS section in Zurich recently said that the gasoline car was a run-out model. And the industry tells me that in 2030, there will hardly be any pure petrol cars on the market, perhaps earlier. The TCS supports the CO2 law, precisely because it is committed to car drivers. But do we then have enough electricity, especially green electricity from the inland? I have long believed that we need to massively expand the production of electricity from renewable energies in Switzerland in order to strengthen security of supply. Before the summer, therefore, I am bringing a proposal to Parliament which is precisely the purpose. It also provides for measures to strengthen security of supply in winter. Do we need an additional electricity agreement with the EU to guarantee security of supply? It does not look as if we can quickly conclude such an agreement. Should the Federal Council therefore sign the framework agreement so that we can better integrate into the European market with a power contract? The question of the framework agreement is currently being discussed in the Federal Council. Different elements play a role. Of course, we need to weigh opportunities and risks. The question of the electricity agreement is an important element. But not only the electricity agreement is crucial for security of supply. Why not? In any case, we must produce more clean electricity in Switzerland and not simply rely on imports – even in a possible electricity agreement with the EU. However, Swiss electricity producers, which are a large part of the public sector, are investing heavily in renewable energy abroad. That is indeed the case. We have to change that. In order to ensure security of supply, companies and their owners, in many cases the cantons, are responsible. You're in charge of production. And does it still need gas power plants? The focus is clearly on the expansion of renewable energies. Hydropower reliably supplies electricity even in winter. Should a supply gap still be emerging, gas power plants could become an issue. But they would have to be climate neutral, and that would be expensive. Fossil energies are expensive. That is why I expect energy producers to really rely on renewable energy from domestic sources. Is that realistic? If we only install solar panels on all suitable roofs in Switzerland, we can produce twice as much electricity as all nuclear power plants together. To exploit this potential is in the foreground for me. I don't think we should just take more money out of the federal fund. The CO2 law is already our climate programme, with which we can strengthen Switzerland at the same time. SP and Greens are calling for a state environmental investment programme to boost the economy after the pandemic. In the USA, Joe Biden even plans a climate-corona program for Switzerland? I don't think we should just take more money out of the federal fund. Rather, we need the right framework conditions. The economy wants to move forward on its own initiative, but needs collateral. We can deliver these with the CO2 Act. In addition, the Climate Fund provides the necessary funds to finance climate action. Does this mean that the federal government lacks the money anyway due to the Corona crisis in order to invest heavily in climate protection? No, the money's not the problem. The CO2 law is already our climate programme, with which we can strengthen Switzerland at the same time. The law provides for contracts for our SMEs. This is how we secure jobs in Switzerland.

text: ['Delegiertenversammlung der SP: Wermuth: Rahmenabkommen in dieser Form inakzeptabel SP-Co-Präsident Cédric Wermuth hat sich für ein geeintes Europa ausgesprochen – und gegen ein Rahmenabkommen in aktueller Form.', 'Zudem hat die Partei ihre restlichen Parolen für die kommenden Abstimmungen gefasst.', 'SDA  Cédric Wermuth spricht in Bern in digitaler Form zu den Delegierten.', 'SP-Co-Präsident Cédric Wermuth hat dem Rahmenabkommen (InstA) Schweiz-EU in der derzeitigen Form eine klare Absage erteilt.', 'Aus Sicht der Sozialdemokraten ist der Lohnschutz in dem Vertragswerk mangelhaft.', 'Europa-freundlich bleibt die SP laut Wermuth aber trotzdem.', 'Das Rahmenabkommen gebe den Lohnschutz zum Abschluss frei und riskiere die Schwächung des Service public.', 'Und dabei gehe es nicht um «Peanuts», sagte Wermuth.', 'Der Aargauer Wermuth schoss direkt auf den Bundesrat: «Vielleicht hätte das InstA eine Chance sein können, aber dann haben es die freisinnige Hors-Sol-Diplomatie und ihre Bundesräte richtig verkackt, wie man dort sagt, wo ich herkomme.»  Im letzten Moment der Verhandlungen hätten diese «auf Befehl ihrer Auftraggeber versucht, die Perspektive eines Beitritts zur EU für immer zu beerdigen und gleichzeitig die ungeliebten Lohnschutzmassnahmen auszuhebeln».', '«Kern der Sozialdemokratie» Gerade der Schutz der Löhne und des Gewerbes vor Sozialdumping sei nicht einfach ein Aspekt der Schweizer Europapolitik unter vielen, sondern ihr absolutes Fundament.', '«Es geht hier nicht um Taktik oder Parteipositionierung.', 'Es geht um den Kern dessen, was es ausmacht, Sozialdemokratin oder Sozialdemokrat zu sein.»  Die entscheidende Frage für die Linke sei eine simple, so Wermuth.', '«Wäre Europa ohne die Union ein besseres Europa?', 'Die Antwort: Nein.', 'Allein schon aufgrund der Tatsache, dass die Aufgaben unserer Zeit objektiv längst die Grenzen des Nationalstaates sprengen.» Die SP wolle, dass die Schweiz vom europapolitischen Abstellgleis wieder herunterkomme und Kurs aufnehme auf mehr Integration in Europa.', 'Schweiz soll in Europa dabei sein Die Sozialdemokraten wollen laut Wermuth, dass sich die Schweiz beteiligt am europäischen Green New Deal und an den europaweiten Investitionsprogrammen nach Covid.', 'Und sie wollten bei den Steuern zusammenarbeiten, bei der Regulierung des Finanzplatzes, beim Aufbau eines europäischen Gesundheitssystems, bei der Bildung, bei der Kultur, beim Ausbau des Arbeitsschutzes.', 'Innerhalb der SP gärt es, was den Umgang mit der EU betrifft.', 'Eine Gruppe hatte Ende April in einem Schreiben an das SP-Präsidium vor einem Scheitern des Rahmenabkommens gewarnt.', 'Gerate die Schweiz ins europapolitische Abseits, sei das fatal.', 'Unterzeichnet haben verschiedene Regierungsräte samt dem Basel-Städtischen Regierungspräsidenten Beat Jans und auch alt SP-Bundesrat Moritz Leuenberger.', 'Berset warnt vor Armutsfalle Vor einer wachsenden Kluft zwischen Arm und Reich warnte Bundesrat Alain Berset die SP-Delegierten über eine Video-Schaltung.', 'Noch nie sei so viel von Solidarität die Rede gewesen wie während der Corona-Pandemie, aber das verstelle den Blick vor anderen Problemen.', '«Viele der Probleme, die vor dieser Krise schon gross waren, sind jetzt noch grösser», sagte der SP-Gesundheitsminister.', '«Die nächsten Jahre werden schwierig – und am schwierigsten werden sie für die Schwächeren.', 'Auch in unserem Land.»  Berset plädierte für mehr Gleichheit und Gerechtigkeit.', 'Der nächste «Test für unsere Gesellschaft» komme, nachdem die Schweiz die Pandemie besiegt haben werde.', 'Nicht nur Arbeitnehmende, sondern auch viele Unternehmen seien darauf angewiesen, dass die Gesellschaft sie nicht einfach fallenlässt.', 'Alle bräuchten Solidarität, wenn sie sich in einer Notlage befinden, sagte Berset und plädierte für eine Annahme des Covid-19-Gesetzes bei der Volksabstimmung am 13.', 'Juni.', '«Die Pandemie können wir ohne dieses Gesetz bekämpfen.', 'Dazu haben wir das Epidemiengesetz.', 'Aber um die Wirtschaftskrise zu bekämpfen und die Finanzhilfen so lange wie nötig weiterzuführen, dazu brauchen wir dieses Covid-19-Gesetz», sagte der Gesundheitsminister.', 'Drei Ja-Parolen und ein Mal Nein Die SP fasste am Samstag auch ihre restlichen Parolen für die eidgenössischen Abstimmungen vom 13.', 'Juni und 26.', 'September: Ja zum Covid-19-Gesetz, zur 99-Prozent-Initiative und zur Ehe für alle, Nein zum Anti-Terror-Gesetz.', 'Drei Mal Ja hatte die Partei bereits im Februar ausgegeben für die Volksinitiative für sauberes Trinkwasser und gesunde Nahrung sowie die Volksinitiative «Für eine Schweiz ohne synthetische Pestizide» und das CO2-Gesetz.', 'Die SP-Delegierten verabschiedeten am Samstag ausserdem mehrere und «Gegen den Genozid an den UigurInnen».']
processed_text: SP Delegates' Meeting: Wermuth: Framework agreements in this form unacceptable SP Co President Cédric Wermuth has spoken out for a united Europe – and against a framework agreement in its current form. In addition, the party has made its remaining slogans for the next votes. SDA Cédric Wermuth speaks digitally to the delegates in Bern. SP Co President Cédric Wermuth has given a clear rejection of the Framework Agreement (InstA) Switzerland-EU in its current form. From the point of view of the social democrats, wage protection in the treaty is inadequate. However, according to Wermuth, the SP remains Europe-friendly. The framework agreement freed up wage protection at the conclusion and risked weakening the service public. And this is not about "peanuts," said Wermuth. The Aargauer Wermuth shot directly at the Federal Council: "Perhaps the InstA could have been a chance, but then the free-minded Hors-Sol diplomacy and its Federal Councils really screwed it up, as they say where I come from." At the last moment of the negotiations, these "at the command of their clients tried to bury the prospect of joining the EU forever and at the same time to eliminate the unloved wage protection measures". «The core of social democracy» It is precisely the protection of wages and trade from social dumping that is not simply an aspect of Swiss European policy among many, but its absolute foundation. «It is not about tactics or party positioning. It's about the core of what it is to be a social democrat." The crucial question for the left is a simple one, says Wermuth. "Would Europe be a better Europe without the Union? The answer: no. It is precisely because of the fact that the tasks of our time have been objectively beyond the borders of the nation-state."The SP wants Switzerland to come down from the European political siding and take a course for more integration in Europe. According to Wermuth, Switzerland should be present in Europe According to the Social Democrats, Switzerland wants to participate in the European Green New Deal and in the European investment programmes according to Covid. And they wanted to work together on taxes, on regulation of the financial centre, on building a European health system, on education, on culture, on developing occupational safety and health. Within the SP, it is a matter of dealing with the EU. A group had warned at the end of April in a letter to the SP Bureau of the failure of the framework agreement. If Switzerland goes off to the European political side, that is fatal. Various government councils, including Beat Jans, President of Basel and former SP Federal Councillor Moritz Leuenberger, have signed the contract. Berset warns of poverty traps Federal Councillor Alain Berset warned the SP delegates about a growing gap between the poor and the rich via a video circuit. Never before has there been so much talk of solidarity as during the Corona pandemic, but that puts the eye on other problems. "Many of the problems that were already big before this crisis are even bigger," said the SP Health Minister. "The next few years will be difficult – and most difficult for the weaker. Also in our country." Berset pleaded for more equality and justice. The next «test for our society» will come after Switzerland has defeated the pandemic. Not only employees, but also many companies are dependent on society not simply dropping them. All of them would need solidarity if they were in distress, Berset said, pleading for the adoption of the Covid 19 law in the referendum on 13 May. ==References== "We can fight the pandemic without this law. That's what we have the epidemics law for. But in order to combat the economic crisis and to continue the financial assistance as long as necessary, we need this Covid-19 law to do so," said the Minister of Health. Three Yes Paroles and One Time No On Saturday, the SP also held its remaining slogans for the Swiss votes of 13 July. ==References== September: Yes to the Covid-19 Act, the 99 percent initiative and marriage for all, No to the Anti-Terror Act. The party had already spent three times in February on the People's Initiative for Clean Drinking Water and Healthy Food, as well as the People's Initiative "For a Switzerland without synthetic pesticides" and the CO2 Act. The SP delegates also passed several resolutions on Saturday: "Together for a climate-friendly future", "Quickly and in solidarity from the pandemic: for a worldwide fair access to Corona vaccines", "For a sustainable financial centre" and "Against the genocide against the Uighurs".
author: Werm Cédric Wermuth

text: ['Subaru gegen CO?-Gesetz: Automarke verschickt Sponsoring-Absage – mit brisanter Begründung In den Kampf um CO?-Regeln werden nun auch Kulturveranstalter hineingezogen: Subaru antwortet auf eine Anfrage mit politischen Seitenhieben.', 'Fabian Renz  Der Luzerner FDP-Ständerat Damian Müller wird zur Zielscheibe der Autobranche.', 'Um Klima und Abgase wird politisch derzeit intensiv gerungen.', 'Am 13.', 'Juni stimmt das Volk über das neue CO?-Gesetz ab, und im März erst traf das Parlament einen folgenschweren Entscheid für die Produzenten von Luxusautos: Die Modelle von Klein- und Nischenmarken werden künftig bei den CO?-Zielwerten nicht mehr bevorzugt, sondern gleich behandelt wie alle übrigen Autos.', 'Wie sich nun zeigt, greift die Auseinandersetzung auch in den unpolitischen Kulturbereich über.', 'Das mussten unlängst die Veranstalter eines Kulturanlasses in der Zentralschweiz erfahren.', 'Sie fragten den Autohersteller Subaru um ein Sponsoring an und erhielten eine Absage – mit explizitem Hinweis auf die für die Branche nachteilige politische Entwicklung.', 'Und mit einem brisanten personellen Seitenhieb: Ausdrücklich wird in der Absage darauf hingewiesen, dass im Patronatskomitee des Anlasses der Luzerner FDP-Ständerat Damian Müller sitzt.', 'Dieser eckt durch sein klimapolitisches Engagement in der Branche an: Er war es, der den Vorstoss für die Gleichbehandlung aller Neuwagen lanciert hat, und er setzt sich aktiv für ein Ja zum CO2-Gesetz im Sommer ein.', '«Bei solchen fiskalischen Belastungen geben wir keine teure Fernsehwerbung mehr in Auftrag.»  Müllers Neuwagen-Motion werde zu massiv höheren CO2-«Strafsteuern» führen, heisst es in der Subaru-Antwort an die Veranstalter, die dieser Zeitung vorliegt.', '«Sie werden verstehen, dass wir (und das Gros der Branche) bei solchen fiskalischen Belastungen keine teure Fernsehwerbung mehr in Auftrag geben oder Sponsoring-Engagements eingehen können.»  Die «schönen Beträge», die man bis vor kurzem für Werbung und Sponsoring eingesetzt habe, «liefern wir jetzt in Bern ab».', 'Den Veranstaltern wird überdies geraten, im Sommer das CO2-Gesetz abzulehnen.', '«Herr und Frau Schweizer» müssten sich gut überlegen, wie sie künftig wählen und abstimmen wollten.', 'FDP-Ständerat ist empört Ständerat Müller zeigt sich empört über die Subaru-Reaktion: Es handle sich um eine «höchst problematische Aktion».', 'Es sei bedenklich, dass Kreise, die so gerne von Souveränität sprächen, derart unsouverän reagierten.', '«Nicht die Absage für das Sponsoring an sich ist störend.', 'Stossend ist vielmehr, dass hier ein demokratisch korrekt zustande gekommener, deutlicher Parlamentsentscheid als Begründung missbraucht wird», ärgert sich Müller.', 'Ihm zufolge versucht Subaru, die Abstimmung über das CO2-Gesetz «unter Androhung finanzieller Sanktionen zu beeinflussen».', 'Seine erfolgreiche Motion für einheitliche Regeln bei den Emissionsabgaben wiederum – die, wie er betont, noch nicht umgesetzt ist – versteht Müller als «liberales Anliegen».', 'Mit dem CO2-Gesetz habe sie nichts zu tun, und die Auswirkungen für Subaru seien noch gar nicht bezifferbar.', '«Fakt ist auch, dass, sobald die eingereichte Motion wirksam wird, die Marke Subaru stark betroffen sein wird.»  Die Emil Frey Gruppe, Schweizer Generalimporteurin der Marke Subaru, verteidigt dagegen auf Anfrage die Sponsoring-Absage.', 'Es verstehe sich von selbst, dass die Sponsoring-Budgets «gerade in der jetzigen, Corona-bedingt besonders schwierigen Situation» schmaler ausfallen würden.', 'Die Auswahl von möglichen Sponsoring-Aktivitäten sei darum eingeschränkter.', '«Fakt ist auch, dass, sobald die eingereichte Motion wirksam wird, die Marke Subaru stark betroffen sein wird», teilt das Unternehmen mit.', 'Noch dauert es über einen Monat bis zum Urnengang.', 'Der Krach um das Subaru-Sponsoring zeigt, dass die heisse Phase im Abstimmungskampf um das CO2-Gesetz wohl eben erst begonnen hat.']
processed_text: Subaru vs. CO? law: Automark sends sponsoring cancellation – with explosive justification Cultural organisers are now also involved in the fight for CO? rules: Subaru answers to a request with political side blows. Fabian Renz The Lucerne FDP stand Damian Müller becomes the target of the automotive industry. Climate and exhaust gases are currently being heavily fought for politically. ==References== The people vote on the new CO? law on June, and only in March did Parliament make a decision which is difficult to follow for luxury car producers: In future, the models of small and niche brands will no longer be preferred in the CO? target values, but will be treated in the same way as all other cars. As is now shown, the debate also spreads into the non-political cultural sphere. This was recently experienced by the organizers of a cultural event in Central Switzerland. They asked the car manufacturer Subaru for sponsorship and received a rejection – with explicit reference to the political development that was detrimental to the industry. And with a frantic personal side blow: In the rejection, it is expressly pointed out that Damian Müller is sitting on the patronage committee of the occasion of the Lucerne FDP stand. It is this one that is ecstatic by its climate policy commitment in the industry: it was he who launched the push for equal treatment for all new cars, and he actively advocates a yes to the CO2 law in the summer. "We no longer commission expensive television advertising for such fiscal burdens." Müller's new-car motion will lead to massively higher CO2 "criminal taxes," says the Subaru response to the organizers of this newspaper. "You will understand that we (and the majority of the industry) can no longer commission expensive television advertising or enter into sponsorship engagements with such fiscal burdens." The "beautiful amounts" that have been used until recently for advertising and sponsorship "we are now delivering in Berne." The organizers are also advised to reject the CO2 law in the summer. "Mr and Mrs Schweizer" would have to think carefully about how they wanted to vote and vote in the future. FDP stand-up is outraged Councilman Müller is outraged by the Subaru reaction: it is a "highly problematic action". It is worrying that circles so fond of talking about sovereignty reacted so unsovereignly. «Not the rejection of sponsorship itself is disturbing. Rather, it is stussing that a democratically correct, clear parliamentary decision is abused as a justification here," Müller is annoyed. According to him, Subaru tries to influence the vote on the CO2 Act "under threat of financial sanctions". Müller sees his successful motion for uniform rules on emissions taxes – which, he stresses, has not yet been implemented – as a "liberal concern". It had nothing to do with the CO2 Act and the impact on Subaru was not yet quantifiable. «It is also true that as soon as the motion submitted becomes effective, the Subaru brand will be severely affected.» Emil Frey Group, Swiss general importer of Subaru brand, defends the sponsorship cancellation on request. It goes without saying that the sponsoring budgets "would be narrower in the current, Corona-related, particularly difficult situation." The selection of possible sponsorship activities is therefore more limited. "The fact is that once the motion submitted becomes effective, the Subaru brand will be severely affected," the company informs. It will take more than a month to complete the urn. The noise around the Subaru sponsorship shows that the hot phase in the voting campaign for the CO2 law has probably just begun.
author: Fabian Renz Damian

processed_text: Opinion and debate TRIBÜNE Nuclear power is sustainable and environmentally friendly Guest commentary by Simon Aegerter Without energy, we would still be sitting in front of damp caves and eating raw meat. Energy is the basis of all progress. For hundreds of thousands of years firewood was the only source of energy. 250 years ago fossil fuels were added: coal, oil and gas. We owe them everything we have today: prosperity, quality of life, health. But now their era is coming to an end. You give us an insoluble waste problem: your use produces CO2, which disturbs the heat balance of the earth. We need to replace them with clean electricity. But where is this supposed to come from? Recently, an internal report from the European Commission's Joint Research Centre (JRC) has found that nuclear power is not only clean but also sustainable. A daring thesis? In the context of sustainable investment, the JRC's expert group has examined whether nuclear energy can cause any significant damage. The answer is no. Have the Commission experts not learned lessons from Fukushima and previous nuclear power plant disasters? However, they have even examined these cases in a particularly meticulous way in all possible aspects. They hold on: Despite a triple GAU, no one has been harmed by radiation. The experts also investigated the alleged unsolved problem of nuclear waste. Deep storage shall be such that a human being must never be exposed to an additional radiation exposure of 0.1 mSv or more. This limit is already being met: high-level radioactive waste stored in Scandinavian granite could affect a person in 20 000 to 50 000 years at a maximum of 0.01 mSv. In Switzerland's Opalinus Clay, the waste would be even more secure. So the problem of nuclear waste is not really one. ==References====External links== These findings are also relevant to us on the revised CO2 Act on June. Is the replacement of fossil fuels from renewable energy? On a normal evening in mid-April, the sun in Germany contributes 0 percent and the wind 3 percent to the power supply. A few more percent come from hydropower. The rest comes from energy sources, which are rightly to be avoided: coal and gas. How's that gonna work? How do we replace the fossil energy that destroys our environment and changes the climate? If nuclear energy had not been misled for decades, the answer would be simple: by building nuclear power plants! For this, however, it would be necessary to have the Swiss once again voted on the phase-out of nuclear energy – and to inform them thoroughly. The JRC's report comes at the right time. Nuclear energy is sustainable. Nuclear energy produces electricity day and night, regardless of the weather. And above all, nuclear energy does not produce CO2 in the plant. Why are we banning this ideal source of energy ourselves? Simon Aegerter is a physicist and has been head of Technorama in Winterthur for many years; he is the author of "The Growth of Borders. About the inexhaustible inventiveness of humans» (NZZ Libro). Nuclear energy produces electricity around the clock and regardless of the weather – without emitting CO2 during operation.
author: Simon Aegerter

die Stadträte abwechselnd zu verschiedenen Politthemen äussern, schrieb Mauch: Gerade Städte seien besonders stark vom Klimawandel und dessen Folgen betroffen – «zum Beispiel durch zunehmende Hitze».', 'Vielleicht auch deshalb seien sie Pionierinnen der Klimapolitik.', 'Die Zürcher Stimmbevölkerung habe bereits vor 13 Jahren Ja zur 2000-Watt-Gesellschaft gesagt und damit «ein ambitioniertes Klimaschutzziel in der Gemeindeordnung verankert».', 'Das CO2-Gesetz sei eine wichtige Voraussetzung, damit nicht nur die Klimaziele des Bundes erreicht werden könnten, sondern auch jene Zürichs.', 'Die Vorlage sei fair und wirksam; sie bedeute auch eine grosse Chance für innovative Unternehmen und die Wirtschaft.', 'Deshalb brauche es «ein überzeugtes Ja – für die Umwelt, die Menschen und die Wirtschaft».', 'Genau in diesem Punkt widerspricht Filippo Leutenegger.', 'Er bezeichnete die Vorlage kürzlich in der NZZ als missratenen Kompromiss, als dirigistischen Eingriff, der mehr Steuern zur Folge habe.', 'Das Gesetz hemme Innovationen, statt sie zu unterstützen, und es bringe viel Bürokratie.', 'Schlagabtausch im «Tagblatt» Es ist nicht das erste Mal, dass sich Mauch und Leutenegger in aller Öffentlichkeit streiten.', 'Und es ist auch nicht das erste Mal, dass sie das über die Stadtratskolumne im «Tagblatt» machen.', 'Anfang 2018, mitten im Wahlkampf um das Stadtpräsidium, erklärte der FDP-Politiker, was er als oberster Zürcher alles besser machen würde als Mauch.', '«Liebe Corine», titelte er sein zum öffentlichen Brief mutiertes Schreiben.', '«Steuersenkung?', 'Ja, ich möchte eine – du nicht.» Auch nach Leuteneggers gescheiterter Präsidentschaftskandidatur und seiner Strafversetzung nach den Wahlen vom Tiefbau- ins Schuldepartement kam es zum öffentlichen Disput.', 'Bei der Bekanntgabe der Ämterverteilung kritisierte er die Stadtpräsidentin indirekt scharf.', 'Das Ganze sei gegen seinen Willen geschehen, «mir wurde das Departement weggenommen».', 'Sein Vertrauen in das Gremium habe sehr gelitten.', 'Ob die neuste öffentlich ausgetragene Meinungsverschiedenheit zum CO2-Gesetz dem Gremium schadet, ist fraglich.', 'Ob es die letzte gewesen ist, ebenso.', 'Nicht einer Meinung: Filippo Leutenegger und Corine Mauch.', 'Annick Ramp / NZZ']
processed_text: Leutenegger vs. the others: The CO2 Act splits the Zurich City Council The head of the school shudder and advertises a no – the president and the other members of the executive counter Florian Schoop The explosion has brought everything a message that is attributable to the amateur area in terms of design. A red flash, numerous fonts – and an old portrait of a politician who was unlovingly copied into the overall picture. But it's not this refreshingly lay-like design of the ad that caused a whirlwind. These are the statements of the photographed politician: "Filippo Leutenegger votes no to the CO2 law", says white on red. The Zurich FDP city council and school principal talked about themselves with this statement a few days ago, which was in advertising form in newspapers and social networks. Not only did this cause resentment to his party, which is making itself strong for the aforementioned law before the vote next Sunday – but also apparently to his colleagues in the city government. Opponents switched While executive politicians usually withdraw on voting issues, after Leutenegger's oscillations, his eight colleagues from the Zurich City Council also held their backs. On Tuesday, they published a counter-indication – and pleaded for a "yes" to the CO2 Act. One could always demand an even better proposal, says the Green Daniel Leupi via Twitter. But this law represents a first step in climate protection. "Others have to follow." Interesting detail: Mentenegger's party colleague Michael Baumer was also involved in the Ja poster campaign. He explained to the Tamedia newspapers: Various opinions were part of a lively discussion. "The climate in the city council tolerates such debates." Meanwhile, city president Corine Mauch made it clear in the same article that the committee had not adopted an official slogan for the CO2 law. The eight members of the city council had placed the advertisement as a private person – and thus financed it privately. This is confirmed by the City Chancellery on request. The status of executives is not mentioned in the advertisement. Nevertheless, one speaker points out: "If the city is particularly affected by higher-level proposals, it occasionally takes its position on them." Voting recommendations of the panel in the form of a media release would only be published if unanimity were observed – for example, in the 2016 enforcement initiative. "Increasing heat" The city president herself has not for the first time been a female executive politician for the presentation. In the last week's issue of the "Tagblatt der Stadt Zürich", she took the floor for the CO2 Act. In a column in which the city councils alternately express themselves on various political issues, Mauch wrote: Cities in particular are particularly affected by climate change and its consequences – "for example by increasing heat". Perhaps that is why they are pioneers in climate policy. The voting population in Zurich already said yes to the 2000 Watt society 13 years ago and thus "an ambitious climate protection goal is anchored in the community order". The CO2 Act is an important prerequisite for achieving not only the federal climate goals, but also those of Zurich. The proposal was fair and effective; it also meant a great opportunity for innovative companies and the economy. That is why it needs "a convincing yes – for the environment, people and the economy". This is precisely the point that Filippo Mentenegger disagrees with. He recently described the proposal in the NZZ as a disadvised compromise, a dirigist intervention that would result in more taxes. The law inhibits innovation instead of supporting it, and it brings a lot of bureaucracy. Swap in the "Tagblatt" It is not the first time that Mauch and Leutenegger are arguing in public. And it is not the first time that they do this about the city council column in the "Tagblatt". At the beginning of 2018, in the middle of the election campaign around the City Bureau, the FDP politician explained what he would do better than Mauch as the top of Zurich. «Dear Corine», he titled his letter mutated to the public letter. « Tax reduction? Yes, I want one – you don't.» Even after Leutenegger's failed presidential candidate and his transfer of sentence after the elections from the civil engineering to the debt department, public debate took place. In announcing the distribution of offices, he indirectly criticized the city president sharply. The whole thing had happened against his will, «I was taken away from the department». His trust in the panel had suffered greatly. It is questionable whether the latest public disagreement on the CO2 law harms the body. Whether it was the last one, so was it. Not one opinion: Filippo Leutenegger and Corine Mauch. Annick Ramp / NZZ
