processed_text: CO2 emissions fraud splatters in Africa Two officials of a vehicle import company paid a collaborator of the Federal Roads Office to escape the sanctions on CO2 emissions. The Confederation has lost 9 million in this case Bernard Wuthrich The corruption case revealed on Monday by the Public Prosecutor's Office of the Confederation (MPC) splashes a Federal Road Office (Ofrou) which is not at its first scandal. It falls in the middle of the campaign on the CO2 law, one of the components of which is the maximum CO2 emission limit imposed on vehicles, above which importers must pay fines. These sanctions are at the very heart of this case. Between June 2014 and September 2017, when the rose pot was discovered, a staff member of the OFRU, who has since left the office, reportedly "manipulated in the Federal Office's computer systems the data determining the CO2 sanctions investigation" in favour of a car import company. Worse still, he was reportedly paid by the company's officials for this service, up to 2,000 francs per month, according to the MPC's statement. Nine million unpaid to Confederation Thanks to this subterfuge, the company in question would not have had to pay fines between 2015 and 2017 for the vehicles it imported that exceeded the standard of 130 grams of CO2 per kilometre, in force at the time. The target value was lowered to 95 grams per kilometre in 2020. If the revision of the CO2 law is accepted by popular vote on 13 June, it will be further reduced by 15% from 2025 and by 37.5% from 2030. These manipulations deprived the Confederation of 9 million francs of revenue. The new CO2 law envisages allocating half of the proceeds of these environmental sanctions to the future climate fund. The MPC shall refer the former employee of Ofrou and the two members of the board of directors of the importing company to the Federal Criminal Court. The former official is accused of forgery in securities committed in the performance of public functions, passive bribery, fraud in contributions and benefits and fraudulent obtaining of a false finding. Already a case of corruption in Viège Both officials of the company are warned of incitement to forge documents in the performance of public functions, corruption, fraud by trade in contributions and benefits and fraudulent obtaining of a false finding. According to our information, the company in question is not an official importer, but a family-owned business that buys used vehicles directly. A hypothesis confirmed by François Launaz, President of the Swiss border, "An official importer cannot afford to do this," he comments. Embarrassing for Ofrou, this case is not the first one that splashes. In 2016, two employees of its branch office in Viège and the former director of a construction company were prosecuted for corruption in connection with the work of bypassing the city of Upper Valais. In 2013, the former boss of OFROU had been in contact with the Federal Financial Control (CDF), who had accused him of failing to comply with the Federal Finance Act in respect of two large-scale IT projects.

text: ['Courrier des lecteurs Bulletins de vote abandonnés Veyrier, 1er juin On entend parler du Service des votations et élections malheureusement lorsqu’on lui impute un dysfonctionnement.', 'Dommage, car en réalité il s’agit là du service de l’État permettant au peuple genevois d’exercer son rôle premier, celui de sa souveraineté, qu’il s’agisse de s’exprimer par un vote communal, cantonal ou fédéral, ou pour des élections, décisions, promulgation de lois ou d’articles constitutionnels.', 'Beaucoup d’habitants de la planète envient cette organisation helvétique.', 'Reste à lui garantir la perfection de son organisation et la sécurité des écrits de l’électeur.', 'On apprend donc par la presse que quelque 7000 bulletins de vote ont été abandonnés sur un trottoir pendant trois jours et nuits.', 'Il ne s’agissait pas en l’occurrence de liasses de billets oubliés devant une banque.', 'Au contraire, ce qui a été déposé représente bien plus de valeur que l’argent, c’est l’exercice même du pouvoir dans notre pays démocratique.', 'Bien que La Poste ait effectué ce dépôt comme elle le fait tous les samedis précédant les votes, le suivi en incombe à la conscience professionnelle des responsables du Service des votations, qui n’a pas à se retrancher derrière son transporteur.', 'On attend donc avec impatience l’ouverture d’une enquête de la part du procureur général qui, ne l’oublions pas, est là pour défendre aujourd’hui le lésé le plus important de la République, son peuple.', 'Gilles Bourquin 13 juin, la voix des animaux Chêne-Bourg, 26 mai Moi, c’est Modestine.', 'Depuis bien longtemps je suis patraque, incapable de me débrouiller, «en soin» car je n’arrive pas à manger seule, je ne sais pas comment m’y prendre, comme si j’avais perdu le mode d’emploi.', 'Devant mon assiette – j’attends.', 'Je reste petite et toute molle.', 'J’ai les pattes arrière tournées vers l’extérieur, je n’arrive pas à marcher droit, je fais lentement des cercles, gênant pour courir après mon repas.', 'Mes pattes ne répondent pas à ce que je leur demande et fonctionnent au ralenti, comme si mon cerveau était loin d’elles et mes neurones ankylosés.', 'En écoutant autour de moi, j’ai appris des choses qu’on m’avait cachées – à vous aussi?', 'Tout a commencé avant ma naissance.', 'Mes parents, courts sur pattes, «travaillant dans le milieu agricole», mangeurs de limaces, de vers et d’insectes assaisonnés au glyphosate ou autres pesticides, m’ont transmis cet héritage de chimie.', 'Allaitée aux pesticides, j’ai ensuite croqué limaces, vers et cie, parachevant ainsi l’héritage chimique parental.', 'Or, les pesticides peuvent causer entre autres: des troubles neurologiques et du comportement, un retard de croissance, une fatigabilité musculaire, une fente palatine, etc.', 'Moi, j’ai de la chance, je n’ai pas de fente palatine, mais mes deux sœurs en sont mortes.', 'J’en ai versé de grosses larmes, mais je garde espoir, et il est placé en vous.', 'Modestine la hérissonne Suzanne Soder Protection contre le bruit Genève, 22 mai En 2018 j’avais écrit à l’État pour lui demander quand un sol phonoabsorbant serait posé à la route de Florissant.', 'Il m’avait été répondu que ces travaux étaient importants et seraient entrepris l’année prochaine, c’est-à-dire en 2019.', 'Comme on peut le constater, rien n’a été fait sur cette route extrêmement bruyante et surtout très habitée, ainsi que sur l’avenue Eugène-Pittard.', 'Alors que l’on parle d’instituer la vitesse de 30 km/h en ville, ne serait-il pas préférable de poser dans les artères très habitées ce revêtement de sol très efficace?', 'Que la vitesse soit réglée à 30 ou 50 km/h, le bruit du démarrage d’une voiture est de même intensité et la route de Florissant est hachée de passages pour piétons qui nécessitent l’arrêt complet du véhicule et donc le redémarrage qui s’ensuit.', 'Marianne Herzog Une Cité de la musique inutile Grand-Saconnex, 18 mai Ce projet, hors mesure, date d’une époque révolue.', 'Il ne correspond plus aux besoins d’aujourd’hui et encore moins aux besoins futurs.', 'Les tarifs d’exploitation sont loin de la réalité et surtout bien trop optimistes.', 'Aucune institution culturelle ne fonctionne sans subventions.', 'De nos jours déjà, l’OSR peine à remplir le Victoria Hall avec ses 900 places.', 'Les mélomanes, un public vieillissant, manque de relève.', 'La jeunesse, malgré les mesures mises en place, reste la minorité.', 'Le Covid et ses descendants vont maintenir les restrictions dictées par Berne et changer les habitudes et comportements.', 'Le streaming déjà en place va prendre de l’ampleur grâce au confort.', 'L’avenir de l’enseignement, c’est la «Toile» comme déjà actuellement; les leçons en classe seront l’exception.', 'Un sujet important, les jeunes qui sortent du Conservatoire ne trouvent plus d’engagement.', 'Le nombre d’élèves diminuera et les 95 salles sont une aberration.', 'Le monde d’après-Covid n’est pas perceptible, ce qui devrait inciter à la prudence.', '[…] La destruction de ce magnifique paradis de verdure, rare sur la place des Nations, est déplorable – on aime notre mère Nature – l’abattage de 126 arbres et l’emprise atmosphérique de cette masse de béton seront fort néfastes sur un environnement déjà fortement impacté.', 'Où sont les défenseurs du climat?', 'Régina Bader Faire son devoir de citoyen Genève, 23 mai La démocratie existe uniquement si l’on fait son devoir de citoyen, c’est-àdire de voter en toute bienveillance.', 'Voter oui pour la loi sur le CO2, c’est accepter de prendre ses responsabilités, c’est prendre des mesures urgentes pour protéger le climat.', 'La loi sur le CO2 est un pas vers un avenir sans pétrole, gaz naturel et charbon.', 'C’est aussi un pas vers la fin de la mainmise d’une élite destructrice et décadente sur notre vie.', 'Ne pas réduire les émissions de CO2 dans le monde entier aurait des conséquences dévastatrices sur nos moyens de subsistance.', 'C’est l’un des plus grands défis de notre époque, il s’agit de sauver le monde.', 'Au diable nos acquis, au diable notre soi-disant bien-être économique, au diable notre égoïsme, le temps est venu de vraiment changer l’avenir et de prendre en main notre destin.', 'On ne peut pas se poser la question en termes de oui ou de non, c’est au-delà de l’intelligence et de la pensée.', 'Voter non serait un crime contre l’humanité.', 'Voter non serait la fin de l’humanité.', 'Alex Simha']

It is a pity, because in reality it is the service of the State that enables the people of Geneva to exercise their primary role, that of their sovereignty, whether it is to express themselves by a communal, cantonal or federal vote, or for elections, decisions, enactment of laws or constitutional articles. Many of the world's inhabitants are becoming this Swiss organization. It remains to guarantee him the perfection of his organization and the security of the voters' writings. It is thus learned by the press that some 7,000 ballot papers were abandoned on a sidewalk for three days and nights. In this case, they were not the liases of banknotes forgotten in front of a bank. On the contrary, what has been deposited is much more valuable than money, it is the very exercise of power in our democratic country. Although La Poste has made this deposit as it does every Saturday before the votes, the responsibility for follow-up lies with the professional conscience of the officials of the Voting Service, which does not have to fall behind its carrier. We therefore look forward to the opening of an investigation by the Attorney General, who, let us not forget, is there to defend today the most important aggrieved of the Republic, its people. Gilles Bourquin June 13th, the voice of the animals Oak-Bourg, May 26th, Moi, c'est Modestine. For a long time I have been a patrac, unable to manage, "careful" because I can't eat alone, I don't know how to take it, as if I had lost the way to use it. In front of my plate – I'm waiting. I'm still small and soft. I have my back legs turned outwards, I can't walk straight, I slowly circle, embarrassing to run after my meal. My legs don't respond to what I ask them and work slow, as if my brain was far away from them and my ankylosed neurons. Listening around me, I learned things that I had hidden – to you too? It all started before I was born. My parents, short on legs, "working in the agricultural environment", eaters of slugs, worms and insects seasoned with glyphosate or other pesticides, have passed on this chemical heritage. Lactated with pesticides, I then chewed slugs, worms and cies, thus finalizing the parental chemical heritage. Pesticides can cause, among other things, neurological and behavioural disorders, stunting, muscle fatigue, a palatine slit, etc. I'm lucky I don't have a palatine slot, but my two sisters died. I've shed big tears, but I keep hope, and it's placed in you. Modestine the hedgehog Suzanne Soder Noise protection Geneva, 22 May In 2018 I wrote to the state asking when a phonobsorbent soil would be laid on the road to Florissant. It was said that this work was important and would be undertaken next year, i.e. in 2019. As can be seen, nothing has been done on this extremely noisy and especially very inhabited road, as well as on Avenue Eugène-Pittard. While we are talking about introducing the speed of 30 km/h in the city, would it not be better to place this very efficient flooring in the very inhabited arteries? Whether the speed is set at 30 or 50 km/h, the noise of starting a car is of the same intensity and the road of Florissant is minced by pedestrian crossings which require the complete stop of the vehicle and therefore the subsequent restart. Marianne Herzog Une Cité de la musique futile Grand-Saconnex, May 18, This project, out of measure, dates back to a past era. It no longer meets today's needs, let alone future needs. Operating rates are far from reality and above all far too optimistic. No cultural institution operates without grants. Today, the OSR is struggling to fill the Victoria Hall with 900 seats. The music lovers, an aging audience, lack of succession. Youth, despite the measures in place, remains the minority. The Covid and his descendants will maintain the restrictions dictated by Bern and change habits and behaviors. The streaming already in place will increase thanks to comfort. The future of teaching is the "Toile" as it already is; lessons in class will be the exception. An important subject, young people who leave the Conservatory no longer find commitment. The number of pupils will decrease and the 95 rooms are an aberration. The post-Covid world is not perceptible, which should encourage caution. [...] The destruction of this magnificent paradise of greenery, rare in the Place des Nations, is deplorable – we love our mother Nature – the slaughter of 126 trees and the atmospheric grip of this concrete mass will be very harmful to an environment already heavily impacted. Where are the climate advocates? Régina Bader Doing her duty as a citizen Geneva, 23 May Democracy exists only if one does his duty as a citizen, i.e. to vote with all benevolence. To vote yes for the CO2 law is to accept its responsibilities, is to take urgent measures to protect the climate. The CO2 law is a step towards a future without oil, natural gas and coal. It is also a step towards the end of the grip of a destructive and decadent elite on our lives. Failure to reduce CO2 emissions worldwide would have devastating consequences for our livelihoods. This is one of the greatest challenges of our time, it is about saving the world. To hell with our achievements, to hell with our so-called economic well-being, to hell with our selfishness, the time has come to really change the future and take over our destiny. 'Dans les classes supérieures, 30 francs de plus devront être payés pour chaque catégorie de vol.', 'Question logique: quels seront les effets d’un tel régime sur la demande de transport aérien et diminueraient de 16%», évaluent les experts de l’E4S.', 'Hausse des émissions Ces seules données prennent une dimension toute particulière au regard de certaines réalités du transport aérien en Suisse.', 'Dans ce pays, l’aviation est le seul secteur dont les émissions de CO2 ont continué de croître au cours des dix dernières années.', 'Cela ne permet cependant pas de déduire que les plus importants acteurs de la branche ne font rien.', '«Au cours des vingt-cinq dernières années, nous avons rendu nos vols plus durables et plus efficients.', 'Nous renouvellerons notre flotte dès cet automne avec cinq Airbus A320 neo.', 'Ceux-ci émettent jusqu’à 15% de CO2 de moins que les modèles précédents», se félicite le directeur exécutif d’Easyjet Switzerland, Jean-Marc Thévenaz.', 'Philippe processed_text: Flying and pollute less with a new air transport tax Researchers at the Enterprise for Society centre reveal the main effects of a possible air ticket tax. The new CO2 law includes a tax on airline tickets. Researchers at the Enterprise for Society (E4S), an institution from UNIL, IMD and EPFL, have just published an in-depth study on the effects of such a tax. Conclusion in case of approval by the people: we will steal less, we will pollute less. Brief reminder of the nature of this tax. From Switzerland, in economy class, an additional 30 francs will be required for a short-haul flight, 60 francs for a medium-haul flight and 90 francs for a long-haul flight. In the higher classes, an additional 30 francs will be required for each category of flight. Logical question: what will be the effects of such a regime on air transport demand and the climate impact of this industry? "Our simulations suggest that the scheduled fee schedule would reduce the number of passengers from 13 to 21%. After the Covid-19 experience, however, the elasticity of demand for air travel should be closer to – 21%. In particular for work-related trips", says Philippe Thalmann, one of the authors of the White Paper on the introduction of a tax on airline tickets in Switzerland. The contribution of this facility to the environment would not be negligible either. "Air transport CO2 emissions would decrease by 16%," experts from E4S estimate. Emissions increase These data alone take on a particular dimension in view of certain realities of air transport in Switzerland. In this country, aviation is the only sector whose CO2 emissions have continued to grow over the past decade. This, however, does not make it clear that the most important players in the industry are doing nothing. "Over the past 25 years, we have made our flights more sustainable and efficient. We will renew our fleet this fall with five Airbus A320 neo. They emit up to 15% less CO2 than previous models," says the Executive Director of Easyjet Switzerland, Jean-Marc Thévenaz. Philippe Rodrik "The scheduled fee schedule would reduce the number of passengers from 13 to 21%." Philippe Thalmann Co-author of the "White Paper" d'E4S

le coprésident des Jeunes Verts suisses, Oleg Gafner, ce résultat n’est pas si surprenant.', '«Il y a dans cette tranche d’âge des gens qui ont déjà un train de vie, qui connaissent leurs dépenses et qui calculent l’effet des taxes prévues dans la loi.', 'Et, dans le contexte économique actuel, cette crainte peut expliquer cette tendance», analyse-t-il.', 'Rien n’est encore perdu, selon lui.', '«La campagne est encore timide et, surtout, elle est très classique et ne parle pas beaucoup aux jeunes.', 'Il manque encore de la mobilisation», souligne-t-il.', 'Pour rappel, la loi prévoit notamment de taxer davantage l’essence, le mazout et les billets d’avion.', 'Fruit de trois ans de débats parlementaires sur deux législatures, le texte est largement soutenu dans le camp écologiste, opposants.', 'Loin, très loin derrière les critiques portant sur des motifs financiers.', 'Entre ceux qui estiment que «le problème du climat ne se résout pas avec les taxes et les impôts mais avec de avis défavorables.', 'Les taxes occultent tout Tout ne serait donc qu’une question d’argent, et elle serait d’autant plus importante pour les portemonnaie de la jeune génération.', 'Un effet accentué par la pandémie et le manque de perspectives qu’elle provoque.', 'Et, plus simplement, certains ont envie de voyager sans s’endetter davantage.', 'Quant au fait que ces taxes soient redistribuées à la prévue ce vendredi.', 'Résultats du sondage Tamedia pour la votation concernant la loi sur le CO2 «Pour un jeune, voir le prix de son billet d’avion pour Barcelone augmenter après une année sans avoir This is what the second Tamedia poll (publisher of this newspaper) published this Wednesday reveals. 51% of respondents in this category would refuse the text and 45% would support it. As age groups rise, the proportion is inverse to 57% of favourable intentions among 65 and over. This figure should be relativized, since the first SSR survey, which was unveiled by the GfS.bern Institute on 7 May, reported approval of 62% among 18-39 year-olds, but still below the senior (65% yes). On the other hand, weaker support from young people was already evident in our first survey and it has since collapsed by 7 points. Above all, this second Tamedia survey reveals that the yes to the CO2 law loses 4 points to reach just 50%. With 4% of the vote undecided, the suspense therefore remained at a little more than three weeks from the vote. Lack of Mobilization Could the youth vote be the law? For the Swiss Young Greens Co-President, Oleg Gafner, this result is not so surprising. "In this age group there are people who already have a life course, who know their expenses and who calculate the effect of the taxes provided for in the law. And in the current economic context, this fear can explain this trend," he analyses. Nothing is lost, according to him. "The campaign is still timid and, above all, it is very classic and does not talk much to young people. There is still a lack of mobilization," he stresses. As a reminder, the law provides for increased taxes on petrol, fuel oil and airline tickets. The text is widely supported in the environmental camp, but the Young Greens are not a vile critic. "Many people would have liked a text that actually goes further and proposes a real paradigm shift. However, voting no would waste valuable time," adds Oleg Gafner. He assures that he will slip a yes into the urn. It is recalled that sections of the climate strikers had supported the referendum to sanction this law deemed too soft. But this argument does not seem to be the one that explains the disaffection of the younger ones. It is only mentioned in 1% of the cases of opponents. Far behind criticism of financial motives. Among those who believe that "the climate problem is not solved with taxes and taxes but with innovation", those who consider that a "family of four will have an extra 1000 francs of taxes" and others who claim that "these instruments harm the economy", 72% of the unfavourable opinions are cumulated. Taxes hide everything So everything would be just a matter of money, and it would be all the more important for the younger generation's wallets. An effect accentuated by the pandemic and the lack of prospects it causes. And, more simply, some people want to travel without going into debt. As for the fact that these taxes are redistributed to the population by a reduction in health insurance premiums or through a climate fund, the respondents remain deaf. "For a young person, seeing the price of his plane ticket to Barcelona increase after a year without travelling is much more palpable than the idea of a climate fund," says Nicolas Jutzet, Vice-President of the Young Swiss Liberals-Radicaux, who left the freedom to vote. This difficult aspect is shared by the Young Greens. They are also relying on what has built their success with a strike "for the future" scheduled this Friday. Results of the Tamedia poll for the vote on the CO2 law "For a young person, seeing the price of his plane ticket to Barcelona increase after a year without having travelled is much more palpable than the idea of a climate fund." Nicolas Jutzet Vice-President of the Young Swiss Liberals-Radicaux

text: ["«La mobilité électrique deviendra le nouveau standard» VOTATIONS Le TCS est l'unique organisation du monde automobile à défendre la loi sur le CO2.", 'Seule une minorité de membres se sont montrés déçus au point de démissionner.', 'Le président du club, Peter Goetschi, juge la transition écologique de la mobilité nécessaire et défend le libre choix du moyen de transport  BERNARD WUTHRICH , BERNE @BdWuthrich  Malgré la hausse annoncée du prix de l’essence de 10 à 12 centimes par litre au maximum, le président du TCS, Peter Goetschi, juge la nouvelle loi sur le CO2 «acceptable» et recommande de voter oui.', 'Le TCS a décidé de soutenir la loi sur le CO2, contrairement aux autres organisations de la branche automobile.', 'Quelle mouche l’at-elle piqué?', 'Nous avons eu des discussions intenses au sujet de cette loi et ce n’est pas une piqûre de mouche qui nous aurait influencés (rires).', 'Nous en avons examiné les conséquences pour nos membres.', 'Nous avons constaté qu’elle leur garantissait le libre choix du moyen de transport, ne contenait aucune interdiction et comportait un plafond pour les coûts de compensation.', 'Nous en sommes arrivés à la conclusion qu’il s’agissait d’un compromis acceptable, même si la loi n’est de loin pas parfaite.', 'Elle ne restreint pas la mobilité individuelle: c’est notre objectif principal aujourd’hui comme dans dix, vingt, trente ou quarante ans.', 'Le TCS soutient ainsi une loi qui prévoit d’augmenter le prix de l’essence et du diesel de 10 à 12 centimes par litre.', 'Comment justifiez-vous cette position vis-à-vis de vos membres?', 'La loi actuelle permet déjà de répercuter, jusqu’à 5 centimes par litre, la compensation pour l’importation de carburants.', 'En réalité, ce n’est que 1,5 centime qui est facturé aux consommateurs.', 'Le plafond va effectivement passer à 10, puis à 12 centimes dès 2025.', 'Mais c’est un tarif maximal.', 'Nous avons fait le calcul.', 'Prenons une consommation moyenne de 7,3 litres pour 100 kilomètres et 13 500 kilomètres par an.', 'Cela représente une dépense supplémentaire de 99 francs si on applique le montant maximal de 12 centimes.', 'Ce n’est pas anodin, c’est vrai, et cela ne comprend pas la hausse de la taxe sur les combustibles ni celle sur les billets d’avion.', 'Mais la Suisse a pris l’engagement de réduire ses émissions de CO2 et la mobilité, qui en génère 30 à 40%, doit y contribuer.', 'Cela nous paraît donc acceptable.', 'Quelles réactions avez-vous reçues de vos membres?', 'Le TCS compte 1,5 million de membres.', 'A ce jour, nous avons enregistré environ 70 résiliations liées à notre position sur la loi sur le CO2.', 'Nous les regrettons évidemment et cherchons le contact personnel avec ces membres.', 'Mais, vu globalement, il s’agit d’un nombre limité et, malgré la crise du Covid-19, notre croissance est supérieure à celle des années précédentes.', 'Les habitants des régions périphériques seront davantage touchés par les effets de la loi sur le CO2.', 'Le TCS les abandonne-t-il à leur sort?', 'Bien sûr que non.', 'Certes, l’offre de transports publics est moins étendue dans ces régions et il était particulièrement crucial pour leurs habitants de plafonner l’augmentation.', 'Ils auront aussi la possibilité de changer progressivement de véhicule.', 'Les prescriptions sont de plus en plus sévères, la consommation au kilomètre diminue, les constructeurs offrent de plus en plus de véhicules électriques et hybrides à des prix de plus en plus abordables, et cela dans toute la gamme.', 'D’autres technologies comme l’hydrogène sont aussi prometteuses.', 'Ainsi, la nécessaire transition écologique devient possible.', 'Mais il y a encore un effort à faire pour disposer d’une infrastructure de recharge performante.', 'Le fonds climatique prévoit précisément de subventionner l’installation de stations de recharge dans les immeubles.', 'Oui, mais ce n’est qu’un premier soutien timide.', 'Il faudra davantage de moyens.', 'Je suis convaincu que la mobilité électrique deviendra le nouveau standard.', 'Il faudra donc des stations de recharge en grande quantité, dans les domaines privé et public.', 'Le propriétaire de sa maison n’a aucune difficulté à installer la sienne.', 'Le locataire doit convaincre son propriétaire ou sa régie immobilière.', 'Le TCS s’engage-t-il dans cette transition?', 'Notre Académie de la mobilité était pionnière dans la mobilité électrique il y a dix ans et nous poursuivons dans cette direction de façon ciblée.', 'D’un côté, nos patrouilleurs doivent être capables de résoudre une panne qui survient sur un moteur électrique.', 'De l’autre, il y a un énorme besoin d’informations fiables et neutres dans ce domaine qui souffre de plusieurs mythes infondés.', 'Enfin, avec la mobilité électrique, on ne change pas simplement de carburant, on change de mobilité.', 'On ne recharge pas une batterie comme on fait le plein à la station-service.', 'Il faut des stations de recharge à la maison, au travail, voire aux deux endroits.', 'C’est un grand défi.', 'Le TCS fête cette année ses 125 ans.', 'Le soutien à la loi sur le CO2 marque-t-il une étape dans son évolution, un positionnement plus «vert» que par le passé?', 'Au départ, le TCS avait été créé par des cyclistes qui réclamaient des routes goudronnées.', 'Au fil des décennies, les attentes de nos membres ont évolué: ils ont voulu des axes de circulation performants, un niveau élevé de sécurité routière, des services de dépannage, etc.', 'Nous nous sommes toujours adaptés à ces nouveaux besoins.', 'Aujourd’hui, ils ne se déplacent plus uniquement en voiture.', 'Ils sont attentifs à toutes les offres de mobilité.', 'Notre soutien à la loi sur le CO2 n’est pas un «virage vert», mais la suite logique de cette adaptation constante aux demandes de nos membres.', 'Soucieux d’assurer un financement durable et de partager équitablement l’espace public, qui n’est pas extensible, le TCS avait aussi soutenu la création des fonds routier et ferroviaire et le contre-projet à l’initiative pour le vélo.', 'En défendant trop le libre choix du moyen de transport, le TCS ne se met-il pas en danger lui-même?', 'Non.', 'La mobilité devient de plus en plus multimodale.', 'Le temps de l’opposition des différents modes de transport est révolu.', 'Nous ne voulons pas obliger nos membres à posséder une voiture pour faire partie du TCS, mais leur permettre de vivre leur mobilité en choisissant librement leur moyen de transport.', 'Peter Goetschi, président du TCS: «La Suisse a pris l’engagement de réduire ses émissions de CO2, et la mobilité, qui en génère 30 à 40%, doit y contribuer.', 'Cela nous paraît donc acceptable.» (MARCO ZANONI/LUNAX POUR LE TEMPS)  «Notre soutien à la loi sur le CO2 n’est pas un «virage vert», mais la suite logique de l’adaptation constante aux demandes de nos membres»  PETER GOETSCHI, PRÉSIDENT DU TCS']
processed_text: "Electric mobility will become the new standard" VOTATIONS The TCS is the only organization in the automotive world to defend the CO2 law. Only a minority of members were so disappointed that they resigned. The club's president, Peter Goetschi, considers the ecological transition of mobility necessary and defends the free choice of means of transport BERNARD WUTHRICH, BERNE @BdWuthrich Despite the announced increase in the price of gasoline from 10 to 12 cents per litre to the maximum, the president of the TCS, Peter Goetschi, considers the new CO2 law "acceptable" and recommends to vote yes. The TCS has decided to support the CO2 law, unlike other organizations in the automotive industry. What fly is it stinging? We had intense discussions about this law and it was not a fly bite that would have influenced us (laughs). We examined the implications for our members. We found that it guaranteed them the free choice of means of transport, contained no prohibitions and contained a ceiling on compensation costs. We have come to the conclusion that this was an acceptable compromise, even if the law is by far not perfect. It does not restrict individual mobility: it is our main objective today as in ten, twenty, thirty or forty years. In this way, the TCS supports a law that provides for an increase in the price of gasoline and diesel from 10 to 12 cents per litre. How do you justify this position vis-à-vis your members? The current law already allows for the transfer, up to 5 cents per litre, of the compensation for the importation of fuels. In fact, only 1.5 cents are charged to consumers. The ceiling will actually rise to 10, then 12 cents as early as 2025. But it's a maximum rate. We did the math. Let's take an average consumption of 7.3 litres per 100 kilometres and 13,500 kilometres per year. This represents an additional expenditure of 99 francs if the maximum amount of 12 cents is applied. This is not annoyance, it is true, and it does not include the increase in the fuel tax or the increase in the tax on airline tickets. However, Switzerland has made a commitment to reduce its CO2 emissions and mobility, which generates 30 to 40%, must contribute to this. That is acceptable to us. What reactions have you received from your members? The TCS has 1.5 million members. To date, we have recorded approximately 70 terminations related to our position on the CO2 law. Of course, we regret them and seek personal contact with them. But, overall, it is a limited number and, despite the crisis of the Covid-19, our growth is higher than in previous years. The effects of the CO2 law will further affect the inhabitants of the peripheral regions. Does the CTF abandon them to their fate? Of course not. Of course, the supply of public transport is less extensive in these regions and it was particularly crucial for their inhabitants to cap the increase. They will also have the opportunity to gradually change vehicles. The requirements are becoming more stringent, the consumption per kilometre is declining, manufacturers are increasingly offering electric and hybrid vehicles at increasingly affordable prices, and this is happening across the range. Other technologies such as hydrogen are also promising. Thus, the necessary ecological transition becomes possible. But there is still an effort to have a high-performance charging infrastructure. The climate fund specifically provides for subsidies for the installation of charging stations in buildings. Yes, but it's just a shy first support. More resources will be needed. I am convinced that electric mobility will become the new standard. This will require large quantities of charging stations, both in the private and public sectors. The owner of his house has no difficulty installing his own. The tenant must convince his owner or his real estate authority. Does the TCS commit to this transition? Our Mobility Academy was a pioneer in electrical mobility ten years ago and we are continuing in this direction in a targeted manner. On one side, our patrollers must be able to solve a breakdown that occurs on an electric motor. On the other hand, there is a huge need for reliable and neutral information in this field which suffers from several unfounded myths. Finally, with electric mobility, we do not simply change fuel, we change mobility. We don't charge a battery like we're filling up at the gas station. Recharging stations are required at home, at work, or in both places. It's a big challenge. The TCS celebrates its 125th anniversary this year. Is support for the CO2 law a step in its evolution, a more "green" position than in the past? Initially, the TCS was created by cyclists seeking paved roads. Over the decades, the expectations of our members have changed: they have wanted efficient roads, a high level of road safety, troubleshooting services, etc. We have always adapted to these new needs. Today, they are no longer only travelling by car. They are attentive to all mobility offers. Our support for the CO2 law is not a "green turn", but the logical continuation of this constant adaptation to the demands of our members. In an effort to ensure sustainable funding and to share the public space, which is not extensible, the TCS also supported the creation of road and rail funds and the counter-project for the bicycle initiative. By defending too much the free choice of means of transport, does not the TCS itself put itself at risk? No. Mobility is becoming increasingly multimodal. The time for opposition of the different modes of transport has passed. We do not want to force our members to own a car to be part of the TCS, but to allow them to live their mobility by freely choosing their means of transport. Peter Goetschi, President of the TCS: "Switzerland has made a commitment to reduce its CO2 emissions, and mobility, which generates 30 to 40%, must contribute to this. This seems acceptable to us." (MARCO ZANONI/LUNAX FOR TIME) "Our support for the CO2 law is not a "green shift", but the logical follow-up of the constant adaptation to the demands of our members" PETER GOETSCHI, CHS PRESIDENT
author: Peter Goetschi

effectués.', 'Chaque habitant devrait recevoir en retour 60 francs.', '4.', 'Le fonds climat: balle au centre Ce fonds sera alimenté par un tiers de la taxe CO2 sur les combustibles et par la moitié processed_text: Cities or countryside, who will pay the bill? To reduce CO2 emissions, the revision introduces taxes on fuel oil, gasoline or theft. The point on the winners and losers. Florent Quiquerez Bern On one side, there is the fight against global warming, on the other side its effect on the purse. Between supporters and opponents of the new CO2 law, the war of numbers rages over new taxes on petrol, heating or theft. Simonetta Sommaruga, a federal adviser in charge of the case, speaks of an additional annual cost of 100 francs for a family of four. In the event of virtuous behaviour, the bill could even be reduced to zero. Fountain, retort the opponents, for whom the bill will be much more expensive. The UDC refers to an additional cost of up to 1000 francs per year for a family of four. The people in the countryside are the ones who would suffer the most. Who's right, who's wrong? To find out, we have identified the four emblematic points of the law that was put to the vote on 13 June. And, in this city-country match, losers and winners get confused. 1. Gasoline: the rural losers Life in the countryside is often dependent on one or even two cars. On average, distances travelled in rural areas are longer than in agglomerations, according to the 2015 figures of the Federal Statistical Office (OFS) on mobility. The increase in the price of petrol will thus affect the inhabitants of the peripheries more, provided that they have not invested in an electric vehicle. However, this increase is not very clear. In the law, the Federal Council does not impose price increases, but allows importers of petrol and diesel to have a greater impact on motorists on the new targets set by Bern to offset CO2 emissions from transport. The maximum cap is now 12 cents per litre. In theory, this could result in an additional 180 fr bill for a vehicle with average fuel consumption and mileage. But not sure that importers use this margin of manoeuvre. Today, to remain competitive, they take only 1.5 cents per litre, while it could puncture up to 5 cents. 2. Heating: ball in the center With the new law, the Federal Council can increase the tax on fossil fuels (mazout, natural gas, coal) to 210 francs per tonne of CO2, compared to 120 today. That would be 50 cents per litre of fuel oil versus 30 today. LUDC believes that rural housing is larger and therefore more penalized. According to the NZZ, which cites a study by Wüest Partner, there are no significant differences between urban and rural areas. The question remains of the price to change the system: 100-000 to 150-000 francs, must be invested for a complete renovation of the house, according to the UDC – and in particular for its insulation. If aid is provided, more owners are found in peripheral regions. An argument to be counterbalanced with the share of dwellings that no longer use fossil fuels. According to the 2015 OFS building figures, more than 1 million buildings are still heated with gas or oil. Proportionally, there are more in urban cantons and less in rural areas. In Valais, 53% of households no longer use fossil fuels. This is 30% in the canton of Vaud and only 13% in Geneva. These households will win with the new law. According to the Federal Office for the Environment (OFEV), a family of four who does not heat oil or natural gas will be reimbursed CHF 348 per year from the CO2 tax. 3. Flights: the losing urbans The new airfare tax will be 30 to 120 francs per flight. And on this point too, it is more urban people who will break down. According to OFS, the inhabitants of cities are more likely to fly than those of the peripheries – almost one flight per year on average for the former, about one every two years for the latter – and fly further. In the case of the airline ticket tax, only the 10% of the population who use this most frequent means of travel should ultimately pay a surcharge, says Confederation. The remaining 90% of the population would benefit financially. More than half of the proceeds of this tax will be distributed evenly to the population. This amount must be deducted from health insurance premiums, regardless of the number of flights performed. Each inhabitant should receive 60 francs in return. 4. The climate fund: ball in the centre This fund will be financed by one third of the CO2 tax on fuels and by half of the tax on airline tickets. Other sources will still pay, like half of the penalties paid by importers whose vehicles exceed Bern's CO2 emission limits. It is difficult to say whether it will benefit the cities or the countryside, as the beneficiaries are multiple. Mountain regions will receive support for measures to prevent the dangers of climate change. The cities could also find themselves there, in the case of, for example, the acquisition of electric buses or the installation of a remote heating network better suited to urban centres. Federal votes
author: Florent Quiquerez Bern

text: ['Berne conteste une hausse des loyers de 140 francs par mois si le oui l’emporte Loi sur le CO2 Contrairement à ce que dit une association de propriétaires, les loyers ne devraient pas augmenter.', 'En cas d’acceptation de la loi sur le CO2 le 13 juin, le loyer d’un appartement de 100 m² augmentera en moyenne de 140 francs.', 'C’est ce qu’affirme l’Association suisse des propriétaires fonciers (HEV) dans une campagne médiatique.D’après elle, la hausse, qualifiée de «pillage du porte-monnaie des locataires», serait due aux «assainissements obligatoires» induits par les «prescriptions irréalistes» du texte.', 'Ces arguments font sortir de ses gonds Carlo Sommaruga, président de l’Asloca.', '«L’annonce prétend que la loi sur le CO2 sera un pillage des bourses des locataires alors que celui-ci a lieu en ce moment, avant même l’entrée en vigueur de la loi, avec un niveau des loyers qui augmente chaque année, et cela par la volonté des bailleurs d’augmenter leurs rendements», s’énerve le conseiller aux États genevois.', 'Pour l’élu socialiste, on ne peut pas affirmer que les loyers vont prendre l’ascenseur en cas de oui.', '«Les assainissements ne seront pas obligatoires.', 'Ils devront être faits si les autres mesures ne suffisent pas.', 'Et, dans ce cas, il faudra prendre en compte les autres facteurs de fixation du loyer, dont les baisses des taux hypothécaires, détaille Carlo Sommaruga.', 'Il pourra donc y avoir une baisse, une stabilité ou une légère augmentation.', 'Chaque cas sera différent mais il n’y aura par contre pas une hausse de 140 francs.»  Ce chiffre se base sur une étude de l’Office fédéral de l’énergie (OFEN), précise le HEV.', 'Or, ce même office, contacté par nos soins ce lundi, réfute être arrivé à cette conclusion dans son rapport de 2015.', '«Nous ne pouvons pas reconstruire ce chiffre sur la base de l’étude.', 'Donc nous ne savons pas quels sont les calculs du HEV», indique Marianne Zünd, porte-parole de l’OFEN.', 'Elle précise que dix grandes propriétés avaient été examinées, ce qui ne constitue pas un échantillon représentatif.', 'L’OFEN précise au contraire que les locataires pourraient voir la facture professeur de politique climatique à l’EPFZ.', 'Elle devrait atteindre 100% dans la plupart des pays européens d’ici à 2030.» En tenant compte de la durée moyenne de circulation d’une voiture, l’ensemble des flottes pourraient être électriques en 2040.', 'Sur le marché européen, les ventes de voitures électriques et hybrides ont passé le million l’an passé, avec plus de 500?000 voitures purement électriques vendues.', 'Pour Anthony Patt, il s’agit d’un effet de la norme européenne obligeant les constructeurs à ne pas dépasser un seuil de 95 grammes d’émissions de CO2 par kilomètre pour les gammes de véhicules neufs.', '«Sans les voitures électriques, les constructeurs ne peuvent pas atteindre cet objectif», souligne-t-il.', 'Des batteries plus efficaces Face à ces mesures, les marques automobiles ont investi dans la production de véhicules électriques et les modèles se multiplient.', 'Des investissements qui ont aussi permis aux voitures électriques de combler certaines de leurs lacunes durant les dix dernières années.', '«L’autonomie moyenne est passée de 100\xa0km en 2010 à 300\xa0km en 2020, souligne Luca Maillard de l’Association transports et environnement (ATE).', 'Techniquement, elle pourrait encore être beaucoup augmentée mais\xa0une autonomie de 300\xa0km est largement suffisante pour couvrir les besoins standard.» Aujourd’hui, les véhicules les plus prendre de pause.»  La vitesse de charge des batteries s’est aussi considérablement améliorée.', 'Les bornes de recharge rapide permettent d’effectuer un chargement en une vingtaine de minutes, mais ces dernières demandent des installations particulières du fait de la puissance délivrée.', '«Pour le chargement quotidien, elles ne sont pas nécessaires, nuance Anthony Patt.', 'En plus, elles ont tendance à dégrader plus vite la batterie.»  Globalement, depuis la publication de l’interview mentionnée en tête de cet article, les batteries ont connu trois changements majeurs.', 'Leur densité énergétique a été multipliée par trois, d’où l’augmentation de l’autonomie.', 'Leur durée de vie en nombre de charges s’est aussi allongée.', '«Actuellement, elles sont censées couvrir 200?000\xa0km, mais cette valeur dépend de nombreux facteurs liés à l’utilisation, précise Luca Maillard.', 'La plupart des constructeurs proposent une garantie d’une durée de huit\xa0ans.» Certains constructeurs annoncent désormais des batteries capables de passer le million de kilomètres.', 'Enfin, elles sont devenues beaucoup moins chères.', '«Leur coût a chuté de 90% en dix ans, détaille Anthony Patt.', 'Il fallait compter 1000\xa0francs par kilowattheure il y a dix ans mais on s’approche des 100\xa0francs par kilowattheure aujourd’hui.»  Un bilan écologique plus positif Sur le plan environnemental, la question de l’avantage des voitures électriques dépend de certains paramètres notamment liés à leur production.', '«La fabrication des batteries demande beaucoup d’énergie mais cette quantité ne cesse de diminuer», souligne Anthony Patt.', 'Selon certaines estimations, si une batterie est produite uniquement en utilisant des énergies d’origine fossile, il faut parcourir environ 100?000 kilomètres avec une voiture électrique pour commencer à observer une réduction des émissions par rapport à une voiture à combustion.', 'Mais aujourd’hui, les constructeurs prennent en compte l’approvisionnement en énergie de leurs usines dans leurs plans de développement.', 'La question de l’absence d’une filière industrielle de recyclage de ces batteries pose encore problème.', '«Techniquement, il est possible d’arriver à une réutilisation quasiment intégrale des matières premières des composants des batteries, y compris du lithium», affirme Luca Maillard, mais aujourd’hui le faible volume de batteries usagées et les coûts élevés qui en découlent freinent la mise en place de cette filière.', "L'instauration de réglementations obligeant à recycler ces batteries pourrait débloquer la situation.", 'Globalement, le bilan environnemental des véhicules électriques est aujourd’hui meilleur que celui des voitures classiques.', '«Pour les véhicules à combustion, il faut aussi prendre en compte les effets liés au transport du pétrole et l’impact des marées noires», rappelle Anthony Patt.', 'Cette différence se vérifie malgré la tendance des SUV, qui domine aujourd’hui l’industrie automobile, y compris dans l’électrique.', '«Parmi les nouveaux modèles électriques mis sur le marché, un modèle sur deux est un SUV, constate Luca Maillard.', 'Mais un SUV électrique électriques dépendra essentiellement de l’origine de l’électricité qui doit les alimenter.', '«Pour parvenir à l’objectif de la neutralité carbone en 2050, il faudra développer la production 'Si la voiture électrique est aujourd’hui un élément de réponse, ce changement doit s’accompagner d’une réflexion plus large sur la mobilité et une diminution de l’usage des véhicules motorisés individuels.']
processed_text: In ten years, the leap forward of the electric car A few days before the vote on the CO2 law, an interview published by Le Temps resurfaced. In the latter, a professor at the EPFZ felt that the emergence of the electric car was unlikely. But ten years later, the data advanced in this article has changed well Etienne Meyer-... "The electric car is an aberration", this is the title of an interview published in 2011 by Le Temps, returned to the front of our site last weekend in the list of the most read articles. In this interview, Lino Guzzella, professor at the EPFZ, questioned about the future of the electric car, says, given in support, that it should not emerge in the next twenty years. With a limited range, battery loading time and cost, he felt that electric vehicles should remain the preserve of a small minority. But ten years later, as several readers have pointed out, this data is no longer up to date. This is not the first time that this text has been exhumed from the internet limbs, but two days before the vote on the CO2 law, it seemed important to us to come back to the question of the electric car and its role in reducing polluting emissions. Millions of sales at the European level In 2020 in Switzerland, 13,200 new electric powered cars were sold to which 26?400 hybrids were added, representing respectively 4.2% and 8% of the 312?900 new vehicles put into service during the year. "The market share of electric vehicles in sales of new cars is growing much faster than expected," says Anthony Patt, professor of climate policy at EPFZ. It is expected to reach 100% in most European countries by 2030." Taking into account the average duration of car traffic, all fleets could be electric by 2040. On the European market, sales of electric and hybrid cars have passed a million last year, with more than 500,000 purely electric cars sold. For Anthony Patt, this is an effect of the European standard requiring manufacturers not to exceed a threshold of 95 grams of CO2 emissions per kilometre for new vehicle ranges. "Without electric cars, manufacturers cannot achieve this goal," he stresses. More efficient batteries In the face of these measures, car brands have invested in the production of electric vehicles and models are increasing. Investments that have also enabled electric cars to fill some of their gaps over the past ten years. "The average range increased from 100 km in 2010 to 300 km in 2020," says Luca Maillard of the Transport and Environment Association (ATE). Technically, it could still be greatly increased but a range of 300 km is largely sufficient to cover the standard needs." Today, the most efficient vehicles can travel up to 600 km without charging. "This limit is no longer a loss of comfort," added Anthony Patt. It is rare to travel this kind of distance without taking a break." The battery charging speed has also improved considerably. The rapid charging stations allow for a load in about 20 minutes, but the latter require special installations due to the power delivered. "For daily loading, they are not necessary, shade Anthony Patt. In addition, they tend to degrade the battery faster." Overall, since the publication of the interview mentioned at the top of this article, the batteries have undergone three major changes. Their energy density has been multiplied by three, hence the increase in autonomy. Their service life in number of loads has also increased. "Currently, they are expected to cover 200?000 km, but this value depends on many factors related to use," says Luca Maillard. Most manufacturers offer an eight-year warranty." Some manufacturers are now announcing batteries capable of passing one million kilometres. Finally, they have become much cheaper. "Their cost has fallen by 90% in ten years," says Anthony Patt. It was necessary to count 1000 francs per kilowatt hour ten years ago but we are approaching 100 francs per kilowatt hour today."A more positive environmental assessment The environmental benefit of electric cars depends on certain parameters, particularly those related to their production. "The production of batteries requires a lot of energy, but this amount is constantly decreasing," says Patt. Some estimates suggest that if a battery is produced only using fossil-derived energies, it is necessary to travel about 100,000 kilometres with an electric car to start observing a reduction in emissions from a combustion car. But today, manufacturers take into account the energy supply of their plants in their development plans. The lack of an industrial recycling industry for these batteries is still a problem. "Technically, it is possible to achieve almost complete reuse of raw materials from battery components, including lithium," says Luca Maillard, "but today the low volume of used batteries and the high costs that result from them hinder the establishment of this industry. The introduction of regulations requiring the recycling of these batteries could unblock the situation. Overall, the environmental performance of electric vehicles is now better than that of conventional cars. "For combustion vehicles, account must also be taken of the effects of oil transport and the impact of oil spills," says Anthony Patt. This difference is true despite the trend of SUVs, which now dominates the automotive industry, including in electricity. "Among the new electric models put on the market, one in two models is a SUV," says Maillard. But an electric SUV keeps a better carbon balance than a combustion SUV, but the difference is less clear than with a small electric car."The reduction in emissions allowed by electric cars will depend essentially on the origin of the electricity that needs to supply them. "To achieve the goal of carbon neutrality in 2050, renewable energy production will have to be developed anyway," says Patt. The transition to the electric car must be made in parallel with this transition." However, one point has not changed in ten years. If the electric car is now an element of response, this change must be accompanied by a broader reflection on mobility and a reduction in the use of individual motor vehicles.

processed_text: Greenhouse gas emissions in slight decline ATMOSPHERE Switzerland is expected to miss its "climate target" by 2020. It is still very far away this year ATS In 2019, Switzerland emitted 46.2 million tonnes of CO2 equivalents. This is about 0.3 million tonnes less than the previous year, says the Federal Office for the Environment (OFEV) on Monday. Environmental organizations say they are "shocked" by this stagnation. Emissions are 14% lower than in the base year, 1990. According to current estimates, Switzerland is expected to miss its 2020 climate target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 20% compared to 1990. In order to significantly reduce emissions, it is essential to strengthen measures, as provided for in the CO2 law, according to OFEV. In the construction sector, emissions remained the same as in the previous year. They represent a total decrease of 34% compared to 1990. This stability, despite a colder winter, is mainly due to improved energy efficiency in buildings and the increasing replacement of oil and gas heating systems with heat pumps and renewable energies. The strong influence of winter temperatures on emissions shows that the building sector continues to heat mostly with fossil fuels, says OFEV. Taking the climate factor into account, emissions in this sector are decreasing by 0.3 million tonnes per year, which is not enough to meet its target of a 40% reduction until 2020. Transportation sector in difficulty Industry emissions also remained unchanged in 2019. Compared to 1990, the decline is 14%. These emissions have been stagnant for several years and if this trend continues, the 20% reduction target until 2020 will be missed. In the transport sector, emissions amounted to about 15 million tonnes of CO2 equivalents in 2019, as in the previous year, 1% higher than the level reached in 1990. More energy efficient vehicles emitted less CO2 per kilometre. But these positive effects are offset by the increase in the number of kilometres travelled.

processed_text: Reflections by a liberal Green on plant health initiatives and the CO2 OPINION law. On June 13, the people will be called to vote on two social projects, writes the Vaudian Green MEP Claude-Alain Gebhard. Their objectives are perfectly commendable and realistically applicable. But it takes more time for Claude-Alain Gebhard, Green MEP at the Grand Conseil Vaudois We must take a position on the CO2 law adopted by Parliament on 25 September, which aims, in agreement with the implementation of the Paris Agreements, to reduce greenhouse gases by 50% by 2030 and an ambitious goal of achieving carbon neutrality by 2050. Surprisingly, this virtuous project is contested by referendum both by the UDC and by the ultra-ecologists, which seems rather suspicious as the arguments diverge... We will also have to decide on two initiatives, called "phytosanitary", aiming with some well-known differences to reach an agricultural production free of chemicals within eight to ten years. These agronomic objectives are theoretically possible for Switzerland, proof of this is organic production with its organic label Bourgeon, which perfectly meets these conditions. "We are already doing this," says Bio Suisse, the national federation of organic farming. However, organic production is currently practised only by 16% of Swiss farmers, the vast majority of mountain farmers who do not use any plant protection products because they are not necessary for their farms mainly herbariums because of the altitude. One or the other of these two initiatives, if accepted by the double majority of citizens and cantons, would require 84% of Swiss farmers to comply almost with the organic specifications in eight to ten years, which seems extremely short in relation to the deadlines of the CO2 law. Liberticide initiatives This project could nevertheless be perfectly feasible in a longer time and without going through these perfectly liberticid initiatives for a large majority of our peasants. Indeed, with an increase in the organic market share of around 16% per year and even 19% in 2020 under the impetus of the pandemic, we would reach at the current rate of almost 100% in less than 20 years. This slower pace would also have the immense advantage of allowing the market and our consumers to adapt progressively to the natural conversion of Swiss agriculture and society to organic. Indeed, this virtuous evolution will inevitably significantly increase the household basket, and this is all the more so if we force this evolution by putting pressure on agriculture, already so often unjustly stigmatized...This project could be perfectly achievable within a longer period of time A longer period will also better guarantee the maintenance of our food security, which was praised to more than 78% by the people on 27 September 2017. According to the FiBL (Research Station for Organic Agriculture), organic agriculture currently produces 20 to 30% less food than conventional agriculture. This lack of productivity should, however, be overcome in twenty to twenty-five years with massive investments in farmers' training and innovative agronomic research to develop organically-adapted plant varieties with greater resistance to diseases and pests. We can even imagine that organic agriculture and refinanced agronomic research can offer new jobs in our country in the future and thus respond to the loss of jobs in the tertiary sector, which shows serious signs of regression. The objectives of the CO2 law and of these two phytosanitary initiatives are perfectly commendable and realistically applicable. They can even generate jobs and added values, without losing food security if they are part of a realistic agenda and involve the entire economy. For this reason, without formally rejecting these ambitious company plans, I will vote yes to the CO2 law and twice not against plant health initiatives.

text: ['L’aviation suisse demande un grand bol d’air Aéroports, employeurs, syndicats se mobilisent pour que la branche de l’aviation puisse redémarrer.', 'Ils adoptent un manifeste qu’ils ont transmis au Conseil fédéral.', 'Ce document est critiqué par les militants du climat  Bernard Wuthrich  Le secteur de l’aviation se mobilise comme jamais.', 'Dans une démarche intitulée «Back in the air», il demande au Conseil fédéral d’agir afin de favoriser la reprise d’un secteur crucial pour l’économie suisse.', 'Signée par les directions des aéroports de Genève et Zurich, par l’association faîtière Aerosuisse, par les organisations patronales et par les syndicats, elle pose trois principes de base.', 'Premièrement, il ne doit y avoir aucune restriction de voyage entre les pays qui présentent un risque de contagion similaire.', 'Deuxièmement, les passagers vaccinés, guéris ou bénéficiant d’un test covid négatif doivent être libres d’entrer en Suisse, de s’y déplacer ou d’en sortir sans entrave autre qu’un test antigénique.', 'Troisièmement, l’état de santé de ces passagers doit être consigné dans un document numérisé harmonisé sur le plan international.', 'Ces revendications ont été remises au président de la Confédération, Guy Parmelin, jeudi à l’aéroport de Zurich.', '«Un petit marché intérieur» «La Suisse est un petit marché intérieur qui a besoin de liaisons aériennes directes dans le monde entier, pour les organisations internationales implantées à Genève, pour les multinationales, pour les branches exportatrices comme la pharma, l’horlogerie, les machines.', 'Le fret aérien représente 50% des exportations en termes de valeur et jusqu’à 82% pour les exportations intercontinentales», plaide le chef économiste d’Economiesuisse, Rudolf Minsch, partenaire de la démarche.', '«Je rappelle qu’on n’achète pas une machine à 2 millions de francs sur catalogue.', 'Les relations directes sont indispensables», ajoute-t-il.', 'Les syndicats se sont associés à la demande déposée par la branche.', '«La situation du personnel de la navigation aérienne est alarmante.', 'Deux tiers des employé·e·s sont au chômage partiel.', 'L’aéroport de Zurich tourne à 25%.', 'La Suisse est tributaire de ses relations internationales.', 'La Confédération exige un test négatif à l’entrée en Suisse par avion.', 'Elle ne l’exige pas pour les arrivées en train ou en voiture.', 'Ce désavantage doit être écarté», requiert Daniel Lampart, chef économiste de l’Union syndicale suisse (USS).', 'Les grévistes du climat protestent Comme la présidente du syndicat du personnel de cabine Kapers, Sandrine Nikolic-Fuss, il demande que le chômage partiel soit prolongé à 24 mois.', 'La branche de l’aviation espère que la situation se décantera d’ici à l’été, «période clé» pour la branche.', '«Les gens veulent voyager et sont prêts à le faire sur le premier avion», poursuit-elle.', '«Cette alliance entre employeurs et syndicats témoigne de l’importance de la liberté de voyager», résume le président d’Aerosuisse, le conseiller national Thomas Hurter (UDC/SH).', 'Mais est-ce compatible avec la volonté de rendre l’économie plus écologique au sortir de la pandémie?', 'La Grève du climat soulève cette question.', 'Elle juge les revendications de la branche aérienne «insoutenables et incompatibles avec les engagements pris par la Suisse dans le cadre de l’Accord de Paris sur le climat».', 'Par la voix d’Anna Lindermeier, les militants du climat rejettent ce qu’ils appellent «un retour à la situation d’avant la crise».', '«Le climat est un élément important.', 'L’aviation veut contribuer à l’améliorer, c’est pour cela que les compagnies acquièrent de nouveaux appareils et de nouveaux moteurs», répond Thomas Hurter.', 'En tant que syndicaliste de gauche, Daniel Lampart slalome entre la défense des intérêts des dizaines de milliers de salariés de la branche et celle du climat.', '«La Suisse est une petite économie ouverte qui ne peut pas se couper du monde.', 'Pour les longues distances, il n’y a pas d’autre solution que l’avion», argumente-t-il.', 'La taxe sur les billets d’avion, un obstacle?', 'Toutefois, l’un des instruments de la nouvelle politique climatique de la Confédération, dans le cadre de la loi sur le CO2, est l’introduction d’une taxe sur les billets d’avion.', 'Le Conseil fédéral en a précisé les modalités mercredi: ce sera 30\xa0francs pour les vols court-courriers, 60\xa0francs pour les moyen-courriers, 90\xa0francs pour les long-courriers, et 30\xa0francs de plus pour les déplacements en classe premium, affaires ou première.', 'Ce supplément ne risque-t-il pas d’entraver le redécollage de l’aviation?', '«La priorité consiste à raccorder efficacement notre pays au reste du monde.', 'Si l’aviation ne se relève pas de la crise actuelle, aucune taxe ne pourra être prélevée», répond laconiquement Thomas Hurter.', '«Il faut aussi que la branche profite de ces recettes», ajoute Rudolf Minsch.', 'Or, pour l’heure, il est prévu que 51% du produit de la taxe soit redistribué à la population et aux entreprises, les 49% restants étant affectés au futur fonds pour le climat, un fonds qui, souligne Daniel Lampart, pourra aussi être utilisé pour financer les trains de nuit en Europe.']
processed_text: Swiss aviation demands a large bowl of air Airports, employers, trade unions are mobilising so that the aviation industry can restart. They adopt a manifesto which they have transmitted to the Federal Council. This document is criticized by climate activists Bernard Wuthrich The aviation sector is mobilizing as never before. In an approach called "Back in the air", he asked the Federal Council to act in order to promote the recovery of a sector crucial to the Swiss economy. Signed by the Geneva and Zurich airport directorates, the Aerosuisse umbrella association, employers' organisations and trade unions, it sets out three basic principles. First, there should be no travel restrictions between countries that present a similar risk of contagion. Second, passengers vaccinated, cured or receiving a negative covid test must be free to enter Switzerland, move or leave without hindrance other than an antigenic test. Thirdly, the health status of these passengers must be recorded in an internationally harmonized digital document. These claims were handed over to the President of the Confederation, Guy Parmelin, on Thursday at Zurich Airport. "A small internal market" "Switzerland is a small internal market that needs direct air links around the world, for international organisations based in Geneva, for multinationals, for exporting industries such as pharma, watchmaking and machinery. Air freight accounts for 50% of exports in terms of value and up to 82% for intercontinental exports", argues the chief economist of the economysuisse, Rudolf Minsch, partner of the approach. "I recall that we don't buy a 2 million francs machine on catalogue. Direct relations are essential," he adds. The unions joined the industry's application. "The situation of air navigation personnel is alarming. Two thirds of employees are partially unemployed. Zurich airport turns 25%. Switzerland is dependent on its international relations. The Confederation requires a negative test when entering Switzerland by air. It does not require it for arrivals by train or car. This disadvantage must be ruled out", demands Daniel Lampart, chief economist of the Swiss Union of Trade Unions (USS). Climate strikers protest Like the president of the Kapers Cabin Staff Union, Sandrine Nikolic-Fuss, he asked that partial unemployment be extended to 24 months. The aviation industry hopes that the situation will be resolved by the summer, a "key period" for the industry. "People want to travel and are ready to do so on the first plane," she continues. "This alliance between employers and trade unions is a testament to the importance of freedom of travel," says Aerosuisse President, National Councillor Thomas Hurter (UDC/SH). But is it compatible with the desire to make the economy more environmentally friendly after the pandemic? The Climate Strike raises this issue. It considers the air industry's claims "unbearable and incompatible with Switzerland's commitments under the Paris Climate Agreement". By the voice of Anna Lindermeier, climate activists reject what they call "a return to the pre-crisis situation". "Climate is an important element. Aviation wants to help improve it, which is why the companies are acquiring new aircraft and engines," says Thomas Hurter. As a left-wing trade unionist, Daniel Lampart slaloms between the defence of the interests of tens of thousands of employees in the industry and that of the climate. "Switzerland is a small open economy that cannot be cut off from the world. For long distances, there is no alternative to the aeroplane," he argues. The tax on airline tickets, an obstacle? However, one of the instruments of the new climate policy of the Confederation, under the CO2 law, is the introduction of a tax on airline tickets. The Federal Council has specified the modalities of this on Wednesday: it will be 30 francs for short-haul flights, 60 francs for medium-haul flights, 90 francs for long-haul flights, and 30 francs for high-class trips, business or first class trips. Is this supplement not likely to hinder the re-alignment of aviation? "The priority is to connect our country effectively with the rest of the world. If aviation does not recover from the current crisis, no tax can be levied," says Thomas Hurter. "The industry must also benefit from these recipes," adds Rudolf Minsch. At present, 51% of the revenue from the tax is expected to be redistributed to the population and businesses, with the remaining 49% allocated to the future climate fund, a fund which, according to Daniel Lampart, can also be used to finance night trains in Europe.
