text: ['André Schneider: «La neutralité carbone en 2050 est un défi pour l’ensemble de l’aviation, chacun doit faire sa part»  Renouvellement des flottes, développement du marché des carburants alternatifs: à l’approche de la loi sur le CO2, le secteur suisse de l’aviation présente ses solutions.', 'André Schneider, directeur général de Genève Aéroport, estime que le secteur a les cartes en main pour atteindre cet objectif  Etienne Meyer-…  Quelques jours avant la votation sur la révision de la loi CO2 le 13\xa0juin, qui prévoit l’introduction d’une taxe sur les billets d’avion, le secteur de l’aviation présente sa feuille de route pour atteindre la neutralité carbone.', 'Ce document est le fruit d’un travail regroupant compagnies aériennes, aéroports, hautes écoles ainsi que l’Office fédéral de l’aviation civile (OFAC) et de l’Office fédéral de l’environnement (OFEV) à l’initiative de l’Aviation Research Center Switzerland (ARCS).', 'Pour André Schneider, directeur général de Genève Aéroport, et président de ce groupe de travail, cette étude apporte la preuve que l’aviation dispose des solutions pour atteindre le zéro émission net en 2050 conformément aux objectifs de la stratégie climatique du Conseil fédéral.', 'Le Temps: Cette feuille de route est-elle une réponse à la taxe sur les billets d’avion prévue par la loi CO2?', 'André Schneider: Nous voulions répondre aux discussions autour de l’aviation en général, pas spécifiquement à la loi CO2.', 'Il y a eu beaucoup de débats autour de l’aviation dont la finalité a été de dire que la seule option pour décarboner le secteur est de réduire le nombre de vols.', 'Nous voulions montrer que l’on peut maintenir notre offre en décarbonant les vols.', 'Nous vivons dans un monde globalisé, les gens ne vont pas cesser du jour au lendemain de prendre l’avion pour rendre visite à leur famille, au Portugal par exemple, en faisant 24 heures de route.', 'Cette étude prévoit une augmentation du nombre de passagers à Cointrin dans les décennies à venir.', 'Est-ce compatible avec une réduction des émissions?', 'Il y a trois scénarios.', 'Dans le cas le plus haut, nous atteindrions 25\xa0millions de passagers en 2040, mais l’hypothèse la plus vraisemblable selon nous est d’atteindre 21\xa0millions.', 'C’est une augmentation relativement faible sachant que nous étions déjà à 18\xa0millions avant la pandémie.', 'Pour Genève, l’objectif du net zéro est atteignable même avec cette augmentation.', 'Il faut aussi souligner qu’il ne s’agit pas pour nous, avec ces scénarios de passagers, d’un objectif à atteindre mais d’une projection pour pouvoir mettre en place une planification pour nos infrastructures.', 'Pour atteindre le net zéro dans l’aviation, les efforts ne concernent-ils pas plus les compagnies que les aéroports?', 'Les compagnies ont beaucoup à faire parce que les aéroports ont pris un peu d’avance dans ce domaine.', 'Aujourd’hui, par exemple, les bâtiments de l’aéroport de Genève construits ces cinq dernières années produisent plus d’énergie qu’ils n’en consomment.', 'Nous transformons aussi le trafic sur le tarmac en allant vers une motorisation électrique.', 'Mais il faut aussi reconnaître que c’est plus facile pour nous.', 'Cependant, ces dernières années, les compagnies ont réduit les émissions par passager transporté.', 'On ne peut pas dire que c’est seulement le problème des compagnies ou des aéroports.', 'C’est un défi qui concerne l’ensemble de l’industrie et chacun doit faire sa part.', 'Nous essayons d’aider les compagnies dans ce sens avec un programme d’incitations.', 'Une partie des taxes qu’elles paient chez nous leur est reversée si elles renouvellent leur flotte avec des avions de dernière génération, moins gourmands en kérosène et moins bruyants.', 'Selon cette feuille de route, une grande partie de la réduction des émissions repose surtout sur l’utilisation de carburants alternatifs.', 'Tout dépend de la temporalité dans laquelle on se place puisque les objectifs courent jusqu’à 2050.', 'Le renouvellement des flottes est aussi un point essentiel, puisque la nouvelle génération d’avions permet de réduire jusqu’à 20% les émissions de CO2 et la consommation de carburant.', 'Mais quand on sait qu’un avion coûte entre 100 à 200\xa0millions de francs, cela n’arrivera pas dans l’immédiat.', 'Dans une première phase, de 2025 à 2040, les biocarburants et les mesures d’optimisation de la gestion des vols vont jouer un rôle majeur.', "L'année 2040, c’est l’horizon auquel on pourrait voir apparaître des avions avec de nouvelles motorisations.", 'Mais ces technologies devraient encore mettre des décennies à émerger.', 'Des constructeurs comme Airbus travaillent dessus, donc ces technologies vont finir par émerger.', 'Nous avons un travail en amont à effectuer dans cette perspective.', 'Imaginons que l’on ait des avions électriques qui disposent de 45\xa0minutes entre leur arrivée et leur départ.', 'Nous allons devoir mettre en place des infrastructures pour pouvoir les recharger dans ce laps de temps.', 'De même pour les carburants alternatifs, il y a toute une préparation à prévoir pour leur stockage.', 'A Genève, nous avions un projet dans ce sens qui ne s’est pas réalisé mais nous avons donc une idée de ce que cela représente.', 'Si ces technologies sont disponibles plus vite, nous réévaluerons les objectifs.', 'Pour le développement des carburants alternatifs, l’étude préconise de privilégier des solutions internationales.', 'Ces capacités ne peuvent-elles pas être développées en Suisse?', 'Les investissements nécessaires pour leur développement industriel ne sont possibles qu’à l’échelle de grands groupes.', "L’intérêt de ce rapport est aussi de montrer que la Suisse peut prendre les choses en main et qu'il faut arrêter de vouloir être un petit village gaulois et de faire les choses dans notre coin.", 'Pour les carburants de synthèse, nous avons des groupes de recherche qui avancent sur différentes solutions, mais probablement pas les ressources pour les produire.', 'Par exemple, pour la production de kérosène via le solaire, il faudrait des champs gigantesques de panneaux solaires.', 'Quand je vois la difficulté d’en installer en Suisse, ce n’est pas ici qu’on va le faire.', 'Une des autres solutions mises en avant consiste à travailler sur l’optimisation des vols.', 'Peut-on encore réellement réduire les émissions de CO2 sur ce plan?', 'Oui, cela passe par des routes de vol plus efficaces ou des méthodes d’atterrissage et de décollage moins gourmandes.', 'Par exemple, on peut imaginer de ne plus utiliser les réacteurs pour le déplacement avant le décollage ou après l’atterrissage en utilisant des moteurs alternatifs électriques.', 'A Genève, ce n’est pas vraiment possible parce qu’il faut aujourd’hui quinze minutes de chauffe aux réacteurs pour le décollage.', 'Sur l’aéroport, il n’y a aucun emplacement de stationnement depuis lequel l’avion doit ensuite rouler quinze minutes avant de décoller.', 'Mais dans des aéroports comme Francfort, les appareils se déplacent parfois très longtemps au sol.', 'Les infrastructures nécessaires ne risquent-elles pas d’augmenter l’emprise au sol de l’aéroport?', 'Les carburants alternatifs peuvent être mixés au kérosène directement dans les citernes ou les pipelines en amont de l’arrivée à l’aéroport.', 'Il faudra certainement des infrastructures spécifiques pour les avions électriques ou à hydrogène mais pour le moment nous n’avons pas encore d’exemple de ce que cela représente.', 'On pourra en discuter quand on aura plus de visibilité.', 'Mais il y a encore de l’espace sur le site actuel, où l’on pourrait les installer.', 'Hormis les changements de technologie, le reste n’est pas insurmontable.']
processed_text: André Schneider: "Carbon neutrality in 2050 is a challenge for all aviation, everyone has to do their part" Fleet renewal, development of the alternative fuel market: as the CO2 law approaches, the Swiss aviation sector presents its solutions. André Schneider, managing director of Genève Aéroport, believes that the sector has the cards in hand to achieve this objective Etienne Meyer-... A few days before the vote on the revision of the CO2 law on 13 June, which provides for the introduction of a tax on airline tickets, the aviation sector presents its roadmap to achieve carbon neutrality. This document is the result of work involving airlines, airports, colleges and the Federal Civil Aviation Office (OFAC) and the Federal Office for the Environment (OFEV) at the initiative of the Aviation Research Center Switzerland (ARCS). For André Schneider, Managing Director of Genève Aéroport, and chairman of this working group, this study provides evidence that aviation has the solutions to achieve zero net emissions by 2050 in line with the objectives of the Federal Council's climate strategy. Time: Is this roadmap a response to the tax on airline tickets under the CO2 law? André Schneider: We wanted to respond to the discussions about aviation in general, not specifically the CO2 law. There has been a lot of debate about aviation, the purpose of which has been to say that the only option to decarbonize the sector is to reduce the number of flights. We wanted to show that we can maintain our offer by decarbonizing flights. We live in a globalised world, people will not stop overnight from flying to visit their families, for example in Portugal, by driving 24 hours. This study predicts an increase in the number of passengers in Cointrin in the coming decades. Is this compatible with emission reduction? There are three scenarios. In the highest case, we would reach 25 million passengers in 2040, but the most likely assumption we believe is to reach 21 million. This is a relatively small increase, knowing that we were already 18 million before the pandemic. For Geneva, the goal of net zero is achievable even with this increase. It should also be stressed that, with these passenger scenarios, it is not a goal to be achieved but a projection to be made so that we can set up planning for our infrastructure. In order to achieve zero net in aviation, are the efforts not more for companies than for airports? Companies have a lot to do because airports have taken a little lead in this area. Today, for example, the buildings at the Geneva airport built over the last five years produce more energy than they consume. We also transform the traffic on the tarmac by going to an electric motorization. But it must also be recognized that it is easier for us. However, in recent years, the companies have reduced emissions per passenger transported. It cannot be said that this is only the problem of airlines or airports. This is a challenge for the whole industry and everyone has to do their part. We are trying to help companies in this direction with an incentive program. Some of the taxes they pay to us are paid if they renew their fleet with last-generation aircraft, less kerosene-savoury and less noisy. According to this roadmap, much of the reduction in emissions is mainly based on the use of alternative fuels. It all depends on the temporality in which we set ourselves, since the targets run until 2050. Fleet renewal is also a key issue, as the new generation of aircraft reduces CO2 emissions and fuel consumption by up to 20%. But when you know that an airplane costs between 100 and 200 million francs, it won't happen immediately. In a first phase, from 2025 to 2040, biofuels and the optimization of flight management will play a major role. In the year 2040, it is the horizon from which planes could appear with new engines. But these technologies should still take decades to emerge. Manufacturers like Airbus are working on it, so these technologies will eventually emerge. We have a work ahead of us to do in this perspective. Let's imagine that there are electric planes that have 45 minutes between their arrival and departure. We're going to have to put in place infrastructure so that we can recharge them in this time frame. Similarly for alternative fuels, there is a whole preparation to be provided for their storage. In Geneva, we had a project in this direction that was not realized, but we have an idea of what this represents. If these technologies are available faster, we will re-evaluate the objectives. For the development of alternative fuels, the study recommends favouring international solutions. Can these capacities not be developed in Switzerland? The investment required for their industrial development is only possible on a large group scale. The point of this report is also to show that Switzerland can take matters in its own hands and that we must stop wanting to be a small Gallic village and do things in our own corner. For synthetic fuels, we have research groups that advance on different solutions, but probably not the resources to produce them. For example, for the production of kerosene via solar, huge fields of solar panels would be required. When I see the difficulty of installing it in Switzerland, it's not here that we're going to do it. One of the other solutions highlighted is to work on the optimization of flights. Can CO2 emissions still be reduced in this respect? Yes, it goes through more efficient flight routes or less greedy landing and take-off methods. For example, one can imagine no longer using reactors for displacement before take-off or after landing using alternative electric motors. In Geneva, this is not really possible because today it takes fifteen minutes of reactor heating to take off. At the airport, there is no parking space from which the aircraft must then drive fifteen minutes before taking off. But at airports like Frankfurt, aircraft sometimes move on the ground for a very long time. Will the necessary infrastructure not increase the right-of-way at the airport? Alternative fuels can be mixed with kerosene directly in tanks or pipelines upstream of arrival at the airport. It will certainly require specific infrastructure for electric or hydrogen aircraft, but at the moment we do not yet have an example of what this represents. We can talk about it when we get more visibility. But there is still space on the current site, where they could be installed. Apart from changes in technology, the rest is not insurmountable.

text: ['Le mythe d’un régulateur bienveillant pour le consommateur EMMANUEL GARESSUS @garessus  Les bonnes intentions ne suffisent pas.', 'Les réglementations veulent répondre à une lacune du marché ou à un déséquilibre d’informations entre les producteurs et les consommateurs.', 'Le but consiste à protéger l’individu des risques des produits financiers, des médicaments, des produits phytosanitaires ou, comme la loi sur le CO2, des effets du réchauffement climatique.', 'Mais atteignent-elles leurs objectifs?', 'L’Etat a longtemps été considéré comme un acteur bienveillant agissant, dans sa fonction de régulateur, pour le bien-être des individus.', 'Cette interprétation a été mise à mal, il y a exactement cinquante ans, par un article de l’économiste George Stigler.', 'Ce dernier, Prix Nobel d’économie en 1982, y défendait l’idée selon laquelle la réglementation était capturée par les industriels et ne profitait pas aux consommateurs.', 'Contrairement aux idées reçues, il prétendait que la production de normes ne serait qu’un service de redistribution politique au profit des entreprises.', 'Les décideurs politiques et les fonctionnaires accorderaient la priorité aux demandes des entrepreneurs afin d’améliorer leurs chances de réélection.', 'Les entreprises, elles, utilisent la densité réglementaire pour freiner l’entrée de concurrents.', 'Les normes sont souvent impopulaires.', 'Les propriétaires de maison individuelle, par exemple, sont intarissables sur les inutiles détails des exigences en matière de rénovation, toutes plus discutables et coûteuses les unes que les autres.', 'Même les réglementations les plus populaires sont parfois néfastes pour les personnes qui pourtant les réclament aux autorités.', 'Pensons par exemple à l’introduction d’un plafond sur les loyers.', 'La ville de Berlin a décidé de geler les loyers pour cinq ans en 2019.', 'La décision était pourtant largement soutenue par les locataires et les partis de gauche.', 'Après deux ans de mise en œuvre, la Cour de Karlsruhe a jugé la loi berlinoise anticonstitutionnelle.', 'Le verdict économique est au moins aussi intéressant.', 'Depuis le gel des loyers, le nombre de nouveaux biens locatifs a diminué de 50% dans la capitale allemande, selon l’institut économique Ifo.', 'Le contrôle des prix modifie en effet les incitations des acteurs économiques et freine la construction.', 'Eviter les généralisations L’idée de capture réglementaire reste très actuelle, selon un dossier réalisé par l’Université de Chicago sur son blog «Promarket»: «Facebook demande à être davantage régulé, les prisons privées plaident en faveur de plus longues incarcérations et Hewlett-Packard exige des contrôles environnementaux plus stricts», indiquent les économistes Luigi Zingales et Filippo Lancieri.', 'Mais le caractère trop général de la démonstration de Stigler réduit la force de sa pensée.', 'L’industrie ne joue pas le premier rôle dans la naissance d’une nouvelle règle, affirme par exemple Cass Sunstein, professeur à Harvard, sur le blog «Promarket».', 'Les groupes d’intérêts économiques exercent toutefois un pouvoir déterminant dans l’élaboration des règles.', 'Ils pèsent d’autant plus fortement sur les textes s’ils sont bien organisés, peu nombreux et mieux informés que les consommateurs, ainsi que l’a révélé l’économiste Mancur Olson dans son ouvrage la Logique de l’action collective (1965).', 'La théorie de la capture réglementaire de Stigler par l’économie est donc excessive et trop générale.', 'L’œuvre de Stigler peut toutefois servir de guide.', 'Personne ne peut ignorer que des acteurs puissants, dans la technologie comme dans l’énergie, accompagnent souvent le processus réglementaire pour le rapprocher de leurs désirs.', 'La réalité est donc plus complexe que ne l’imaginait Stigler.', 'En son for intérieur, le consommateur le sait très bien: il existe de bonnes et de mauvaises règles.', 'C’est pourquoi son premier besoin consiste non pas à être protégé par l’Etat mais à recueillir toutes les informations nécessaires sur un produit ou un service.', 'Des normes de transparence peuvent l’y aider.', 'De plus, en Suisse, il dispose d’un droit supplémentaire.', 'Grâce à la démocratie directe, il a l’occasion de peser sur les choix législatifs.']
processed_text: The myth of a benevolent regulator for the consumer EMMANUAL GARESSUS @garessus Good intentions are not enough. Regulations are intended to address a market gap or an imbalance in information between producers and consumers. The aim is to protect the individual from the risks of financial products, medicines, plant protection products or, like the CO2 law, from the effects of global warming. But are they achieving their goals? The state has long been regarded as a benevolent actor acting, in its role as regulator, for the well-being of individuals. This interpretation was undermined, exactly fifty years ago, by an article by economist George Stigler. The latter, the Nobel Prize winner in 1982, defended the idea that regulation was captured by industrialists and did not benefit consumers. Contrary to the ideas received, he claimed that the production of standards would be merely a service of political redistribution for the benefit of enterprises. Policy makers and public servants would give priority to entrepreneurs' requests to improve their chances of re-election. Companies use regulatory density to curb the entry of competitors. Standards are often unpopular. Individual homeowners, for example, are inexhaustible about the unnecessary details of renovation requirements, all more questionable and costly than each other. Even the most popular regulations are sometimes harmful to those who yet demand them from the authorities. Consider, for example, the introduction of a ceiling on rents. The city of Berlin decided to freeze the rents for five years in 2019. However, the decision was largely supported by tenants and left-wing parties. After two years of implementation, the Karlsruhe Court ruled the Berlin law unconstitutional. The economic verdict is at least as interesting. Since the rent freeze, the number of new rental properties has decreased by 50% in the German capital, according to the Ifo Economic Institute. Price control changes the incentives of economic actors and hinders construction. Avoiding generalizations The idea of regulatory capture remains very current, according to a dossier written by the University of Chicago on its blog "Promarket": "Facebook asks to be regulated more, private prisons advocate for longer incarcerations and Hewlett-Packard requires stricter environmental controls," says economists Luigi Zingales and Filippo Lancieri. But the too general character of Stigler's demonstration reduces the strength of his thinking. The industry does not play a leading role in the birth of a new rule, says Harvard professor Cass Sunstein on the "Promarket" blog. Economic interest groups, however, have a decisive role to play in rule-making. They weigh all the more heavily on the texts if they are well organized, few and better informed than the consumers, as the economist Mancur Olson revealed in his book The Logic of Collective Action (1965). The theory of Stigler's regulatory capture by the economy is therefore excessive and too general. Stigler's work, however, can be used as a guide. No one can ignore that powerful actors, both in technology and energy, often accompany the regulatory process to bring it closer to their desires. The reality is therefore more complex than Stigler imagined. The consumer knows this very well inside: there are good and bad rules. This is why its first need is not to be protected by the State but to collect all the necessary information about a product or service. Transparency standards can help. In addition, in Switzerland, it has an additional duty. Through direct democracy, it has the opportunity to influence legislative choices.

How much will the bill be for the others? Between supporters and opponents of the reform, the differences are deep Bernard Wuthrich The revision of the CO2 law will not without consequences for people who will not change their heating and mobility habits. The project will reward those who take little or no aircraft, opt for an electric vehicle and do not heat up with fuel oil. The stakes are more pronounced in the peripheral regions – this is reflected in the first surveys. The ecological tax levied since 2008 on oil and natural gas cannot exceed 120 francs per tonne of CO2, or about 30 cents per litre. The amount actually received is 96 francs per tonne of CO2, or 25 cents per litre. In order to encourage owners to favour more environmentally friendly heating (heat pumps, solar, wood, biogas) and to better isolate their housing, the levy will be increased by (four) steps and capped at 210 francs per tonne by 2028. At this date, the additional cost compared to today is estimated to be between 25 and 30 cents per litre. Not to mention the cost of the heating change, which can be subsidized. Between 30 and 120 francs per flight The CO2 tax will not be extended to diesel and gasoline. But the price per litre per column will increase by another channel: compensation is required to import fuels, and importers can pass it on to prices. The law in force sets a maximum amount of 5 cents per litre. The supplement actually paid by motorists is only 1.5 cents. The ceiling will be raised to 10 cents as early as 2022, then to 12 cents as early as 2025. Finally, the revision includes a tax on airline tickets. The Federal Council clarified its intentions in a draft ordinance. Depending on the categories, the increase will be 30 francs (short-haul flights in economy class), 60 francs (short-haul flights in premium economic class, business or first; medium-haul flights in economy class), 90 francs (medium-haul flights in higher class; long-haul flights in economy class) or 120 francs (long-haul flights in higher class). 97 francs more per family How much is it going to cost Swiss households? The Federal Office for the Environment (OFEV) presented an estimate for an average family of four persons. In its calculation, it includes the redistribution of part of the revenue to the population (two thirds of the proceeds of the CO2 tax and 51% of the surcharge on airline tickets, see below). The OFEV is based on various assumptions: average living space of 128 square metres, fuel consumption of 8 litres per square metre, fuel consumption of 6 litres per 100 kilometres, average annual distance of 12?500 kilometres. He concludes that a family that will not change their lifestyle will pay 164 francs more per year to warm up and 53 francs more to travel by car. If only one air trip is made per year, this household will benefit from the redistribution of air tax revenues at a rate of 120 francs per year. In the end, it will pay 97 net more than it does today. "C"est du cinéma" Balivernes, retort the opponents. "The administration figures mislead, in particular the living space taken into account. In a family home in the countryside, the living space is generally much larger," says National Councillor Christian Imark (UDC/SO), who does not spare his efforts or his media appearances to demolish the arguments of the Federal Council. It is based on other references: consumption of 8 litres per 100 km, annual distance of 20,000 km. And each time it retains the maximum amounts defined in the law, for both fuels and fuels. Isn't that exaggerated? "Not at all. It's not a horror scenario. Simonetta Sommaruga also said that the maximum amounts would be applied. His bill of about 100 francs is cinema," he replied. His extrapolation gives a result ten times higher: even after a partial discount, a family of four could pay another 1000 francs a year, he says. "The Time to Change Habits" The Infras office extrapolated the financial consequences of the reform for households in 2018. SonntagsZeitung updated this data. She concludes that a wealthy family with an apartment of 230 square meters and two big cars and who travels several times a year by plane will be able to pay up to 2200 francs more. A middle-class family that makes four short flights each year, heats up with fuel oil and keeps a car will pay another 470 francs by 2030. On the other hand, the same family will be reimbursed 580 francs if it adopts an exemplary climate behavior: no car, no plane, ecological heating. "It is ultimately a question of mentality: the people who produce CO2 will pay, it is true, a little more. It is therefore time to change his habits," argues the advisor to the Damian Müller (PLR/LU) states, who is in favour of reform. He finds Simonetta Sommaruga's numbers credible. By dividing them by twelve, "the monthly extra cost for a family of four is CHF 8.30, thanks to the clever system of reimbursement," he says. We'll see on June 13 that was the most convincing.

maintenus en l’état.', 'Ils constituent des obstacles rédhibitoires à l’essor du marché des capitaux durables dans notre pays.', 'Paysage incitatif La loi sur le CO2 s’inscrit parfaitement dans ce processed_text: CO2 law: at the heart of sustainable finance YVES MIRABAUD PRESIDENT OF THE GENEVA FUNDING FINANCIAL PLACE Swiss citizens will be asked to speak on 13 June about the CO2 law adopted by parliament in September 2020 but attacked by referendum. For the Financial Place, this law is an essential link in the transition to a more resilient and sustainable economy. Geneva is at the centre of the mechanism put in place to achieve this goal. The canton at the end of the lake enjoys an exceptional position in sustainable finance thanks to the presence of financial institutions, asset managers, international organizations, NGOs, a leading academic sector and authorities engaged at both the Confederation, canton and city level. Geneva is the home of the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) providing seventeen keys to meet the challenges facing the world. The United Nations has also inspired the Sustainable Management Principles adopted by many local and international banking and financial institutions. A more sustainable asset allocation For the Financial Place, the priority is to reorient capital flows to meet the sustainable development goals set out in the Paris Climate Agreement or the UN 2030 Agenda. In this context, banking and financial actors have largely integrated the ESG criteria (environmental, social and governance) into all their activities, from investment to the capital market and credit. The involvement of financial intermediaries is, of course, necessary for the sustainable allocation of assets. However, it is not sufficient. Investors are called upon to become actively involved in this concerted approach. Indeed, banks, asset managers and independent managers act on behalf of their customers, in accordance with their instructions. The latter, whether they are natural persons or institutional investors (pension funds), must be able to make their investment decisions with full knowledge of the facts. They should be provided with adequate information on the ESG profile of the products offered. In the end, they're the ones who cut! The political world and the authorities also have a role to play in the direction of financial flows. In particular, it is up to them to set the legal and regulatory framework to accompany the transition. In keeping with the liberal tradition of Confederation, these rules must be inciting rather than coercive. For example, in order to strengthen the attractiveness of Geneva and Switzerland as a place for issuing and trading green bonds (the so-called "green bonds"), the advance tax and stamp duty cannot be maintained in the state. They are a resuscitatory obstacle to the development of the sustainable capital market in our country. Incentive landscape The CO2 law fits perfectly into this incentive landscape. This text is based on a combination of financial incentives, investments, innovations and new technologies. The law offers all companies the opportunity to reconcile economic efficiency and climate protection. From multinationals to SMEs, all companies ready to invest in climate-friendly measures can be freed from CO2 tax. The approach provides cumulative benefits as it reduces both emissions and business costs. The climate fund provided for in the law illustrates the shift in capital flows towards more sustainability. Indeed, the revenue from the CO2 tax on fossil fuels and airline tickets will contribute up to CHF 450 million per year to a climate fund. The latter will finance sustainable investments, such as district heating networks or electric car charging stations. It will also provide financial support for the renovation of the buildings. Finally, it will support Swiss companies so that they can market climate-friendly technologies more quickly. With regard to the activities of banks and insurance, the CO2 law requires Finma and the SNB to periodically measure the financial risks resulting from climate change. The Finma has already carried out such an exercise by publishing in 2019 its Climate Risk Monitoring Report, updated in 2020. These risks can be divided into two categories. The first concerns the physical risks that relate to the threat of rising losses and costs to the economy as a result of natural disasters and gradual changes in the climate. Such risks may result in substantial losses for insurance and reinsurance undertakings. The second is related to the transition risks resulting from environmental policy measures or disruptive technological breakthroughs. Building bridges between the two shores of Geneva The Fondation Genève Place Financière (FPGF) is committed to the CO2 law, which is the missing link in the Swiss scheme, in favour of a transition to a more sustainable economic model and capital allocation. For Geneva, the stakes are great: the canton is a leader in sustainable finance at the global level. Its unique ecosystem will be mobilized at the end of November 2021 for the second edition of Building Bridges Week. As its name suggests, this large-scale event aims to build bridges between the financial centre and the international community, with the particular aim of accelerating the financing of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals. The acceptance by the Swiss people of the CO2 law on 13 June would be a strong signal from our canton and our country in favour of this just cause! This text focuses on a combination of financial incentives, investment, innovation and new technologies

text: ['Opinions  Non à une loi coûteuse, inefficace et antisociale Patrick Eperon Comité économique «Non à la loi sur le CO2»  À lire ou entendre Madame la conseillère fédérale Sommaruga ou une bonne partie des partisans de la nouvelle loi sur le CO2, qui sera soumise au vote du peuple le 13 juin prochain, le citoyen peut avoir l’impression que cette loi ne ferait que des gagnants, ce qui est évidemment impossible: il n’existe pas de taxe magique qui permettrait en définitive à chacune et chacun de toucher davantage d’argent qu’il ou elle a dû payer au préalable en s’acquittant de cette taxe!', 'Chacune et chacun devrait donc calculer dès maintenant ce qu’il devrait payer au titre des taxes fixées dans la nouvelle loi sur le CO2; bien avant de se faire rembourser une certaine somme supplémentaires qu’il devrait assumer au titre de la nouvelle loi sur le CO2, dès l’entrée en vigueur de celle-ci; bien avant de tabler sur le remboursement d’une certaine somme par l’intermédiaire de processed_text: Opinions No to an expensive, ineffective and anti-social law Patrick Eperon Economic Committee "No to the CO2 law" To read or hear Madam Federal Councillor Sommaruga or a good part of the supporters of the new CO2 law, which will be put to the vote on June 13, the citizen may have the impression that this law would only be winners, which is obviously impossible: there is no magic tax that would ultimately allow everyone to receive more money than he or she had to pay in advance by paying this tax! Therefore, each individual should calculate immediately what he or she should pay in respect of the taxes set out in the new CO2 law; long before he or she is reimbursed a certain amount through his or her sickness fund, due to a partial redistribution of the proceeds of taxes. Similarly, each head of enterprise should now budget for the additional expenses that he or she would have to incur under the new CO2 law upon its entry into force; well before relying on the repayment of a certain amount through the AVS fund to which his or her business is affiliated, due to a partial redistribution of the proceeds of taxes. The new CO2 law sets different taxes. Most of this is an increase of 12 cents per litre of gasoline (which would add to the 4 cents in force since 1 January this year), as well as an increase of almost 30 cents per litre of fuel oil or some 3.8 cents per kWh of gas, a means of heating that is widely encouraged for years in urban areas. Finally, each passenger of a airline aircraft (once out of the pandemic) should pay a new fee per flight, i.e. 240 francs for a family of four people travelling to Morocco. The CO2 law is therefore expensive for a large part of households that own at least one car or heat up oil or gas, or go on vacation at least once a year by plane: a large majority of Swiss, Genevan or Vaudois, in the midst of economic crisis Covid-19! The CO2 law will not save the climate! As a reminder, Switzerland is only responsible for one thousandth of global CO2 emissions. However, the CO2 law could only lead to a reduction of half a million global CO2 emissions. That is why climate activists point out that this law is ineffective. Finally, and perhaps more importantly, it should be stressed that CO2 taxes are consumption taxes which, by definition, are not linked to the income of those who have to pay them. This means that CO2 taxes are antisocial, as the Economic Committee "No to the CO2 law" and climate strikers opposed to it stress. In short, the CO2 law is based on punishment and not innovation, which has contributed significantly to the reduction of CO2 emissions per capita in Switzerland by some 24% over the past decade. Face-to-face CO2 law: what to vote for? The Chambers approved the CO2 law, but a referendum against it was launched and the Swiss vote was required on this subject on 13 June. Intended to bring Switzerland into line with the Paris Climate Agreement, this text is defended here by the Geneva MP Alexandre de Senarclens and fought by the communications and political campaign delegate of the Centre patronal in Lausanne.

processed_text: The unanimous Green Liberals behind the CO2 law President Jürg Grossen's party welcomes this law, which must be only an intermediate step towards climate-neutral Switzerland. ATS The delegates of the Green Liberal Party (PVL), meeting in a virtual assembly on Saturday, adopted their slogans for the votes of 13 June. They recommend the "yes" to the CO2 law, yes to the Covid-19 law, and the "no" to the "no" to the "no" to terrorism law. They had already accepted the clean drinking water initiative in February and left the right to vote on pesticides. A possible ecological turning point The CO2 law is an important intermediate step towards a climate-neutral Switzerland, but others have to follow, the Liberal Greens believe. According to them, Switzerland must take on a pioneering role in climate protection. Ecological change is possible, as the technologies and know-how to do so are available. "If we implement it properly, this law offers a great opportunity for our economy and society," said National Advisor Isabelle Chevalley (VD). The Liberal Greens have also clearly approved the Covid-19 law, which is considered particularly necessary to support businesses and self-employed economically affected by the pandemic. Through it, culture, sport and the media received the necessary support during the crisis. Rejection of the law would jeopardize support measures and create legal uncertainty. The Liberal Greens, on the other hand, swept the terrorism law from 148 votes to 11. They believe that it attacks liberal values and the rule of law by including vague formulations that open the door to arbitrary mistakes and decisions. According to them, the presumption of innocence is abolished and the principle of separation of powers is violated, since coercive measures can be ordered by the police without evidence.

text: ['Le sursaut écologiste que les libéraux vont aimer Perspectives Les chercheurs d’Avenir Suisse veulent une politique climatique très ambitieuse pour la Suisse, à condition qu’elle soit résolument libérale.', 'Les milieux libéraux n’ont pas toujours été les plus actifs ou les plus bavards en matière d’écologie, en particulier sur le réchauffement climatique.', 'Or, à en croire Avenir Suisse, le laboratoire d’idées fondé par les grandes entreprises suisses, cet abandon politique est une erreur.', 'Les politiques d’obédience étatique ou dirigiste, voire moralisatrice, risquent de l’emporter.', 'Avenir Suisse l’avoue dans un ouvrage très fouillé sur le plan scientifique, dense en informations, bien argumenté (théorie libérale), qui vient de paraître*.', 'Et s’en explique dans un passage qui appelle ses partisans, les esprits libéraux, ceux qui défendent les principes de l’économie de marché, à un véritable sursaut politique.', '«Les libéraux rendraient service à euxmêmes et au monde s’ils traitaient le changement climatique avec le même sérieux que le fait la gauche.»  Leur différence avec la gauche et les Verts?', 'Les moyens à mettre en œuvre pour protéger «un bien commun», un climat qui ne péjore pas les chances de développement des générations futures.', 'Avenir Suisse considère que la vérité sur les externalités (les dégâts causés à l’environnement non pris en compte dans la formation des prix) et leur intégration dans le système économique sont des outils efficaces pour atteindre une société à zéro carbone.', 'L’État doit fixer des objectifs mais ne pas déterminer les technologies pour y parvenir; le marché (la concurrence) est bien plus efficace.', 'Quant aux interdictions (décréter un embargo absolu sur le pétrole à brève échéance), elles sont souvent peu convaincantes et pourraient même avoir un effet contraire: rendre le cours du pétrole moins cher dans les régions laxistes.', 'Pour faire simple, la voie royale et… libérale pour stopper le réchauffement climatique passe par une tarification dissuasive des gaz à effet de serre d’origine fossile (taxe CO2).', 'Les taxes sur les billets d’avion?', 'Une bêtise politique (Avenir Suisse utilise un terme plus poli) qui braque les citoyens et dont l’efficacité sera dérisoire.', 'On pourrait croire qu’Avenir Suisse torpille la révision de la loi sur le CO2, en votation le 13 juin prochain.', 'Même si les auteurs s’interdisent tout mot d’ordre explicite (une règle valable pour tous les sujets de votations), ils jugent que cette révision «améliore certains instruments et devrait permettre d’atteindre les objectifs pour 2030».', 'Mais, à leurs yeux, la révision manque d’ambition (!)', 'et devra être réformée très rapidement.', 'Pour le laboratoire à idées libéral, la Suisse doit être non seulement exemplaire dans l’efficacité des mesures mais également plus ambitieuse à l’échelon international.', 'Avenir Suisse plaide pour une collaboration étroite avec l’Union européenne et pense qu’il serait judicieux que les pays vertueux taxent à la frontière les États «parasites», ceux qui traînent les pieds.', 'Un fonds pour l’avenir Sur le plan intérieur, Avenir Suisse dénonce l’inefficacité du plan bâtiments des cantons (subventions pour l’isolation et les nouveaux systèmes de chauffage), l’échec des normes automobiles et pense que le nouveau fonds climatique risque de devenir la caisse à subventions en libre-service pour les innombrables lobbies intéressés par la part des recettes provenant de la taxe sur le CO2 qui ne sera pas redistribuée à la population.', 'Si l’on songe à un fonds, Avenir Suisse avance une solution plus inédite: accumuler de l’épargne pour financer les nouvelles technologies qui seront nécessaires pour retirer du CO2 de l’atmosphère dès 2050 et aider les futures générations à s’adapter aux effets prévisibles du changement climatique.', 'Les libéraux orphelins en matière de politique climatique vont adorer.', 'P.V.', '* www.avenir-suisse.ch/fr  «Les libéraux rendraient service à eux-mêmes et au monde s’ils traitaient le changement climatique avec le même sérieux que le fait la gauche.»']

text: ['La taxe carbone est-elle juste?', 'OPINION.', 'Le débat ne doit pas se focaliser sur la taxe elle-même, car c’est un outil indispensable pour préserver notre environnement, mais sur la manière de redistribuer au mieux le produit de la taxe, écrivent\xa0Kenza Benhima, Mathieu Grobéty, Aleksandra Malova et Simon Scheidegger, de l’HEC-Unil  Kenza Benhima, HEC-Unil, Institut\xa0CREA Mathieu Grobéty,\xa0Institut\xa0CREA Aleksandra Malova, HEC-Unil Simon Scheidegger, HEC-Unil  La taxe carbone est-elle juste?', 'C’est une question à laquelle on ne peut répondre complètement sans rappeler son rôle.', 'Celui-ci est de corriger une défaillance des marchés.', 'Lorsque nous achetons des biens et services, nous payons les coûts de production.', 'Mais il existe aussi des coûts cachés.', 'Le dioxyde de carbone (CO2) produit par les humains provoque un réchauffement climatique aux conséquences potentiellement catastrophiques.', 'En l’absence de taxe, on ne paie donc pas le vrai coût de la processed_text: Is the carbon tax fair? OPINION. The debate should not focus on the tax itself, because it is an indispensable tool to preserve our environment, but on how to best redistribute the tax proceeds, Kenza Benhima, Mathieu Grobéty, Aleksandra Malova and Simon Scheidegger, from HEC-Unil Kenza Benhima, HEC-Unil, CREA Institute Mathieu Grobéty, CREA Institute Aleksandra Malova, HEC-Unil Simon Scheidegger, HEC-Unil Is the carbon tax fair? It is a question that cannot be answered completely without recalling its role. This is to correct a market failure. When we buy goods and services, we pay for production costs. But there are also hidden costs. The carbon dioxide (CO2) produced by humans causes global warming with potentially catastrophic consequences. In the absence of a tax, therefore, the real cost of production, which in fact should include such damage, is not paid. From this point of view, it is the market that is unfair and the tax that is fair. However, it is important to consider the impact of the tax on individuals. There is no doubt that the tax will affect households in an unequal manner. While consumption of goods and services that contribute most to CO2 emissions increases with income, the share of these goods and services is higher for modest revenues (except for aviation). These households may feel the effect of the carbon tax more strongly than others. According to the Federal Statistical Office, a Swiss household with an income of less than 13?622 francs spends 1% of the latter on average on energy from its home, while the latter accounts for more than one sixth of the greenhouse gas emissions in Switzerland. This share is 3% for households with an income of less than 4914 francs. Is the carbon tax unfair, however? What is unfair or not First of all, the impact of the carbon tax depends on the existence of alternatives to taxed goods and services. If these alternatives are taken into account, their impact is less. The increase in the price of plane tickets does not mean the end of the holidays, nor that holidays will necessarily cost more! This only means that we will travel more often by train, and less far. Savings can even be made, for example, by heating a house with a heat pump instead of a heating oil. Of course, it takes time and money to change the heating system. Finally, the state takes one hand and gives the other back However, even in this case, it is not the tax itself that should be considered unfair, because unless it is distorted, it cannot correct these effects. Rather, it is the tax system as a whole to do so. This is possible thanks to revenues from the CO2 tax, which provides a "double dividend": it not only helps to improve society by changing behaviour harmful to the climate, but it also generates a financial manna that can reward virtuous acts and correct inequalities due to the tax. The modest households will receive more.It is therefore the details of the CO2 law on which the Swiss people are required to vote on 13 June that will determine whether or not the carbon tax is fair. What about it? The revenue from the tax will have two main uses: to accompany the transition to a greener economy and to redistribute the money collected to households. Will this help to limit the impact of the tax on modest households? Absolutely. In part, the income from the household tax will be distributed equitably, meaning that modest households will receive more in proportion to their income. Second, using these resources to encourage the adoption of green technologies also allows households to be less affected by the tax. This happens, for example, when a family installs a heat pump with climate fund subsidies, which avoids paying the fuel oil tax. So finally the state takes one hand and gives back the other. In conclusion, the debate should not focus on the tax itself, because it is an indispensable tool to preserve our environment, an invaluable resource for future generations, but on how to best redistribute the tax proceeds to make them as fair as possible.
author: Kenza Benhima Mathieu Grobéty Aleksandra Malova Simon S

We should start without delay the necessary changes in mobility and heating. The planned taxes are an incentive, she says Bernard Wuthrich The new CO2 law is being fought by a double referendum, one launched by automobile and oil organizations and supported by the UDC, the other by a part of the climate strikers. Federal Councillor Simonetta Sommaruga responded to their criticisms. Time: Is Switzerland more affected by global warming than other countries? Simonetta Sommaruga: Yes, in Switzerland, the Alpine country, temperatures rise twice as much as the world average. Glacier melts, agriculture suffers ever more frequent periods of drought. This generates significant costs, largely borne by the municipalities and the cantons. What does the CO2 law actually bring to mountain areas? The CO2 Act creates a fund that will help municipalities to carry out flood protections and landslides caused by the melting of glaciers or to stabilize lifts. This is also why the Groupement pour les régions de montagne and the Swiss Alpine Club support the bill. Opponents say that many countries are failing to meet Paris commitments and that Switzerland's efforts will only reduce global CO2 emissions by half a million. Is that worth it? Switzerland is not alone. The EU and even the US have launched ambitious programmes. The new law will speed up technological progress and ensure jobs at home, rather than leaving us on the spectators' bench watching other countries occupy innovative sectors. Climate strikers want the state of emergency to be proclaimed and climate neutrality to be achieved by 2030 already. How do you respond to their impatience? I met them. I understand their impatience and I appreciate that they are very well informed. But they won't gain anything by defeating the CO2 law, because we would lose years to tie up a new project. In case of no, the oil and automobile lobby would be the big winner. Halving our CO2 emissions in the next ten years is already an ambitious goal. The new law promotes investment in Switzerland. It's better than paying $8 billion a year abroad to buy oil. You're pointing the finger at oil and automobile organizations. But is it not legitimate for them to defend their economic model and their jobs? In our democratic system, a referendum is always legitimate. What we need to know is that the release of coal, oil and fossil fuels is inevitable. The path is set. All of Switzerland's economic partners are moving in this direction. A no to the law will not prevent this transformation. Maintenance of a petrol car is increasingly expensive. The garage operators will focus on other propulsion models, electric or hybrid. They will always have work, but it will not be exactly the same as today. Switzerland has the training and innovation potential to support this change. The oil and automobile lobby is not alone in fighting the law. GastroSwitzerland also supports the referendum. Are the concerns of this industry, which is already very affected by the pandemic, not legitimate? Today, only large companies can free themselves from the CO2 tax, with climate-friendly measures. With the new law, SMEs will be able to do so too. This will benefit the carpenter, the baker, the restaurant owner. J的observes that, unlike GastroSwitzerland, HotellerieSwitzerland supports the new law. Mountain regions suffer from global warming. But is the new law not going to penalise the inhabitants of these areas, who need the car more because they have less access to public transport? The inhabitants of these areas are more dependent on the car, that is true. However, the new law encourages importers to market cars that consume less fuel. People who need one will pay less, even if they don't opt for an electric model. In addition, a majority of households in peripheral regions are already heating without oil or natural gas. They do not pay the CO2 tax but still receive their share of the redistribution. It's positive for them. And they fly less often than city dwellers. In the end, they will benefit from the law and the return of the tax. Your services have calculated that the law would cost an additional 100 francs to a family of four who do not change their habits. Opponents put forward figures ten times higher. Honestly, won't the truth lie between these two ends? We have taken as a model a representative family: parents, two children, heating oil, petrol car, one flight in Europe per year. Opponents took extreme examples. Do you know many families who have a 250 square meter villa that consumes a lot of fuel and makes three or four flights away each year? I'm not. The principle of the law is simple. Those who behave environmentally friendly will save money through the tax redistribution mechanism. That is why the law is social and supportive of families. Do we not run the risk that the Swiss will fly to a foreign airport close to our borders, which will reduce the amounts to be redistributed? All neighbouring countries already levy a tax on airline tickets. It is certainly lower. But it is not redistributed to the population. It is part of public budgets. Our mechanism is very social: 51% of revenues are reimbursed to the population, including children, and the other half feed the climate fund. Is this climate fund not a gas plant that promises a lot of money to many people? It will be used to finance many projects: money will go to the population, for example to help it change heating. He will go to the municipalities to create remote heating and mountain areas to carry out flood protection works. Young people will have night trains. But I would like to recall the basic mechanism: taxes are incentives. They aim to convince the population to change their habits in order to reduce CO2 emissions. To replace the current fleet with electric vehicles, batteries will have to be purchased using ores, such as lithium, that must be extracted from the earth. Is it really ecological? The extraction of raw materials is a sensitive issue. I know her well, because I was formerly president of Swissaid and I was able to observe the consequences of the extraction of cobalt but also of oil. Switzerland is concerned about this issue. We still need to make progress, for example by strengthening the circular economy and promoting battery recycling. For this, we have, here in Switzerland, successful companies. The CO2 law is only one step. There'll be another one. You announced it. This will be the counter-project for glaciers. What measures will it include? Let us start with this decade, which is crucial. If nothing is done now, we will have to make such a catch-up effort after 2030 that it will cost significantly more to achieve climate neutrality in 2050. But I cannot say today what measures will have to be taken after 2030. This will depend on many factors, such as technological change, the degree of electrification of mobility and the replacement of heating. If no one heats up anymore, we'll have solved a lot of the problem. Meanwhile, the CO2 law does not prohibit anything, it is a liberal law that makes us take an important step forward for climate protection.

text: [" Très léger recul des émissions de gaz à effet de serre en 2019 Selon un rapport de l'Office fédéral de l'environnement (OFEV), les émissions de gaz à effet de serre en Suisse ont légèrement diminué ATS  En 2019, la Suisse a émis 46,2\xa0millions de tonnes d’équivalents CO2.", 'C’est environ 0,3\xa0million de tonnes de moins que l’année précédente, indique lundi l’Office fédéral de l’environnement (OFEV), qui plaide pour un renforcement des mesures.', 'Les émissions sont inférieures de 14% à celles de l’année de référence 1990.', 'Selon les estimations actuelles, la Suisse devrait manquer son objectif climatique pour 2020 de réduire de 20% les émissions de gaz à effet de serre par rapport à 1990.', 'Pour diminuer significativement les émissions, il est indispensable de renforcer les mesures, comme le prévoit la loi sur le CO2, selon l’OFEV.', 'Stabilité dans le bâtiment et l’industrie Dans le secteur du bâtiment, les émissions sont restées identiques à l’année précédente.', 'Elles représentent une diminution totale de 34% par rapport à 1990.', 'Cette stabilité, malgré un hiver plus froid, est principalement due à l’amélioration de l’efficacité énergétique des bâtiments et au remplacement croissant des systèmes de chauffage au mazout et au gaz par des pompes à chaleur et des énergies renouvelables.', 'La forte influence des températures hivernales sur les émissions montre que le secteur du bâtiment continue majoritairement de se chauffer avec des combustibles fossiles, souligne l’OFEV.', 'Si l’on tient compte du facteur climatique, les émissions de ce secteur baissent de 0,3\xa0million de tonnes par an, ce qui n’est pas suffisant pour atteindre son objectif de réduction de 40% jusqu’en 2020.', 'Les émissions de l’industrie sont elles aussi restées inchangées en 2019.', 'Par rapport à 1990, le recul est de 14%.', 'Ces émissions stagnent depuis plusieurs années et si cette tendance se poursuit, l’objectif de réduction de 20% jusqu’en 2020 sera manqué.', 'Hausse des kilomètres parcourus Dans le secteur des transports, les émissions se sont chiffrées à environ 15\xa0millions de tonnes d’équivalents CO2 en 2019, comme l’année précédente, soit 1% de plus que le niveau atteint en 1990.', 'L’adjonction de biocarburants aux carburants fossiles a augmenté ces dernières années, atteignant près de 4% des ventes totales de carburants en 2019.', 'Les véhicules plus efficaces sur le plan énergétique ont également émis moins de CO2 par kilomètre effectué.', 'Mais ces effets positifs sont annulés par l’augmentation du nombre de kilomètres parcourus.', 'Si la tendance se maintient, le secteur des transports manquera l’objectif de moins 10% jusqu’en 2020.', 'Baisse dans l’agriculture Les émissions causées par l’agriculture ont quant à elles légèrement diminué par rapport à 2018, pour atteindre quelque 6,5\xa0millions de tonnes d’équivalents CO2, soit environ 12% de moins qu’en 1990.', 'Les émissions de gaz à effet de serre synthétiques, tels que les fluides frigorigènes, ont légèrement diminué par rapport à 2018, pour atteindre environ 1,6\xa0million de tonnes en 2019.', 'Depuis le 1er\xa0janvier 2019, le Protocole de Montréal régit 18 gaz à effet de serre synthétiques importants.', 'Sa mise en œuvre, aussi en Suisse, devrait entraîner un net recul des émissions de ce type de gaz.', 'Néanmoins, la Confédération n’atteindra probablement pas la réduction prévue pour les autres émissions, de quelque 10% par rapport à 1990, jusqu’en 2020, avertit l’OFEV.', 'L’inventaire suisse des gaz à effet de serre pour les années de 1990 à 2019 a été remis au Secrétariat de l’ONU sur les changements climatiques le 12\xa0avril 2021.', 'Il dresse un tableau complet des émissions de gaz à effet de serre de la Suisse, qui sont régies par le Protocole de Kyoto.']
processed_text: Very small decrease in greenhouse gas emissions in 2019 According to a report by the Federal Office for the Environment (FOEV), Swiss greenhouse gas emissions decreased slightly ATS In 2019, Switzerland emitted 46.2 million tonnes of CO2 equivalents. It is about 0.3 million tonnes less than the previous year, says the Federal Office for the Environment (OFEV) on Monday, which calls for a strengthening of the measures. Emissions are 14% lower than in the 1990 reference year. According to current estimates, Switzerland is expected to miss its 2020 climate target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 20% compared to 1990. In order to significantly reduce emissions, it is essential to strengthen measures, as provided for in the CO2 law, according to OFEV. Building and Industry Stability In the construction sector, emissions remained the same as in the previous year. They represent a total decrease of 34% compared to 1990. This stability, despite a colder winter, is mainly due to improved energy efficiency in buildings and the increasing replacement of oil and gas heating systems with heat pumps and renewable energies. The strong influence of winter temperatures on emissions shows that the building sector continues to heat mostly with fossil fuels, says OFEV. Taking the climate factor into account, emissions in this sector are decreasing by 0.3 million tonnes per year, which is not enough to meet its target of a 40% reduction until 2020. Industry emissions also remained unchanged in 2019. Compared to 1990, the decline is 14%. These emissions have been stagnant for several years and if this trend continues, the 20% reduction target until 2020 will be missed. Kilometers travelled up In the transport sector, emissions amounted to about 15 million tonnes of CO2 equivalents in 2019, as in the previous year, 1% higher than the level reached in 1990. The addition of biofuels to fossil fuels has increased in recent years, reaching nearly 4% of total fuel sales in 2019. Energy-efficient vehicles also emitted less CO2 per kilometre. But these positive effects are offset by the increase in the number of kilometres travelled. If the trend continues, the transport sector will miss the target of less than 10% by 2020. Declining in agriculture Agriculture emissions have decreased slightly from 2018 to about 6.5 million tonnes of CO2 equivalents, about 12% less than in 1990. Synthetic greenhouse gas emissions, such as refrigerant, decreased slightly from 2018 to about 1.6 million tonnes in 2019. As of January 1, 2019, the Montreal Protocol regulates 18 significant synthetic greenhouse gases. Its implementation, also in Switzerland, is expected to lead to a sharp reduction in emissions of this type of gas. However, the Confederation is unlikely to achieve the planned reduction for other emissions by some 10% compared to 1990, until 2020, warns OFEV. The Swiss greenhouse gas inventory for the years 1990 to 2019 was submitted to the UN Secretariat on Climate Change on 12 April 2021. It provides a comprehensive picture of Switzerland's greenhouse gas emissions, which are governed by the Kyoto Protocol.

processed_text: Anti-pesticidal initiatives are losing speed Broadcasted on Wednesday, a poll shows that both initiatives are struggling. They divide the electorate into two distinct ATS camps The two anti-pesticidal initiatives have lost support, the "yes" being at present slightly below 50%. The yes to the CO2 law also recedes, but remains the majority. The Covid and anti-terrorism laws remain popular with two thirds of the respondents. As in the first poll two weeks ago, anti-pesticidal initiatives and the CO2 law divide the electorate into two distinct camps, showing the new 20 Minutes/Tamedia survey, conducted five weeks before the votes of June 13 and broadcast on Wednesday. The voters of the UDC and the PLR remain clearly opposed to these texts in favour of the environment. On the other hand, the approval of Green, PS and Liberal Green supporters is very high. With this clear polarization, mobilization in both camps and voting behaviour at the centre will be decisive. Greens and the City of Point Support for the Clean Drinking Water Initiative has decreased by six percentage points from the first survey. 48% of respondents now agree with the proposal, while 50% would reject it. The left-wing voters and the Liberal Greens are in favour of the initiative, while the voters of the UDC, the PLR and the Centre are opposed to it. As expected, support is highest among the Greens, as well as among urban dwellers, who are 62% to approve it. As in the first survey, it is clear that the proposal is particularly difficult to reach young people. For example, only 30% of 18-34 year olds approve of the scheme, compared with 51% of those over 65. The most convincing argument for supporters is that more than a million people in Switzerland use water contaminated with pesticides from agriculture. The rejection of opponents is based on the idea that the initiative would weaken agriculture because it could produce less food. Equal Camps for the other initiative Approval of the initiative "for a Switzerland without synthetic pesticides" is also declining. Five weeks before the vote, 49% were in favour of the project and 49% opposed it, 2% not speaking. As for the lines of conflict between voters, the pattern is almost the same as for the drinking water initiative. It is similar at the party level. The initiative is also supported more strongly in the city and with increasing age. The proponents are particularly convinced by the scientists' argument that pesticides are a health hazard, a link between these products and certain types of cancer, and a decrease in fertility. Opponents believe that the initiative poses a threat to security of supply and will lead to higher food prices by complicating production and imports. Short majority for the CO2 law The CO2 law has also lost support, but remains approved by a very short majority: 50% of respondents are in favour, 46% against, 4% not declaring their voting intentions. As with the two agricultural initiatives, this bill divides partisans and opponents into well-defined camps. The supporters of the UDC and the PLR are opposed to it, the centrist electorate is divided into two camps of equal size, while the voters of the Greens, the PS and the Liberal Greens are very clearly in favour of the text. As with anti-pesticidal initiatives, mobilization in both camps and voting behaviour at the centre will be decisive. The divide is also clear between cities and rural areas, with urban dwellers in favour of the law and rural dwellers opposed (61% versus 42% of the yes). For its supporters, the law has an incentive effect that rewards climate-friendly behaviour, with people emitting more CO2 paying more. Opponents believe that the climate problem will not be solved by taxes, but only by innovation.

Binkert, directeur financier de la compagnie.', 'Pour arriver à un bilan neutre, la société devrait exploiter 50 à 55% de ses capacités.', 'Elle a été loin de ce seuil en début d’année: fin avril, lors de la publication de ses résultats trimestriels, elle indiquait ne fonctionner qu’au quart de son niveau d’avant-pandémie.', 'Conséquence: la compagnie aérienne a essuyé une perte de 201\xa0millions de francs durant les trois premiers mois de l’année.', 'Son chiffre d’affaires a chuté de 67,5% sur un an, à 299,6\xa0millions de francs.', 'Selon ses dirigeants, le chômage partiel n’est désormais plus un remède adapté à la pire crise affrontée depuis les débuts de l’entreprise en 2002.', '«Nous devons préparer la compagnie à l’avenir, a insisté Dieter Vranckx en conférence de presse.', 'Maintenir sa capacité d’investissement, mais aussi son aptitude à rembourser les crédits octroyés durant la pandémie.» Les compagnies Swiss et Edelweiss bénéficient d’une garantie à hauteur de 1,3 milliard de francs de la part de la Confédération.', 'La société aérienne assure que son plan de restructuration ne contrevient pas aux engagements pris pour bénéficier de ces soutiens.', 'Demande en baisse de 20% Préparer la compagnie à l’avenir, c’est composer avec une demande durablement affaiblie.', 'Pointant la chute des voyages d’affaires, la société table sur une baisse de la fréquentation de 20% en 2023, par rapport à 2019.', '«Le phénomène est très problématique, confirme Andreas Wittmer, responsable du centre d’étude du secteur aérien de l’Université de Saint-Gall, car les voyages d’affaires financent massivement le trafic global: cette catégorie de voyageurs recourt volontiers à la classe business et elle fait souvent ses réservations à très court terme, ce qui lui des solutions peuvent encore être trouvées pour réduire les 400 licenciements envisagés chez les stewards et les hôtesses de l’air.', 'Une compagnie comme Swiss devrait tout faire pour d’abord sauver convention collective de travail, mais le droit suisse ne les met pas à l’abri d’une telle issue.', 'Porte-parole d’Aeropers qui représente les intérêts de la profession, Thomas Steffen veut promouvoir le travail à temps partiel pour éviter les 120 renvois envisagés.', '«Chez Edelweiss, certains pilotes disposent d’un jour de congé fixe chaque semaine.', 'C’est ce type de solutions que nous aimerions mettre en place.» Interpelée à ce sujet, la direction de Swiss n’a pas fermé la porte, signalant que l’un de ses quatre axes de développement était justement dédié aux nouveaux modes de travail.', 'La durabilité pour autre défi La baisse des déplacements à caractère professionnel n’est pas le seul changement de tendance que Swiss affronte puisque le secteur aérien doit réduire son empreinte carbonique.', '«Les mesures prises pour baisser les émissions de CO2 risquent aussi d’avoir un impact négatif sur la demande», remarque l’expert Andreas Wittmer.', 'La compagnie n’est d’ailleurs pas satisfaite du dispositif prévu par la Confédération sur lequel la population se prononce le 13\xa0juin.', 'S’il se dit favorable à toute action qui améliore la situation dans ce domaine, le patron de Swiss juge l’ordonnance d’application de la loi sur le CO2 «contre-productive» pour son secteur.', 'Selon Dieter Vranckx, les taxes prélevées sur les billets d’avion doivent servir à financer les initiatives menées par l’aviation.', 'Il dit être en étroite discussion avec la Confédération à ce sujet.']

The diagnosis is made by the company, which draws the conclusions: it intends to eliminate 1,700 jobs and reduce its fleet by 15%. Some 700 layoffs could be pronounced Aline Bassin "The next world will not be the same as before the pandemic."A year and a half after the start of the health crisis, Swiss acknowledged the profound changes that the new coronavirus has brought about for its sector of activity. The airline's managers have made it clear by presenting their restructuring plan to the press on Thursday. Dieter Vranckx, director of Lufthansa Group's subsidiary, said that the situation remains "difficult" and "extended", but that the crisis is now mainly "structural". In order to adapt to this new situation, Swiss plans to eventually eliminate 1,700 jobs, or 20% of its workforce. According to society, natural departures will not be enough to achieve this goal. Up to 780 dismissals could be pronounced. Cabin personnel are most affected with 400 jobs at risk, twice as much as those working on the ground. The geographical distribution of this resizing is not specified, nor are the destinations that could charge for it. We are still burning 2 million cash a day Markus Binkert, the financial manager of Swiss Car the company also plans to reduce its fleet – which has 90 aircraft – by around 15%, mainly through the withdrawal of some Airbus. On short and medium-haul routes, the number of aircraft should be reduced from 69 to 59, while it would increase from 31 to 26 on long-haul routes. The aim of this reduction is to save half a billion francs by 2023. "We still burn 2 million francs of cash a day," says Markus Binkert, the company's financial director. To achieve a neutral balance sheet, the company should exploit 50 to 55% of its capacity. It was far from this threshold at the beginning of the year: at the end of April, when its quarterly results were published, it indicated that it was operating only at a quarter of its pre-pandemic level. As a result, the airline lost 201 million francs in the first three months of the year. Its turnover fell by 67.5% over a year to CHF 299.6 million. According to his managers, partial unemployment is no longer a remedy for the worst crisis since the start of the company in 2002. "We have to prepare the company for the future," Dieter Vranckx stressed at a press conference. Maintaining its investment capacity, as well as its ability to repay the credits granted during the pandemic." Swiss and Edelweiss companies benefit from a guarantee of 1.3 billion francs from the Confederation. The airline ensures that its restructuring plan does not contravene the commitments made to receive these support. Demand down by 20% Preparing the company in the future is dealing with a permanently weakened demand. Pointing to the fall in business travel, the company is planning to drop attendance by 20% in 2023, compared to 2019. "The phenomenon is very problematic," confirms Andreas Wittmer, head of the air sector study centre at the University of Saint-Gallen, "because business travel is massively financing global traffic: this category of passengers is willing to use the business class and often makes their bookings in the very short term, which is worth higher fares." Together with his team, he is completing a study in collaboration with the airline to better understand the change in the behaviour of this type of passenger. Part-time and early retirement The representatives of the various trades have learned the news without surprise, but they intend to fight to limit the damage during the consultation phase which runs until 25 May. "The problem," said Sandrine Nikolic-Fuss, president of the cabin crew union, "is that our sector has already made a great deal of sacrifices since the beginning of the pandemic." She refers to wage concessions, sabbatical leave or early retirement. In his view, only in the latter category can solutions be found to reduce the 400 dismissals envisaged in stewards and air stewardesses. A company like Swiss should do everything possible to save its jobs first Sandrine Nikolic-Fuss, president of the cabin staff union For the staff representative, Swiss should first stop any delegation of flights to Helvetic that is not part of the Lufthansa alliance: "A company like Swiss should do everything to save its jobs first before keeping it in a company that offers minimum working conditions compared to what is happening in the industry." Negotiations also bogged down with the pilots. In principle, they are protected from dismissal by 2023 by their collective labour agreement, but Swiss law does not protect them from such an outcome. Spokesperson for Aeroopers, who represents the interests of the profession, Thomas Steffen wants to promote part-time work to avoid the 120 dismissals envisaged. "At Edelweiss, some pilots have a fixed day off each week. It is this type of solution that we would like to put in place." Asked about this, Swiss management did not close the door, pointing out that one of its four development axes was precisely dedicated to new ways of working. Sustainability for another challenge The decline in professional travel is not the only trend change Swiss faces since the airline sector needs to reduce its carbon footprint. "The measures taken to reduce CO2 emissions are also likely to have a negative impact on demand," said expert Andreas Wittmer. The company is also not satisfied with the arrangements provided for by the Confederation, on which the population pronounces itself on 13 June. If he is in favour of any action that improves the situation in this area, Swiss's boss considers the CO2 enforcement order "counterproductive" for his sector. According to Dieter Vranckx, the taxes levied on airline tickets are to be used to finance aviation initiatives. He said he was in close discussion with Confederation on this matter.

raté son rendez-vous.', 'Ce mouvement pour le climat pouvait pourtant craindre le pire pour son retour sur la scène publique après les grandes manifestations de 2019: une météo menaçante, des élèves priés de rester en classe et un esprit casanier forgé par une année de pandémie.', 'Vendredi à 17 heures, au départ du cortège, on ne comptait que quelques centaines de personnes sur la plaine de Plainpalais.', 'Finalement, les rangs ont grossi au fil de la marche et nous avons compté environ 2000 participants, jeunes pour la plupart, dans les Rues-Basses.', 'Les organisateurs estiment avoir climatiques se sont joints des groupes féministes et les syndicats.', 'Qui a fait le pas vers l’autre?', '«Les militants du climat sont venus nous chercher, raconte le syndicaliste Davide de Filippo, président de la Communauté genevoise d’action syndicale.', 'Car ils se rendent compte qu’ils ont à apprendre en termes de rapport de force.', 'De notre côté, cela nous a réveillés.', 'Car ces redistribution.', 'Et la transition climatique va générer de nouveaux emplois», répond le syndicaliste.', 'Les syndicats veulent justement favoriser les reconversions professionnelles.', '«Plutôt que soutenir l’aéroport pour sauver des emplois, on veut favoriser les transferts.', 'Un chauffeur sur le tarmac pourrait aller travailler aux TPG.', 'Et un bagagiste devenir transporteur à l’Hôpital.»  Ce rapprochement entre syndicats et mouvements pour le climat, mais aussi avec les féministes, est clairement assumé.', '«Justice sociale et climatique sont indissociables, assure un des orateurs en prélude au cortège.', 'Car les injustices ont la même cause, le capitalisme.', 'Comme il a besoin de croissance, il exploite sans fin les ressources naturelles, et comme il recherche le profit à court terme, il est incapable d’intégrer les coûts qu’il fait supporter à l’environnement.»  Division sur la loi sur le CO2 Ces prises de position ont trouvé leur expression sur les nombreux calicots portés 'Parmi les manifestants, un argument est souvent revenu, exprimé notamment par Magali, une étudiante de 24 ans: «Avec le Covid, on a vu que les gouvernements pouvaient agir rapidement.', 'Ils doivent accélérera le progrès technologique et garantira des emplois chez nous, plutôt que de nous laisser sur le banc des spectateurs à regarder d’autres pays occuper les secteurs novateurs.', 'Les grévistes c’est que la sortie du charbon, du pétrole et des énergies fossiles est inéluctable.', 'La voie est tracée.', 'Tous les partenaires économiques de la Suisse vont dans cette direction.', 'Un non à la montagne souffrent du réchauffement climatique.', 'Mais la nouvelle loi ne va-t-elle pas pénaliser les habitants de ces régions, qui ont plus besoin de la voiture car ils ont moins facilement accès situera-t-elle pas entre ces deux extrémités?', 'Nous avons pris comme modèle une famille représentative: les parents, deux enfants, chauffage au mazout, voiture à essence, un vol en Europe par exemple pour l’aider à changer de chauffage.', 'Il ira aux communes pour créer des chauffages à distance et aux régions de montagne pour réaliser des ouvrages de protection contre les crues.', 'Les jeunes auront des trains de nuit.', 'Mais j’aimerais rappeler le mécanisme de base: les taxes sont incitatives.', 'Elles ont pour but de convaincre la population de changer ses habitudes afin de renforçant l’économie circulaire et en favorisant le recyclage des batteries.', 'Pour cela, nous avons, ici en Suisse, des entreprises performantes.', 'La loi sur le CO2 n’est qu’une étape.', 'Il y en aura une autre.', 'Vous l’avez annoncée.', 'Ce sera le contre-projet à l’initiative pour les glaciers.', 'Quelles mesures comprendra-t-il?', 'Commençons déjà avec cette décennie, qui est cruciale.', chauffages.', 'Si plus personne ne se chauffe au mazout, on aura résolu une bonne partie du problème.', 'En attendant, la loi sur le CO2 n’interdit rien, c’est une loi libérale qui nous fait faire un
