processed_text: "We don't gain anything to make the CO2 law fail" CLIMATE For Environment Minister Simonetta Sommaruga, "the release of fossil fuels is inevitable." We should start without delay the necessary changes in mobility and heating. The taxes are being encouraged, she says PROPOSED BY BERNARD WUTHRICH, BERNE @BdWuthrich The new CO2 law is being fought by a double referendum, one launched by automobile and oil organizations and supported by the UDC, the other by a part of the climate strikers. Federal Councillor Simonetta Sommaruga responded to their criticisms. Is Switzerland more affected by global warming than other countries? Yes, in Switzerland, the Alpine country, temperatures rise twice as much as the world average. Glacier melts, agriculture suffers ever more frequent periods of drought. This generates significant costs, largely borne by the municipalities and the cantons. What does the CO2 law actually bring to mountain areas? The CO2 Act creates a fund that will help municipalities to carry out flood protections and landslides caused by the melting of glaciers or to stabilize lifts. This is also why the Groupement pour les régions de montagne and the Swiss Alpine Club support the bill. Opponents say that many countries are failing to meet Paris commitments and that Switzerland's efforts will only reduce global CO2 emissions by half a million. Is that worth it? Switzerland is not alone. The EU and even the US have launched ambitious programmes. The new law will speed up technological progress and ensure jobs at home, rather than leaving us on the spectators' bench watching other countries occupy innovative sectors. Climate strikers want the state of emergency to be proclaimed and climate neutrality to be achieved by 2030 already. How do you respond to their impatience? I met them. I understand their impatience and I appreciate that they are very well informed. But they won't gain anything by defeating the CO2 law, because we would lose years to tie up a new project. In case of no, the oil and automobile lobby would be the big winner. Halving our CO2 emissions in the next ten years is already an ambitious goal. The new law promotes investment in Switzerland. It's better than paying $8 billion a year abroad to buy oil. You're pointing the finger at oil and automobile organizations. But is it not legitimate for them to defend their economic model and their jobs? In our democratic system, a referendum is always legitimate. What we need to know is that the release of coal, oil and fossil fuels is inevitable. The path is set. All of Switzerland's economic partners are moving in this direction. A no to the law will not prevent this transformation. Maintenance of a petrol car is increasingly expensive. The garage operators will focus on other propulsion models, electric or hybrid. They will always have work, but it will not be exactly the same as today. Switzerland has the training and innovation potential to support this change. The oil and automobile lobby is not alone in fighting the law. GastroSwitzerland also supports the referendum. Are the concerns of this industry, which is already very affected by the pandemic, not legitimate? Today, only large companies can free themselves from the CO2 tax, with climate-friendly measures. With the new law, SMEs will be able to do so too. This will benefit the carpenter, the baker, the restaurant owner. J的observes that, unlike GastroSwitzerland, HotellerieSwitzerland supports the new law. Mountain regions suffer from global warming. But is the new law not going to penalise the inhabitants of these areas, who need the car more because they have less access to public transport? The inhabitants of these areas are more dependent on the car, that is true. However, the new law encourages importers to market cars that consume less fuel. People who need one will pay less, even if they don't opt for an electric model. In addition, a majority of households in peripheral regions are already heating without oil or natural gas. They do not pay the CO2 tax but still receive their share of the redistribution. It's positive for them. And they fly less often than city dwellers. In the end, they will benefit from the law and the return of the tax. Your services have calculated that the law would cost an additional 100 francs to a family of four who do not change their habits. Opponents put forward figures ten times higher. Honestly, won't the truth lie between these two ends? We have taken as a model a representative family: parents, two children, heating oil, petrol car, one flight in Europe per year. Opponents took extreme examples. Do you know many families who have a 250 square meter villa that consumes a lot of fuel and makes three or four flights away each year? I'm not. The principle of the law is simple. Those who behave environmentally friendly will save money through the tax redistribution mechanism. That is why the law is social and supportive of families. Do we not run the risk that the Swiss will fly to a foreign airport close to our borders, which will reduce the amounts to be redistributed? All neighbouring countries already levy a tax on airline tickets. It is certainly lower. But it is not redistributed to the population. It is part of public budgets. Our mechanism is very social: 51% of revenues are reimbursed to the population, including children, and the other half feed the climate fund. Is this climate fund not a gas plant that promises a lot of money to many people? It will be used to finance many projects: money will go to the population, for example to help it change heating. He will go to the municipalities to create remote heating and mountain areas to carry out flood protection works. Young people will have night trains. But I would like to recall the basic mechanism: taxes are incentives. They aim to convince the population to change their habits in order to reduce CO2 emissions. To replace the current fleet with electric vehicles, batteries will have to be purchased using ores, such as lithium, that must be extracted from the earth. Is it really ecological? The extraction of raw materials is a sensitive issue. I know her well, because I was formerly president of Swissaid and I was able to observe the consequences of the extraction of cobalt but also of oil. Switzerland is concerned about this issue. We still need to make progress, for example by strengthening the circular economy and promoting battery recycling. For this, we have, here in Switzerland, successful companies. The CO2 law is only one step. There'll be another one. You announced it. This will be the counter-project for glaciers. What measures will it include? Let us start with this decade, which is crucial. If nothing is done now, we will have to make such a catch-up effort after 2030 that it will cost significantly more to achieve climate neutrality in 2050. But I cannot say today what measures will have to be taken after 2030. This will depend on many factors, such as technological change, the degree of electrification of mobility and the replacement of heating. If no one heats up anymore, we'll have solved a lot of the problem. Meanwhile, the CO2 law does not prohibit anything, it is a liberal law that makes us take an important step forward for climate protection.

processed_text: "The CO2 law lays down a framework for finally beginning to reduce our emissions" In a joint statement, Swiss scientists support the revision of the CO2 law, which was put to vote in June. Three questions to Sonia Seneviratne, climatologist at the EPFZ Mattia Pillonel Sonia Seneviratne is a climatologist at the Swiss Federal Polytechnic School in Zurich. On 22 April, she and many of the world's scientists issued a statement calling for a yes vote on the revision of the CO2 law because of the climate emergency. "Time": The scientific world calls for the yes to the CO2 law. Why take a stand? Sonia Seneviratne: It is important for us to position ourselves, simply because there is an urgent need to act. It is essential that this vote is passed. If not, it would be catastrophic. The CO2 law provides a framework for finally beginning to reduce our emissions. It provides a number of objectives and incentives that encourage people to consume less fossil fuels. The initiative is pushing for behaviour that is more in line with the goals set out in the Paris Agreement. A refusal would make us take a huge delay. It cannot be said that the law is extremely ambitious, but it is an indispensable first step towards the right direction. What do you mean by "first step"? If we really want to be in line with the Paris Agreement, we need to set bolder goals. One of the problems of the CO2 law is that it includes emissions compensation abroad. In fact, our carbon emissions will not decrease by 50% in Switzerland, but rather by 38%. But if we want to stabilize global warming, the goal is obviously to achieve zero emissions. This is the next part, which has not yet been discussed in Parliament. The Federal Council suggested this target for 2050. After the vote, it is imperative that we continue the debate and get to zero as soon as possible. The net zero in 2050, is it a achievable goal you think? I think if the will is there, we can. Finally, we don't really have a choice. In case we don't get there, we'll have lost the chance to limit the warming to 1.5 degrees. You have to be aware of the consequences. Switzerland has ratified the Paris Agreement, and it was one of the countries that wanted to do so. It is a question of coherence in our future policy. In fact, we should even aim at zero net by 2040, if we want to ensure that the temperature rise is kept below 1.5 degrees for a lesser impact on the climate.
author: Sonia Seneviratne

There are some absences that are very quickly noticed. On Thursday, the youth sections of the country's main parties launched their campaign for a yes to the CO2 law submitted to the vote on 13 June. In order to symbolize the importance of this project, which is supposed to limit global warming, they sent representatives who have not yet reached the age of 18. Two parties, however, lacked the call: the UDC Youth, but especially the PLR Youth. For if within the Agrarian party the rejection clearly prevails, it is the opposite in the PLR, which is fully committed to the "yes". "As we are divided, we leave the freedom to vote," explains Nicolas Jutzet, Vice-President of Youth PLR. That young people thus leave their elders behind leaves no one indifferent in the LRP. "It doesn't please us," admits his general secretary, Fanny Noghero. This law is primarily intended to preserve the environment for future generations. It is a pity that the main concerned do not follow us." "Neither drama nor surprise" However, Fanny Noghero relativizes this fracture. "This is neither a drama nor a surprise. Young PLRs often have more libertarian positions than the party." Evidence with the new police measures against terrorism, also put to the vote on 13 June. The youth section advocates no, while the project is led by Federal Councillor PLR Karin Keller-Sutter. Within the Young PLR, you stay straight in your boots. "Global warming is an important issue, but some of the answers provided by the law are not defensible," says Nicolas Jutzet, who recalls that the project also divides the Swiss party. While it acknowledges that the PLR has committed itself to incorporating a liberal approach into the text, it points to measures that will increase bureaucracy and risk creating additional costs. "An attempt is being made to impose new behaviours through bans and paternalistic demands," said the Young PLR in a press release. But the worst was avoided. In fact, manoeuvres were carried out behind the scenes to remove the freedom to vote, while the non could have won. What would have been a disavowal for the presidency. Florent Quiquerez

One less passenger on an airplane, in addition to the loss of profits for the carrier, is also, in terms of unsold goods: a train ticket to the airport or a taxi race, a consumption or meal before departure, a tourist guide or newspapers, a purchase at a shop and a passenger tax. This is largely enough to put a no to the CO2 law on the ballot on 13 June next. Catherine Locca

longue plaidoirie, Laïla Batou, avocate du prévenu, revient sur le droit de manifester et l’état de nécessité, déjà invoqué dans d’autres procès liés aux manifestations proclimat.', 'Elle rappelle "The struggle continues," said Olivier de Marcellus in front of the courthouse on Thursday afternoon. The proclimate activist appeared before the Police Court after challenging two violations imposed by criminal orders. But before going to the judge, he wanted to speak to some 30 activists who had come to support him. He had brought the leaflets himself. "I came for Olivier because I find these accusations ridiculous," explains Martine. The seven-year-old is accused of having twice violated the Public Domain Protests Act (LMDPu) by organizing unauthorised rallies. "Christmas Ballad" The facts date back to 2018. In December, the Break Free collective, including Olivier de Marcellus, organized a "Christmas Ballad" in Rues-Basses to denounce the positions of the PLR and the UDC on the CO2 law. "We were about fifteen, some dressed as Santa Claus, walking on the sidewalks, singing and distributing leaflets," said the activist, on the stand. He assured him: the small group had no banner, no megaphone and did not make any obstructions to the movement. A policeman crosses the group and the sum of dispersal, but the militants, thinking in their rights, continue their journey. It is only after the action, when Olivier de Marcellus, then alone, returns with the signs under his arm, that the police question the street of Coutance. One hundred kilos of coal L'another case concerns slightly earlier facts. Also with the Break Free collective, Olivier de Marcellus is accused of having, without prior permission, organized a demonstration to pour 100 kilos of coal in front of the German consulate on September 19, 2018. The action was aimed at supporting the Zadists of the Hambach Forest in western Germany, threatened by the extension of a coal mine of the RWE company. As with the first charge, the activist denies having been an instigator of the action. And when asked why the activists left without cleaning up, despite the demands of the police: "We are accused of not cleaning our little pile, but does RWE remove his big shit after polluting the planet?" Smile in the room. In a lengthy argument, Laila Batou, the defendant's lawyer, discusses the right to demonstrate and the state of necessity, already invoked in other trials related to proclimate demonstrations. It also recalls that, at its adoption in 2008, the Public Domain Demonstrations Act (LMDPu) was intended to address "large-scale demonstrations to avoid spillovers and not to burden climate activists disguised as Santa Claus". According to her, this action was comparable to a school leaving or a bachelor's funeral, and in this case it should also be announced to the authorities. The lawyer will conclude by recalling that her client has been a fervent environmental activist for many years. "Olivier de Marcellus will be among the people who have contributed to global awareness of global warming. And it is not these people that must be amended or sent to prison for five days." The judgment will be rendered later. Lea Frischknecht

text: ['Un oui libéral à la loi sur le CO2 OPINION La loi CO2, sans être parfaite, est un bon compromis et un premier pas vers une Suisse climatiquement neutre.', 'Même si l’on peut déplore l’absence de mesures destinées à certains secteurs, notamment l’agriculture ou la finance, la loi a su rallier tous les bords politiques, à l’exception des extrêmes.', 'Par ailleurs, contrairement à ce argumentation qui, manifestement, ne comprend pas très bien les mécanismes prévus et leur ampleur ou, au minimum, dénote une gymnastique mentale incohérente.', 'Avec ce système, à chacun donc de prendre ses responsabilités en main et de diminuer ses émissions de CO2  Il convient donc de donner quelques exemples pour illustrer mes propos.', 'Prenons une famille de quatre personnes, possédant une petite voiture essence, avec laquelle elle parcourt 5000 kilomètres par année.', 'Elle vit dans un appartement de 120 m2, chauffé au gaz, et part une fois par année en voyage en avion, à moins de cinq heures de vol de la Suisse; une famille relativement moyenne en somme.', 'Malgré ce que certains peuvent penser, cette famille recevra plus d’argent qu’elle n’en dépensera en taxes.', 'Elle peut s’attendre à un gain supplémentaire net de 80 francs par an.', 'De même, une famille de ce type qui aurait décidé de remplacer ses trajets en avion par des trajets en train ou d’abandonner la voiture gagnerait encore plus.', 'Prenons maintenant une autre famille de quatre personnes à titre d’exemple.', 'Celle-ci, peu soucieuse du climat, roule en véhicule particulièrement polluant et parcourt 10 business.', 'Nous parlons donc ici d’une famille aisée et polluante.', 'Elle pourra s’attendre à payer environ 1000 francs par année.', 'Une somme relativement indolore pour une famille aisée mais qui sera justement reversée aux familles dont l’impact écologique est moindre en comparaison.', 'En effet, l’idée de cette loi est avant tout de récompenser les ménages qui polluent moins que la moyenne mathématiquement, une redistribution vers les plus faibles revenus si les habitudes ne changent pas.', 'Au contraire, en cas d’adaptation des habitudes, effet recherché par cette loi, l’impact sur le à notre consommation.', 'Avec ce système, à chacun donc de prendre ses responsabilités en main et de diminuer ses émissions de CO2.', 'Il est donc nécessaire d’accepter ce pas en avant dans la politique climatique suisse, qui nous permettra d’avancer sur d’autres projets à l’avenir, notamment afin de s’attaquer directement à la demande de certains produits, aux politiques de gestion des processed_text: A liberal yes to the CO2 OPINION law The CO2 law, without being perfect, is a good compromise and a first step towards a climate-neutral Switzerland. Although the lack of measures for certain sectors, such as agriculture or finance, is regrettable, the law has been able to win over all political sides, with the exception of extremes. Moreover, contrary to what some right-wing opponents claim, who suddenly seem to discover a social fibre, it is both climatically and socially just. Climate just because the mechanisms put in place respect the polluter pays principle. A liberal and ecological system that seeks to restore the real cost of the products and services we consume, thus reflecting an incentive logic and allowing both to strengthen investments in critical ecological areas such as the energy transition and to minimize the impact on the purchasing power of households through a system of payment of part of the revenue from the tax. This mechanism of reversal is one of the essential points of this text and guarantees a form of social justice. Today, the Young Liberal Radicals (JLR), whose logic is, as usual, more libertarian and anti-statistical than anything else, join the extreme left in an argumentation which clearly does not understand the mechanisms envisaged and their magnitude or, at least, an incoherent mental gymnastics. With this system, everyone should therefore take responsibility and reduce CO2 emissions. So we should give a few examples to illustrate my remarks. Let's take a family of four, owning a small gasoline car, with which she travels 5,000 kilometers a year. She lives in an apartment of 120 m2, heated with gas, and leaves once a year on a plane trip, less than five hours flight from Switzerland; a relatively average family in sum. Despite what some may think, this family will receive more money than it will spend on taxes. It can expect an additional net gain of 80 francs per year. Similarly, a family of this type who would have decided to replace their air trips with train trips or abandon the car would gain even more. Let us now take another family of four as an example. It is not climate-friendly and is driven in a particularly polluting vehicle and travels 10,000 kilometres per year. She also lives in a large house of 400 m2 also heated by gas. Finally, she travels several times a year by plane, by family, which is also in business class. So here we are talking about an easy and polluting family. It will be able to expect to pay about 1000 francs per year. A relatively painless amount for a well-off family, which will be given back to families with less ecological impact in comparison. Indeed, the idea of this law is above all to reward households that pollute less than average and to charge those who pollute more than average. As we know, well-off households tend to pollute more. This means that, beyond the incentive character, there will be a mathematical redistribution to the lowest incomes if habits do not change. On the contrary, in the event of a change in habits, the effect sought by this law, the impact on purchasing power should be relatively non-existent, regardless of the level of income. The purpose of this law is above all to tackle the climate crisis by integrating environmental costs into our consumption. With this system, it is up to everyone to take charge of their responsibilities and reduce their CO2 emissions. It is therefore necessary to accept this step forward in Swiss climate policy, which will allow us to move forward on other projects in the future, in particular in order to directly address the demand for certain products, the environmental risk management policies of certain companies and in order to invest in an ambitious and indispensable transition. MARC WUARIN COPRESIDENT OF GENEVOUS YOUNG VERTALIBERALS

processed_text: In the countryside, the temptation to vote 5xnon In the agricultural world, heated by the two anti-pesticidal initiatives, many could refuse all the objects that were put to the vote on Sunday in order to manifest their anger. A "swimming" reflex that directly threatens the CO2 law Yan Pauchard They will certainly be many to slip a 5xnon into the ballot box on Sunday. As a slogan for these federal votes of 13 June, the formula resonates increasingly in the agricultural world. Heated by both anti-pesticidal initiatives, many are ready to reject all objects in order to manifest their anger. "We often hear farmers say they will refuse everything," says Nicolas Kolly, UDC Group Leader at the Grand Conseil Fribourg. Another canton and another political side, the finding is similar. President of the Vert·es Vaudois, Alberto Mocchi "sees this 5xno appear increasingly, especially on social networks". "The two plant initiatives are a break, they are experienced in the countryside as a direct attack," observes the future trustee of the village of Daillens, in Gros-de-Vaud, a region where "the debates about these objects are extremely tense." The emotion is indeed strong. "Many peasants are shocked by the attitudes and comments of some politicians who have not hesitated to claim that they were sowing death in their fields," said the Friburgish national councillor Pierre-André Page, a farmer by profession, in the Glâne. On the side of the supporters of the two texts, the adviser to the Neuchâtel states Céline Vara for her part regrets that, in recent months, the Federal Council has made "alarmist comments on the consequences in case of acceptance of the two anti-pesticidal initiatives, by eluciating the benefits that our country can have by doing without these products and by affluent people already under pressure from the pandemic". Consequences for the CO2 Act? Neuchâtel is concerned about the consequences of these stresses, in particular, on the outcome of the CO2 law, which, despite broad political support, sees the "yes" being eroded in the polls. "Friends falsely denounce an ecological project while it is a compromise supported by the PLR and the Centre," notes Céline Vara, who notes that her colleagues from the right centre find it difficult to convince their base. The last few weeks have been challenging. The nerves are alive. After death threats, Céline Vara asked for police protection. "I had never experienced anything like this," he admits. "The campaign has gone wrong. Clearly. On both sides", deplores the Friburgish PLR Councillor Jacques Bourgeois, who calls for "a cold head". "We must go beyond the feeling of saying "we will show them" and look at each object calmly," continues the former director of the Swiss Farmers' Union, who pleads in particular for the yes to the CO2 law, "which remains an incentive law": "Farmers have every interest in it, because they will be the first victims of global warming that will impact their crops." Rejection also in the cities For Kevin Grangier, the president of the Vaudian UDC, this opposition reflex is not unique to the peripheral regions but also affects the cities. "I was able to see several calls to vote 5Xnon on open billboards in Lausanne," he says. The explanation is a certain general rejection of what comes from the state. "Everything accumulates," he analyses. A law that will significantly increase the price of gasoline, thus restricting freedom of movement, a law that is absolved against the background of health measures and controversy on the vaccine passport, or a law against terrorism that is not certain that it will not be used to monitor a climate activist or a person deemed to be a plottist." Green National Councillor Christophe Clivaz also sees "a clear driving effect between the five objects although their problem is different". For Valaisan, this refusal reflex cannot be explained without taking into account the context of the Covid-19. "Five objects of voting, that's already a lot. They're complicated to understand. After a year of pandemics, the population is tired and tired of the various restrictions. It's simple to finally say no to everything. It is a pity when it is urgent to take measures in favour of the climate." On the margins of society During these votes, "a Neinsager temptation" is possible, in the eyes of political scientist Pascal Sciarini, among farmers "formerly protected and who feel abandoned today". But also in other spheres. In his view, a context of great uncertainty always introduces a bias favouring the status quo. The professor of the University of Geneva remains cautious about the consequences on the final result of the elections, which he believes is only within a margin of society: "The covid law or the law on police measures to combat terrorism should not be pre-tested, but it is certain that the CO2 law is the most fragile."

While over the years the work has expanded, some passages remain dizzying in the Anniviers Valley. Between Niouc and Les Pontis, the route seems to be suspended in the void. There is no room for two lanes. However, on average, nearly 3000 vehicles borrow each day. Car-dependent, like the majority of the inhabitants of the peripheral regions, the Anniviards will thus be affected by the CO2 law, which is expected to lead to an increase in the price of fuel. Every day, public transport carries out 11 races from the plain. On average, you have to wait 75 to 90 minutes between two postal buses. This discourages more than one inhabitant from using them. "It must be accepted that individual transport will always be necessary for peripheral regions like ours," says Melly. The president of the municipality of Anniviers adds: "To maintain a life, a school in the valley, we need a minimum population and therefore pendulums who work in Sion or Martigny and who represent about 30% of the assets of the municipality." The car, a necessary comfort Are there Annivors who do not own a private vehicle? David Melly doesn't know anything about it. "Even citizens who pay great attention to the environment have a car," he slips. Located on the terrace of a restaurant in Vissoie, Delphine is part of this fringe of the population. If she admits that she could use public transport, she points out that the car offers some comfort. In some situations, it is still necessary: "If I decide to go to the cinema in Sierre, there is no more bus to go back to the valley once the session is over." On the weekend, the last race starts from the plain at 8:45 pm. In order to form an opinion on the law subject to vote, Delphine calculated the extra cost that acceptance of the text would entail for her. It is estimated at 75 francs per year. More than supermontable, she says. And even if it were to be superior, this "penalty" does not frighten. "I agree to pay more to live in this incredible setting," she says, looking at the surrounding mountains. These peaks attract many tourists throughout the year. In the winter, they visit the ski areas of the valley. The latter will also be affected by the CO2 law, due to diesel used by the ladies. For the Grimentz-Zinal ski lifts, the bill should increase by "some tens of thousands of francs," says director Pascal Bourquin. For the time being, there is no alternative. "We depend on the manufacturers and on the evolution of the engines," says Pascal Bourquin, who sees the first prototypes of the hydrogen lady as a solution for the future. Acceptance of the law may well encourage owners to change these devices. But in the mountains, the deal is a little different. "Climate realities are greatly increasing the cost of fuel oil replacement above 1500 metres above sea level," says Melly. This is especially the case for remote residences in village centres. Since 2004, Anniviers has held a 7.7% stake in the Gougra driving forces, representing a production of 45 million kilowatt hours per year. As much as total consumption in the communal territory. The 4500 hectares of forest, maintained by the commune and the bourgeoisie, allow CO2 to be absorbed twice that produced by the local population. Environmental actions that go unnoticed in the eyes of urban residents, says Melly. Similarities with the Lex Weber and the LAT The Christian Democrat has the impression that the peripheral regions serve as scapegoats for the supporters of the law. Once again. Because David Melly found similarities in the current campaign with the Lex Weber in 2012 and the LAT a year later. "Despite the acceptance of these two texts, Switzerland is still at the same speed. We simply gave ourselves a good conscience by slowing down the pace in the mountains. With the CO2 law, peripheral regions will be penalized, without taking into account their efforts to promote the environment, and generate a flow of money from these regions to urban centres," he regrets. Aware of the need to act, David Melly would prefer it to be done by inducement rather than by obligation. An obligation that could encourage Anniviards to oppose the CO2 law? David Melly isn't sure. text: ['Opinions  La loi qu’il faut pour agir en faveur du climat Alexandre de Senarclens Député PLR  Le réchauffement climatique est un des plus grands défis posés à l’humanité.', 'La Suisse est particulièrement touchée, le pays se réchauffe deux fois plus vite que la moyenne mondiale avec pour conséquences vagues de chaleur, sécheresses, inondations, fonte des glaciers et recul de la biodiversité, pour ne citer qu’elles.', 'Plus globalement, ces bouleversements climatiques ont et auront des incidences géopolitiques avec des déplacements de population du sud vers le nord («réfugiés climatiques») et des tensions renouvelées sur la maîtrise de l’eau dans des régions du monde souffrant de sécheresse.', 'Conscient de ses responsabilités, notre pays a signé l’Accord de Paris sur le climat et s’est engagé à réduire ses émissions de gaz à effet de serre (CO2) de moitié d’ici à 2030, par rapport à son niveau de 1990.', 'C’est précisément l’objectif que poursuit la nouvelle loi sur le CO2.', 'Pour y parvenir, cette loi prévoit nombre de mesures.', 'On peut citer, en particulier, les nouvelles normes pour les bâtiments; des règles d’émission de CO2 plus contraignantes pour les importateurs de véhicules; une hausse de 10 à 12 centimes par litre d’essence à partir de 2025; une augmentation à certaines conditions de l’actuelle taxe sur le CO2 avec la possibilité pour les entreprises d’en être exemptées si elles prennent des engagements pour réduire leurs émissions; une nouvelle taxe sur les billets d’avion en fonction de la distance parcourue et de la classe de transport.', 'Ces taxes sont toutes dites «incitatives».', 'Ainsi, leur produit ne tombe pas dans les caisses de l’État mais est reversé aux citoyens et aux entreprises.', 'En particulier, un fonds pour le climat sera créé pour permettre l’assainissement des bâtiments, la promotion des sources d’énergie renouvelable, le remplacement des chauffages polluants, etc.', 'Ce fonds contribuera aussi à la promotion de l’innovation, par des prêts aux entreprises pour assurer le développement et la commercialisation de procédés visant à réduire les émissions.', 'Le solde de l’argent prélevé, non versé au fonds pour le climat, sera redistribué à la population par un rabais sur les primes d’assurances maladie ainsi qu’aux caisses de compensation AVS.', 'Cette nouvelle loi renforce la loi actuellement en vigueur.', 'En termes économiques, elle offrira des opportunités de croissance et des incitations à l’innovation.', 'De même, le recul de la consommation d’énergie fossile aura pour effet de diminuer notre dépendance vis-à-vis de l’étranger, renforçant ainsi la position des entreprises suisses face à la concurrence internationale.', 'La loi sur le CO2 est basée sur le principe du pollueur-payeur afin d’inciter le citoyen à changer certains de ses comportements.', 'Ces mesures sont efficaces et vont nous permettre d’atteindre nos objectifs environnementaux.', 'Agissons maintenant pour préserver nos conditions de vie et soutenons la loi sur le CO2 dans les urnes.', 'Face-à-face Loi CO2: que voter?', 'Les Chambres ont approuvé la loi sur le CO2 mais un référendum lancé contre elle ayant abouti, le vote des Suisses est requis sur cet objet le 13 juin.', 'Destiné à mettre la Suisse au diapason de l’Accord de Paris sur le climat, ce texte est défendu ici par le député genevois Alexandre de Senarclens et combattu par le délégué communication et campagnes politiques du Centre patronal à Lausanne.']
processed_text: Opinions The law it takes to act in favor of climate Alexander de Senarclens Deputy PLR Global warming is one of the greatest challenges facing humanity. Switzerland is particularly affected, the country warms twice as fast as the global average with the consequences of heat waves, droughts, floods, melting glaciers and loss of biodiversity, to name but a few. More broadly, these climate changes have and will have geopolitical implications with population displacements from the south to the north ("climate refugees") and renewed tensions over water control in drought-stricken regions of the world. Aware of its responsibilities, our country has signed the Paris Climate Agreement and has committed itself to reducing its greenhouse gas (CO2) emissions by half by 2030, from its 1990 level. This is precisely the objective of the new CO2 law. To achieve this, the Act provides for a number of measures. These include new standards for buildings; more stringent CO2 emission rules for vehicle importers; an increase of 10 to 12 cents per litre of gasoline from 2025; an increase under certain conditions of the current CO2 tax with the possibility for companies to be exempted if they make commitments to reduce their emissions; a new tax on airline tickets based on distance travelled and class of transport. These taxes are all so-called "incentives". Thus, their product does not fall into the State funds but is donated to citizens and businesses. In particular, a climate fund will be set up to enable the clean-up of buildings, the promotion of renewable energy sources, the replacement of pollutant heaters, etc. This fund will also help promote innovation through loans to businesses to develop and commercialize processes to reduce emissions. The balance of the money collected, not paid to the climate fund, will be redistributed to the population by a discount on health insurance premiums and to the AVS compensation funds. This new law reinforces the law currently in force. In economic terms, it will offer opportunities for growth and incentives for innovation. Similarly, the decline in fossil energy consumption will reduce our dependence on foreign countries, thereby strengthening the position of Swiss companies in the face of international competition. The CO2 law is based on the polluter pays principle in order to encourage citizens to change some of their behaviour. These measures are effective and will enable us to achieve our environmental objectives. Let us now act to preserve our living conditions and support the CO2 law in the ballot box. Face-to-face CO2 law: what to vote for? The Chambers approved the CO2 law, but a referendum against it was launched and the Swiss vote was required on this subject on 13 June. Intended to bring Switzerland into line with the Paris Climate Agreement, this text is defended here by the Geneva MP Alexandre de Senarclens and fought by the communications and political campaign delegate of the Centre patronal in Lausanne.

text: [' Subjectif  De la liberté  MA SEMAINE SUISSE «La Suisse ne se lie pas, elle défend ses intérêts en s’adaptant au plus fort», écrivait dans ces colonnes la chroniqueuse Joëlle Kuntz (LT du 05.05.2021).', 'Voilà pourquoi un jour ou l’autre la Suisse s’adaptera aux règles de l’UE, non sans quelques années d’épreuves.', 'C’est une pression à court terme.', 'Il est toutefois une menace bien plus grave, quoique plus diffuse et plus lointaine, qui mine sournoisement la cohésion nationale et la stabilité des institutions.', 'C’est la perte de confiance dans l’Etat et dans les autorités, alimentée par de profonds antagonismes au sein de la population sur la conception de la liberté.', 'Des discordances qui traversent même le Conseil fédéral où les socialistes s’opposent à la loi contre le terrorisme et l’UDC à la loi sur le CO2 et à la loi Covid-19.', 'La défiance, voire la suspicion, qui s’exprime avec véhémence provient aujourd’hui des adversaires de la loi Covid-19, «Amis de la Constitution» et autres adeptes de la théorie de la dictature sanitaire.', 'Ils sont des centaines, voire des milliers à manifester leur hostilité chaque semaine en Suisse au nom de la liberté.', 'En réalité les cinq objets soumis le 13 juin au vote populaire, les deux initiatives phytosanitaires, la loi Covid-19, la loi sur le CO2 et la loi contre le terrorisme, sont révélateurs de deux visions irréconciliables des droits individuels et des contraintes collectives nécessaires à la préservation de notre environnement et à la sécurité physique ou sanitaire, voire à contrôler l’assujettissement aux algorithmes.', 'Le peuple est de plus en plus souvent appelé à trancher du même débat: interdiction de se dissimuler le visage, identification électronique, entreprises responsables, etc.', 'Deux siècles après Benjamin Constant, nous voici en train de rejouer le débat qu’il avait théorisé en 1819, «de la liberté des Anciens comparée à celle des Modernes».', 'L’opposition entre une conception de la liberté «qui se composait de la participation active et constante au pouvoir collectif», au risque de «l’assujettissement de l’individu à l’autorité de l’ensemble», et une liberté consistant à permettre à chacun de vivre, de penser, de parler, d’aller et venir, d’entreprendre ou de commercer en citoyens autonomes.', 'Une description rudimentaire, certes, qui ne tient pas compte de la complexité et des interférences de la société moderne et des enjeux environnementaux.', 'La liberté signifie-t-elle uniquement l’absence de contraintes sur les individus ou la possibilité de continuer à décider en commun de restrictions pour échapper collectivement à la tyrannie du terrorisme ou à l’emprise des pandémies et de la dégradation des conditions de vie?', 'Ce débat entre liberté et sécurité, la Grande-Bretagne l’avait eu dès 2005 lors de la vague de terrorisme qui avait frappé Londres.', 'Premier ministre à l’époque, Tony Blair admettait que les menaces bien réelles allaient toujours plus peser sur notre perception libérale des droits individuels.', '«Mais parce que notre conception de la liberté n’évolue pas au même rythme que le monde réel, ces libertés sont menacées», prophétisait-il.', 'Les derniers sondages avant le scrutin du 13 juin montrent en tout cas que plus la menace semble éloignée, moins la population est prête à sacrifier son droit à la jouissance immédiate.', 'Ce sont ces contradictions qu’un gouvernement hétéroclite, loin d’un Tony Blair, est supposé arbitrer.', 'Et cela nécessite une vision du long terme dont un gouvernement arithmétique est incapable.', 'YVES PETIGNAT JOURNALISTE  Plus la menace semble éloignée, moins la population est prête à sacrifier son droit à la jouissance immédiate']
processed_text: Subjective From Freedom MY WEEK SWITZERLAND "Switzerland does not bind, it defends its interests by adapting to the strongest," wrote in these columns columnist Joëlle Kuntz (LT of 05.05.2021). This is why Switzerland will one day adapt to EU rules, not without a few years of trials. It's a short-term pressure. It is, however, a much more serious, albeit more diffuse and distant, threat that skews national cohesion and institutional stability. It is the loss of confidence in the state and in the authorities, fuelled by deep antagonisms within the population on the conception of freedom. Discords that even cross the Federal Council where the socialists oppose the anti-terrorism and UDC law to the CO2 law and the Covid-19 law. The mistrust, even suspicion, which is expressed vehemently today comes from the opponents of the Covid-19 law, "Friends of the Constitution" and other followers of the theory of health dictatorship. They are hundreds, if not thousands, of demonstrating their hostility in Switzerland every week in the name of freedom. In reality, the five objects submitted on 13 June to the popular vote, the two phytosanitary initiatives, the Covid-19 Act, the CO2 Act and the Anti-Terrorism Act, reveal two irreconcilable visions of individual rights and collective constraints necessary to preserve our environment and to protect physical or health security, and even to control the subjection to algorithms. The people are increasingly called upon to decide on the same debate: prohibition of face concealment, electronic identification, responsible companies, etc. Two centuries after Benjamin Constant, we are replaying the debate he had theorized in 1819, "of the freedom of the Ancients compared to that of the Moderns". The opposition between a conception of freedom "which consisted of active and constant participation in collective power", at the risk of "subjugation of the individual to the authority of the whole", and a freedom consisting of allowing everyone to live, think, speak, come and come, to undertake or trade as autonomous citizens. A rudimentary description, of course, that does not take into account the complexity and interference of modern society and environmental issues. Does freedom mean only the absence of constraints on individuals or the possibility of continuing to decide jointly on restrictions to escape collectively from the tyranny of terrorism or the grip of pandemics and the deterioration of living conditions? This debate between freedom and security, Britain had had it since 2005 during the wave of terrorism that had struck London. At the time, Prime Minister Tony Blair admitted that real threats would increasingly affect our liberal perception of individual rights. "But because our conception of freedom does not evolve at the same pace as the real world, these freedoms are threatened," he prophesied. The latest polls before the 13 June election show, in any case, that the longer the threat seems to be, the less people are willing to sacrifice their right to immediate enjoyment. It is these contradictions that a heterogeneous government, far from a Tony Blair, is supposed to arbitrate. And that requires a long-term vision that an arithmetical government is unable to achieve. JOURNALIST YVES The longer the threat seems to be, the less people are willing to sacrifice their right to immediate enjoyment.
author: Joëlle Kuntz

text: [' A travers la loi sur le CO2, la bataille de la protection des Alpes est lancée Partisans et adversaires de la nouvelle loi sur le CO2 croisent le fer à distance.', 'Pour les premiers, la protection des Alpes, très exposées aux changements climatiques, doit dominer les débats.', 'Pour les seconds, c’est le porte-monnaie qui prime: la réforme coûte trop cher à la population et à l’économie  Bernard Wuthrich  La campagne référendaire contre la loi sur le CO2 s’anime.', 'Mardi, partisans et opposants ont confronté leurs arguments à distance autour des coûts et des bénéfices de la révision proposée.', 'Pour le comité d’opposition, composé de diverses associations économiques de la branche pétrolière, automobile, immobilière et patronale, la réforme coûte trop cher à la population et aux entreprises en pleine pandémie.', '«Dans la situation actuelle, il serait irresponsable d’imposer des charges encore plus lourdes à l’économie suisse, qui est aux prises avec la crise du coronavirus et les mesures de confinement depuis un an.', 'La nouvelle loi sur le CO2 rendrait le carburant, le mazout et le gaz plus chers, ce qui aurait un impact sur l’ensemble de la chaîne de valeur», avertit le président de GastroSuisse, Casimir Platzer, qui a rejoint le comité référendaire.', 'Le projet prévoit de relever le plafond de la taxe sur le CO2 sur les combustibles fossiles de 120 à 210\xa0francs par tonne émise et celui de la compensation pour l’importation de carburants de 5 à 10, puis 12 centimes par litre.', 'A cela s’ajoute une nouvelle taxe sur les billets d’avion qui oscillera entre 30 et 120\xa0francs par vol, selon la distance parcourue et la classe de voyage.', 'Casimir Platzer estime les coûts supplémentaires à environ 700\xa0millions de francs pour l’économie.', 'Une partie des recettes sera versée dans un fonds pour le climat.', 'Celui-ci sera utilisé pour subventionner la rénovation des bâtiments, des projets de lutte contre les crues et les éboulements et des programmes de reconversion énergétique, notamment.', 'Pour Christophe Reymond, directeur du Centre patronal, ce fonds «n’est rien d’autre qu’une usine à gaz à subventions, une cagnotte climatique, une boîte noire».', 'Les enjeux pour les régions alpines Justement, le fonds pour le climat prévoit d’allouer aux régions de montagne des aides financières pour lutter contre les risques naturels tels que les chutes de pierre, les éboulements, les glissements de terrain provoqués par la fonte des glaciers.', 'C’est pour cela que le comité de l’Initiative des Alpes a choisi, mardi, de présenter les enjeux dans un village des Alpes bernoises: Guttannen.', 'Juchée à 1000 mètres d’altitude, cette localité proche du col du Grimsel est exposée à des risques accrus de laves torrentielles et d’inondation que par le passé.', '«Les régions de montagne recevront des aides du fonds pour le climat pour se protéger contre les risques naturels», relève le conseiller national Jon Pult (PS/GR), président de l’Initiative des Alpes, qui se décrit lui-même comme un montagnard qui «souffre de voir les glaciers fondre et la nature se transformer à cause de la crise climatique.', 'Je suis donc d’autant plus en colère lorsque les opposants à la loi sur le CO2 nous traitent, nous, la population des montagnes, comme des rustres».', 'Le ton est donné, la campagne est lancée.', 'Elle dure jusqu’au 13\xa0juin, date du scrutin.']
processed_text: Through the CO2 law, the battle for the protection of the Alps is launched Partisans and opponents of the new CO2 law cross iron from a distance. For the former, the protection of the Alps, which is highly exposed to climate change, must dominate the debates. For the latter, it is the purse that prevails: the reform costs too much to the population and the economy Bernard Wuthrich The referendum campaign against the law on CO2. On Tuesday, supporters and opponents faced their arguments remotely about the costs and benefits of the proposed revision. For the opposition committee, composed of various economic associations in the oil, automotive, real estate and employer sectors, reform costs too much to the population and companies in the midst of a pandemic. "In the current situation, it would be irresponsible to impose even heavier burdens on the Swiss economy, which has been struggling with the coronavirus crisis and containment measures for the past year. The new CO2 law would make fuel, fuel oil and gas more expensive, which would have an impact on the entire value chain," warns GastroSwitzerland's president Casimir Platzer, who joined the referendum committee. The project plans to increase the CO2 tax ceiling on fossil fuels from 120 to 210 francs per tonne emitted and the compensation for the import of fuels from 5 to 10 and 12 cents per litre. To this is added a new tax on airline tickets which will oscillate between 30 and 120 francs per flight, depending on the distance travelled and the class of travel. Casimir Platzer estimates the additional costs to the economy at about 700 million francs. A portion of the revenue will be transferred to a climate fund. This will be used to subsidize the renovation of buildings, flood and fall-out projects and energy conversion programmes, among others. For Christophe Reymond, director of the Centre patronal, this fund "is nothing but a grant gas plant, a climate pool, a black box". The stakes for the Alpine regions The climate fund plans to allocate financial aid to mountain regions to combat natural risks such as rock falls, landslides and landslides caused by the melting of glaciers. That is why the Alpine Initiative Committee chose Tuesday to present the stakes in a village in the Bernese Alps: Guttannen. Skipped at 1000 meters above sea level, this locality near the Grimsel Pass is exposed to increased risks of torrential lavas and flooding than in the past. "Mountain regions will receive support from the climate fund to protect themselves from natural hazards," said National Advisor Jon Pult (PS/GR), president of the Alpine Initiative, who describes himself as a mountain mountain who "suffers from seeing glaciers melt and nature transform due to the climate crisis. I am therefore all the more angry when the opponents of the CO2 law treat us, the people of the mountains, as we are the rustres." The tone is set, the campaign is launched. It lasts until 13 June, the date of the election.

text: ['Quel redécollage?', 'OPINION.', 'Pour obtenir une modification rapide, durable et équitable des comportements, il faut que l’autorité politique instaure des contraintes acceptables par la population, écrit\xa0Philippe Dugerdil, membre de la CARPE (carpe.ch)  Philippe Dugerdil, Membre de la CARPE (carpe.ch)  Dans l’espoir d’une sortie de la pandémie et du redémarrage de l’économie, il convient de se poser la question de la forme à lui donner sachant qu’un danger encore plus grand nous guette: le changement climatique.', 'Le Conseil fédéral s’est engagé d’ici à 2030 à réduire de 50% les émissions de gaz à effet de serre par rapport à leur niveau de 1990.', 'Le canton de Genève s’est prononcé en décembre 2019 pour une réduction de 60%.', 'Ces objectifs ne peuvent pas être atteints sans encadrer la reprise de l’activité économique vers une diminution des émissions.', 'Certaines voix conservatrices envisagent cette perspective avec horreur et suggèrent de laisser faire le marché.', 'Le premier paramètre qu’ils omettent, c’est l’échelle de temps: il faut réduire de 60% en dix ans.', 'Cela prendra des siècles Ne compter que sur les lois du marché ne peut garantir cet objectif pour trois raisons.', 'La première est que la prise de décision individuelle (le «moteur» du marché) dépend de la perception du danger qui est sujette aux biais cognitifs.', '«Tant que je ne vois rien, je n’y crois pas» (principe Covera du psychologue et Prix Nobel d’économie D. Kahneman).', 'La seconde, c’est que le changement est sujet à la «tragédie du bien commun» de l’écologue G. Hardin.', 'Il peut dans ce contexte se décliner de la manière suivante: pourquoi ferais-je un effort pour améliorer la planète si mon voisin n’en fait pas?', 'La troisième est liée à l’inertie du phénomène: quand l’individu aura trop chaud et décidera enfin d’agir, il sera trop tard car on ne pourra pas faire baisser la température.', 'Cela prendra des siècles.', 'Donc le retour d’une «sanction du marché» pour rétablir l’équilibre ne fonctionnera pas.', 'On l’a compris: pour obtenir une modification rapide, durable et équitable des comportements, il faut que l’autorité politique instaure des contraintes acceptables par la population.', 'La loi sur le CO2 est l’une d’elles et il serait irresponsable de ne pas l’accepter même si on la juge imparfaite, car le temps presse.', 'Même les entreprises basées sur le carbone admettent qu’il faut agir pour le climat… mais autrement disent-elles.', 'Une autre déclinaison de la tragédie du bien commun: faire payer les dégâts à l’environnement par les autres.', 'Mais au-delà de cette loi, nous devrons réfléchir sur l’économie de l’après-carbone.', 'Comment s’organiser pour développer des activités économiques, des emplois, des services, des loisirs «propres»?', 'Prenons l’exemple emblématique du transport aérien.', 'Dans un article du Temps publié le 3\xa0mai, Pascaline Minet indique que «l’aviation correspond en fait à 27% de l’impact climatique de la Suisse».', 'Pour respecter les objectifs du canton, une récente étude de l’ONG Noé21 a calculé que le nombre de passagers de l’aéroport de Genève devrait passer de 18\xa0millions à 3\xa0millions par année à l’horizon 2030.', 'On ne peut être plus clair.', 'C’est ce type de mesure qui devra être appliqué si les autorités ont le courage de tenir leurs engagements.', 'Le temps de développement d’un avion «propre» est en effet incompatible avec les délais dont on parle.', 'Car demain c’est dans neuf ans Ce qui est vrai pour l’aéroport l’est aussi pour tout le pan de l’économie reposant sur la combustion des énergies fossiles.', 'Il est donc urgent pour les autorités de repenser le modèle économique global afin d’éviter de laisser trop de gens sur le carreau.', 'Une réflexion et un concours d’idées auprès des acteurs économiques, académiques\xa0et de la population conduiraient sans doute à identifier des pistes pour une économie de comme le veut l’adage «gouverner c’est prévoir», nos autorités doivent urgemment lancer une réflexion sur l’économie de l’après-carbone et les métiers «CO2-compatibles».', 'Car demain c’est dans neuf processed_text: What re-adhesive? OPINION. In order to achieve a rapid, sustainable and equitable change in behaviour, the political authority must introduce constraints acceptable to the population, writes Philippe Dugerdil, member of CARPE (carpe.ch) Philippe Dugerdil, member of CARPE (carpe.ch) In the hope of an exit from the pandemic and the revival of the economy, we must ask ourselves the question of the form to be given to him knowing that an even greater danger awaits us: climate change. The Federal Council committed itself by 2030 to reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 50% from 1990 levels. The Canton of Geneva issued a 60% reduction in December 2019. These objectives cannot be achieved without regulating the recovery of economic activity towards a reduction in emissions. Some conservative voices look at this perspective with horror and suggest that the market should be allowed. The first parameter they omit is the time scale: it is necessary to reduce by 60% in ten years. It will take centuries to rely only on the laws of the market cannot guarantee this objective for three reasons. The first is that individual decision-making (the "motor" of the market) depends on the perception of the danger that is subject to cognitive biases. "As long as I don't see anything, I don't believe it" (Conservatory Covera principle and Nobel Prize in Economics D. Kahneman). The second is that change is subject to the "tragedy of the common good" of environmentalist G. Hardin. In this context, it can be described as follows: why would I make an effort to improve the planet if my neighbour did not? The third is linked to the inertia of the phenomenon: when the individual is too hot and finally decides to act, it will be too late because we cannot lower the temperature. It will take centuries. So the return of a "market sanction" to restore balance will not work. It has been understood that to achieve rapid, sustainable and equitable change in behaviour, political authority must introduce constraints acceptable to the population. The CO2 law is one of them and it would be irresponsible not to accept it even if it is considered imperfect, because time is running out. Even carbon-based companies admit that we need to act for the climate... but otherwise they say. Another declination of the tragedy of the common good: to make others pay for the damage to the environment. But beyond this law, we will have to think about the post-carbon economy. How can we organise to develop economic activities, jobs, services, "clean" leisure? Let us take the emblematic example of air transport. In a Time article published on May 3, Pascaline Minet states that "aircraft actually corresponds to 27% of Switzerland's climate impact". In order to meet the canton's objectives, a recent study by NGO Noé21 estimated that the number of passengers at Geneva airport should increase from 18 million to 3 million per year by 2030. We can't be clearer. It is this type of measure that will have to be applied if the authorities have the courage to fulfil their commitments. The development time of a "clean" aeroplane is indeed incompatible with the time limits referred to. Because tomorrow is in nine years' time What's true for the airport is also true for the whole of the economy based on burning fossil fuels. It is therefore urgent for the authorities to rethink the overall economic model in order to avoid leaving too many people on the tile. A reflection and a competition of ideas with economic, academic and population actors would probably lead to the identification of avenues for a local economy that would provide jobs for the future. It is also necessary to organise and then start the corresponding projects. It is now that we need to think, not 2030. In short, if, as stated in the "governance is to be expected", our authorities urgently need to think about the post-carbon economy and the "CO2-compatible" trades. Because tomorrow's nine years away.
author: Philippe Dugerdil Philippe Dugerdil

processed_text: François Launaz: "Motorists are milk cows of the CO2 law" The automotive and oil lobby is fighting the revision of the CO2 law. For the president of the importers, this one is "punitive" and is mainly intended to raise money that will not benefit those who have to use the car Bernard Wuthrich The automotive and oil sectors are fighting the revision of the CO2 law. The President of Auto-Swiss, François Launaz, explains why importers do not want it. Time: Does the CO2 law not anticipate the announced end of oil? François Launaz: Yes, but the car manufacturers also anticipate. More and more brands are announcing that there will be more new generation of combustion engines from 2030 onwards. They will be replaced by electric propulsions and possibly also hydrogen. Our industry has already launched a decarbonisation process. Despite the crisis, the share of electric cars is increasing among new registrations: in one year, it has increased from 21 to 37%. Why then do you not support the CO2 law since it is going in your direction? We could support it if the motorists were not the milk cows who will have to pay for their more expensive petrol but will receive almost nothing in return. Traffic accounts for 35% of CO2 emissions. It is a reality that we do not dispute. And I support the polluter pays principle. The climate fund promises a lot of money to a lot of people, but apart from a few speccadilles for battery charging stations, car owners will not get anything. On the other hand, we're going to puncture them to develop night trains, for example. That's not fair. The installation of charging stations is not nothing, is it? The fund plans to allocate 60 million francs to a range of measures, including the installation of these charging stations. In the end, we're only going to spend 5 to 10 million. They're peanuts. It would take 60 to 70 million per year for these stations alone, at a rate of about 1500 francs per unit. That's what I asked in a letter to Simonetta Sommaruga. Moreover, if incentive taxes work, the fund's budget will go down one day to zero. And there'll be no more money for anyone. Does the oil and automobile lobby not cling to its achievements by fighting the CO2 law? I don't think so. The reason for the referendum is to reject a punitive law that costs too much and does not sufficiently support the decarbonization of mobility. We agree with the planned CO2 emission targets, which are currently 95 grams per kilometre and will gradually decrease to zero by 2040 or 2050. But we need support. We agree to replace cars using fuel with electric vehicles. But they cost more to buy because of the batteries. Europe understood it well. It does more to force building owners to install charging stations for their tenants and to encourage motorists to buy an electric vehicle. Is your opposition not motivated by the increase in the price of gasoline from 10 to 12 cents per litre? We agreed with 8 cents per litre, provided that these recipes benefit the ecological transition of mobility. I would like to add something that is never mentioned: the project plans to divert some of the tax revenues currently used to finance mobility infrastructure in cities and agglomerations to the climate fund. This diversion is counterproductive, since, to absorb population growth, we need these investments in infrastructure. These 10 to 12 cents will be paid by importers to offset the purchase of fuel. Will they be fully passed on to column prices? According to the experts, the maximum levy will be necessary from the first day to cover the obligation to compensate for fuel emissions over the entire period up to 2030. It will necessarily be passed on to prices. How much will the CO2 law cost an average family? I don't want to get into a number quarrel. Simonetta Sommaruga says it will cost 100 francs a year, opponents announced an amount of 1000 francs. On average, the truth will lie somewhere between these two extremes. But I think that the averages per person do not reflect the reality for the population anyway: the law will certainly cost households much more with two cars and a heating oil. Some of the taxes will be reimbursed to the public and businesses. Isn't that a fair measure? I find it hard to understand this mechanism. This will be done through health insurance premiums. It is therefore a cross-cutting subsidy that demonstrates the inability of the political world to solve the problem of health costs. It is aberrant to think that a reduction of 60 to 80 francs per year on health insurance premiums could alter the behaviour of the population in terms of mobility or heating. In addition, not all members of the Federal Council have a low CO2 function vehicle. Before they want to tax the population, they should set an example. The Federal Council claims that the CO2 law is a social reform. Are you in dispute with that argument? On the one hand, I do not see what is social to repay the same amount to a billionaire as to a modest taxpayer. And on the other hand, this law will clearly have antisocial effects for people and SMEs dependent on the car. In a context of crisis, it is not reasonable to tax lower incomes and small businesses more.
author: François Launaz

text: ['La loi CO2 coûtera surtout aux familles les plus riches Climat Les classes populaires seront peu touchées et la taxe sur le CO2 est sociale, selon une étude.', 'La nouvelle loi sur le CO2, soumise au peuple en juin, touchera principalement les hauts revenus peu sensibilisés à l’environnement et non les simples travailleurs et la population rurale, comme le disent les opposants, selon une étude dont la «SonntagsZeitung» s’est fait l’écho.', 'Une riche famille de quatre personnes qui prend l’avion chaque année, vit dans une grande villa mal isolée et possède deux voitures chères devra supporter des coûts supplémentaires de 2200 francs, selon l’étude.', 'Une famille moins aisée n’aurait à supporter que 460 francs de coûts supplémentaires, même si elle possède une voiture et que sa petite maison est également mal isolée.', 'L’étude conclut que la taxe sur le CO2 serait donc sociale et relève que les prélèvements sur le fioul domestique sont beaucoup plus importants que les prélèvements sur l’essence et le diesel.', 'ATS']
processed_text: The CO2 law will cost mostly the richest families Climate The popular classes will be poorly affected and the CO2 tax is social, according to one study. The new CO2 law, submitted to the people in June, will mainly affect high incomes that are not aware of the environment, not just workers and the rural population, as the opponents say, according to a study which the "SonnagsZeitung" echoed. A rich family of four who fly each year, lives in a large, poorly insulated villa and owns two expensive cars will have to bear an additional cost of 2200 francs, according to the study. A less affluent family would have to bear only 460 francs of additional costs, even if it owns a car and its small house is also poorly isolated. The study concludes that the CO2 tax would therefore be social and notes that the levies on domestic fuel oil are much larger than the levies on petrol and diesel. ATS
