text: ['«La taxe carbone est l’instrument libéral par essence» PHILIPPE THALMANN Renchérir les activités fortement émettrices de gaz à effet de serre afin de mieux rendre compte de leur coût réel pour l’environnement: c’est le principe de la taxe carbone, une des principales armes de la Suisse contre le changement climatique.', 'Elle pourrait être renforcée en cas d’acceptation de la révision de la loi sur le CO2 le 13 juin.', 'Le professeur d’économie de l’environnement à l’EPFL et membre du laboratoire E4S livre son analyse  PROPOS RECUEILLIS PAR BERNARD WUTHRICH ET PASCALINE MINET @@BdWuthrich @pascalineminet  Comment réorienter nos économies de manière à réduire leurs émissions de gaz à effet de serre?', 'C’est la redoutable tâche à laquelle doivent s’atteler toutes les nations engagées dans la lutte contre le changement climatique.', 'Selon les travaux les plus récents du Groupe d’experts intergouvernemental sur l’évolution du climat (GIEC), pour éviter les pires conséquences du réchauffement, il est indispensable d’atteindre la neutralité carbone en 2050 – à ce moment-là, nous ne devrons pas émettre plus de CO2 que nous pourrons en absorber.', 'Le Conseil fédéral s’est engagé à relever le défi.', 'Pour y parvenir, différents outils existent, dont l’un a la faveur des économistes: c’est la taxe carbone.', 'En renchérissant les activités et produits qui émettent de grandes quantités de gaz à effet de serre, cette taxe doit rendre plus compétitives les alternatives plus écologiques et ainsi faciliter leur déploiement.', 'La Suisse fait figure de précurseuse dans ce domaine puisqu’elle est un des rares Etats à avoir adopté une telle taxe, même si elle n’est que partielle.', 'La loi révisée sur le CO2, sur laquelle les Suisses s’exprimeront le 13 juin, entend renforcer cette approche.', 'Qu’est-ce que la taxe carbone?', 'C’est une taxe sur les produits énergétiques proportionnelle à la quantité de gaz à effet de serre qui sera émise lors de leur combustion.', 'En Suisse, une taxe carbone a été introduite en 2008 sur les combustibles fossiles, principalement l’huile de chauffage et le gaz.', 'C’est une taxe incitative destinée à encourager les propriétaires d’immeubles à remplacer leur chaudière à mazout par un raccordement au réseau de chauffage à distance, une pompe à chaleur ou une autre ressource renouvelable, ou au minimum à assainir leur bâtiment pour moins consommer.', 'Elle repose sur un principe économique de base: quand quelque chose devient plus cher, on cherche à en acheter moins ou à le substituer.', 'Pour des raisons politiques, il a été décidé de ne pas soumettre les carburants à cette taxe, même s’ils entraînent aussi d’importantes émissions de CO2.', 'Quels sont les avantages d’une telle taxe?', 'C’est l’instrument le moins dirigiste qui soit.', 'Il n’y a aucune interdiction, on peut continuer à consommer autant de mazout qu’on le souhaite, ou trouver la meilleure solution pour en utiliser moins.', 'Chacun est libre de son choix.', 'Cette taxe a fait ses preuves.', 'C’est dans le secteur du bâtiment, le seul à lui être soumis, que les réductions d’émissions ont été les plus importantes, d’environ un tiers depuis 1990.', 'En revanche, dans le secteur des transports, qui n’est pas concerné, il n’y a pas eu de diminution des émissions au cours de la même période.', 'Que prévoit la loi révisée sur le CO2 par rapport à la taxe carbone?', 'La nouvelle loi prévoit une continuation de la taxe et son augmentation graduelle.', 'Aujourd’hui nous sommes à 96 francs par tonne de CO2, soit 25 centimes par litre de mazout, avec un plafond à 120 francs.', 'La nouvelle loi prévoit de la faire monter par étapes jusqu’à 240 francs si nécessaire.', 'Le sentier de progression est tracé par rapport aux objectifs de réduction à atteindre.', 'Si on respecte ces objectifs, le niveau de la taxe ne bougera pas.', 'Si les émissions ne diminuent pas suffisamment, on devra renchérir le mazout, de manière à atteindre les objectifs.', 'Et il n’est toujours pas question de l’étendre aux carburants.', 'Mais ceux-ci seront touchés autrement.', 'Où se situe la Suisse par rapport à la taxation du carbone?', 'Le niveau de la taxe suisse est l’un des plus élevés au monde.', 'Mais peu d’Etats ont réellement introduit une taxe carbone.', 'L’Allemagne ou l’Autriche par exemple y réfléchissent, mais n’y sont pas encore parvenus.', 'Il faut toutefois rappeler que ce n’est qu’un des instruments dont les Etats disposent pour lutter contre le réchauffement climatique.', 'Il y a aussi la promotion des transports publics, des énergies renouvelables, la réglementation, ou encore le marché de droits d’émissions, qui concerne les gros émetteurs.', 'Une quarantaine d’entreprises participent déjà à ce système en Suisse.', 'Depuis l’année dernière, notre marché carbone est connecté au marché européen.', 'Au lieu de mettre en place la taxe carbone, on aurait aussi pu généraliser ce régime à toutes les entreprises et tous les propriétaires de bâtiments, mais cela aurait nécessité de calculer des droits d’émissions pour chaque participant et d’évaluer ce que chacun a réellement émis.', 'Cela représente beaucoup de bureaucratie.', 'La taxe carbone est plus simple à mettre en place.', 'Il y a tout de même des résistances dans certains milieux économiques.', 'En général, les taxes ne dopent pas l’économie, au contraire…  La taxe carbone est l’instrument libéral par essence.', 'Si elle est peu appréciée, c’est qu’on la paie encore sur ses émissions résiduelles, même si on pollue peu.', 'Comme la taxe poubelle, qu’on paie sur ses derniers sacs, même quand on a trié de manière exemplaire.', 'A la place de la taxe, on pourrait choisir de subventionner les entreprises qui réduisent leurs émissions, mais, dans ce cas, d’où viendrait l’argent?', 'On fait ça dans l’agriculture: on paye les paysans pour préserver les espaces naturels, car on souhaite maintenir leur activité.', 'Mais cela n’a pas de sens de le faire dans le domaine du transport aérien ou de l’industrie.', 'Pour des raisons d’efficacité et d’acceptabilité sociale, la taxe doit cependant être accompagnée de mesures compensatoires.', 'Elle peut en effet être un fardeau pour certaines catégories de la population.', 'On peut utiliser les recettes générées par la taxe pour aider les ménages ou les entreprises en difficulté à réduire leurs émissions.', 'Cela se fait déjà dans le secteur des transports, où la taxe prélevée sur les poids lourds sert à subventionner le ferroutage.', 'Qui sera le plus touché par la taxe carbone?', 'La taxe CO2 sur les combustibles a surtout un impact sur les ménages qui vivent dans des maisons ou appartements chauffés au mazout et mal isolés.', 'Les locataires ne peuvent rien faire dans cette situation.', 'Mais il ne faut toutefois pas surestimer cet effet, car le propriétaire d’un immeuble dont les charges sont élevées est obligé d’adapter son loyer s’il veut éviter que les gens aillent s’installer ailleurs.', 'Et puis il y a le Programme Bâtiments, qui aide justement les propriétaires à assainir leurs immeubles.', 'La nouvelle loi sur le CO2 pourrait aussi entraîner un renchérissement des carburants, puisque les importateurs devront compenser une plus grande partie de leurs émissions et vont répercuter ces frais sous forme de hausse de prix.', 'Mais celle-ci est encadrée.', 'Actuellement, la limite est de 5 centimes.', 'Elle va augmenter au plus à 10 centimes puis à 12 dès 2025.', 'D’un point de vue économique, ça n’a pas de sens de fixer un tel plafond, car on ne sait pas combien les projets de compensation coûteront.', 'Mais il a été fixé de manière à rassurer les automobilistes.', 'Le fonds climatique n’est-il pas un instrument paradoxal, puisqu’il sera alimenté par les recettes de la taxe carbone, qui seront logiquement amenées à diminuer à l’avenir?', 'Le fonds pour le climat sera alimenté par différentes sources: la taxe sur le CO2, celle sur les billets d’avion, mais aussi les sanctions sur les ventes de véhicules à trop fortes émissions, notamment.', 'Il est vrai que le prélèvement d’une taxe incitative sur les émissions polluantes ne doit pas avoir pour objectif de financer une dépense publique pérenne, puisque la recette diminue justement quand la taxe incitative déploie ses effets.', 'Le fonds pour le climat n’a pas ce problème: le jour où il n’y aura plus d’émissions de CO2, la taxe ne produira plus de recettes, mais il n’y aura plus besoin non plus de subventions pour réduire les émissions.', 'Dans les années à venir, le taux de la taxe va augmenter, mais les émissions de CO2 sur lesquelles elle est prélevée vont baisser, si bien que la recette pourrait encore augmenter un peu avant de baisser fatalement.', 'Le remboursement d’une partie des taxes incitatives à la population via les assurances maladie est-il une bonne solution?', 'C’est un système bonus-malus.', 'Si vous êtes dans la moyenne, vous récupérez via votre assurance maladie le montant de taxes que vous avez payé.', 'Si vous polluez davantage, ce qu’on vous rembourse sera moins important que ce que vous aurez payé.', 'On récompense ainsi automatiquement ceux qui ont réduit leur impact climatique, sans qu’il soit nécessaire de surveiller ce que chacun fait.', 'Comment fixer le montant de la taxe?', 'S’il existait une taxe mondiale, on pourrait lier son montant à l’objectif de réduction de température qui a été fixé par tous les pays signataires de l’Accord de Paris.', 'Mais on est loin d’un tel scénario.', 'C’est pourquoi un petit pays comme la Suisse doit assumer sa responsabilité et se fixer un objectif de réduction de ses émissions de gaz à effet de serre.', 'Il se donne ensuite les moyens nécessaires pour atteindre cet objectif, notamment une taxe CO2 qui augmente progressivement.', 'Pourrait-on avoir un niveau de taxe plus bas si elle était adoptée par un nombre de pays plus grand?', 'En théorie, oui.', 'Malheureusement, cela ne fonctionne pas.', 'C’est pour cela que la Suisse s’est fixé un objectif de zéro émission nette de CO2 d’ici à 2050.', 'Il a été défini indépendamment de ce que fait le reste du monde.', 'On espère évidemment que tout le monde agisse pour réduire les émissions de gaz à effet de serre.', 'Il faudrait d’ailleurs commencer par arrêter de subventionner le charbon dans les pays où c’est encore le cas.', 'Y a-t-il en Suisse des subventions qui se révèlent négatives pour le climat?', 'On peut s’interroger sur la déductibilité fiscale des frais de déplacement, surtout pour les trajets effectués en voiture entre le domicile et le lieu de travail.', 'Le système actuel, qui varie d’un canton à l’autre, est une incitation à utiliser la voiture.', 'Dans tous les cantons romands sauf Genève, l’automobiliste peut déduire quelque 70 centimes par kilomètre sans limitation.', 'On pourrait plafonner la déduction au montant de l’abonnement général CFF, par exemple, comme le fait la Confédération.', 'On peut aussi citer les subventions à l’agriculture, qui ne prennent pas vraiment en compte l’impact climatique de la production agricole.', 'La Confédération finance par exemple des publicités pour la viande suisse alors qu’il s’agit de l’aliment qui produit le plus de gaz à effet de serre.', 'Mais c’est un sujet délicat.', 'Le fonds climatique prévoit de subventionner le développement de kérosène vert: c’est à double tranchant, car c’est aussi une manière de subventionner le transport aérien.', 'On parle souvent de zéro émission nette de CO2.', 'Que faut-il entendre par là?', 'Le principe est le suivant: on peut continuer à émettre du CO2 – le scénario du Conseil fédéral avance le chiffre de 8 millions de tonnes en 2050 – mais ce qui est émis est retiré de l’atmosphère la même année et stocké de manière permanente sans jamais être réémis.', 'On parle d’émissions négatives.', 'Il y a plusieurs manières de le faire.', 'On peut aspirer l’air et en séparer chimiquement le CO2, que l’on conserve éternellement à l’état minéral.', 'On peut aussi faire pousser des arbres, qui transforment le CO2 en matière organique.', 'Prenons l’exemple d’une usine d’incinération: 40% des matières qui sont brûlées dans une telle installation sont organiques.', 'Elles contiennent du CO2 retiré de l’atmosphère, que l’on peut séparer chimiquement des fumées, comprimer et enfouir dans un réservoir géologique.', 'Ce procédé peut aussi s’appliquer à une cimenterie.', 'C’est une technologie que l’on connaît déjà, mais elle n’existe pas encore à l’échelle industrielle.', 'Elle coûte très cher et l’on ne sait pas à l’heure actuelle qui va payer ni où le CO2 sera enfoui.', 'Mais les nouvelles technologies peuvent se développer rapidement.', 'Et recourir à cette approche semble indispensable, car les émissions réelles de gaz à effet de serre ne pourront pas être complètement ramenées à zéro d’ici à 2050.']
processed_text: "The carbon tax is the liberal instrument by essence" PHILIPE THALMANN To increase the cost of greenhouse gas-emitting activities in order to better account for their real cost to the environment: this is the principle of the carbon tax, one of Switzerland's main weapons against climate change. It could be strengthened if the revision of the CO2 law was accepted on 13 June. EPFL's environmental economics professor and member of the E4S laboratory delivers his analysis ABOUT BERNARD WUTHRICH AND PASCALINE MINET @@BdWuthrich @pascalineminet How can we reorient our economies to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions? This is the daunting task facing all nations involved in the fight against climate change. According to the most recent work of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), in order to avoid the worst consequences of warming, it is essential to achieve carbon neutrality in 2050 – at that time, we will not have to emit more CO2 than we can absorb from it. The Federal Council is committed to meeting the challenge. To achieve this, different tools exist, one of which is favored by economists: it is the carbon tax. By increasing the cost of activities and products that emit large quantities of greenhouse gases, this tax must make alternatives more environmentally friendly and thus facilitate their deployment. Switzerland is a precursor in this area, since it is one of the few States to have adopted such a tax, even if it is only partial. The revised CO2 law, on which the Swiss will express themselves on 13 June, intends to reinforce this approach. What is the carbon tax? It is a tax on energy products proportional to the amount of greenhouse gases that will be emitted when they are burned. In Switzerland, a carbon tax was introduced in 2008 on fossil fuels, mainly heating oil and gas. It is an incentive tax to encourage building owners to replace their oil boiler with a remote heating connection, a heat pump or other renewable resource, or at least to clean up their building to reduce consumption. It is based on a basic economic principle: when something becomes more expensive, it is sought to buy less or to substitute it. For political reasons, it has been decided not to subject fuels to this tax, even if they also cause significant CO2 emissions. What are the benefits of such a tax? It's the least direct instrument ever. There is no ban, you can continue to consume as much fuel oil as you want, or find the best solution to use less fuel. Everyone is free to choose. This tax has proved its worth. Only in the construction sector, the only one to be submitted to it, have emission reductions been the largest, about a third since 1990. However, in the transport sector, which is not concerned, there was no decrease in emissions during the same period. What does the revised CO2 law provide for in relation to the carbon tax? The new law provides for a continuation of the tax and its gradual increase. Today we are at 96 francs per tonne of CO2, or 25 cents per litre of oil, with a ceiling of 120 francs. The new law provides for a gradual increase of up to 240 francs if necessary. The path of progress is set in relation to the reduction objectives to be achieved. If these objectives are met, the level of the tax will not change. If emissions do not decrease sufficiently, fuel oil will have to be increased to meet the targets. And there is still no question of extending it to fuels. But these will be affected differently. Where is Switzerland in relation to carbon taxation? The Swiss tax is one of the highest in the world. But few states have actually introduced a carbon tax. Germany or Austria, for example, think about it, but have not yet done so. It should be recalled, however, that this is only one of the instruments available to States to combat global warming. There is also the promotion of public transport, renewable energy, regulation, or the emission rights market, which concerns large emitters. Some 40 companies are already participating in this system in Switzerland. Since last year, our carbon market has been connected to the European market. Instead of introducing the carbon tax, it could also have been extended to all businesses and building owners, but it would have required calculating emission charges for each participant and assessing what each had actually issued. That is a lot of bureaucracy. The carbon tax is simpler to implement. There are still resistances in some economic circles. In general, taxes do not boost the economy, on the contrary... The carbon tax is the liberal instrument by essence. If it is not appreciated, it is still being paid on its residual emissions, even if it is not polluted. Like the garbage tax, which we pay on his last bags, even when we have sorted in an exemplary way. Instead of the tax, one could choose to subsidize companies that reduce their emissions, but in this case, where would the money come from? We do this in agriculture: we pay farmers to preserve the natural spaces, because we want to maintain their activity. But this does not make sense in the air transport or industry sector. For reasons of efficiency and social acceptability, however, the tax must be accompanied by compensatory measures. It can be a burden for certain categories of the population. Tax revenues can be used to help households or businesses in difficulty reduce their emissions. This is already being done in the transport sector, where the tax on heavy goods vehicles is being used to subsidise the road haulage. Who will be most affected by the carbon tax? The CO2 fuel tax has an impact on households living in oil-fired and poorly insulated homes or apartments. Tenants can't do anything in this situation. However, this effect should not be overestimated, as the owner of a building with high loads is obliged to adjust its rent if he wants to avoid people moving elsewhere. And then there's the Buildings Program, which helps the owners clean up their buildings. The new CO2 law could also lead to higher fuel prices, as importers will have to offset a greater proportion of their emissions and pass these costs on as price increases. But this one is framed. Currently, the limit is 5 cents. It will increase to no more than 10 cents and then to 12 cents from 2025. From an economic point of view, it makes no sense to set such a ceiling, because we do not know how much compensation projects will cost. But it has been fixed in such a way as to reassure the motorists. Is the climate fund not a paradoxical instrument, since it will be fed by carbon tax revenues, which will logically be reduced in the future? The climate fund will be financed by various sources: the CO2 tax, the airline ticket tax, and sanctions on sales of vehicles with too high emissions, in particular. It is true that the purpose of levying an incentive tax on polluting emissions should not be to finance a sustainable public expenditure, since the revenue is decreasing precisely when the incentive tax is applied. The climate fund does not have this problem: on the day that there will be no more CO2 emissions, the tax will no longer generate revenue, but there will also be no need for subsidies to reduce emissions. In the coming years, the tax rate will rise, but the CO2 emissions from which it is levied will decrease, so that the revenue could increase a little further before it will fall fatally. Is the reimbursement of part of the tax incentives to the population via health insurance a good solution? It's a bonus-malus system. If you are average, you will recover the amount of taxes you paid through your health insurance. If you pollute more, what you are reimbursed will be less important than what you have paid. This automatically rewards those who have reduced their climate impact, without the need to monitor what everyone is doing. How to fix the amount of the tax? If there was a global tax, it could be linked to the temperature reduction target set by all the countries that signed the Paris Agreement. But we are far from such a scenario. This is why a small country like Switzerland must assume its responsibility and set a target for reducing its greenhouse gas emissions. It then gives itself the means to achieve this objective, including a CO2 tax which is gradually increasing. Could a lower level of tax be achieved if it were adopted by a larger number of countries? In theory, yes. Unfortunately, it doesn't work. This is why Switzerland has set a target of zero net CO2 emissions by 2050. It has been defined independently of what the rest of the world does. Of course, it is hoped that everyone will act to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The first step should be to stop subsidizing coal in countries where it is still the case. Are there subsidies in Switzerland that are negative for the climate? The tax deductibility of travel expenses can be questioned, especially for journeys by car between home and work. The current system, which varies from canton to canton, is an incentive to use the car. In all French cantons except Geneva, motorists can deduct some 70 cents per kilometre without limitation. The deduction could be capped on the amount of the SBB general subscription, for example, as the Confederation does. Agriculture subsidies, which do not really take account of the climate impact of agricultural production, can also be mentioned. For example, the Confederation finances advertisements for Swiss meat when it is the food that produces the most greenhouse gases. But it's a delicate subject. The climate fund plans to subsidize the development of green kerosene: it is double-edged, because it is also a way to subsidize air transport. We often talk about zero net CO2 emissions. What does that mean? The principle is that CO2 can continue to be emitted – the Federal Council scenario puts the figure of 8 million tonnes in 2050 – but what is emitted is removed from the atmosphere in the same year and stored permanently without ever being re-emitted. We're talking negative emissions. There are several ways to do this. The air can be drawn and chemically separated from the CO2, which can be kept forever in the mineral state. Trees can also be grown, which transform CO2 into organic matter. Example of an incineration plant: 40% of the materials that are burned in such a facility are organic. They contain CO2 removed from the atmosphere, which can be chemically separated from smoke, compressed and buried in a geological reservoir. This process can also be applied to a cement plant. It is a technology that is already known, but it does not yet exist on an industrial scale. It is very expensive and it is not known at this time who will pay or where CO2 will be buried. But new technologies can develop quickly. And using this approach seems essential, as actual greenhouse gas emissions cannot be completely reduced to zero by 2050.

text: ["En vue des votations du 13 juin, les projets environnementaux ont la cote Le premier sondage réalisé par l'institut gfs.bern pour la SSR laisse présager le oui pour la loi sur le CO2, la loi processed_text: In view of the votes of 13 June, environmental projects are ranked The first poll conducted by the gfs.bern institute for the SSR suggests the yes for the CO2 law, the Covid-19 law and the police measures against terrorism. The two anti-pesticid initiatives are also supported by a majority, but their fate remains open Bernard Wuthrich Five weeks before the election, it is an environmental vote that is emerging for June 13, according to the first poll conducted by the institute gfs.bern for the SSR. But be careful: if the yes is in the lead for both pesticide initiatives, the next few weeks, as is often the case with popular initiatives, can still bring opinion to the side of no. As for the CO2 law, it is, for the time being, quite clearly yes. The clean drinking water initiative and the one which wants to ban synthetic pesticides have comparable public support: the yes is 54% for the first and 55% for the second, while the no is 40% and 42% respectively. Approval is more pronounced in French and Italian-speaking Switzerland than in other countries. 60% yes to the CO2 law Both initiatives are at a stage of forming the opinion called "mean". gfs.bern leaves "open" the outcome of the vote on these two proposals. In both cases, the same pattern appears. The urban population and retired people have a greater sympathy for these environmental measures: 65% of the inhabitants of cities and agglomerations are in favour of the clean water initiative, compared with only 41% in rural areas. While the fate of the two texts remains uncertain, the fate of the CO2 law seems clearer. With 60%, yes far ahead of no (35%). The stage of the formation of opinion is described as'medium to advanced'. The support is very clear to the left and to the center. The rejection of the reform is equally clear to the UDC electorate. On the other hand, the formation of opinion is still "not very strong" at the PLR, which recommends the yes. Men, the middle class, Italian Switzerland and rural areas are more critical than other categories of the population surveyed. The increase in heating and car use, mainly in peripheral areas, seems to be the main concern of skeptics. The Covid-19 Act widely approved The other two objects of the June 13 election are on the way to acceptance. The law on police measures to combat terrorism was approved at 67%, but positions were not yet clearly defined. gfs.bern is not yet in danger of prognosis on the final result of the vote. As for the Covid-19 law, the yes largely leads the ball with 67%, against only 29% of no. It should be adopted by a large majority. Apart from the UDC and the government's distrust, support is broad enough for a project that serves as a legal basis for support measures for businesses and people who are responsible for health restrictions. The survey was conducted for 15 days among 22,732 voting rights holders. The margin of error is about 2.8%.

text: ['Courrier des lecteurs Classe moyenne à la caisse Genève, 11 mai On dirait que la loi sur le CO2 a été élaborée par les Verts tant elle veut faire passer la population à la caisse!', 'En effet, tout est prévu pour nous vider le portefeuille.', 'Augmentation du prix de l’essence: 12 centimes par litre.', 'Mais qui peut se le permettre?', 'En aucun cas la classe moyenne ni les plus modestes.', 'Terminés aussi les voyages en avion pour les familles et les jeunes: une taxe de 120 francs peut être prélevée sur chaque billet.', 'C’est inacceptable pour des familles qui ont des proches à l’étranger et qui doivent s’y rendre plusieurs fois par an.', 'Restreindre la mobilité en la rendant inaccessible, voilà bien la plus mauvaise des manières pour inciter les gens à moins polluer.', 'Ce sera donc les personnes qui n’habitent pas dans un centreville que l’on va pénaliser alors que ce sont eux qui ont le moins bon accès à des transports publics de qualité et en suffisance.', 'L’augmentation des taxes sur le carburant sera un coup de matraque sur le budget de ces ménages.', 'Elle sera particulièrement discriminatoire envers les personnes qui habitent dans les régions périphériques et de montagne.', 'Quant aux PME qui ont besoin d’une flotte de véhicules (transports, nettoyage, livraison à domicile, agriculture), elles seront largement désavantagées.', 'C’est inacceptable.', 'D’autant plu que l’impact de ces mesures sur le climat sera quasi nul.', 'Je voterai non à ce projet de loi.', 'René Desbaillets, président de l’ACS, section de Genève Une occasion à ne pas rater Genève, 17 mai ll est vrai que la Cité de la musique est une «occasion en or» (TdG du 30.4), il faut la saisir, surtout, faut-il le répéter, elle ne coûtera pas un centime au contribuable, car financée par des fonds privés.', 'Soyons donc visionnaires pour notre ville et les générations futures en votant oui le 13 juin!', 'Ce projet magnifique respecte l’environnement et la nature, et valorisera hautement notre vie musicale genevoise, toutes catégories confondues.', 'Que l’opposante à ce projet (TdG du 8 mai) défende son point de vue est compréhensible, sauf que ses argumentations n’ont aucune vision du futur, ni de vision culturelle valable.', 'Heureusement, nos bâtisseurs des siècles passés avaient l’esprit plus aventureux, pourquoi ne pas faire comme eux?', 'Ursula Hotz Pachoud']
processed_text: Readers' mail Middle class at the caisse Geneva, May 11 It seems that the CO2 law was drafted by the Greens as much as it wants to get the population to the caisse! Indeed, everything is planned to empty our wallet. Gasoline price increase: 12 cents per litre. But who can afford it? Under no circumstances are the middle class or the most modest. Air travel for families and young people is also completed: a tax of 120 francs can be levied on each ticket. This is unacceptable for families with relatives abroad who have to go there several times a year. Restricting mobility by making it inaccessible is the worst way to encourage people to reduce pollution. It will therefore be people who do not live in a city centre that will be penalized when they have the least access to quality and sufficient public transport. The increase in fuel taxes will be a blow to the budget of these households. It will be particularly discriminatory against people living in peripheral and mountain areas. SMEs who need a fleet of vehicles (transport, cleaning, home delivery, agriculture) will be at a considerable disadvantage. That's unacceptable. The impact of these measures on the climate will be almost zero. I will vote no to this bill. René Desbaillets, president of the ACS, Geneva section An opportunity not to miss Geneva, 17 May It is true that the Cité de la musique is a "gold opportunity" (TdG of 30.4), it must be seized, above all, it must be repeated, it will not cost the taxpayer a cent, because financed by private funds. Let us therefore be visionary for our city and future generations by voting yes on June 13th! This magnificent project respects the environment and nature, and will highly value our Geneva musical life, all categories combined. That the opponent of this project (TdG of 8 May) defends his point of view is understandable, except that his arguments do not have any vision of the future, nor any valid cultural vision. Fortunately, our builders of past centuries were more adventurous, why not do as they did? Ursula Hotz Pachoud

processed_text: For a liberal environmental policy OPINION. By saying yes to the CO2 law, we continue to write Switzerland's success story in the sense of liberal and intergenerational responsibility, writes the National Councillor Jacqueline de Quattro Jacqueline de Quattro, National Councillor Each of us is anxious to leave an intact environment for future generations. The pandemic that we are going through has made us even more aware of the importance of preserving our natural resources and our environment. CO2 law is one way to achieve this. It sets the stage for a more sustainable world while providing the economy with the opportunity not only to be at the forefront of progress, but also to maintain and create jobs. A development model that favours both a liberal environmental and climate policy and respect for carbon neutrality. Winner, winner. Jacqueline de Quattro, National Councillor. Partien/Keystone Many societal issues are controversial between extremists and hypocrites. Common sense often struggles to be heard. The fight against global warming does not escape this phenomenon. In the extremist camp, there are some organizations that want to reach zero emissions by 2030, with little concern for paralyzing the lives of the population and the prospects for the economy. They are inspired by unacceptable authoritarian methods, worthy of the former USSR, whose CO2 balance was also disastrous. Switzerland doesn't need these sterile debates On the other side, there are hypocrites that begin by relativizing the problem and always end up saying that the proposed instrument is not the right one or that it is not the right time. They also point out that Switzerland is a small country, so its CO2 emissions would not have any influence at the international level. Wrong. A global problem cannot be solved without every one of them making their own efforts in accordance with their responsibility and economic potential. It is clear that the compliance of poor or emerging states with the Paris Agreement depends largely on what rich countries will do. A global problem cannot be solved without everyone making their own efforts Switzerland does not need these sterile debates between extremists and hypocrites that do not lead to any solution. The liberal-radicals have assumed their responsibilities and are committed to the CO2 law. This package of measures is a constructive, balanced compromise that gives companies room for manoeuvre and freedom of decision-making. A 50% reduction in emissions in 2030 compared to 1990 is a realistic target. Realistic but also effective. The CO2 law provides for economic incentives where they have effects, particularly in industry and construction. When incentive taxes are used, their product will not feed the state funds. On the contrary. Essentially, the population and businesses are given back to maintain the purchasing power and competitiveness of our economy. The PLR does not deny its values Much of the product is indeed allocated to support measures for technological innovation, such as, for example, synthetic aviation fuels, the development of construction materials to replace cement or biodegradable packaging instead of plastic. Great stakes for tomorrow's Switzerland. With the CO2 law, we are building on our country's innovation capabilities, which will enable us to secure important future markets. Undoubted added value for employment and research. In addition, innovation and technological progress lead to improved energy efficiency. Every kilowatt hour of energy saved gives us extra room for manoeuvre and brings us closer to carbon neutrality. By committing to the CO2 law, the PLR does not deny its values. However, we are for the truth of the costs. Those who consume more resources at the expense of future generations pay the price accordingly. By saying yes to the CO2 law, we continue to write Switzerland's success story in the sense of liberal and intergenerational responsibility. This is an opportunity for our economy and a duty to future generations.

Florent Quiquerez Bern Was the green turn of the PLR a strategic mistake? Not at all. If it were to be done again, I'd do the same thing again. As a reminder, in the programmes of the Radical Party of the 1970s, we already presented our solutions to the environment. The climate is a major challenge for Switzerland and the world, and will remain so. This is our responsibility as a party to deal with it. Today, the CO2 law is an acceptable compromise. The mistake would have been to reject this project. The majority of your voters are not following you. Are you disconnected? With 22 of the 28 sections of the PLR that said yes to this text, we cannot say that we are disconnected from the database. But in front of us, the opponents are very noisy. It is easier to focus a campaign on fear than to explain the complexity of a text. Our members do not like state interventions, but sometimes they are necessary. In the environmental field, the principle of individual responsibility must be supplemented with guidelines. Without these, there would be no treatment of wastewater or the introduction of particulate filters. We have succeeded in incorporating liberal aspects into this law. That's what we need to explain. How is a tax-rich law liberal? Because she doesn't prohibit anything, but gives directions. Incentive taxes put people on the right track without forcing them to do so. If they don't want to adopt new behaviors, then they'll have to pay. But the money will come back from one side directly to the people, and from another part to a fund for innovation. Your electorate is allergic to taxes. Was that the right model? The liberal spirit is inherently opposed to taxes. But what is the alternative? A catalogue of prohibitions as demanded by the Greens and Socialists? Or the ban on new combustion cars by 2025, as the Liberal Green Party supports? With the CO2 law, the people who generate the most CO2 emissions will have to go to the cash register and the others will have more money in the purse. This is the polluter pays principle. But if we don't do anything now, the bill will be heavier in the future, because the fight against the effects of global warming is very expensive. How can this mistrust be explained? Coronavirus is playing against us. I feel a lot of anger from people who have been deprived of freedoms. For them, this law is seen as a new state interference. The other problem is the sling against antipesticidal initiatives. There is an amalgam, which pushes a certain electorate to vote three times no. This is a pity, because the CO2 law is essential for agriculture, which suffers from global warming. Finally, what makes matters more difficult is that the project is carried by Simonetta Sommaruga. Our opponents are trying to make it a left-wing text. The dynamics would have been different if Doris Leuthard had been in command. Your internal poll showed that the PLR electorate was ready for this green turn. Is he schizophrenic or selfish? Neither. It is sensitive to environmental protection. But our members feel that they are already doing a lot for the climate, and do not want the state to force them to do even more. It is true that many citizens or entrepreneurs are engaged, but there are others who do not. And for these, the incentive taxes are perfect. This beautiful speech is not resisting when we talk about an increase in gasoline of 12 cents. From November to April, the price of gasoline varied by 24 cents. Who noticed it? Today, between regions, there are already price differences, but people continue to roll. This increase in the price of gasoline will require the importers to decide whether to impose it and the price will only increase if the targets are not met. I do not deny that this law will have an impact on household income, but we must not think in the short term. This law allows for innovations, creates opportunities. It's promising for the economy. However, the Employers' Centre is against it. I find it difficult to understand this position. The future belongs to companies that rely on the technologies of the future. Of course, this is a challenge for SMEs already affected by coronavirus, but this shift is inevitable. Moreover, many economic sectors have encouraged us to engage in this law. And if this text were so bad, I don't think the USAM would leave the freedom to vote. Above all, I believe that it is the road and oil sectors that do not want it and that put a lot of money to say it. You only have ten days to convince. How are you going to do that? We have planned an action with all party presidents who support the law. We will also write to the young people. We will again send a call to all our members to explain the benefits of the law in their respective circles. This project is almost your baby. Would a failure of the law be that of the PLR? It would be pretentious to say that he's our baby. This is primarily a Confederation project. We have worked for this compromise with the Centre, the Liberal Greens, the Socialist Party or the Greens. The overwhelming majority of the parliament is in favour, the Federal Council too, as well as associations such as the TCS, the Swiss Peasants' Union, Swissbanking, Swissmem, the Swiss Alpine Club, about 200 companies... What we have to say to the population is that with a no on 13 June, there would be no more CO2 law and nothing to protect the climate. We could not fulfil our commitments under the Paris Agreement. This would undermine Switzerland's credibility. Federal votes 13 June 2021 Tamedia poll on CO2 law Petra Gössi calls on PLR voters not to be mistaken in battle on 13 June. KEYSTONE Survey The suspense is still to be put Of the five objects submitted to the vote on June 13, it is indeed the CO2 law that might occupy the end of the campaign. According to the third and last Tamedia poll (editor of this content), the text supposed to allow Switzerland to comply with the Paris Climate Agreements is the only one that can still switch on one side or the other. If, between the first and the second surveys, support had fallen to just 50% of the favourable intentions, compared with 46% of the negative views, the yes side had three points (53%) and the no remained stable. The undecided therefore seem to be leaning for the text. In any case, for a law which was widely supported by the economic circles and by all parties, except UDC, nothing was to be expected of such suspense. Hesitations to the PLR Clearly aware of the uncertain outcome, the close-to-left, Green and Green-liberal polled have tightened the ranks to the maximum, gratifying still some percentages of favourable opinions. Within the electorate of the Agrarian party, on the other hand, the yes capped at 13%. At the PLR, the base has obviously not yet turned green, even if there is a slight change in trend. Indeed, while 58% of the supporters rejected the CO2 law – unlike the party's bodies campaigning for the text – they were still 61% two weeks ago. Fracture city-country While it already announces deep on the so-called antipesticid voting, the city-country divide is also widening on the CO2 law. Unsurprisingly, the urban electorate supports the text most massively with 65% positive intentions (61% two weeks ago). The trend is inverse in the countryside, where the bill of the law will be the saltiest one according to the opponents, and the non wins with 54%. Agglomerations are in the national average. Young people change their minds Another lesson from this third survey, the big surprise of our second survey is disappearing. The 18-34, who still rejected the law 15 days ago, now support it with a hair (50% of yes) but remain the most sceptical, membership increasing with age. Finally, without surprise, the arguments put forward reveal the tone of a campaign that focused solely on the question of taxes. Julien Wicky

text: ['Opinions Loi sur le CO2: la Suisse ne peut rester de glace ÉDITORIAL.', 'Avec la loi sur le CO2, la population suisse a l’occasion et sans doute aussi le devoir de démontrer qu’elle se préoccupe du réchauffement de la planète, qui l’affecte très directement.', 'Mais il ne faudra laisser personne sur le bord de la route  Bernard Wuthrich  La Suisse a la réputation de tenir ses engagements politiques.', 'Avec la loi sur le CO2, elle a l’occasion rêvée de démontrer que l’Accord de Paris sur le climat n’est pas, pour elle, une simple déclaration d’intention.', 'Si modeste soit sa contribution par rapport à l’état de la planète, elle peut apporter, le 13\xa0juin, la démonstration que sa promesse de protéger le climat n’est pas une coquille vide.', 'La Suisse a les moyens et sans doute aussi le devoir d’ajouter sa pierre à l’édifice environnemental mondial.', 'Notamment parce que, berceau des glaciers, château d’eau du continent européen, elle est directement touchée par le réchauffement, qui fait fondre les neiges naguère éternelles et libère des pans de rochers naguère figés par le pergélisol, désormais en voie de liquéfaction.', 'La nouvelle loi sur le CO2 mettra à disposition des moyens importants pour se détourner des comportements les plus polluants et favoriser des ressources plus en harmonie avec la sauvegarde de la nature.', 'Le fonds pour le climat permettra de soutenir toute une série de programmes: promotion des chauffages propres, assainissement des bâtiments, trains de nuit, innovations technologiques,\xa0etc.', 'Cette réforme est cependant le fruit d’un compromis politique.', 'Or, comme tout compromis, elle est imparfaite.', 'La médaille a ainsi son revers, ou plutôt ses revers.', 'Quasiment improvisé par le parlement, le fonds pour le climat peut être perçu comme une usine à gaz, une sorte de fourre-tout dont il s’agira, après le nécessaire oui du 13\xa0juin, d’extraire les meilleurs projets.', 'Autre point délicat: destinée à inciter la population à modifier ses habitudes en changeant de chauffage ou de véhicule, la loi pénalisera celles et ceux qui, malgré les subventions, n’auront pas les moyens de le faire.', 'Ces personnes se trouvent principalement dans les régions périphériques.', 'Il s’agira de s’en préoccuper lors de la mise en œuvre des nouvelles règles afin de ne pas les laisser sur le bord de la route.', 'Même imparfaite, la loi sur le CO2 doit être soutenue.', 'Il n’est pas imaginable que la Suisse ne fasse rien pour préserver le climat, comme le suggèrent les lobbys pétrolier et automobile, qui n’ont évidemment aucun intérêt à voir le marché de l’énergie se transformer.', 'Il n’est pas davantage imaginable de rejeter la réforme sous prétexte qu’elle ne va pas assez loin ni assez vite, comme l’affirment les activistes du climat, dont le discours d’impatience et d’idéalisme aurait, s’il était entendu, des conséquences économiques et sociales dramatiques.']
processed_text: Opinions Law on CO2: Switzerland cannot remain EDITORIAL ice. With the CO2 law, the Swiss population has the opportunity and no doubt also the duty to demonstrate that it is concerned with global warming, which affects it very directly. But no one will have to be left on the roadside Bernard Wuthrich Switzerland has a reputation for fulfilling its political commitments. With the CO2 law, it has the perfect opportunity to demonstrate that the Paris Climate Agreement is not a mere declaration of intent. Although modest in its contribution to the state of the planet, on 13 June it can demonstrate that its promise to protect the climate is not an empty shell. Switzerland has the means and probably the duty to add its stone to the global environmental building. In particular, because, the cradle of glaciers, the water castle of the European continent, it is directly affected by the warming, which melts snows from time to time eternal and releases strips of rocks previously frozen by permafrost, now in the process of liquefaction. The new CO2 law will provide important means to turn away from the most polluting behaviors and promote resources that are more in harmony with nature conservation. The climate fund will support a range of programmes: clean heating, building cleanliness, night trains, technological innovations, etc. However, this reform is the result of a political compromise. Like any compromise, it is imperfect. The medal has its setback, or rather its setbacks. Almost improvised by parliament, the climate fund can be seen as a gas plant, a kind of tote that it will be, after the necessary yes of 13 June, extracting the best projects. Another delicate point is that, in order to encourage people to change their habits by changing their heating or vehicle, the law will penalise those who, despite subsidies, will not have the means to do so. These people are mainly in the peripheral regions. This will be a concern when implementing the new rules so as not to leave them on the roadside. Even imperfect, the CO2 law must be supported. It is not conceivable that Switzerland will do nothing to preserve the climate, as suggested by the oil and automotive lobby, which obviously have no interest in seeing the energy market transform. Nor is it conceivable to reject the reform on the pretext that it does not go far enough or fast enough, as the climate activists affirm, whose discourse of impatience and idealism would, if it were heard, have dramatic economic and social consequences.

text: ['Biden se pose en rassembleur sur le climat ENVIRONNEMENT Le président américain a invité 40 chefs d’Etat et de gouvernement à participer à un sommet virtuel qui doit s’ouvrir le 22 avril, Jour de la Terre.', "Il entend relancer l’engagement international dans la lutte contre le réchauffement  PASCALINE MINET @pascalineminet  C'était une des principales promesses de campagne du candidat Biden.", "Dès son élection à la Maison-Blanche, le nouveau président américain s'est empressé de concrétiser le retour de son pays dans l'Accord de Paris sur le climat, délaissé quatre ans plus tôt par Donald Trump.", "Dans la foulée, il promettait d'organiser une conférence internationale afin de mobiliser les Etats dans la lutte contre le réchauffement.", "Ce sommet – purement virtuel, pandémie oblige – se tiendra les 22 et 23 avril et rassemblera les principaux pays émetteurs de CO2, ainsi que quelques autres, particulièrement impliqués ou directement touchés par le changement climatique (la Suisse n'a pas été conviée).", "L'administration américaine espère que cet événement servira de catalyseur à l'action climatique, dans une année décisive qui culminera avec la prochaine Conférence internationale sur le climat ou COP26, en novembre à Glasgow.", "Promesses insuffisantes Adopté en 2015, l'Accord de Paris s'est fixé pour objectif de contenir le réchauffement de la planète à 2°C, et même si possible à 1,5°C, d'ici à la fin du siècle, par rapport au niveau préindustriel.", 'Pour y parvenir, les 196 Etats signataires se sont tous engagés à réduire leurs émissions de gaz à effet de serre.', "Las, leurs promesses sont pour l'heure largement insuffisantes: elles mènent vers un réchauffement de 3°C, dont les conséquences (accroissement des sécheresses, cyclones, et autres événements extrêmes, disparition de certains écosystèmes) seraient très graves, d'après les projections scientifiques.", "Afin de se rapprocher de l'objectif de 1,5°C, l'Accord de Paris prévoit que les pays arrivent tous les cinq ans avec de nouveaux plans plus ambitieux de réduction de leurs émissions de gaz à effet de serre (ces plans sont appelés «contributions déterminées au niveau national», ou NDC, dans le jargon onusien).", 'Le rendez-vous a en partie été manqué en 2020, en raison de la pandémie de Covid-19, qui a aboutit au report de la COP26.', "Seule une cinquantaine de pays (dont la Suisse) ont fait état de NDC révisés, d'après le décompte de l'organisation Climate Action Tracker.", 'Les projets des autres Etats sont donc attendus de pied ferme.', "L'année passée a tout de même eu son lot d'annonces encourageantes.", "La Chine, incontournable en tant que premier émetteur mondial de gaz à effet de serre, a promis de parvenir d'ici à 2060 à la neutralité carbone (ce qui signifie qu'elle ne devra alors pas émettre plus de CO2 qu'elle ne pourra en absorber).", "De leurs côtés, les dirigeants de l’Union européenne se sont mis d'accord pour diminuer d’au moins 55% leurs émissions d’ici à 2030, quand les Britanniques visent un objectif encore plus ambitieux de 68% à la même échéance.", 'De nouvelles promesses pourraient être faites dans le cadre du sommet des 22 et 23 avril.', "Déjà, le Canada a annoncé qu'il révisait à la hausse son objectif de réduction des gaz à effet de serre d'ici à 2030 par rapport à 2005, le portant à 36%, contre 30% précédemment.", 'Mais ce sont surtout les Etats-Unis qui sont attendus au tournant.', "«Le président Biden arrive à ce sommet avec le besoin de réparer la crédibilité des Etats-Unis après quatre années au pouvoir d'un président qui niait l'existence du changement climatique et qui a fait tout ce qui était en son pouvoir pour saper les efforts entrepris dans son pays pour réduire les émissions de gaz à effet de serre», estime John Podesta, ancien conseiller sur le climat du président Obama, lors d'une conférence de presse en ligne.", "La Maison-Blanche a annoncé qu'elle ferait connaître le nouvau NDC américain avant ou durant la rencontre virtuelle.", "«Nous espérons que c'est au minimum une réduction de 50% des émissions d'ici à 2030, par rapport à leur niveau de 2005, qui sera communiquée, a indiqué Rachel Cleetus, de l'ONG Union of Concerned Scientists.", "Des analyses ont montré que c'était réalisable, mais aussi que c'était le minimum nécessaire pour arriver à l'objectif de neutralité climatique en 2050, déjà annoncé par Biden.» Les organisations de défense du climat attendent également du nouveau président qu'il accroisse les fonds alloués pour l'adaptation des Etats les plus démunis face au réchauffement.", 'Reste à savoir comment les autres pays, et en particulier la Chine, accueilleront le retour américain dans la bataille climatique.', "Dépêché à Shanghai la semaine passée, l'émissaire américain pour le climat John Kerry a publié avec son homologue chinois Xie Zhenhua un communiqué dans lequel les deux pays s'engagent à coopérer sur le changement climatique et à développer leurs stratégies respectives de réduction d'émissions de gaz à effet de serre d'ici au sommet écossais.", "«Les relations entre les deux pays se sont beaucoup détériorées par rapport à 2015, lorsque l'Accord de Paris a été négocié, reconnaît John Podesta.", "Mais tous deux ont intérêt à conserver un canal de communication ouvert sur la question du climat.»  Déforestation galopante au Brésil Le comportement d'autres acteurs importants du réchauffement sera également scruté dans les jours à venir.", 'Lundi 19 avril, le Kremlin a fait savoir que le président russe Vladimir Poutine participerait au sommet virtuel de jeudi.', "La protection de l'Arctique apparaît comme l'un des rares terrains de coopération possible entre Moscou et Washington.", 'Le président brésilien Bolsonaro assistera aussi à la rencontre.', "Il a promis de mettre fin à la déforestation illégale d'ici à 2030 dans son pays, moyennant un soutien financier en provenance de le secteur de l’énergie  Avions cloués au sol, trafic routier réduit et usines qui fonctionnent au ralenti: la pandémie de Covid-19 et les mesures prises pour la contenir ont donné un coup de frein He intends to relaunch international engagement in the fight against warming PASCALINE MINET @pascalineminet It was one of the main campaign promises of candidate Biden. As soon as he was elected to the White House, the new US president hastened to realize his country's return to the Paris Climate Agreement, abandoned four years earlier by Donald Trump. As a result, he promised to organize an international conference to mobilize States in the fight against warming. This summit – purely virtual, pandemic – will take place on 22 and 23 April and will bring together the main countries emitting CO2, as well as a few others, particularly involved or directly affected by climate change (Switzerland was not invited). The US administration hopes that this event will serve as a catalyst for climate action, in a decisive year that will culminate with the next International Climate Conference or COP26 in November in Glasgow. Insufficient Promises Adopted in 2015, the Paris Agreement has set itself the goal of containing global warming at 2°C, and even if possible at 1.5°C, by the end of the century, compared to pre-industrial levels. In order to achieve this, all 196 signatory States have committed themselves to reducing their greenhouse gas emissions. Their promises are, for the time being, largely insufficient: they lead to a warming of 3°C, the consequences of which (increase in droughts, cyclones, and other extreme events, the disappearance of some ecosystems) would be very serious, according to scientific projections. In order to move closer to the 1.5°C target, the Paris Agreement provides for countries to arrive every five years with new, more ambitious plans to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions (these plans are called "nationally determined contributions", or NDC, in the UN jargon). The meeting was partly missed in 2020, due to the Covid-19 pandemic, which resulted in the postponement of COP26. Only about 50 countries (including Switzerland) reported revised NDCs, according to the count of Climate Action Tracker. The projects of the other States are therefore expected on a firm footing. Last year, however, had its share of encouraging announcements. China, as the world's largest emitter of greenhouse gases, has promised to achieve carbon neutrality by 2060 (which means that it will not have to emit more CO2 than it can absorb). For their part, the leaders of the European Union have agreed to cut emissions by at least 55% by 2030, when the British are aiming for an even more ambitious target of 68% at the same time. New promises could be made at the summit on 22 and 23 April. Already, Canada has announced that it is increasing its greenhouse gas reduction target by 2030 compared to 2005, to 36%, compared to 30% previously. But it is the United States that is expected at the turn of the day. "President Biden arrives at this summit with the need to repair the credibility of the United States after four years in the power of a president who denied the existence of climate change and who has done everything in his power to undermine the efforts made in his country to reduce greenhouse gas emissions," said John Podesta, former climate advisor to President Obama, at an online press conference. The White House announced that it would make known the US NDC nouveau before or during the virtual meeting. "We hope that it will be at least a 50% reduction in emissions by 2030, compared to their 2005 level," said Rachel Cleetus of the NGO Union of Concerned Scientists. Analyses have shown that this is feasible, but also that it is the minimum necessary to reach the climate neutrality target in 2050, already announced by Biden." Climate organisations also expect the new president to increase the funds allocated for the adaptation of the poorest states in the face of warming. It remains to be seen how the other countries, and in particular China, will welcome the American return to the climate battle. In Shanghai last week, the US climate envoy John Kerry, along with his Chinese counterpart Xie Zhenhua, issued a communiqué in which the two countries committed to cooperate on climate change and develop their respective strategies for reducing greenhouse gas emissions by the Scottish summit. "The relationship between the two countries has deteriorated considerably since 2015, when the Paris Agreement was negotiated," says John Podesta. But both have an interest in maintaining an open channel of communication on the climate issue." Blowout deforestation in Brazil The behaviour of other important warming actors will also be scrutinized in the coming days. On Monday, 19 April, the Kremlin announced that Russian President Vladimir Putin would participate in the virtual summit on Thursday. Arctic protection appears to be one of the few areas of cooperation between Moscow and Washington. Brazilian President Bolsonaro will also attend the meeting. He promised to end illegal deforestation by 2030 in his country, with financial support from abroad. But this announcement was received with coldness by Brazilian activists, as the cleared areas have been increasing in Brazil since the new president came to power. "Bolsonaro is a negationist. Since his election, there have been many setbacks in climate protection in Brazil; the increase in deforestation is only the visible tip of the iceberg. Both Brazilian civil society and the private sector are calling for climate action. But it lacks the necessary transparency and political will," says Izabella Teixeira, who served as Environment Minister for former President Lula. In September 2019, during Donald Trump's presidency, activists gathered in front of the Washington Capitol to draw the attention of power to climate change. The new president, Joe Biden, wants the United States to regain its leading role in the fight against warming. In its recent inventory of greenhouse gases, the Federal Office for the Environment points out that their emissions fell only marginally in Switzerland in 2019 and that further measures are needed to achieve this objective. Such measures should be introduced in the revised CO2 law, which is subject to vote next June. A strong rebound in greenhouse gas emissions is expected in the grounded aircraft energy sector, reduced road traffic and idle plants: the Covid-19 pandemic and the measures taken to contain it have put a brake on global greenhouse gas emissions. Unfortunately, the impact of this crisis on the rise in temperatures is expected to be negligible, and the overall trend remains towards an increase in emissions, particularly in the energy sector. To reverse the trend, international coordination seems more essential than ever. Despite decades of global climate action, since the introduction of the Kyoto Protocol in 1997, global greenhouse gas emissions have continued to grow, on average 1.5% per year over the last decade, according to the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) count. They reached a record level in 2019, at 59.1 gigatonnes (or billion tons) CO2 equivalent, an increase of 2.6% over the previous year, due to the increase in forest fires. Hottest year 2020 Then came the coronavirus pandemic, which has greatly slowed the global economy. According to a study published in Nature, the impact of the measures taken by states to combat Covid-19 could lead to an overall reduction of 7% in emissions in 2020, the largest decline recorded in recent history. In a recent report, however, UNEP stressed that this reduction will have only a small effect on temperature increase: UN experts estimate that it will only correspond to 0.01 degree of warming avoided by 2050. In its annual report on the global state of climate, published on 19 April, the World Meteorological Organization reported that this temporary decline in emissions had had no noticeable impact on atmospheric concentrations of greenhouse gases. Countries "must act now to protect people from the disastrous effects of climate change," UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres warned at the presentation of this report, which also shows that 2020 is among the warmest year ever recorded, on a par with 2016 and 2019. In order to achieve the Paris Agreement's goal of containing warming to +2°C by the end of the century compared to its pre-industrial level, experts believe that greenhouse gas emissions should be reduced by 7.6% each year between 2020 and 2030. Some believe that proper "green" recovery plans would help to achieve this. But the signals are not encouraging. However, energy-related emissions account for about three quarters of the global total for all sectors. "This is a dark warning, which shows that the economic recovery after the covid crisis is to date anything but sustainable for our climate," said IEA director Fatih Birol, who called on governments to act quickly to contain their emissions. processed_text: ‘COV', ‘CO2', these taxes are returned to the population through health insurance premiums Each Swiss citizen receives 87 francs each year in return for environmental taxes. With the new CO2 law, this amount will be doubled. Instructions for use Bernard Wuthrich Take your health insurance policy. Below the amount of your gross monthly premium, you find a line (and a number) that is not always known what it is. It reads as follows: "Redistribution of the environmental tax (COV and CO2) to the population: in your favour, CHF 7.25." It is through the health insurance premiums that the incentives are refunded to the population. There are two. The first is the incentive tax on volatile organic components (VOCs), levied on paints, varnishes, detergents and solvents since 2000. It is reimbursed to the population in the form of a deduction of 13 francs per year per person for sickness benefits. The second is the CO2 tax levied on fossil fuels (mazout, natural gas) since 2008. Two thirds of its revenue is returned to the population – via LAMal premiums – and to businesses – through the payroll subject to AVS contributions. The discount is 70 francs per year per person. 80 francs per person A total of 87 francs per year, or 7.25 francs per month, is paid to the population. With the new CO2 law, this redistributive effect will increase. According to the Federal Office for the Environment (OFEV), it is expected to increase by about 80 francs per person per year and thus increase to 167 francs, always through health insurance premiums. According to OFEV, these additional 80 francs will come from two sources. The increase in the CO2 fuel tax from 25 to 30 cents will result in a redistributive effect of 20 francs per person per year. As for the surcharge on airline tickets, its revenues will be distributed in two pots: 51% will be distributed to the population, in a uniform manner and regardless of the number of flights carried out. According to OFEV, this should amount to about 60 francs per year per person. The remaining 49% will be contributed to the climate fund and will be used to finance measures such as the promotion of night trains or the development of synthetic kerosene.
author: Bernard Wu

processed_text: Recycled concrete still struggles to impose For the sector's umbrella associations, building a sustainable economy in construction requires stronger political action. Among the solutions proposed: promoting recycled materials in public works Etienne Meyer At two months of the vote on the revision of the CO2 law, four umbrella associations in the construction sector call for the establishment of framework conditions adapted to the establishment of a circular economy in the sector. On Tuesday, the Swiss Company of Entrepreneurs, the Swiss Association of Recycling Materials Construction, the Swiss Association of the Cement Industry and the Swiss Association of the Gravel and Concrete Industry organized a press conference to present their proposals to meet the challenges posed by the climate objectives of the Confederation. This call comes at a time when a subcommittee of the National Council's Committee on the Environment, Spatial Planning and Energy has been working on this topic since autumn 2020. It is expected to publish the results of its work in May. But the sector's umbrellas fear that it will result in regulations that are considered counterproductive. According to industry representatives, targets to reduce CO2 emissions from homes will lead to increased waste generation in the construction sector. "Currently, the renewal rate of the housing stock is around 1% per year, and in order to achieve the climate goals it would be between 3 and 5%," says Gian-Luca Lardi, President and CEO of the Swiss Enterprise Corporation (SSE). An exemplary demand from the public authorities Today, construction accounts for 84% of waste generation in Switzerland, or 74 million tonnes, mainly excavation and demolition waste. "We are already recycling about 70% of demolition materials," says Gian-Luca Lardi. At the same time, however, the use of recycled concrete is only 20% in construction sites due to a certain reluctance to use this material. For the umbrellas, the public authorities, which account for almost half of the order book, could play an accelerator role by calling for the use of recycled materials. This under-utilization of recycled building materials has concrete consequences. "They are large stocks that accumulate at recycling sites," says Kurt Morgan, president of the Swiss Construction Materials Recycling Association. A part of the waste is exported abroad in border areas, but the weight of the waste materials and their transport costs mean that they are not exported very far." Their use would also make a stone two blows by reducing the share of waste put into landfills and by resolving the problem of the lack of local landfills. Legal Barriers Beyond setting an example, the umbrellas also call on the public authorities to remove the legal barriers that, in their view, limit the establishment of an efficient circular economy in the construction sector. "We are increasingly concerned about regulation from a spatial planning point of view," Morgan says. Waste recycling centres must be set up in industrial areas shared with other companies that do not want to have noisy and smelly activities near them." Another example discussed is the impossibility of using certain incineration wastes as fuels for cement production, which requires very high temperatures. "We could save an additional 400,000 tonnes of CO2 each year by using waste that is not suitable for conventional recycling as alternative fuels," says Gerhard Pfister, President of the Swiss Cement Industry Association. One way to increase the share of alternative fuels used in this industry, which is currently considered to be very polluting, is to increase to 70%. "These are a few examples. We must not act against regulation, we must accept it, but today there are contradictions that we can avoid," concluded Gerhard Pfister.
author: Etienne Meyer
