text: ['INTERVIEW «Je n’appellerais pas cela un coup» ESPACE Le président de l’EPFZ, Joël Mesot, annonce le transfert de Didier Queloz à Zurich.', 'L’astrophysicien genevois y dirigera un nouveau centre sur l’origine de la vie.', 'Objectif: «Renforcer la place de la recherche suisse et européenne», explique le patron de la haute école  PROPOS RECUEILLIS PAR CÉLINE ZÜND , ZURICH @celinezund  En septembre, le chercheur Prix Nobel de physique Didier Queloz quittera l’Observatoire de l’Université de Genève pour diriger un nouveau centre sur l’origine de la vie à l’EPFZ, tout en gardant un poste à 50% à l’Université de Cambridge.', 'Joël Mesot, président de la haute école, répond à nos questions.', 'Vous accueillerez bientôt le professeur Didier Queloz, Prix Nobel d’astrophysique.', 'Qu’est-ce qui a motivé cette décision?', 'Didier Queloz nous rejoint en septembre pour participer à la création d’un nouveau centre de recherche sur l’une des toutes grandes questions qui animent la science, l’origine de la vie et les interrogations passionnantes qui y sont liées: comment la vie s’est elle développée sur la Terre?', 'Y a-t-il de la vie en dehors du système solaire?…  Ce transfert est un sacré coup pour l’EPFZ… Je n’appellerais pas cela un coup.', 'C’est une manière de nous positionner pour renforcer la place de la recherche suisse et européenne.', 'J’ai rencontré Didier Queloz au WEF, à Davos, en 2020.', 'Il était en train de développer un projet similaire au nôtre à Cambridge.', 'Nous avons alors décidé de joindre nos forces avec un projet qui, j’espère, deviendra un pôle de coopération national et international.', 'Est-ce que cela ne va pas plutôt exacerber la concurrence entre institutions en Suisse?', 'Je parlerais plutôt de concurrence entre les continents.', 'Nous devons penser au niveau européen, alors que des initiatives similaires se développent en Asie ou aux Etats-Unis.', 'Quelles seront les conséquences de ce transfert sur vos relations avec l’Université de Genève?', 'Nous ne comptons pas faire cavalier seul, mais développer des initiatives pour renforcer nos collaborations autour de ce projet.', 'Nous avons aussi déjà des collaborations très fructueuses avec l’Université de Genève, comme depuis longtemps à travers le CERN, mais aussi sur un nouveau projet concernant la diplomatie scientifique et un autre sur les technologies quantiques.', 'Nous collaborons par exemple avec l’EPFL dans le domaine de la cybersécurité et du Swiss Data Science Center.', 'Comment comptez-vous intensifier les liens entre l’EPFZ et la Suisse romande?', 'Je l’ai toujours dit, c’est très important à mes yeux d’établir un pont avec les institutions romandes et en particulier l’EPFL.', 'Pas parce que je suis Romand – je me sens plutôt citoyen du monde et j’ai passé plus de temps en Suisse alémanique qu’en Suisse romande –, mais parce que c’est un atout pour la recherche et la Suisse en général.', 'Comme de moins en moins de Romands viennent étudier à l’EPFZ, nous songeons actuellement à créer des bourses pour encourager les échanges avec l’EPFL.', 'Auriez-vous investi dans un centre sur l’origine de la vie s’il ne devait pas être dirigé par un porteur de Nobel?', 'Oui.', 'Cette idée de centre sur l’origine de la vie précède ma rencontre avec Didier Queloz.', 'Lorsque j’ai visité tous les départements après ma prise de fonction, j’ai constaté qu’il y avait un grand désir, dans quatre ou cinq départements, de mener des recherches dans cette direction.', 'L’idée d’un tel centre de recherche sur l’origine de la vie est alors née dans le cadre de l’initiative OpenETH.', 'Avec cette initiative, nous encourageons depuis plusieurs années les idées de recherche interdépartementale et avec d’autres institutions.', 'Quelles autres initiatives sont nées de cette réflexion?', 'La création de deux postes de recherche sur l’impact du réchauffement climatique sur les Alpes aux Grisons.', 'La collaboration avec la Croix-Rouge internationale et l’EPFL, ou encore sur les sciences diplomatiques avec l’Université de Genève et le Gesda (Geneva Science and Diplomacy Anticipator).', 'Le futur centre sur l’origine de la vie s’inscrit dans ce développement.', 'Faudra-t-il renoncer à des investissements dans d’autres domaines de recherche cruciaux, comme la numérisation ou la sécurité cybernétique?', 'Nous investissons massivement dans la numérisation et nous continuerons à la faire.', 'Nous avons créé un nouveau centre de recherche sur l’intelligence artificielle avec, au départ, 30 professeurs.', 'Il en compte actuellement plus de 80.', 'Ces différents domaines ne sont pas en compétition, ils sont complémentaires: nous utiliserons l’intelligence artificielle pour explorer l’origine de la vie.', 'Vous êtes arrivé à la tête de l’EPFZ il y a deux ans dans une période mouvementée, marquée par les affaires de mobbing.', 'Qu’avez-vous mis en place depuis pour éviter que de tels cas ne se reproduisent?', 'Tout un catalogue de mesures.', 'Par exemple, il existe un programme d’initiation complet pour les nouveaux professeurs, et un nouveau guide de recrutement aide les professeurs à clarifier les attentes, droits et obligations mutuels avec les futurs doctorants.', 'Et nous avons mis en place un système pour désamorcer les conflits à un stade précoce, que ce soit entre étudiants ou avec la hiérarchie.', 'Quelles sont les mesures les plus susceptibles de changer la donne?', 'Nous avons revu le processus de sélection de nos professeurs de manière à examiner aussi les compétences sociales des candidats et candidates.', 'En outre, notre nouvelle ordonnance de doctorat prévoit qu’il y ait toujours dès le début deux personnes de référence pour un doctorant ou une doctorante.', 'Nous avons aussi une nouvelle ombudspersonne externe et un nouveau service de conseil externe.', 'Enfin, nous allons lancer une campagne contre la discrimination et pour le respect dès l’automne.', 'Elle a été différée en raison du covid.', 'Durant cette année de pandémie, les experts sont devenus à la fois des figures incontournables et des cibles, comme pour l’UDC qui réclame la dissolution de la task force covid.', 'Avez-vous l’impression que l’on tente de museler les scientifiques?', 'Si nous décidions de museler les experts suisses, alors les médias se tourneraient vers des interlocuteurs étrangers et nous n’aurions rien gagné.', 'Mais je n’ai pas l’impression que ce soit la volonté de la majorité.', 'Nous devrons encore faire un bilan du travail de la task force, mais à mon avis il a été extrêmement positif, malgré quelques accrochages ou malentendus.', 'Martin Vetterli a pris position dans le «Blick» en faveur de la loi sur le CO2.', 'Est-ce le rôle d’un président d’EPF de donner des consignes de vote?', 'En général, plus on monte dans la hiérarchie, plus on se retient de s’exprimer, car nous avons un devoir de réserve.', 'Il y a cependant des situations dans lesquelles on peut intervenir directement dans le débat, à mon avis: si notre institution est directement concernée, comme ce fut le cas lors de l’initiative contre l’immigration de masse.', 'Ou lorsqu’on fait face à un thème d’intérêt prioritaire.', 'Quelle est votre position sur la loi CO2?', 'Je soutiens la position du Conseil fédéral et d’une majorité claire du parlement.', 'C’est important de prendre rapidement des mesures concrètes pour atteindre les objectifs climatiques.', 'La loi sur le CO2 est une bonne base pour agir, qui laisse suffisamment de degrés de liberté et ouvre des opportunités pour l’économie suisse et sa chaîne d’innovation.', 'Que diriez-vous si des chercheurs prenaient position contre la loi CO2 pour signaler qu’elle ne va pas assez loin?', 'Est-ce légitime pour un chercheur de jouer un rôle militant?', 'Les chercheurs sont des citoyens comme les autres, le principe de la liberté d’expression vaut aussi pour eux.', 'Cela dit, qui s’engage dans le débat politique doit aussi accepter la critique.', 'Vous ne songez donc pas à encadrer les prises de position des scientifiques comme compte le faire l’Université de Lausanne?', 'Je ne connais pas la situation exacte à Lausanne.', 'A l’EPFZ, nous menons une discussion à l’interne sur la nécessité de mieux expliquer notre travail et ce qu’est la recherche.', 'Mais aussi sur les chances et risques qu’un engagement sur la place publique peut entraîner pour les chercheurs et l’institution.', 'La pandémie a accéléré la nécessité de mener une telle discussion et montré qu’il faut intensifier ce dialogue entre science et société.', 'Autre sujet chaud: l’Europe.', 'Quelle conséquence aurait un abandon de la voie bilatérale pour la recherche?', 'Pour nous la question centrale est encore et toujours la participation au projet de recherche Horizon Europe.', 'Une rupture avec l’Europe nous ferait perdre en attractivité en tant qu’université.', 'Or il ne s’agit pas seulement de nous, mais du futur de la Suisse et de son économie dans des domaines particuliers: médical, énergétique.', 'Les défis posés dans ces domaines ne seront pas résolus avec l’Asie ou les USA, mais avec nos voisins proches, car les enjeux sont locaux.', 'Joël Mesot, président de l’Ecole polytechnique fédérale de Zurich: «Nous ne comptons pas faire cavalier seul, mais développer des initiatives pour renforcer nos collaborations autour de ce projet.» (DOMINIC BÜTTNER POUR LE TEMPS)  «Cette idée de centre sur l’origine de la vie précède ma rencontre avec Didier Queloz» EN DATES En 1995, première découverte par Michel Mayor et Didier Queloz d’une planète en dehors de notre système solaire: une exoplanète orbitant autour d’une étoile de type solaire, 51 Pegasi b. processed_text: INTERVIEW "I wouldn't call it a blow" SPACE The president of the EPFZ, Joël Mesot, announces the transfer of Didier Queloz to Zurich. The Genevan astrophysicist will lead a new centre there on the origin of life. Purpose: "Strengthening the place of Swiss and European research", explains the boss of the high school PROPOSED RECUILLISED BY CÉLINE ZÜND, ZURICH @celinezund In September, the Nobel Prize-winning researcher in physics Didier Queloz will leave the Observatory of the University of Geneva to lead a new centre on the origin of life at EPFZ, while keeping a 50% position at Cambridge University. Joël Mesot, president of the high school, answers our questions. You will soon be welcoming Professor Didier Queloz, Nobel Prize in Astrophysics. What was the reason for this decision? Didier Queloz joined us in September to participate in the creation of a new research centre on one of the major issues that animates science, the origin of life and the exciting questions that are related to it: how did life develop on Earth? Is there life outside the solar system?... This transfer is a big blow for the EPFZ... I wouldn't call it a blow. It is a way of positioning us to strengthen the place of Swiss and European research. I met Didier Queloz at the WEF in Davos in 2020. He was developing a project similar to ours in Cambridge. We then decided to join forces with a project which I hope will become a centre of national and international cooperation. Is this not going to exacerbate the competition between institutions in Switzerland? I'd rather talk about competition between continents. We must think at European level, while similar initiatives are developing in Asia or the United States. What will be the consequences of this transfer on your relationship with the University of Geneva? We do not intend to go alone, but to develop initiatives to strengthen our collaborations around this project. We have already very fruitful collaborations with the University of Geneva, as we have for a long time through CERN, but also on a new project on scientific diplomacy and another on quantum technologies. For example, we collaborate with EPFL in the field of cybersecurity and the Swiss Data Science Center. How do you intend to intensify the links between EPFZ and French-speaking Switzerland? I have always said, it is very important to me to build a bridge with Roman Catholic institutions and in particular EPFL. Not because I'm Romand – I feel like a citizen of the world and I spent more time in German-speaking Switzerland than in French-speaking Switzerland – but because it's an asset for research and Switzerland in general. As fewer and fewer Romands come to study at EPFZ, we are currently considering creating scholarships to encourage exchanges with EPFL. Would you have invested in a centre on the origin of life if it were not to be run by a Nobel holder? Yes. This idea of a centre on the origin of life precedes my meeting with Didier Queloz. When I visited all the departments after I took office, I found that there was a great desire in four or five departments to conduct research in this direction. The idea of such a research centre on the origin of life was then born under the OpenETH initiative. With this initiative, we have been encouraging ideas for interdepartmental research and with other institutions for several years. What other initiatives have emerged from this reflection? The creation of two research posts on the impact of global warming on the Alps in the Grisons. Collaboration with the International Red Cross and EPFL, or on diplomatic science with the University of Geneva and the Gesda (Geneva Science and Diplomacy Anticipator). The future centre on the origin of life is part of this development. Should investment in other critical areas of research, such as digitization or cyber security, be abandoned? We are investing heavily in digitization and will continue to do so. We have created a new research centre on artificial intelligence with, initially, 30 professors. It currently has more than 80. These different areas are not in competition, they are complementary: we will use artificial intelligence to explore the origin of life. You came to the head of the EPFZ two years ago in a turbulent period, marked by mobbing cases. What have you put in place since then to prevent such cases from happening again? A whole catalog of measurements. For example, there is a comprehensive initiation program for new faculty, and a new recruitment guide helps faculty clarify mutual expectations, rights and obligations with future PhD students. And we have put in place a system to defuse conflicts at an early stage, whether between students or with the hierarchy. What measures are most likely to change the situation? We reviewed the selection process for our faculty to also examine the social skills of the candidates. In addition, our new PhD order provides that there are always two reference persons for a PhD student from the beginning. We also have a new external ombud and a new external advisory service. Finally, we will launch a campaign against discrimination and for respect in the autumn. She was delayed because of the covid. During this pandemic year, experts have become both key figures and targets, as for the UDC, which calls for the dissolution of the Covid Task Force. Do you feel that they are trying to muzzle scientists? If we decided to muzzle the Swiss experts, then the media would turn to foreign interlocutors and we wouldn't have won anything. But I don't feel like it's the will of the majority. We will still have to take stock of the work of the Task Force, but in my opinion it has been extremely positive, despite some clashes or misunderstandings. Martin Vetterli took a position in the "Blick" in favour of the CO2 law. Is it the role of a president of EFF to give voting instructions? In general, the higher the hierarchy, the more we refrain from expressing ourselves, because we have a duty of reserve. There are, however, situations in which we can intervene directly in the debate, in my opinion: if our institution is directly concerned, as was the case with the initiative against mass immigration. Or when faced with a priority theme. What is your position on the CO2 law? I support the position of the Federal Council and a clear majority of Parliament. It is important to take prompt and concrete action to achieve climate goals. The CO2 law is a good basis for action, which leaves enough freedom and opens up opportunities for the Swiss economy and its innovation chain. What would you say if researchers took a stand against the CO2 law to point out that it does not go far enough? Is it legitimate for a researcher to play a militant role? Researchers are citizens like others, the principle of freedom of expression also applies to them. However, who engages in political debate must also accept criticism. So you're not thinking about framing the positions of scientists as the University of Lausanne plans to do? I don't know the exact situation in Lausanne. At EPFZ, we are conducting an internal discussion on the need to better explain our work and what research is. But also on the opportunities and risks that a public engagement can entail for researchers and the institution. The pandemic has accelerated the need for such a discussion and has shown the need to intensify this dialogue between science and society. Another hot topic is Europe. What would result in a shift away from the bilateral path to research? For us the central question is still and still is participation in Horizon Europe research project. A break with Europe would make us lose in attractiveness as a university. But it is not just about us, but about the future of Switzerland and its economy in particular areas: medical, energy. The challenges in these areas will not be solved with Asia or the USA, but with our close neighbours, because the stakes are local. Joël Mesot, President of the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich: "We do not intend to go alone, but to develop initiatives to strengthen our collaborations around this project." (DOMINIC BÜTTNER FOR TIME) "This idea of a centre on the origin of life precedes my encounter with Didier Queloz" IN DATES In 1995, Michel Mayor and Didier Queloz first discovered a planet outside our solar system: an exoplanet orbiting around a solar-type star, 51 Pegasi b. October 2019 Announcement of the Nobel Prize in Physics to the two Swiss researchers, and to the American-Canadian James Peebles. September 2021 Didier Queloz leaves the University of Geneva, where he works at 50%, to create a centre on the origin of life in Zurich. (LT) "We are living a historic moment for research on life in the Universe" RESEARCH Didier Queloz wants to make the future centre on life of the EPFZ an international "magnet" To explore the mystery of life: this is the announced objective of the "Centre for Origin and Prevalence of Life" which will be led by the Genevois Didier Queloz at EPFZ in September. "It's a long story and an extraordinary adventure," stresses the future director on the phone, who leaves the Observatory of the University of Geneva. What is life? Where and how was she born? Is it outside our planet? To answer these questions, the centre will bring together scientists from several disciplines: biology, astrophysics, chemistry, earth sciences and the environment. "We are living a historic moment, of the same order of importance as the discovery of the Moon with Apollo. The research on this great issue of the origin of life is in full swing, thanks to the advances of science in several disciplines," said Didier Queloz. Other life research hubs were established in Harvard, Cambridge and California. In Zurich, about 15 people are involved in the preparatory work, for a project destined to grow. At this stage, no funding is articulated. "This will be one of my roles: to define a budget," explains Didier Queloz, who wants to make this centre an international "magnet" for research. A strategic will Why in Zurich and not in Geneva? "At EPFZ, there is excellence, critical numbers of researchers, funding and a strategic will to do something new," explains the researcher. In October 2019, Didier Queloz was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics, together with his former professor Michel Mayor, for discovering, in 1995, the first planet around a star other than our Sun. In 2013, he was recruited by the prestigious English University of Cambridge to hold an astronomy chair devoted to exoplanets. If he leaves Geneva, where he still holds a 30% faculty position, it's also for "his survival," he says laughing: "I can't lead everything on the front. But I was born in Geneva, I have an emotional relationship with this city and my relations with the University of Geneva will not end, we will continue to work together. Geneva and Zurich, it's one big village." The researcher relativizes the loss for his home town: "At 55 years old, I'm already part of the past! The future is young researchers. I don't care about the University of Geneva, which attracts brilliant people, and the Department of Astronomy, which will remain the largest in the country." At the origin of this project, there is also the meeting between two Romands in Davos. When he spoke with Joël Mesot at the WEF, Didier Queloz spoke of his work in Cambridge for the Initiative for Planetary Science and Life in the Universe, which brought together researchers on the issues of life in the Universe. The president of the EPFZ then informed him of the interest in his institution to carry out a similar programme. C.Z.

processed_text: The WWF will discreetly celebrate its 60th anniversary Pandemia obliges, the popular organization will modestly blow its 60 candles. It was founded in Morges and became a multinational environmentalist with 5 million members and 6000 employees ATS The WWF celebrates its 60th anniversary on Thursday in a relative discretion. In addition to an unfavourable health environment, the Gland-based organization (VD) prefers to devote all its energy to its projects on the ground. "There will nevertheless be one or the other wink," says Pierrette Rey, NGO spokesman for French-speaking Switzerland. In particular, she points out that "retro" articles from the 1960s are available in the online shop. To mark the event, the Swiss section will also broadcast a video of its director Thomas Vellacott on Thursday, in which he will answer 60 questions. The latest study of the WWF that we have relayed: The EU, the world's second-largest importer-related deforestation leader A list of successes Without festive events, such as those organised for its 50th anniversary, the WWF wants to value its last great successes. A list was developed for its website, between the creation of a maritime park in Malaysia, the protection of the Amazon and the preservation of the Persian panther in the Caucasus. But rather than focusing on the past, the NGO wants to put the cursor on its current struggles. And there are many of them. In Switzerland, for example, support for the CO2 law is at the top of the list. "This is a crucial chapter in the fight to protect the climate," says Pierrette Rey about the vote on 13 June. Evolution This commitment to climate shows how the organization has evolved in 60 years. At the time of its creation, on 29 April 1961 in Morges, the founders, a group of biologists and businessmen mainly British, wanted to preserve the great fauna in Africa. "From the conservation of certain species, we have moved on to a comprehensive approach, including the defence of forests and seas, climate, energy and agriculture issues," notes Perrette Rey. However, some things have not changed in an organization that was presided over for 15 years (1981-1996) by Prince Philip, who recently died. This is the case with its iconic panda-shaped logo, which has changed very little in six decades. The desire to raise awareness among children also remains at the heart of his mission, including magazines and "nature" camps, which have been organized in Switzerland for many years. "This allows us, in a way, to be part of the family. We thus remain in the heart and spirit of the population," the spokesman notes. Among its other features, the WWF strives, wherever it is on the planet, to find solutions with local actors. This approach distinguishes him from other NGOs with a more offensive style: "We can show our teeth if necessary, but always by being oriented towards finding solutions". No Pandemic Effect In 60 years, WWF has become one of the world's largest environmental organizations. It claims more than 5 million members across the globe and a presence in more than 100 countries with 6,000 collaborators. Some seventeen people work at the international headquarters in Gland. The site underwent a major restructuring in 2016 with the departure of 100 posts to new hubs in Kenya, Singapore and England. Pierrette Rey recalled that the operation was aimed at better distributing forces, especially to the countries of the South. According to her, the siege of Gland is not threatened by new cuts. For its part, the WWF Switzerland is based in Zurich with antennas in Lausanne and Bellinzone. It employs some 250 people, plus more than 6,000 volunteers. In its latest annual report, the Swiss section reported that it had received 8.6 million francs in its 2020 fiscal year from foundations, public institutions, donors and executors. These recipes were not affected by the coronavirus crisis. "At first, we had some fears, but they did not materialize. The evolution of donations remains positive," says Rey.

processed_text: On the revision of the CO2 law, economic camps far from being homogeneous With the exception of the TCS, the oil and road lobby is fighting the revision of the law. Economic organizations are shared. On the left, some climate strikers reject the law, believing that it does not go far enough Bernard Wuthrich The revision of the CO2 law opposes camps that are not homogeneous. The majority of the large umbrella associations have chosen the one that supports the new law. This committee includes Economiesuisse and 36 branches, such as Swiss Banking, the Swiss Company of Entrepreneurs (SSE), Swiss Textiles, the Association of Swiss Electric Enterprises (AES) or the Swiss Insurance Association (SAA). Companies are also committed to the revision: Novartis, Siemens, IKEA, BKW, Alpiq and Axpo, among others. "We are not satisfied with all aspects of the law, such as the climate fund. But it is an acceptable compromise that prompts us to slip a yes of reason into the urn. It's better to act now than to wait. A refusal would imply a return of several years", explains the director of Economiesuisse, Monika Rühl. In front of this camp stands a sling of opposition made up of other economic actors. It is led by the oil and automotive industry, with the notable exception of the TCS, which has decided to support the revision of the CO2 law. Opposition of the oil and automotive lobby The opposition committee includes Avenergy (ex-oil union), Swissoil, Citec Switzerland (tanks), Ramoneur Suisse, Auto-suisse, l'Astag, ACS, the Swiss Union of Automotive Professionals (UPSA), Routesuisse. The Employers' Centre and GastroSwitzerland are also part of this committee, which can count on the support of the Swiss Union of Arts and Crafts (USAM), the UDC and some liberal-radical dissents. "The new law is inefficient in climate terms. It will at best reduce global CO2 emissions by half a million. The 4000 Swiss companies, including the Employers' Centre, which have concluded target agreements with the Energy Agency for the Economy have achieved impressive results in terms of climate and energy efficiency", counter-arguments the director of the Employers' Centre, Christophe Reymond. He sees in the commitment of Economysuisse "a will to repaint itself in green". The French-speaking climate strike movements are also fighting the new law, believing that it does not go far enough.

processed_text: The CO2 law, a chance for our economy It is certainly interesting to discuss the costs of the CO2 law. But what about the cost of inaction? The OECD has calculated that the impact of climate change could rise to 10% of GDP. For Switzerland, the cost could reach 4% of GDP. While it is enough to invest 1% of GDP to limit the effects of climate change. Regarding the financial impact on our everyday lives, the Federal Council has made a realistic calculation. A family of four, driving 12,500 km a year with a car that consumes 6 litres/100 km. This family lives in a housing of 128 m2 and is heated by oil with an annual consumption of 8 l/m2. Finally, this family flies once a year to go somewhere in Europe. This family will pay in all, including the redistribution of the tax, about 100 francs per year. Climate protection is worth 2 coffees per month. The revision of the law requires that fuel sellers compensate up to 90% of CO2 emissions. To do this, they can add up to 12 cts/l. But for now, we're talking about five cents/l. In 2012, the average price of gasoline was 1.82 francs/l and in 2019 it was 1.60 francs/l, a difference of 22 cents/l. Everyone can see that this addition, even of 12 cts/l, is not significant given the variations in the price of gasoline over time. On the other hand, you just have a car tomorrow that consumes 7.4 l/100 km instead of 8 l/100 km and your bill will be the same. The idea, of course, is to encourage car owners to look at the consumption of their new car when they change it. This law would be ineffective because as long as large emitters like China do nothing, it will not change anything. It is too easy to say that "as long as the other does nothing, I do nothing". First of all, doing nothing is not an option because our economy would be too late and that would penalize our businesses. Next, let us not forget that one third of China's greenhouse gas emissions are emitted for the manufacture of export products. So we, Switzerland, are participating in China's CO2 emissions. So it's nice to say today that we don't need to do anything here in Switzerland. It's a trick to see the oil lobby come to the rescue of the widow and the orphan claiming that this law is antisocial. The purpose of this law is not to levy taxes, but to emit less CO2. Everyone can act to minimize the taxes that affect them. They are not families with no means that take the plane all the time or drive in big cars that consume a lot. Some low-income families may even benefit from this law. Finally, for those who think that man is not responsible for climate change, reducing oil consumption means avoiding billions of dollars going abroad. Some of these billions can be invested in Switzerland. What's the problem? It is still strange that it is a nationalist party that encourages us to consume fossil fuels that come entirely from abroad, even from countries that promote a very radical Islam. With what money do you think terrorists are financing themselves? It is interesting to read the draft ordinance of the Act, since it clearly states that at least 40% of the measures financed by the available funds must be implemented in rural and mountain areas. This twists the necks of those who want to cause a city/country divide. This CO2 law is an opportunity for our economy, it will enable us to boost innovation and keep our SMEs at the forefront of progress. It should also be recalled that Switzerland has signed the Paris Agreement. To date, we have reduced our greenhouse gas emissions by 14% between 1990 and 2019. We should be at -20% by 2020. It is very unlikely that we will succeed. So it's time to act responsibly and reasonably. What will we say to our children when they understand that we are burning gold to heat ourselves? They'll think we're crazy and they'll be right. Oil is far too precious to be burned like this. It must be used to feed petrochemicals that produce, among other things, medicines and other goods that we cannot manufacture without oil. Voting yes to the CO2 law is a way to be patriotic and boost OUR economy while helping to limit the impact of climate change. ISABELLE CHEVALLEY DRES SCIENCES, NATIONAL COUNCIL PVL/VD This law is not intended to levy taxes, but to emit less CO2. Everyone can act to minimize the taxes that affect them.

processed_text: OPINION CO2 law: the cost of inaction ROGER NORDMANN NATIONAL CONSULTANT, PRESIDENT OF THE PS GROUP OF THE FEDERAL ASSEMBLY Just before launching its fight against the CO2 law, the oil lobby took care to put on its camouflage outfit. The former Swiss Petroleum Union has changed its name and is now known as Avenergy, a name that suggests that it is taking care of our energy future. We could smile at it as crude as the string is, but if the fireworks succeed, it will cost us billions. By proposing to reject the CO2 law, the oil lobby obviously seeks to extend its situational pension as much as possible. Let us recall that this is a substantial one, since in recent years we have spent an average of CHF 8 billion a year in Switzerland on the import of fossil products, not to mention taxes. Of course, the primary objective of the CO2 law is to protect the climate, i.e. to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions. It is a matter of fulfilling our commitments under the Paris Agreement. However, by stimulating investments in energy efficiency, as well as in renewable electricity and heat generation, climate protection policy generates very interesting indirect economic benefits. The first is obviously the gradual reduction in oil spending. If the CO2 law is accepted, the fossil import bill could rise from about 8 billion to about 5 billion by 2030, and eventually gradually move towards zero. The second advantage is the gradual shift in spending from the purchase of fossil energy to investment. It helps to maintain an increased share of value added in Switzerland, instead of financing oil-exporting states. In general terms, it is a matter of improving the energy efficiency of all our equipment, buildings and infrastructure, and of equipping ourselves to generate more renewable energy. It will be recalled here that these resources have the advantage of not requiring the purchase of primary energy, since water, wind and sun arrive free of charge in Switzerland. The third economic advantage is to limit the costs of global warming. If the international community fulfils its commitments, the increase in temperatures may be limited if it is not stopped. In terms of prosperity, each degree avoided counts. In contrast, any acceleration of warming will throw hundreds of millions of people on the roads of exile due to rising sea levels or the transformation of their region into burning and uninhabitable land. If the living conditions of billions of human beings gradually deteriorate, even the richest countries will suffer the economic blow. While the quantification of the fourth advantage is almost impossible, the latter is far from negligible: the reduction in overall oil consumption will also reduce the temptation to use military force to capture this resource. It will be recalled here that most armed conflicts have a direct or indirect connection to energy. In the face of such an essential issue as the energy future, the political parties that support the CO2 law, namely the PS, the PDC, the Greens, the PLR and the Liberal Greens, have agreed on a moderate formulation, capable of gaining a solid majority. The costs of failure would be so high that all chose to build a solid compromise. In this sense, the text submitted to the Swiss people represents only one step on the path that will free us from fossil fuels. But this is a necessary and decisive step, which must be taken without delay in order to have a chance to win the battle against global warming.

text: ['Une fraude aux émissions de CO2 éclabousse l’Ofrou CORRUPTION Deux responsables d’une entreprise d’importation de véhicules ont payé un collaborateur de l’Office fédéral des routes pour échapper aux sanctions sur les émissions de CO2.', 'La Confédération a perdu 9 millions dans cette affaire  BERNARD WUTHRICH , BERNE @BdWuthrich  L’affaire de corruption révélée lundi par le Ministère public de la Confédération (MPC) éclabousse un Office fédéral des routes (Ofrou) qui n’en est pas à son premier scandale.', 'Elle tombe en pleine campagne sur la loi sur le CO2, dont l’une des composantes est la limite maximale d’émissions de CO2 imposée aux véhicules, au-dessus de laquelle les importateurs doivent payer des amendes.', 'Ces sanctions sont précisément au cœur de cette affaire.', 'Entre juin 2014 et septembre 2017, date à laquelle le pot aux roses a été découvert, un collaborateur de l’Ofrou, qui a quitté l’office depuis, a «manipulé dans les systèmes informatiques de l’office fédéral les données déterminantes pour l’enquête sur les sanctions en matière de CO2» en faveur d’une société d’importation de voitures.', 'Pire, il a été payé par les responsables de cette entreprise pour ce service, à hauteur de 2000 francs par mois, selon le communiqué du MPC.', 'Grâce à ce subterfuge, la société en question n’a pas eu à payer d’amendes entre 2015 et 2017 pour les véhicules qu’elle importait et qui dépassaient la norme de 130 grammes de CO2 par kilomètre, en vigueur à l’époque.', 'La valeur cible a été abaissée à 95 grammes par kilomètre en 2020.', 'Si la révision de la loi sur le CO2 est acceptée en votation populaire le 13 juin, elle sera encore réduite de 15% à partir de 2025 et de 37,5% dès 2030.', 'Neuf millions non payés à la Confédération Ces manipulations ont privé la Confédération de 9 millions de francs de recettes.', 'La nouvelle loi sur le CO2 prévoit d’affecter la moitié du produit de ces sanctions écologiques au futur fonds pour le climat.', 'Le MPC renvoie l’ancien employé de l’Ofrou ainsi que les deux membres du conseil d’administration de la société d’importation devant le Tribunal pénal fédéral.', 'L’ancien fonctionnaire est accusé de faux dans les titres commis dans l’exercice de fonctions publiques, de corruption passive, d’escroqueries en matière de contributions et de prestations et d’obtentions frauduleuses d’une constatation fausse.', 'Les deux responsables de l’entreprise sont prévenus d’incitation à falsification de documents dans l’exercice de fonctions publiques, de corruption, d’escroquerie par métier en matière de contributions et de prestations et d’obtentions frauduleuses d’une constatation fausse.', 'Selon nos informations, la société visée n’est pas un importateur officiel, mais une entreprise familiale d’achat direct de véhicules d’occasion.', 'Une hypothèse que confirme le président de la faîtière Autosuisse, François Launaz: «Un importateur officiel ne peut pas se permettre de tels agissements», commente-t-il.', 'Embarrassante pour l’Ofrou, cette affaire n’est pas la première qui l’éclabousse.', 'En 2016, deux collaborateurs de son antenne de Viège ainsi que l’ancien directeur d’une entreprise de construction avaient été poursuivis pour corruption dans le cadre des travaux du contournement de la ville haut-valaisanne.', 'En 2013, l’ancien patron de l’Ofrou avait eu des démêlés avec le Contrôle fédéral des finances (CDF), qui lui avait reproché de ne pas avoir respecté la loi fédérale sur les finances à propos de deux projets informatiques d’envergure.']
processed_text: CO2 emissions fraud splatters over Ofrou CORRUPTION Two officials of a vehicle import company paid a staff member of the Federal Roads Office to escape the sanctions on CO2 emissions. The Confederation lost 9 million in this case BERNARD WUTHRICH, BERNE @BdWuthrich The corruption case revealed Monday by the Public Prosecutor's Office of Confederation (MPC) splashes a Federal Road Office (OFrou) which is not at its first scandal. It falls in the middle of the campaign on the CO2 law, one of the components of which is the maximum CO2 emission limit imposed on vehicles, above which importers must pay fines. These sanctions are at the very heart of this case. Between June 2014 and September 2017, when the rose pot was discovered, a staff member of OFRU, who has since left the office, "manipulated in the federal office's computer systems the data determining the CO2 sanctions investigation" in favour of a car import company. Worse, it was paid by the company's officials for this service, up to 2,000 francs per month, according to the MPC's statement. As a result of this subterfuge, the company did not have to pay fines between 2015 and 2017 for the vehicles it imported that exceeded the standard of 130 grams of CO2 per kilometre, in effect at the time. The target value was lowered to 95 grams per kilometre in 2020. If the revision of the CO2 law is accepted by popular vote on 13 June, it will be further reduced by 15% from 2025 and by 37.5% from 2030. Nine million unpaid to the Confederation These manipulations deprived the Confederation of 9 million francs of revenue. The new CO2 law envisages allocating half of the proceeds of these environmental sanctions to the future climate fund. The MPC shall refer the former employee of Ofrou and the two members of the board of directors of the importing company to the Federal Criminal Court. The former official is accused of forgery in securities committed in the performance of public functions, passive bribery, fraud in contributions and benefits and fraudulent obtaining of a false finding. The two officials of the company are warned of incitement to forge documents in the performance of public functions, corruption, fraud by trade in contributions and benefits and fraudulent obtaining of a false finding. According to our information, the company in question is not an official importer, but a family-owned business that buys used vehicles directly. A hypothesis confirmed by François Launaz, President of the Autosuisse branch, "An official importer cannot afford such actions," he comments. Embarrassing for Ofrou, this case is not the first one that splashes. In 2016, two employees of its branch office in Viège and the former director of a construction company were prosecuted for corruption in connection with the work of bypassing the city of Upper Valais. In 2013, the former boss of OFROU had been in contact with the Federal Financial Control (CDF), who had accused him of failing to comply with the Federal Finance Act in respect of two large-scale IT projects.
